Chapter I

Chapter Summary & Character Study
Summary

Kate Croy waits in her father's shabby lodgings. While waiting, she moves between the sofa and an armchair, looks at the prints on the wall, and stands on the balcony. She also looks at her reflection in a mirror over the mantel, readjusting her hat and hair.

Her father, Lionel Croy, eventually enters. He says he has been to the chemist because he is unwell. Kate tells him he looks well and then says she is willing to go away and live with him. He expresses surprise and refuses her offer.

Kate explains that her Aunt Maud has made her a proposal with one condition: that Kate must break off all contact with her father. In response, Kate has come to him. Mr. Croy says this is a proper requirement from her aunt and advises Kate to accept the offer. He tells her she should use him to get a better deal from her aunt, suggesting she make her aunt feel how much of a sacrifice it is to give him up. He advises her to marry a man her aunt selects, after which he will resume relations with her.

Kate again offers to choose him over her aunt and asks him to stand with her. He refuses, calls her sick, and accuses her of being in love with someone her aunt disapproves of. He opens the door for her to leave. He asks who the man is, and Kate replies that the man wants to be kind to him. Mr. Croy forbids her from marrying anyone her aunt disapproves of and threatens to make her regret it if she defies them. Kate says she is not afraid of him.

He gives her his final advice and reveals his anger that she gives half of her inheritance to her sister, Marian, instead of to him.

Character Study

Based on the text, here is a concise character study.

### Kate Croy

Kate is introduced in a state of controlled impatience and disgust with her surroundings, which she sees as a direct reflection of her family’s “failure of fortune and of honour.” She is presented as proud, self-aware, and resilient; while observing the shabby room, she also observes her own handsome reflection in the mirror, affirming her personal value as separate from her family's collapse.

Her situation shifts due to an ultimatum from her Aunt Maud: she will be taken care of financially if she completely severs ties with her father. In response, Kate makes a decisive move, coming to her father not to abandon him but to offer to live with him and reject her aunt’s proposal. When he refuses, deducing she is in love with someone her aunt disapproves of, her situation shifts again. She is left isolated, rejected by the father she offered to save, and must now proceed alone.

### Lionel Croy (The Father)

Mr. Croy is presented through his absence and deception before he even appears. He has lied about being ill and inhabits a "vulgar" space that belies his appearance. When he enters, he is a man of profound contradictions: physically immaculate, charming, and looking the part of a "perfectly" respectable English gentleman, yet he is entirely untrustworthy, manipulative, and amoral. He "dealt out lies" and his polished exterior serves to mask his inner corruption.

His situation is immediately challenged by Kate’s unexpected offer. His initial plan was to make a grand, noble show of sacrificing her for her own good. When she preempts this, he is momentarily "disconcerted" but quickly pivots. His shift is from feigned parental concern to that of a cynical strategist, advising Kate to leverage her "duty" to him to get a better financial deal from her aunt. He ultimately rejects Kate’s genuine appeal for solidarity, revealing his core motivation is not parental feeling but resentment that she gave her inheritance money to her sister instead of to him.

She waited, Kate Croy, for her father to come in, but he kept her unconscionably, and there were moments at which she showed herself, in the glass over the mantel, a face positively pale with the irritation that had brought her to the point of going away without sight of him. It was at this point, however, that she remained; changing her place, moving from the shabby sofa to the armchair upholstered in a glazed cloth that gave at once—she had tried it—the sense of the slippery and of the sticky. She had looked at the sallow prints on the walls and at the lonely magazine, a year old, that combined, with a small lamp in coloured glass and a knitted white centre-piece wanting in freshness, to enhance the effect of the purplish cloth on the principal table; she had above all, from time to time, taken a brief stand on the small balcony to which the pair of long windows gave access. The vulgar little street, in this view, offered scant relief from the vulgar little room; its main office was to suggest to her that the narrow black house-fronts, adjusted to a standard that would have been low even for backs, constituted quite the publicity implied by such privacies. One felt them in the room exactly as one felt the room—the hundred like it or worse—in the street. Each time she turned in again, each time, in her impatience, she gave him up, it was to sound to a deeper depth, while she tasted the faint, flat emanation of things, the failure of fortune and of honour. If she continued to wait it was really, in a manner, that she might not add the shame of fear, of individual, personal collapse, to all the other shames. To feel the street, to feel the room, to feel the table-cloth and the centre-piece and the lamp, gave her a small, salutary sense, at least, of neither shirking nor lying. This whole vision was the worst thing yet—as including, in particular, the interview for which she had prepared herself; and for what had she come but for the worst? She tried to be sad, so as not to be angry; but it made her angry that she couldn't be sad. And yet where was misery, misery too beaten for blame and chalk-marked by fate like a "lot" at a common auction, if not in these merciless signs of mere mean, stale feelings?

Translation

Kate Croy waited for her father to come in, but he was taking an unreasonably long time. At moments, she saw her own face in the mirror above the fireplace, and it was visibly pale with the frustration that had almost made her leave without seeing him. However, she stayed. She changed positions, moving from the worn sofa to an armchair covered in a slick, glazed fabric that felt both slippery and sticky – she’d already tested it. She’d looked at the dull prints on the walls, and the lonely, year-old magazine, which, along with a small colored-glass lamp and a faded, knitted white doily, only emphasized the dingy purple tablecloth on the main table. Most of all, she’d occasionally stepped onto the small balcony accessible through the long windows. The unpleasant little street outside offered no escape from the unpleasant little room. It mostly made her think that the narrow, black house fronts, built to a standard that would be low even for the back of buildings, were a perfect representation of the hidden lives within. You felt the rooms exactly as you felt the street—filled with hundreds just like it, or worse. Every time she turned back inside, every time she almost gave up on him in her impatience, she sank deeper into despair, tasting the stale, lifeless atmosphere of failure and disgrace. If she kept waiting, it was really so she wouldn't have to add the shame of fear and personal breakdown to all the other problems she was facing. To feel the street, to feel the room, to feel the tablecloth and doily and lamp, at least gave her the small, comforting feeling that she wasn't avoiding the truth or lying to herself. This whole experience was the worst thing yet, especially the meeting she had prepared for. Why else had she come, but for the worst? She tried to be sad, so she wouldn't be angry, but it made her angry that she couldn’t even be sad. And yet, where else could misery be found—misery too battered to complain, marked by fate like a discarded item at a public sale—if not in these unrelenting signs of ordinary, stale feelings?

Her father's life, her sister's, her own, that of her two lost brothers—the whole history of their house had the effect of some fine florid, voluminous phrase, say even a musical, that dropped first into words, into notes, without sense, and then, hanging unfinished, into no words, no notes at all. Why should a set of people have been put in motion, on such a scale and with such an air of being equipped for a profitable journey, only to break down without an accident, to stretch themselves in the wayside dust without a reason? The answer to these questions was not in Chirk Street, but the questions themselves bristled there, and the girl's repeated pause before the mirror and the chimney-place might have represented her nearest approach to an escape from them. Was it not in fact the partial escape from this "worst" in which she was steeped to be able to make herself out again as agreeable to see? She stared into the tarnished glass too hard indeed to be staring at her beauty alone. She readjusted the poise of her black, closely-feathered hat; retouched, beneath it, the thick fall of her dusky hair; kept her eyes, aslant, no less on her beautiful averted than on her beautiful presented oval. She was dressed altogether in black, which gave an even tone, by contrast, to her clear face and made her hair more harmoniously dark. Outside, on the balcony, her eyes showed as blue; within, at the mirror, they showed almost as black. She was handsome, but the degree of it was not sustained by items and aids; a circumstance moreover playing its part at almost any time in the impression she produced. The impression was one that remained, but as regards the sources of it no sum in addition would have made up the total. She had stature without height, grace without motion, presence without mass. Slender and simple, frequently soundless, she was somehow always in the line of the eye—she counted singularly for its pleasure. More "dressed," often, with fewer accessories, than other women, or less dressed, should occasion require, with more, she probably could not have given the key to these felicities. They were mysteries of which her friends were conscious—those friends whose general explanation was to say that she was clever, whether or no it were taken by the world as the cause or as the effect of her charm. If she saw more things than her fine face in the dull glass of her father's lodgings, she might have seen that, after all, she was not herself a fact in the collapse. She didn't judge herself cheap, she didn't make for misery. Personally, at least, she was not chalk-marked for the auction. She hadn't given up yet, and the broken sentence, if she was the last word, would end with a sort of meaning. There was a minute during which, though her eyes were fixed, she quite visibly lost herself in the thought of the way she might still pull things round had she only been a man. It was the name, above all, she would take in hand—the precious name she so liked and that, in spite of the harm her wretched father had done it, was not yet past praying for. She loved it in fact the more tenderly for that bleeding wound. But what could a penniless girl do with it but let it go?

Translation

The history of her family—her father's life, her sister's, her own, and that of her two brothers who had died—was like a beautiful, complex story, perhaps even a musical piece. It started with words and notes, full of promise, but then stopped abruptly, never reaching a conclusion. Why had this family been set in motion, with such grand expectations and the appearance of preparing for a successful journey, only to fail without a clear cause, collapsing on the side of the road with no apparent reason?

The answer to these questions wasn't to be found on Chirk Street, but the questions themselves were ever-present, haunting her. The girl's frequent moments of contemplation in front of the mirror and the fireplace might have been her closest attempt to escape them. Wasn't it a way to escape the "worst" of her situation to be able to make herself look appealing again? She gazed intently into the tarnished mirror, not just admiring her beauty. She adjusted her black, feathered hat, smoothed her dark hair, and observed both her beautiful profile and the face she presented to the world.

She was completely dressed in black, which emphasized her fair complexion and made her hair appear even darker. Her eyes looked blue on the balcony and almost black in the mirror. She was attractive, but her appeal wasn't dependent on any particular features or accessories. This was a significant aspect of the impression she created. The impression remained, but no amount of analysis could fully explain it. She possessed a graceful presence, a strong character, without the obvious physical attributes. She was slender and unassuming, often quiet, but somehow always caught the eye—she was uniquely pleasing to look at. She was often "more dressed" with fewer accessories than other women, or conversely, less dressed with more, but she couldn't explain how she achieved these effects. Her friends were aware of these mysteries, and they generally explained it by saying she was intelligent, whether they believed her intelligence was the cause or the result of her charm.

If she saw more than just her pretty face in the dull mirror of her father's home, she might have realized that she wasn't a victim of her family's downfall. She didn't see herself as worthless, and she wasn't consumed by sadness. Personally, at least, she wasn't destined to be ruined. She hadn't given up hope, and if she were the last one standing, the unfinished story would eventually find some resolution. For a moment, her eyes fixed, she lost herself in the thought of how she could still turn things around if she were a man. It was the family name, above all, that she wanted to salvage—the cherished name she loved, which, despite her father's mistakes, could still be redeemed. In fact, she loved it even more tenderly because of its wounded state.

But what could a poor girl do with it but let it go?

When her father at last appeared she became, as usual, instantly aware of the futility of any effort to hold him to anything. He had written her that he was ill, too ill to leave his room, and that he must see her without delay; and if this had been, as was probable, the sketch of a design, he was indifferent even to the moderate finish required for deception. He had clearly wanted, for perversities that he called reasons, to see her, just as she herself had sharpened for a talk; but she now again felt, in the inevitability of the freedom he used with her, all the old ache, her poor mother's very own, that he couldn't touch you ever so lightly without setting up. No relation with him could be so short or so superficial as not to be somehow to your hurt; and this, in the strangest way in the world, not because he desired it to be—feeling often, as he surely must, the profit for him of its not being—but because there was never a mistake for you that he could leave unmade or a conviction of his impossibility in you that he could approach you without strengthening. He might have awaited her on the sofa in his sitting-room, or might have stayed in bed and received her in that situation. She was glad to be spared the sight of such penetralia, but it would have reminded her a little less that there was no truth in him. This was the weariness of every fresh meeting; he dealt out lies as he might the cards from the greasy old pack for the game of diplomacy to which you were to sit down with him. The inconvenience—as always happens in such cases—was not that you minded what was false, but that you missed what was true. He might be ill, and it might suit you to know it, but no contact with him, for this, could ever be straight enough. Just so he even might die, but Kate fairly wondered on what evidence of his own she would some day have to believe it.

Translation

When her father finally showed up, she immediately realized, as always, how pointless it was to try to pin him down. He'd written that he was sick, too sick to leave his room, and that he needed to see her urgently. If that had been a manipulative ploy—which it probably was—he hadn't even bothered to make it believable. He clearly just wanted to see her, for reasons he considered valid, just as she had been looking forward to a conversation. But now she felt again, in the inescapable way he used her, all the familiar pain, the same kind her poor mother had felt, the way he couldn't even touch you gently without causing a reaction. No interaction with him could be brief or superficial enough to avoid hurting you somehow. And this, strangely, wasn't because he wanted to inflict pain – he probably recognized it would be better for him if it didn’t – but because he couldn't help but make any mistake possible and always reinforced your doubts about him. He could have been waiting for her on the sofa in his living room, or he could have stayed in bed and received her there. She was glad she didn't have to see his inner sanctum, but it would have reminded her less of how untruthful he was. This was the exhaustion of every meeting: he dispensed lies as easily as dealing cards from a dirty old deck for a game of manipulation you were forced to play with him. The problem—as always in these situations—wasn't that you minded the lies, but that you missed the truth. He might be sick, and it might suit her to know it, but no interaction with him, even for this, could ever be straightforward. He might even die, Kate thought, but she wondered what proof she'd ever have to believe it.

He had not at present come down from his room, which she knew to be above the one they were in: he had already been out of the house, though he would either, should she challenge him, deny it or present it as a proof of his extremity. She had, however, by this time, quite ceased to challenge him; not only, face to face with him, vain irritation dropped, but he breathed upon the tragic consciousness in such a way that after a moment nothing of it was left. The difficulty was not less that he breathed in the same way upon the comic: she almost believed that with this latter she might still have found a foothold for clinging to him. He had ceased to be amusing—he was really too inhuman. His perfect look, which had floated him so long, was practically perfect still; but one had long since for every occasion taken it for granted. Nothing could have better shown than the actual how right one had been. He looked exactly as much as usual—all pink and silver as to skin and hair, all straitness and starch as to figure and dress—the man in the world least connected with anything unpleasant. He was so particularly the English gentleman and the fortunate, settled, normal person. Seen at a foreign table d'hôte, he suggested but one thing: "In what perfection England produces them!" He had kind, safe eyes, and a voice which, for all its clean fulness, told, in a manner, the happy history of its having never had once to raise itself. Life had met him so, half-way, and had turned round so to walk with him, placing a hand in his arm and fondly leaving him to choose the pace. Those who knew him a little said, "How he does dress!"—those who knew him better said, "How does he?" The one stray gleam of comedy just now in his daughter's eyes was the funny feeling he momentarily made her have of being herself "looked up" by him in sordid lodgings. For a minute after he came in it was as if the place were her own and he the visitor with susceptibilities. He gave you funny feelings, he had indescribable arts, that quite turned the tables: that had been always how he came to see her mother so long as her mother would see him. He came from places they had often not known about, but he patronised Lexham Gardens. Kate's only actual expression of impatience, however, was "I'm glad you're so much better!"

Translation

He hadn't come downstairs yet; she knew he was in the room above them. He'd already been outside, although if she confronted him, he would either deny it or present it as evidence of his desperation. However, she'd stopped challenging him entirely. It wasn't just that her anger faded when she was with him, but he had a way of downplaying the painful things in her life so that, after a little while, she forgot about them. The problem was that he also did the same with anything funny or lighthearted; she almost thought she could still connect with him if she focused on that. He wasn't even amusing anymore; he was simply too cold and unfeeling. His flawless appearance, which had served him so well for so long, was still almost perfect, but she'd long since stopped paying attention to it. The reality of the situation just confirmed how right she'd been. He looked exactly the same as always – all pink and silver with his skin and hair, all crispness and formality in his posture and clothes – the most detached and carefree person in the world. He was the epitome of the English gentleman, the fortunate, well-adjusted, and ordinary man. If you saw him at a foreign hotel, you would think, "How perfectly England produces them!" He had kind, reassuring eyes and a voice that, despite its pleasant fullness, clearly showed he'd never had to raise it in any kind of distress. Life had met him halfway, embraced him, and walked with him, offering him its arm and letting him choose the pace. Those who knew him superficially would say, "How well-dressed he is!" – those who knew him better would wonder, "How does he manage?"

The only flicker of amusement in his daughter's eyes at that moment was the fleeting sensation he gave her of being "looked up to" by him in their humble lodgings. For a moment after he entered, it was as if the place was hers and he was the visitor, the one with the delicate sensibilities. He had a way of making you feel ridiculous; he had these strange skills that completely flipped the situation. That's how he had always gotten away with seeing her mother as long as her mother allowed him to. He went to places they didn't know about, but he treated their neighborhood with condescension. However, Kate's only true expression of annoyance was, "I'm glad you're feeling better!"

"I'm not so much better, my dear—I'm exceedingly unwell; the proof of which is, precisely, that I've been out to the chemist's—that beastly fellow at the corner." So Mr. Croy showed he could qualify the humble hand that assuaged him. "I'm taking something he has made up for me. It's just why I've sent for you—that you may see me as I really am."

Translation

"I'm not doing much better, darling – I feel really sick. The evidence? I just went to the pharmacy – that awful guy on the corner," Mr. Croy said, proving he could make a modest gesture to comfort his visitor. "I'm taking medicine he mixed for me. That's why I asked you to come – so you can see what I'm truly going through."

"Oh papa, it's long since I've ceased to see you otherwise than as you really are! I think we've all arrived by this time at the right word for that: 'You're beautiful—n'en parlons plus.' You're as beautiful as ever—you look lovely." He judged meanwhile her own appearance, as she knew she could always trust him to do; recognising, estimating, sometimes disapproving, what she wore, showing her the interest he continued to take in her. He might really take none at all, yet she virtually knew herself the creature in the world to whom he was least indifferent. She had often enough wondered what on earth, at the pass he had reached, could give him pleasure, and she had come back, on these occasions, to that. It gave him pleasure that she was handsome, that she was, in her way, a sensible value. It was at least as marked, nevertheless, that he derived none from similar conditions, so far as they were similar, in his other child. Poor Marian might be handsome, but he certainly didn't care. The hitch here, of course, was that, with whatever beauty, her sister, widowed and almost in want, with four bouncing children, was not a sensible value. She asked him, the next thing, how long he had been in his actual quarters, though aware of how little it mattered, how little any answer he might make would probably have in common with the truth. She failed in fact to notice his answer, truthful or not, already occupied as she was with what she had on her own side to say to him. This was really what had made her wait—what superseded the small remainder of her resentment at his constant practical impertinence; the result of all of which was that, within a minute, she had brought it out. "Yes—even now I'm willing to go with you. I don't know what you may have wished to say to me, and even if you hadn't written you would within a day or two have heard from me. Things have happened, and I've only waited, for seeing you, till I should be quite sure. I am quite sure. I'll go with you."

Translation

"Oh, Dad, I haven't seen you through rose-colored glasses in ages. I think we've finally landed on the right word for it: 'You're wonderful – let's not talk about it anymore.' You're still as wonderful as ever—you look great." He was sizing up her appearance at the same time, as she knew he always would; noticing, evaluating, sometimes disapproving of what she was wearing, showing her he still cared about her. He might not actually care, but she knew she was the person in the world he cared about the most. She'd often wondered what could possibly bring him joy at this stage of his life, and she always came back to this: it pleased him that she was attractive, that she was, in her own way, a worthwhile asset. It was also very clear, however, that he didn't get any satisfaction from the same things, as far as they were similar, in his other child. Poor Marian might be attractive, but he definitely didn't care. The problem, of course, was that her sister, widowed and almost broke, with four energetic children, was not a worthwhile asset.

She then asked him how long he'd been staying where he was, though she knew it didn't really matter, that whatever answer he gave probably wouldn't be the truth. She didn't even hear his answer, truthful or not, because she was already focused on what she wanted to tell him. This was really why she'd waited—what was more important than the small amount of resentment she still felt about his constant, practical rudeness. The result of all of this was that, within a minute, she'd said it: "Yes—even now I'm willing to go with you. I don't know what you wanted to say to me, and even if you hadn't written, you would have heard from me within a day or two. Things have happened, and I've just waited, until I was absolutely sure before seeing you. I'm absolutely sure. I'll go with you."

It produced an effect. "Go with me where?"

Translation

It had an impact. "Where are we going?"

"Anywhere. I'll stay with you. Even here." She had taken off her gloves and, as if she had arrived with her plan, she sat down.

Translation

Anywhere. I'll stay with you, even here.

She took off her gloves and sat down, as though she'd already decided.

Lionel Croy hung about in his disengaged way—hovered there as if, in consequence of her words, looking for a pretext to back out easily: on which she immediately saw she had discounted, as it might be called, what he had himself been preparing. He wished her not to come to him, still less to settle with him, and had sent for her to give her up with some style and state; a part of the beauty of which, however, was to have been his sacrifice to her own detachment. There was no style, no state, unless she wished to forsake him. His idea had accordingly been to surrender her to her wish with all nobleness; it had by no means been to have positively to keep her off. She cared, however, not a straw for his embarrassment—feeling how little, on her own part, she was moved by charity. She had seen him, first and last, in so many attitudes that she could now deprive him quite without compunction of the luxury of a new one. Yet she felt the disconcerted gasp in his tone as he said: "Oh my child, I can never consent to that!"

Translation

Lionel Croy was just lingering around, detached—he seemed to be hanging back, as if he was looking for an excuse to avoid the situation because of what she said. But she immediately realized that she’d underestimated something: he was actually planning the same thing. He didn’t want her to come to him, especially not to be with him permanently. He had called her to break things off with some flair and formality. The plan was that part of the elegance of the breakup would be him sacrificing himself for her sake, to make it appear that he was being noble. There was no style or grace unless she was the one who wanted to leave him. His plan had been to gracefully let her have what she wanted, but definitely not to actively push her away. However, she didn’t care at all about his discomfort, because she knew she wasn’t feeling any sympathy herself. She’d seen him in so many different moods that she could now completely disregard his feelings without any guilt. And yet, she noticed the shocked sound in his voice when he said, "Oh my dear, I can never agree to that!"

"What then are you going to do?"

Translation

So, what are you going to do?

"I'm turning it over," said Lionel Croy. "You may imagine if I'm not thinking."

Translation

"I'm giving it up," said Lionel Croy. "You can bet I'm thinking hard."

"Haven't you thought then," his daughter asked, "of what I speak of? I mean of my being ready."

Translation

"So, haven't you considered," his daughter asked, "what I'm talking about? You know, that I'm ready."

Standing before her with his hands behind him and his legs a little apart, he swayed slightly to and fro, inclined toward her as if rising on his toes. It had an effect of conscientious deliberation. "No. I haven't. I couldn't. I wouldn't." It was so respectable, a show that she felt afresh, and with the memory of their old despair, the despair at home, how little his appearance ever by any chance told about him. His plausibility had been the heaviest of her mother's crosses; inevitably so much more present to the world than whatever it was that was horrid—thank God they didn't really know!—that he had done. He had positively been, in his way, by the force of his particular type, a terrible husband not to live with; his type reflecting so invidiously on the woman who had found him distasteful. Had this thereby not kept directly present to Kate herself that it might, on some sides, prove no light thing for her to leave uncompanioned a parent with such a face and such a manner? Yet if there was much she neither knew nor dreamed of, it passed between them at this very moment that he was quite familiar with himself as the subject of such quandaries. If he recognised his younger daughter's happy aspect as a sensible value, he had from the first still more exactly appraised his own. The great wonder was not that in spite of everything his own had helped him; the great wonder was that it hadn't helped him more. However, it was, to its old, eternal, recurrent tune, helping him all the while; her drop into patience with him showed how it was helping him at this moment. She saw the next instant precisely the line he would take. "Do you really ask me to believe you've been making up your mind to that?"

Translation

He stood in front of her, hands clasped behind his back, legs slightly spread, and subtly rocking back and forth. He leaned towards her, as if he were about to stand on his toes. It gave the impression of careful consideration. "No. I haven't. I couldn't. I wouldn't." His respectable facade, something she was keenly aware of, reminded her of their past struggles, of the hopelessness at home, and how little his outward appearance ever revealed about the true man. His charm had been a great burden to her mother. It was always more visible to the outside world than whatever terrible things he had done—thank God no one truly knew! He had, in his own way and due to his personality, been a terrible husband to live with. His very nature reflected poorly on the woman who found him repulsive.

Hadn't this constantly reminded Kate that leaving her father, with his face and manner, alone might not be easy for her? Even though there was much she didn't know or understand, they both understood at this moment that he was well aware of how he was a source of these kinds of questions. While he acknowledged that his younger daughter’s happiness was valuable, he had from the beginning had an even more exact understanding of his own. The real surprise wasn't that his own personality had helped him; the real surprise was that it hadn't helped him more. However, it was, with its old, familiar, and recurring tune, still helping him. Kate’s acceptance of his presence demonstrated how it was helping him at this moment. She immediately knew exactly what he would say next. "Do you really expect me to believe you’ve actually made up your mind to do that?"

She had to consider her own line. "I don't think I care, papa, what you believe. I never, for that matter, think of you as believing anything; hardly more," she permitted herself to add, "than I ever think of you as yourself believed. I don't know you, father, you see."

Translation

She needed to figure out what she thought. "I don't care, Dad, what you believe. Actually, I don't really think of you as someone who believes things. It's almost like," she added carefully, "I don't think you believe anything at all. I don't really know you, Father, you see."

"And it's your idea that you may make that up?"

Translation

So, you think you can just make that up?

"Oh dear, no; not at all. That's no part of the question. If I haven't understood you by this time, I never shall, and it doesn't matter. It has seemed to me that you may be lived with, but not that you may be understood. Of course I've not the least idea how you get on."

Translation

Oh, no, definitely not. That's not what we're talking about. If I haven't understood you by now, I never will, and it doesn't even matter. I've gotten the impression that you can be tolerated, but not truly understood. And honestly, I have no idea how you manage to cope.

"I don't get on," Mr. Croy almost gaily replied.

Translation

"I'm not doing well," Mr. Croy replied, almost cheerfully.

His daughter took in the place again, and it might well have seemed odd that in so little to meet the eye there should be so much to show. What showed was the ugliness—so positive and palpable that it was somehow sustaining. It was a medium, a setting, and to that extent, after all, a dreadful sign of life; so that it fairly put a point into her answer. "Oh, I beg your pardon. You flourish."

Translation

His daughter looked at the place again, and it was strange how much evidence there was, considering how unremarkable it seemed at first glance. What was obvious was the ugliness—it was so real and intense that it almost provided a sense of stability. It was like a backdrop, a stage, and in that way, it was a terrible sign of existence. It gave her answer a cutting edge. "Oh, I'm sorry. You're doing great."

"Do you throw it up at me again," he pleasantly inquired, "that I've not made away with myself?"

Translation

"Are you going to bring up again," he asked with a smile, "that I'm still alive?"

She treated the question as needing no reply; she sat there for real things. "You know how all our anxieties, under mamma's will, have come out. She had still less to leave than she feared. We don't know how we lived. It all makes up about two hundred a year for Marian, and two for me, but I give up a hundred to Marian."

Translation

She acted like the question didn't need an answer; she just sat there, focused on what was real. "You know how all our worries, because of our mother's will, have come out. She had even less to leave us than she thought. We barely survived. It all amounts to about two hundred pounds a year for Marian, and two for me, but I give a hundred to Marian."

"Oh, you weak thing!" her father kindly sighed.

Translation

"Oh, you poor thing," her father said with a gentle sigh.

"For you and me together," she went on, "the other hundred would do something."

Translation

"For you and me, together," she continued, "the other hundred would help us out with something."

"And what would do the rest?"

Translation

And what would the others do?

"Can you yourself do nothing?" He gave her a look; then, slipping his hands into his pockets and turning away, stood for a little at the window she had left open. She said nothing more—she had placed him there with that question, and the silence lasted a minute, broken by the call of an appealing costermonger, which came in with the mild March air, with the shabby sunshine, fearfully unbecoming to the room, and with the small homely hum of Chirk Street. Presently he moved nearer, but as if her question had quite dropped. "I don't see what has so suddenly wound you up."

Translation

"Are you completely useless?"

He looked at her, then put his hands in his pockets, turned away, and stood by the open window for a moment. She didn't say anything else – that question had put him on the spot. The silence lasted a minute, broken by a costermonger's cry, which drifted in with the gentle March air, the weak sunlight that made the room look even shabbier, and the everyday sounds of Chirk Street. After a while, he came closer, as if he'd forgotten her question. "I don't get why you're so upset all of a sudden."

"I should have thought you might perhaps guess. Let me at any rate tell you. Aunt Maud has made me a proposal. But she has also made me a condition. She wants to keep me."

Translation

I figured you might have guessed. Anyway, let me tell you. Aunt Maud has offered me something. But there's a catch. She wants to take care of me.

"And what in the world else could she possibly want?"

Translation

What else could she possibly want?

"Oh, I don't know—many things. I'm not so precious a capture," the girl a little dryly explained. "No one has ever wanted to keep me before."

Translation

Oh, I don't know – a lot of things, I guess. I'm not that important, the girl said with a bit of a sarcastic tone. Nobody's ever wanted to keep me around.

Looking always what was proper, her father looked now still more surprised than interested. "You've not had proposals?" He spoke as if that were incredible of Lionel Croy's daughter; as if indeed such an admission scarce consorted, even in filial intimacy, with her high spirit and general form.

Translation

Her father, who always cared about appearances, now seemed even more surprised than curious. "You haven't had any marriage proposals?" he asked, as if it were unbelievable for Lionel Croy's daughter. It was as though he thought such a confession didn't fit, even between a father and daughter, given her proud personality and overall demeanor.

"Not from rich relations. She's extremely kind to me, but it's time, she says, that we should understand each other."

Translation

She's not related to wealthy people. She's very kind to me, but she says it's time we understood each other better.

Mr. Croy fully assented. "Of course it is—high time; and I can quite imagine what she means by it."

Translation

Mr. Croy completely agreed. "Absolutely—it's about time. And I can easily understand what she's getting at."

"Are you very sure?"

Translation

"Are you absolutely certain?"

"Oh, perfectly. She means that she'll 'do' for you handsomely if you'll break off all relations with me. You speak of her condition. Her condition's of course that."

Translation

Oh, absolutely. She's saying she'll take good care of you financially if you end things with me. You're talking about her offer, right? Her offer is, basically, that.

"Well then," said Kate, "it's what has wound me up. Here I am."

Translation

"Well," said Kate, "that's what's been upsetting me. Here I am now."

He showed with a gesture how thoroughly he had taken it in; after which, within a few seconds, he had, quite congruously, turned the situation about. "Do you really suppose me in a position to justify your throwing yourself upon me?"

Translation

He gestured to show he understood everything. Then, in just a few seconds, he completely flipped the situation. "Do you honestly think I'm the one who needs to explain why you're suddenly confiding in me?"

She waited a little, but when she spoke it was clear. "Yes."

Translation

She paused briefly, but when she answered, it was obvious. "Yes."

"Well then, you're a bigger fool than I should have ventured to suppose you."

Translation

"Wow, you're even dumber than I thought you were."

"Why so? You live. You flourish. You bloom."

Translation

Why are you asking? You're alive. You're thriving. You're doing great.

"Ah, how you've all always hated me!" he murmured with a pensive gaze again at the window.

Translation

"Oh, I know you've all always hated me!" he mumbled, looking thoughtfully out the window again.

"No one could be less of a mere cherished memory," she declared as if she had not heard him. "You're an actual person, if there ever was one. We agreed just now that you're beautiful. You strike me, you know, as—in your own way—much more firm on your feet than I am. Don't put it to me therefore as monstrous that the fact that we are, after all, parent and child should at present in some manner count for us. My idea has been that it should have some effect for each of us. I don't at all, as I told you just now," she pursued, "make out your life; but whatever it is I hereby offer you to accept it. And, on my side, I'll do everything I can for you."

Translation

"You are anything but just a sweet memory," she said, as if she hadn't heard him. "You're a real person, if anyone ever was. We just agreed you're beautiful. You seem to me, in your own way, much more stable and secure than I am. So, don't act like it's a huge deal that we're actually parent and child, and that it should mean something to us. I think it should have some impact on both of us. I don't, as I told you, try to control your life, but I offer you my support to live it however you want. And I'll do everything I can for you."

"I see," said Lionel Croy. Then, with the sound of extreme relevance, "And what can you?" She only, at this, hesitated, and he took up her silence. "You can describe yourself—to yourself—as, in a fine flight, giving up your aunt for me; but what good, I should like to know, would your fine flight do me?" As she still said nothing he developed a little. "We're not possessed of so much, at this charming pass, please to remember, as that we can afford not to take hold of any perch held out to us. I like the way you talk, my dear, about 'giving up!' One doesn't give up the use of a spoon because one's reduced to living on broth. And your spoon, that is your aunt, please consider, is partly mine as well." She rose now, as if in sight of the term of her effort, in sight of the futility and the weariness of many things, and moved back to the poor little glass with which she had communed before. She retouched here again the poise of her hat, and this brought to her father's lips another remark in which impatience, however, had already been replaced by a funny flare of appreciation. "Oh, you're all right! Don't muddle yourself up with me!"

Translation

"I understand," said Lionel Croy. Then, with a tone of extreme importance, "And what about you?" She hesitated at this, and he continued her silence. "You can imagine yourself, in a dramatic gesture, giving up your aunt for me; but honestly, what good would that do me?" Since she still said nothing, he elaborated. "We're not in a position, at this point, to turn down any opportunity that comes our way, please remember that. I love the way you talk, darling, about 'giving up'! You don't stop using a spoon just because you're down to eating soup. And your spoon, your aunt, remember, is also partly mine." She stood up then, as if realizing the pointlessness and exhaustion of the situation, and went back to the little mirror she had been looking in. She adjusted her hat, and this prompted her father to make another comment, in which his impatience had already been replaced by a humorous fondness. "Oh, you'll be fine! Don't involve yourself with me!"

His daughter turned round to him. "The condition Aunt Maud makes is that I shall have absolutely nothing to do with you; never see you, nor speak, nor write to you, never go near you nor make you a sign, nor hold any sort of communication with you. What she requires is that you shall simply cease to exist for me."

Translation

His daughter turned to him and said, "Aunt Maud's condition is that I have absolutely nothing to do with you. I can't see you, talk to you, write to you, go near you, or even acknowledge you in any way. Basically, she wants you to completely disappear from my life."

He had always seemed—it was one of the marks of what they called the "unspeakable" in him—to walk a little more on his toes, as if for jauntiness, in the presence of offence. Nothing, however, was more wonderful than what he sometimes would take for offence, unless it might be what he sometimes wouldn't. He walked at any rate on his toes now. "A very proper requirement of your Aunt Maud, my dear—I don't hesitate to say it!" Yet as this, much as she had seen, left her silent at first from what might have been a sense of sickness, he had time to go on: "That's her condition then. But what are her promises? Just what does she engage to do? You must work it, you know."

Translation

He always seemed—and this was one of the things that made him seem so awful—to try to appear cheerful and lighthearted when he thought someone was offended. But it was amazing how often he *thought* someone was offended, and even more amazing when he *wasn't*. Anyway, he was putting on that act now. "Your Aunt Maud is absolutely right, I'll say that much!" But as the statement, even though she had seen it all before, left her speechless, possibly from feeling disgusted, he continued, "That's what she *thinks*. But what does she *promise* to do? What's she actually going to do? You need to figure that out."

"You mean make her feel," Kate asked after a moment, "how much I'm attached to you?"

Translation

"You mean," Kate asked after a pause, "make her realize how much I care about you?"

"Well, what a cruel, invidious treaty it is for you to sign. I'm a poor old dad to make a stand about giving up—I quite agree. But I'm not, after all, quite the old dad not to get something for giving up."

Translation

Wow, this treaty is really unfair for you to agree to. I'm just a poor old dad, and I understand why you'd want to quit – I get it. But, at the end of the day, I'm not so clueless that I don't expect to get something in return for giving in.

"Oh, I think her idea," said Kate almost gaily now, "is that I shall get a great deal."

Translation

"Oh, I think she's under the impression," Kate said, almost cheerfully, "that I'm going to inherit a lot of money."

He met her with his inimitable amenity. "But does she give you the items?"

Translation

He greeted her with his unique charm. "But does she give you the stuff?"

The girl went through the show. "More or less, I think. But many of them are things I dare say I may take for granted—things women can do for each other and that you wouldn't understand."

Translation

The girl went through the show. "Pretty much, I guess. But a lot of them are things I probably don't even think about anymore – things women do for each other that you wouldn't get."

"There's nothing I understand so well, always, as the things I needn't! But what I want to do, you see," he went on, "is to put it to your conscience that you've an admirable opportunity; and that it's moreover one for which, after all, damn you, you've really to thank me."

Translation

"The things I don't need are the easiest for me to understand, always! But what I want to do," he continued, "is to make you realize that you have a great opportunity. And, frankly, you should be grateful to me for it."

"I confess I don't see," Kate observed, "what my 'conscience' has to do with it."

Translation

"I honestly don't understand," Kate said, "what my sense of right and wrong has to do with this."

"Then, my dear girl, you ought simply to be ashamed of yourself. Do you know what you're a proof of, all you hard, hollow people together?" He put the question with a charming air of sudden spiritual heat. "Of the deplorably superficial morality of the age. The family sentiment, in our vulgarised, brutalised life, has gone utterly to pot. There was a day when a man like me—by which I mean a parent like me—would have been for a daughter like you a quite distinct value; what's called in the business world, I believe, an 'asset.'" He continued sociably to make it out. "I'm not talking only of what you might, with the right feeling do for me, but of what you might—it's what I call your opportunity—do with me. Unless indeed," he the next moment imperturbably threw off, "they come a good deal to the same thing. Your duty as well as your chance, if you're capable of seeing it, is to use me. Show family feeling by seeing what I'm good for. If you had it as I have it you'd see I'm still good—well, for a lot of things. There's in fact, my dear," Mr. Croy wound up, "a coach-and-four to be got out of me." His drop, or rather his climax, failed a little of effect, indeed, through an undue precipitation of memory. Something his daughter had said came back to him. "You've settled to give away half your little inheritance?"

Translation

"Well, you should be embarrassed, honestly. Do you even realize what you and all these cold, empty people represent?" He asked this with a sudden burst of enthusiasm, as if he'd just found religion. "You're proof of how shallow and worthless our morals have become. Family loyalty, in this crude, heartless world, is completely gone. There was a time when a man like me—a father like me—would have been a significant advantage for a daughter like you; a real 'asset,' as they say in the business world."

He went on, friendly as could be, explaining himself. "I'm not just talking about what you could do *for* me, but what you could do *with* me – that's your chance, your opportunity. Unless," he added casually, "they amount to pretty much the same thing. Your duty, and your chance, if you have any sense, is to use me. Show your family feeling by figuring out what I'm good for. If you understood the situation the way I do, you'd see I'm still valuable – good for a lot of things. The truth is, dear," Mr. Croy concluded, "you can get a great deal out of me." His dramatic finale, however, wasn't quite as impressive as he hoped, because his memory kicked in a little too quickly. Something his daughter had said earlier came back to him. "So, you've decided to give away half your inheritance?"

Her hesitation broke into laughter. "No—I haven't 'settled' anything."

Translation

She stopped hesitating and started laughing. "No—I haven't 'fixed' anything."

"But you mean, practically, to let Marian collar it?" They stood there face to face, but she so denied herself to his challenge that he could only go on. "You've a view of three hundred a year for her in addition to what her husband left her with? Is that," the remote progenitor of such wantonness audibly wondered, "your morality?"

Translation

"But are you actually going to let Marian take the blame?" They were standing right in front of each other, but she wouldn't react to his accusation, so he just continued. "You're planning on giving her an extra three hundred a year on top of what her husband left her? Is that," the person who caused this scandalous situation thought out loud, "your idea of being moral?"

Kate found her answer without trouble. "Is it your idea that I should give you everything?"

Translation

Kate easily found the answer. "So, you think I should just give you everything?"

The "everything" clearly struck him—to the point even of determining the tone of his reply. "Far from it. How can you ask that when I refuse what you tell me you came to offer? Make of my idea what you can; I think I've sufficiently expressed it, and it's at any rate to take or to leave. It's the only one, I may nevertheless add; it's the basket with all my eggs. It's my conception, in short, of your duty."

Translation

He clearly understood the whole situation, and it affected how he responded. "Not at all. How can you even suggest that, when I'm turning down what you came here to propose? Do what you want with my suggestion; I believe I've made myself clear, and you can either accept it or reject it. And by the way, it's the only idea I have; it's all I've got to offer. Basically, it's my understanding of what you should do."

The girl's tired smile watched the word as if it had taken on a small grotesque visibility. "You're wonderful on such subjects! I think I should leave you in no doubt," she pursued, "that if I were to sign my aunt's agreement I should carry it out, in honour, to the letter."

Translation

The girl's weary smile focused on the word, as if it had become something small and strangely visible. "You're amazing at talking about these things! I want you to be absolutely clear," she continued, "that if I were to sign my aunt's agreement, I would honor it completely, to every detail."

"Rather, my own love! It's just your honour that I appeal to. The only way to play the game is to play it. There's no limit to what your aunt can do for you."

Translation

Honey, come on! I'm just saying this because I respect you. The only way to get through this is to actually do it. Your aunt can do anything for you.

"Do you mean in the way of marrying me?"

Translation

Are you asking if I want to marry you?

"What else should I mean? Marry properly——"

Translation

What else am I supposed to say? Get married the right way.

"And then?" Kate asked as he hung fire.

Translation

"And then?" Kate asked, waiting for him to continue.

"And then—well, I will talk with you. I'll resume relations."

Translation

And then—okay, I'll talk to you. We'll start being in contact again.

She looked about her and picked up her parasol. "Because you're not so afraid of any one else in the world as you are of her? My husband, if I should marry, would be, at the worst, less of a terror? If that's what you mean, there may be something in it. But doesn't it depend a little also on what you mean by my getting a proper one? However," Kate added as she picked out the frill of her little umbrella, "I don't suppose your idea of him is quite that he should persuade you to live with us."

Translation

She looked around and grabbed her parasol. "Is it because you're more scared of her than anyone else? If I were to get married, my husband, at worst, would be less frightening? Maybe you're right. But it also depends on what you think is a 'proper' husband. Anyway," Kate added, smoothing the frill of her little umbrella, "I doubt you think he'd try to convince you to live with us."

"Dear no—not a bit." He spoke as not resenting either the fear or the hope she imputed; met both imputations, in fact, with a sort of intellectual relief. "I place the case for you wholly in your aunt's hands. I take her view, with my eyes shut; I accept in all confidence any man she selects. If he's good enough for her—elephantine snob as she is—he's good enough for me; and quite in spite of the fact that she'll be sure to select one who can be trusted to be nasty to me. My only interest is in your doing what she wants. You shan't be so beastly poor, my darling," Mr. Croy declared, "if I can help it."

Translation

"Oh, absolutely not," he said, not seeming to mind the fear or the hope she was suggesting. In fact, he seemed almost relieved by both. "I'm leaving the entire matter up to your aunt. I agree with her completely, without even thinking about it. I'll trust her judgment on any man she chooses. If he's good enough for her—even though she's a huge snob—he's good enough for me. And even though she'll probably pick someone who will treat me badly. My only concern is that you do what she wants. You're not going to be dirt poor, my love," Mr. Croy said, "if I can help it."

"Well then, good-bye, papa," the girl said after a reflection on this that had perceptibly ended for her in a renunciation of further debate. "Of course you understand that it may be for long."

Translation

"Okay, bye Dad," the girl said, having clearly decided she wasn't going to argue anymore. "You know this could be a long time, right?"

Her companion, hereupon, had one of his finest inspirations. "Why not, frankly, for ever? You must do me the justice to see that I don't do things, that I've never done them, by halves—that if I offer you to efface myself, it's for the final, fatal sponge that I ask, well saturated and well applied."

Translation

At this point, her companion had a brilliant idea. "Why not commit to this forever? You have to admit, I don't do things halfway. If I'm offering to disappear, it's a complete, irreversible commitment – I'm asking for a total wipe, done thoroughly and without reservation."

She turned her handsome, quiet face upon him at such length that it might well have been for the last time. "I don't know what you're like."

Translation

She looked at him with her beautiful, calm face for a long time, maybe as if it were the last time. "I don't understand you."

"No more do I, my dear. I've spent my life in trying, in vain, to discover. Like nothing—more's the pity. If there had been many of us, and we could have found each other out, there's no knowing what we mightn't have done. But it doesn't matter now. Good-bye, love." He looked even not sure of what she would wish him to suppose on the subject of a kiss, yet also not embarrassed by his uncertainty.

Translation

"Not anymore, my dear. I've wasted my life

trying to figure things out, but it was useless. It's like nothing—it's a shame. If there were more of us, and we could have found each other, who knows what we could have accomplished. But it doesn't matter now. Goodbye, love." He looked uncertain about whether she'd want him to kiss her, but he wasn't uncomfortable about not knowing.

She forbore in fact for a moment longer to clear it up. "I wish there were some one here who might serve—for any contingency—as a witness that I have put it to you that I'm ready to come."

Translation

She actually hesitated a moment before explaining it further. "I wish someone was here who could be a witness—in case anything happens—that I've told you I'm prepared to come."

"Would you like me," her father asked, "to call the landlady?"

Translation

"Do you want me," her father asked, "to call the landlady?"

"You may not believe me," she pursued, "but I came really hoping you might have found some way. I'm very sorry, at all events, to leave you unwell." He turned away from her, on this, and, as he had done before, took refuge, by the window, in a stare at the street. "Let me put it—unfortunately without a witness," she added after a moment, "that there's only one word you really need speak."

Translation

You probably won't believe me, she continued, "but I honestly hoped you'd found a solution. I'm really sorry to leave you feeling sick, no matter what."

He turned away from her then, and just like he'd done before, he went to the window and stared out at the street.

"Let me just say—and unfortunately, there's no one here to back me up," she added a moment later, "that there's only one thing you really need to say."

When he took this up it was still with his back to her. "If I don't strike you as having already spoken it, our time has been singularly wasted."

Translation

He was still facing away from her when he said this. "If you don't think I've already said this, then we've both completely wasted our time."

"I'll engage with you in respect to my aunt exactly to what she wants of me in respect to you. She wants me to choose. Very well, I will choose. I'll wash my hands of her for you to just that tune."

Translation

I'll do exactly what my aunt wants me to do regarding you. She wants me to make a choice. Fine, I will. I'll cut ties with her for you, just like that.

He at last brought himself round. "Do you know, dear, you make me sick? I've tried to be clear, and it isn't fair."

Translation

He finally calmed down. "You know, honey, you're making me upset. I've tried to be upfront, and this isn't right."

But she passed this over; she was too visibly sincere. "Father!"

Translation

But she ignored it; she was clearly being genuine.

"Father!"

"I don't quite see what's the matter with you," he said, "and if you can't pull yourself together I'll—upon my honour—take you in hand. Put you into a cab and deliver you again safe at Lancaster Gate."

Translation

"I don't understand what your problem is," he said. "If you don't get a grip, I swear I'll do something about it. I'll put you in a cab and make sure you get home safely to Lancaster Gate."

She was really absent, distant. "Father."

Translation

She seemed out of it, far away. "Dad."

It was too much, and he met it sharply. "Well?"

Translation

He'd had enough. He reacted to it abruptly, saying, "So?"

"Strange as it may be to you to hear me say it, there's a good you can do me and a help you can render."

Translation

I know this might sound odd, but you could actually help me out.

"Isn't it then exactly what I've been trying to make you feel?"

Translation

Isn't that exactly the point I've been trying to get you to understand?

"Yes," she answered patiently, "but so in the wrong way. I'm perfectly honest in what I say, and I know what I'm talking about. It isn't that I'll pretend I could have believed a month ago in anything to call aid or support from you. The case is changed—that's what has happened; my difficulty's a new one. But even now it's not a question of anything I should ask you in a way to 'do.' It's simply a question of your not turning me away—taking yourself out of my life. It's simply a question of your saying: 'Yes then, since you will, we'll stand together. We won't worry in advance about how or where; we'll have a faith and find a way.' That's all—that would be the good you'd do me. I should have you, and it would be for my benefit. Do you see?"

Translation

"Yes," she answered calmly, "but you're misunderstanding me. I'm being completely truthful, and I know what I'm saying. It's not that I would have pretended a month ago that I could have asked for your help or support. The situation has changed – that's the difference; my problem is a new one. But even now, it's not about asking you to *do* anything. It's simply about you not abandoning me – not removing yourself from my life. It's just about you saying, 'Okay, since you want to, we'll face this together. We won't worry about how or where; we'll have faith and find a solution.' That's all – that's the help you could give me. I'd have you, and it would be for my own good. Do you understand?"

If he didn't it was not for want of looking at her hard. "The matter with you is that you're in love, and that your aunt knows and—for reasons, I'm sure, perfect—hates and opposes it. Well she may! It's a matter in which I trust her with my eyes shut. Go, please." Though he spoke not in anger—rather in infinite sadness—he fairly turned her out. Before she took it up he had, as the fullest expression of what he felt, opened the door of the room. He had fairly, in his deep disapproval, a generous compassion to spare. "I'm sorry for her, deluded woman, if she builds on you."

Translation

If he didn't do it, it wasn't because he hadn't stared at her intensely. "The problem is you're in love, and your aunt knows it and—I'm sure for good reasons—hates and opposes it. And she has every right! I trust her judgment completely on this. Please, leave." Although he wasn't angry, but rather deeply sad, he essentially kicked her out. Before she could respond, he opened the door, as the ultimate way to express his feelings. Despite his strong disapproval, he still felt a considerable amount of compassion. "I feel sorry for her, that misguided woman, if she's counting on you."

Kate stood a moment in the draught. "She's not the person I pity most, for, deluded in many ways though she may be, she's not the person who's most so. I mean," she explained, "if it's a question of what you call building on me."

Translation

Kate stood for a moment in the draft. "She's not the person I feel the most sorry for. Even though she's mistaken about a lot of things, she's not the one who's *most* mistaken. I mean," she clarified, "if you're asking about how much I'm affected by all of this."

He took it as if what she meant might be other than her description of it. "You're deceiving two persons then, Mrs. Lowder and somebody else?"

Translation

He suspected there was more to her statement than what she was actually saying. "So, you're lying to two people, Mrs. Lowder, you and someone else?"

She shook her head with detachment. "I've no intention of that sort with respect to any one now—to Mrs. Lowder least of all. If you fail me"—she seemed to make it out for herself—"that has the merit at least that it simplifies. I shall go my way—as I see my way."

Translation

She shook her head, distancing herself from the idea. "I have no interest in that kind of relationship with anyone now—especially not with Mrs. Lowder. If you fail me"—she seemed to be figuring this out as she spoke—"at least that makes things simpler. I'll do what I have to do—as I see fit."

"Your way, you mean then, will be to marry some blackguard without a penny?"

Translation

So, you're saying you'll marry some worthless bum who's broke?

"You ask a great deal of satisfaction," she observed, "for the little you give."

Translation

You're expecting a lot of happiness, considering how little you contribute.

It brought him up again before her as with a sense that she was not to be hustled; and, though he glared at her a little, this had long been the practical limit to his general power of objection. "If you're base enough to incur your aunt's disgust, you're base enough for my argument. What, if you're not thinking of an utterly improper person, do your speeches to me signify? Who is the beggarly sneak?" he demanded as her response failed. Her response, when it came, was cold but distinct. "He has every disposition to make the best of you. He only wants in fact to be kind to you."

Translation

It brought him back to her, as if he knew she wouldn't be rushed. Even though he gave her a dirty look, that was about as far as his complaints ever went these days. "If you're willing to disgust your aunt, you're willing to do anything. What are you even talking about if you're not interested in someone completely unsuitable? Who is this worthless creep?" he demanded, since she wouldn't answer. Her reply, when it finally came, was icy but clear. "He's genuinely trying to make things better for you. Actually, he just wants to be nice to you."

"Then he must be an ass! And how in the world can you consider it to improve him for me," her father pursued, "that he's also destitute and impossible? There are asses and asses, even—the right and the wrong—and you appear to have carefully picked out one of the wrong. Your aunt knows them, by good fortune; I perfectly trust, as I tell you, her judgment for them; and you may take it from me once for all that I won't hear of any one of whom she won't." Which led up to his last word. "If you should really defy us both——!"

Translation

"Well, he's an idiot! And how can you think it'll make him better for me," her father continued, "that he's also broke and completely unsuitable? There are different kinds of idiots – some are okay, and some are awful – and you seem to have found one of the awful ones. Luckily, your aunt knows these types; I trust her opinion completely, and I'm telling you, I won't even consider someone she doesn't approve of. And that's final." Which brought him to his final threat. "If you actually go against both of us——!"

"Well, papa?"

Translation

"So, Dad?"

"Well, my sweet child, I think that—reduced to insignificance as you may fondly believe me—I should still not be quite without some way of making you regret it."

Translation

Alright, kid, even though you might think I'm completely powerless, I still have a few tricks up my sleeve that could make you wish you hadn't done this.

She had a pause, a grave one, but not, as appeared, that she might measure this danger. "If I shouldn't do it, you know, it wouldn't be because I'm afraid of you."

Translation

She hesitated, seriously, but not, it seemed, to assess the risk. "If I don't do it, understand, it won't be because I'm scared of you."

"Oh, if you don't do it," he retorted, "you may be as bold as you like!"

Translation

"Oh, if you don't do it," he snapped back, "you can be as defiant as you want!"

"Then you can do nothing at all for me?"

Translation

So, there's nothing you can do to help me?

He showed her, this time unmistakably—it was before her there on the landing, at the top of the tortuous stairs and in the midst of the strange smell that seemed to cling to them—how vain her appeal remained. "I've never pretended to do more than my duty; I've given you the best and the clearest advice." And then came up the spring that moved him. "If it only displeases you, you can go to Marian to be consoled." What he couldn't forgive was her dividing with Marian her scant share of the provision their mother had been able to leave them. She should have divided it with him.

Translation

This time, he made it absolutely clear. He showed her right there on the landing, at the top of the winding staircase, surrounded by that weird smell that always seemed to linger there. He showed her how pointless her pleading was. "I've never claimed to do more than what was expected of me. I've given you the best and most straightforward advice." And then he snapped. "If you're not happy, you can go to Marian for comfort." What he couldn't stand was that she had split the small inheritance their mother left them with Marian. She should have shared it with him instead.

Chapter II

Chapter Summary & Character Study
Summary

After her mother’s death, a young woman went to live with her wealthy aunt, Mrs. Lowder (Aunt Maud). While living in her aunt’s house, she discovered she enjoyed material comforts. She also discovered that her aunt had long been concerned about her family. The young woman, Kate, spent much of her time alone in her room, feeling pressure from her aunt and postponing a "surrender" to her.

Kate visited her sister, Marian, a widow with four children. During the visit, which took place in Marian's home after the children’s dinner, Marian told Kate not to "throw herself away." Marian explained that she was afraid Kate would marry Merton Densher, whom she dislikes for having no money. Marian insisted that Kate must marry for money and do what their Aunt Maud wants.

Kate replied that their father had told her the same thing the previous day. She then revealed that she had visited their father and offered to go live with him. Marian reacted with horror. Kate explained that their father had refused her offer, believing she should stay with Aunt Maud and threatening to curse her if she left.

As Kate was leaving, she asked whom Marian meant by "Aunt Maud's young man." Marian named Lord Mark. Kate dismissed this as gossip. To end the conversation, they agreed that Marian would stop mentioning Lord Mark as long as Kate assured her she was not involved with anyone else. Kate denied everything and left.

Character Study

Based on the text, here is a concise character study:

  • *Kate Croy**
    • Kate is presented as an intelligent, observant, and deeply conflicted young woman whose situation has shifted dramatically. Forced by her mother's death and financial ruin to live with her wealthy aunt, she is acutely aware of her new dependence. She is introspective, analyzing her own surprising susceptibility to the material comforts her aunt provides, while also feeling trapped and scrutinized. She views herself as a "trembling kid" before the "lioness" Aunt Maud, and feels a burdensome, resentful duty toward her sister. She hides her true thoughts from others, often accepting their interpretations of her actions to maintain peace, a state she sees as a "hypocrisy of stupidity."
  • *Mrs. Lowder (Aunt Maud)**
    • Presented entirely through Kate's perception, Aunt Maud is a formidable and powerful figure. She is physically described as "majestic" and "magnificent," but her personality is seen as "sharp," controlling, and possessing a "strong will." Kate views her as a "lioness" and a "besieger," a complex and "unscrupulous" force who is both "passionate" and "practical." In the past, she maintained a calculated distance from Kate's family, offering just enough to create a sense of grievance. Now, having taken Kate in, her influence is an immense, looming pressure that dictates Kate's options.
  • *Marian Condrip**
Kate’s elder sister, Marian, is presented as a woman diminished by circumstance. A "demoralised, querulous" widow with children, she has lost her youthful charm and become, in Kate’s eyes, selfish and manipulative. Her situation is one of financial desperation, and she relentlessly pressures Kate to secure their aunt’s fortune for the family’s benefit. She is fixated on Kate making a strategic marriage and is openly hostile to any prospect, like Merton Densher, who lacks money. Her perspective is portrayed as vulgar and "abject," shaped by her unhappy marriage and the influence of her late husband's family.

She had gone to Mrs. Lowder on her mother's death—gone with an effort the strain and pain of which made her at present, as she recalled them, reflect on the long way she had travelled since then. There had been nothing else to do—not a penny in the other house, nothing but unpaid bills that had gathered thick while its mistress lay mortally ill, and the admonition that there was nothing she must attempt to raise money on, since everything belonged to the "estate." How the estate would turn out at best presented itself as a mystery altogether gruesome; it had proved, in fact, since then a residuum a trifle less scant than, with Marian, she had for some weeks feared; but the girl had had at the beginning rather a wounded sense of its being watched on behalf of Marian and her children. What on earth was it supposed that she wanted to do to it? She wanted in truth only to give up—to abandon her own interest, which she, no doubt, would already have done had not the point been subject to Aunt Maud's sharp intervention. Aunt Maud's intervention was all sharp now, and the other point, the great one, was that it was to be, in this light, either all put up with or all declined. Yet at the winter's end, nevertheless, she could scarce have said what stand she conceived she had taken. It wouldn't be the first time she had seen herself obliged to accept with smothered irony other people's interpretation of her conduct. She often ended by giving up to them—it seemed really the way to live—the version that met their convenience.

Translation

After her mother died, she went to Mrs. Lowder. Remembering the effort and pain that took, she realized how much she'd changed since then. She had no other options—no money in her childhood home, just unpaid bills that piled up while her mother was dying. And she was told not to try to borrow money, because everything was tied up in the "estate." How that estate would work out was a scary mystery. In the end, it turned out to be a little more than she had feared, but at first she felt like someone was watching her, possibly to protect Marian and her children. What did they think she was going to do with it? Really, she just wanted to give up—to forget about her own interests. She probably would have, too, if Aunt Maud hadn't interfered so sharply. Aunt Maud’s intervention was always harsh. The main issue was that she had to either accept everything, or reject it all. Still, by the end of winter, she wasn't sure what her actual position was. It wouldn't be the first time she’d been forced to accept other people's views of her actions, doing it with a hidden smile. She often gave in to them – it felt like the only way to get by – and went along with the version that suited them best.

The tall, rich, heavy house at Lancaster Gate, on the other side of the Park and the long South Kensington stretches, had figured to her, through childhood, through girlhood, as the remotest limit of her vague young world. It was further off and more occasional than anything else in the comparatively compact circle in which she revolved, and seemed, by a rigour early marked, to be reached through long, straight, discouraging vistas, which kept lengthening and straightening, whereas almost everything else in life was either, at the worst, round about Cromwell Road, or, at the furthest, in the nearer parts of Kensington Gardens. Mrs. Lowder was her only "real" aunt, not the wife of an uncle, and had been thereby, both in ancient days and when the greater trouble came, the person, of all persons, properly to make some sign; in accord with which our young woman's feeling was founded on the impression, quite cherished for years, that the signs made across the interval just mentioned had never been really in the note of the situation. The main office of this relative, for the young Croys—apart from giving them their fixed measure of social greatness—had struck them as being to form them to a conception of what they were not to expect. When Kate came to think matters over with the aid of knowledge, she failed quite to see how Aunt Maud could have been different—she had rather perceived by this time how many other things might have been; yet she also made out that if they had all consciously lived under a liability to the chill breath of ultima Thule they couldn't, either, on the facts, very well have done less. What in the event appeared established was that if Mrs. Lowder had disliked them she had yet not disliked them so much as they supposed. It had at any rate been for the purpose of showing how she struggled with her aversion that she sometimes came to see them, that she at regular periods invited them to her house, and in short, as it now looked, kept them along on the terms that would best give her sister the perennial luxury of a grievance. This sister, poor Mrs. Croy, the girl knew, had always judged her resentfully, and had brought them up, Marian, the boys and herself, to the idea of a particular attitude, for signs of the practice of which they watched each other with awe. The attitude was to make plain to Aunt Maud, with the same regularity as her invitations, that they sufficed—thanks awfully—to themselves. But the ground of it, Kate lived to discern, was that this was only because she didn't suffice to them. The little she offered was to be accepted under protest, yet not, really, because it was excessive. It wounded them—there was the rub!—because it fell short.

Translation

As a child and young woman, the imposing, wealthy home on Lancaster Gate, across the park and the long South Kensington area, seemed to Kate to be the furthest point in her limited world.
