It was more distant and less frequently visited than anything else in the relatively small world she moved in. Reaching it seemed to involve long, straight, and discouraging paths that always seemed to stretch further, while everything else in her life was either close to Cromwell Road or, at most, in the nearby Kensington Gardens. Mrs. Lowder, her only "real" aunt (not just an aunt by marriage), should have been the one to offer help, both in the past and when serious difficulties arose. Kate had long believed that the gestures Mrs. Lowder made across that distance never truly addressed the situation. Aside from giving the young Croys a sense of their social standing, Mrs. Lowder's main role, as they saw it, was to shape their expectations by showing them what they shouldn't hope for. When Kate later reflected on the situation with more understanding, she couldn't see how Aunt Maud could have acted differently – instead, she realized how many other things could have happened. However, she also understood that if they had all lived under the threat of utter rejection, they couldn't have realistically expected less. The established truth was that even if Mrs. Lowder disliked them, she hadn't disliked them as much as they'd thought. In fact, her visits and regular invitations, and everything she did, seemed designed to show her struggle with her aversion. She kept them around on terms that allowed her sister, Mrs. Croy, to perpetually feel aggrieved. Kate knew that her mother had always judged her resentfully and had raised them to adopt a specific attitude, and they all nervously watched each other to see if they were fulfilling the role. That attitude was designed to show Aunt Maud, as consistently as her invitations, that they were perfectly fine on their own, thank you very much. But Kate later realized the real reason for this was that they *weren't* fine on their own. They were supposed to accept what little she offered with reluctance, not because it was too much, but because it wasn't enough. That's what hurt them.

The number of new things our young lady looked out on from the high south window that hung over the Park—this number was so great (though some of the things were only old ones altered and, as the phrase was of other matters, done up), that life at present turned to her view from week to week more and more the face of a striking and distinguished stranger. She had reached a great age—for it quite seemed to her that at twenty-five it was late to reconsider; and her most general sense was a shade of regret that she had not known earlier. The world was different—whether for worse or for better—from her rudimentary readings, and it gave her the feeling of a wasted past. If she had only known sooner she might have arranged herself more to meet it. She made, at all events, discoveries every day, some of which were about herself and others about other persons. Two of these—one under each head—more particularly engaged, in alternation, her anxiety. She saw as she had never seen before how material things spoke to her. She saw, and she blushed to see, that if, in contrast with some of its old aspects, life now affected her as a dress successfully "done up," this was exactly by reason of the trimmings and lace, was a matter of ribbons and silk and velvet. She had a dire accessibility to pleasure from such sources. She liked the charming quarters her aunt had assigned her—liked them literally more than she had in all her other days liked anything; and nothing could have been more uneasy than her suspicion of her relative's view of this truth. Her relative was prodigious—she had never done her relative justice. These larger conditions all tasted of her, from morning till night; but she was a person in respect to whom the growth of acquaintance could only—strange as it might seem—keep your heart in your mouth.

Translation

From the tall window overlooking the park, our young woman observed so many new things (though some were just old things that had been changed or "dressed up"), that her life seemed more and more like an impressive and unfamiliar person. She felt old, considering she was already twenty-five, and she regretted not understanding these things sooner. The world was different than she had previously understood, and she felt like she’d wasted her past. If she'd known earlier, she might have better prepared herself. She discovered something new every day, some about herself and some about others. Two of these discoveries, one about herself and one about someone else, occupied her thoughts. She realized how much material things appealed to her. She blushed to admit that if life now felt appealing, like a well-dressed gown, it was because of the pretty decorations. She was terribly susceptible to pleasure from those kinds of things. She loved the lovely rooms her aunt had given her, literally more than she'd ever liked anything else; and she felt uneasy suspecting her aunt knew this. Her aunt was amazing—she had never fully appreciated her. Her aunt's influence touched everything in her life. But when it came to her aunt, the more she knew, the more apprehensive she became.

The girl's second great discovery was that, so far from having been for Mrs. Lowder a subject of superficial consideration, the blighted home in Lexham Gardens had haunted her nights and her days. Kate had spent, all winter, hours of observation that were not less pointed for being spent alone; recent events, which her mourning explained, assured her a measure of isolation, and it was in the isolation above all that her neighbour's influence worked. Sitting far downstairs Aunt Maud was yet a presence from which a sensitive niece could feel herself extremely under pressure. She knew herself now, the sensitive niece, as having been marked from far back. She knew more than she could have told you, by the upstairs fire, in a whole dark December afternoon. She knew so much that her knowledge was what fairly kept her there, making her at times more endlessly between the small silk-covered sofa that stood for her in the firelight and the great grey map of Middlesex spread beneath her lookout. To go down, to forsake her refuge, was to meet some of her discoveries half-way, to have to face them or fly before them; whereas they were at such a height only like the rumble of a far-off siege heard in the provisioned citadel. She had almost liked, in these weeks, what had created her suspense and her stress: the loss of her mother, the submersion of her father, the discomfort of her sister, the confirmation of their shrunken prospects, the certainty, in especial, of her having to recognise that, should she behave, as she called it, decently—that is still do something for others—she would be herself wholly without supplies. She held that she had a right to sadness and stillness; she nursed them for their postponing power. What they mainly postponed was the question of a surrender—though she could not yet have said exactly of what: a general surrender of everything—that was at moments the way it presented itself—to Aunt Maud's looming "personality." It was by her personality that Aunt Maud was prodigious, and the great mass of it loomed because, in the thick, the foglike air of her arranged existence, there were parts doubtless magnified and parts certainly vague. They represented at all events alike, the dim and the distinct, a strong will and a high hand. It was perfectly present to Kate that she might be devoured, and she likened herself to a trembling kid, kept apart a day or two till her turn should come, but sure sooner or later to be introduced into the cage of the lioness.

Translation

The girl's second major realization was that Mrs. Lowder hadn't just given a passing thought to the situation; the troubled household in Lexham Gardens had become an obsession for her. Kate had spent the entire winter alone, carefully observing, and her isolation, explained by her mourning, only intensified the impact of her neighbor.

Even sitting downstairs, Aunt Maud’s presence weighed heavily on her sensitive niece. Kate now understood that she had been under scrutiny for a long time. She knew more than she could ever have expressed, even sitting by the fire upstairs on a long, dark December afternoon. She knew so much that her knowledge kept her there, constantly moving between the small, silk-covered sofa in the firelight and the large gray map of Middlesex spread beneath her window. To go downstairs, to leave her sanctuary, meant confronting some of her discoveries, facing them or running from them. Up there, they were just like the distant sounds of a siege heard from a protected fortress.

In those weeks, she had almost enjoyed the things that caused her anxiety and stress: her mother's death, her father's withdrawal, her sister's distress, the confirmation of their reduced circumstances, and especially the certainty that if she behaved "decently" – meaning, doing something for others – she would be left completely without resources. She believed she had a right to sadness and stillness; she clung to them because they delayed things. What they mainly postponed was the question of surrender – though she couldn't yet say exactly what she would be surrendering: everything, perhaps. That was how it felt at times, a surrender to Aunt Maud's overwhelming "personality." It was her personality that made Aunt Maud so formidable, and it loomed large because, in the dense, foggy atmosphere of her carefully constructed life, some aspects were exaggerated and others uncertain. Both the vague and the clear aspects of her personality represented a strong will and an iron hand.

Kate was fully aware that she might be consumed, and she compared herself to a trembling young goat, kept separate for a short time until her turn came, but inevitably doomed to be brought into the lioness’s cage.

The cage was Aunt Maud's own room, her office, her counting-house, her battlefield, her especial scene, in fine, of action, situated on the ground-floor, opening from the main hall and figuring rather to our young woman on exit and entrance as a guard house or a toll-gate. The lioness waited—the kid had at least that consciousness; was aware of the neighbourhood of a morsel she had reason to suppose tender. She would have been meanwhile a wonderful lioness for a show, an extraordinary figure in a cage or anywhere; majestic, magnificent, high-coloured, all brilliant gloss, perpetual satin, twinkling bugles and flashing gems, with a lustre of agate eyes, a sheen of raven hair, a polish of complexion that was like that of well-kept china and that—as if the skin were too tight—told especially at curves and corners. Her niece had a quiet name for her—she kept it quiet; thinking of her, with a free fancy, as somehow typically insular, she talked to herself of Britannia of the Market Place—Britannia unmistakable, but with a pen in her ear, and felt she should not be happy till she might on some occasion add to the rest of the panoply a helmet, a shield, a trident and a ledger. It was not in truth, however, that the forces with which, as Kate felt, she would have to deal were those most suggested by an image simple and broad; she was learning, after all, each day, to know her companion, and what she had already most perceived was the mistake of trusting to easy analogies. There was a whole side of Britannia, the side of her florid philistinism, her plumes and her train, her fantastic furniture and heaving bosom, the false gods of her taste and false notes of her talk, the sole contemplation of which would be dangerously misleading. She was a complex and subtle Britannia, as passionate as she was practical, with a reticule for her prejudices as deep as that other pocket, the pocket full of coins stamped in her image, that the world best knew her by. She carried on, in short, behind her aggressive and defensive front, operations determined by her wisdom. It was in fact, we have hinted, as a besieger that our young lady, in the provisioned citadel, had for the present most to think of her, and what made her formidable in this character was that she was unscrupulous and immoral. So, at all events, in silent sessions and a youthful off-hand way, Kate conveniently pictured her: what this sufficiently represented being that her weight was in the scale of certain dangers—those dangers that, by our showing, made the younger woman linger and lurk above, while the elder, below, both militant and diplomatic, covered as much of the ground as possible. Yet what were the dangers, after all, but just the dangers of life and of London? Mrs. Lowder was London, was life—the roar of the siege and the thick of the fray. There were some things, after all, of which Britannia was afraid; but Aunt Maud was afraid of nothing—not even, it would appear, of arduous thought. These impressions, none the less, Kate kept so much to herself that she scarce shared them with poor Marian, the ostensible purpose of her frequent visits to whom yet continued to be to talk over everything. One of her reasons for holding off from the last concession to Aunt Maud was that she might be the more free to commit herself to this so much nearer and so much less fortunate relative, with whom Aunt Maud would have, directly, almost nothing to do. The sharpest pinch of her state, meanwhile, was exactly that all intercourse with her sister had the effect of casting down her courage and tying her hands, adding daily to her sense of the part, not always either uplifting or sweetening, that the bond of blood might play in one's life. She was face to face with it now, with the bond of blood; the consciousness of it was what she seemed most clearly to have "come into" by the death of her mother, much of that consciousness as her mother had absorbed and carried away. Her haunting, harrassing father, her menacing, uncompromising aunt, her portionless little nephews and nieces, were figures that caused the chord of natural piety superabundantly to vibrate. Her manner of putting it to herself—but more especially in respect to Marian—was that she saw what you might be brought to by the cultivation of consanguinity. She had taken, in the old days, as she supposed, the measure of this liability; those being the days when, as the second-born, she had thought no one in the world so pretty as Marian, no one so charming, so clever, so assured, in advance, of happiness and success. The view was different now, but her attitude had been obliged, for many reasons, to show as the same. The subject of this estimate was no longer pretty, as the reason for thinking her clever was no longer plain; yet, bereaved, disappointed, demoralised, querulous, she was all the more sharply and insistently Kate's elder and Kate's own. Kate's most constant feeling about her was that she would make her, Kate, do things; and always, in comfortless Chelsea, at the door of the small house the small rent of which she couldn't help having on her mind, she fatalistically asked herself, before going in, which thing it would probably be this time. She noticed with profundity that disappointment made people selfish; she marvelled at the serenity—it was the poor woman's only one—of what Marian took for granted: her own state of abasement as the second-born, her life reduced to mere inexhaustible sisterhood. She existed, in that view, wholly for the small house in Chelsea; the moral of which moreover, of course, was that the more one gave oneself the less of one was left. There were always people to snatch at one, and it would never occur to them that they were eating one up. They did that without tasting.

Translation

Aunt Maud’s room was also her office, her accounting department, her battleground, and the center of her activities. It was located on the ground floor, opening into the main hall, and it seemed to Kate like a guard post or a toll booth as she went in and out. Aunt Maud was like a lioness waiting for her prey—Kate knew this. She understood that she was perceived as vulnerable. Aunt Maud would have been a remarkable lioness in a show, an extraordinary sight in a cage or anywhere else. She was regal, impressive, vibrant, with a constant sheen of expensive fabrics, glittering details, agate-like eyes, raven hair, and a complexion as smooth as fine china. Her skin looked stretched, especially around her curves and angles. Kate had a private nickname for her—she kept it secret. Thinking of Aunt Maud, Kate playfully imagined her as a symbol of Britain, a strong, unyielding woman, but with a pen tucked behind her ear. Kate felt she wouldn't be truly satisfied until she could add to that image a helmet, a shield, a trident, and a ledger.

However, Kate realized that the real challenges she faced weren't so simple. She was learning more about Aunt Maud every day, and she'd already realized that relying on easy comparisons was a mistake. There was a whole side of Aunt Maud, a side of showiness and shallow values, of fancy decorations and overblown emotions. She indulged in superficial things, and her conversations were often misleading. Kate understood that she was a complex and shrewd person. Aunt Maud was as passionate as she was practical. She had a deep-seated set of prejudices. She had a carefully guarded pocket of money that the world recognized her by. She operated with strategic purpose, using both aggressive and defensive tactics. Kate felt she was like someone under siege, with Aunt Maud as the formidable enemy. What made her so dangerous was her lack of scruples and morals.

Kate pictured her this way in her own mind. Aunt Maud’s influence created a sense of danger for Kate. The younger woman lingered and hesitated, while the older one, both aggressive and cunning, controlled as much territory as possible.

But what, after all, were these dangers, if not the everyday struggles and harsh realities of London life? Mrs. Lowder *was* London, she *was* life—the noise of the siege and the intensity of the fight. There were some things that frightened even the image of Britain. Aunt Maud, however, feared nothing, not even challenging intellectual thought.

Kate kept these thoughts to herself. She rarely shared them with poor Marian, whose visits were ostensibly to talk things over. One of Kate's reasons for delaying her final agreement with Aunt Maud was to have more freedom to help her less fortunate relative, Marian, who Aunt Maud wanted nothing to do with. The most difficult part of Kate's situation was that every interaction with her sister weakened her resolve and limited her choices. It further emphasized the role, which was not always uplifting or pleasant, that family played in one's life.

She was now confronted with this family bond. The awareness of it seemed to be the most significant thing that had come to her with her mother's death. Much of that awareness had been absorbed and taken away with her mother. Her irritating, demanding father, her intimidating aunt, her nephews and nieces, who had nothing, all intensified Kate's sense of duty and compassion. Kate’s thinking, especially about Marian, was that she could see what could happen to you if you focused too much on family ties. She'd once understood the burden this entailed, back in the days when she, as the second-born, had thought no one in the world was as beautiful as Marian, or as charming, clever, and destined for happiness and success. That view had changed now, but she'd had to maintain a façade of familiarity for various reasons. Marian was no longer beautiful, and Kate didn't see her intelligence as obvious anymore. Nevertheless, bereft, disappointed, demoralized, and irritable, Marian was even more emphatically Kate's elder sister and part of her life. Kate’s most consistent feeling about her was that Marian would force her to do things. Always, in uncomfortable Chelsea, at the door of the small house where Marian lived, and whose small rent weighed on Kate’s mind, she fatalistically asked herself before going inside what Marian would demand this time.

She noticed with deep understanding that disappointment made people selfish. She was amazed by the serenity—it was Marian's only comfort—of what Marian took for granted: her own position of subservience as the second-born, her life reduced to nothing more than constant support for her sister. Marian existed, in Kate's view, entirely for the small house in Chelsea, with the moral being that the more one gave, the less of oneself remained. There were always people ready to exploit one’s generosity, and it would never occur to them that they were consuming one’s very being. They did so without any thought.

There was no such misfortune, or at any rate no such discomfort, she further reasoned, as to be formed at once for being and for seeing. You always saw, in this case, something else than what you were, and you got, in consequence, none of the peace of your condition. However, as she never really let Marian see what she was, Marian might well not have been aware that she herself saw. Kate was accordingly, to her own vision, not a hypocrite of virtue, for she gave herself up; but she was a hypocrite of stupidity, for she kept to herself everything that was not herself. What she most kept was the particular sentiment with which she watched her sister instinctively neglect nothing that would make for her submission to their aunt; a state of the spirit that perhaps marked most sharply how poor you might become when you minded so much the absence of wealth. It was through Kate that Aunt Maud should be worked, and nothing mattered less than what might become of Kate in the process. Kate was to burn her ships, in short, so that Marian should profit; and Marian's desire to profit was quite oblivious of a dignity that had, after all, its reasons—if it had only cared for them—for keeping itself a little stiff. Kate, to be properly stiff for both of them, would therefore have had to be selfish, have had to prefer an ideal of behaviour—than which nothing, ever, was more selfish—to the possibility of stray crumbs for the four small creatures. The tale of Mrs. Lowder's disgust at her elder niece's marriage to Mr. Condrip had lost little of its point; the incredibly fatuous behaviour of Mr. Condrip, the parson of a dull suburban parish, with a saintly profile which was always in evidence, being so distinctly on record to keep criticism consistent. He had presented his profile on system, having, goodness knew, nothing else to present—nothing at all to full-face the world with, no imagination of the propriety of living and minding his business. Criticism had remained on Aunt Maud's part consistent enough; she was not a person to regard such proceedings as less of a mistake for having acquired more of the privilege of pathos. She had not been forgiving, and the only approach she made to overlooking them was by overlooking—with the surviving delinquent—the solid little phalanx that now represented them. Of the two sinister ceremonies that she lumped together, the marriage and the interment, she had been present at the former, just as she had sent Marian, before it, a liberal cheque; but this had not been for her more than the shadow of an admitted link with Mrs. Condrip's course. She disapproved of clamorous children for whom there was no prospect; she disapproved of weeping widows who couldn't make their errors good; and she had thus put within Marian's reach one of the few luxuries left when so much else had gone, an easy pretext for a constant grievance. Kate Croy remembered well what their mother, in a different quarter, had made of it; and it was Marian's marked failure to pluck the fruit of resentment that committed them, as sisters, to an almost equal fellowship in abjection. If the theory was that, yes, alas, one of the pair had ceased to be noticed, but that the other was noticed enough to make up for it, who would fail to see that Kate couldn't separate herself without a cruel pride? That lesson became sharp for our young lady the day after her interview with her father.

Translation

She thought there wasn't a problem, or at least nothing that was truly unpleasant, about existing and being aware of yourself simultaneously. You always saw yourself as something different from what you truly were, and as a result, you never found peace in your own situation. However, because she never let Marian truly see her, Marian might not have realized that she herself was also seeing things. So, Kate didn't consider herself a hypocrite in terms of virtue, because she gave herself up completely. Instead, she was a hypocrite in terms of being foolish, because she kept to herself anything that wasn't directly related to her. What she guarded most closely was her private feeling as she watched her sister instinctively do everything possible to please their aunt. This attitude perhaps highlighted how poor you could become if you were overly concerned about not having money. Kate was the one who was meant to manipulate Aunt Maud, and what happened to Kate in the process didn't matter. In short, Kate was supposed to sacrifice everything so Marian could benefit. And Marian's desire to benefit didn't consider the dignity that she, if she had only cared, had reason to maintain. To be properly selfless for both of them, Kate would have had to be selfish, preferring an idea of how she should act – which is, ironically, the most selfish thing of all – over the chance of any advantage for the four children. The story of Mrs. Lowder’s disgust at her older niece's marriage to Mr. Condrip hadn't lost its impact. Mr. Condrip, the pastor of a boring suburban parish, was incredibly foolish, and his saintly profile, which he always displayed, was clearly documented to support consistent criticism. He systematically presented his profile because he had nothing else to offer – no way of confronting the world head-on, no understanding of how to live and mind his own business. Aunt Maud's criticism of the situation remained consistent; she was not the type to think such actions were less of a mistake just because they had acquired more tragic circumstances. She hadn't been forgiving, and the only way she seemed to overlook the issue was to ignore—with the surviving offender—the small, united family they now represented. Of the two terrible events she lumped together, the marriage and the burial, she had attended the former, just as she had sent Marian a generous check before it happened. But this was only a slight acknowledgment of her connection to Mrs. Condrip's choices. She disapproved of noisy children with no future, and she disapproved of weeping widows who couldn't fix their mistakes. Therefore, she had put within Marian's reach one of the few remaining luxuries when so much else was gone: an easy reason to constantly complain. Kate Croy remembered very well how their mother had handled a similar situation in a different context, and it was Marian's noticeable failure to embrace resentment that bound them, as sisters, to almost equal humiliation. If the idea was that, yes, unfortunately, one of them was no longer being noticed, but the other was being noticed enough to compensate, who wouldn't see that Kate couldn't distance herself without being cruelly proud? That lesson became clear to our young woman the day after her meeting with her father.

"I can't imagine," Marian on this occasion said to her, "how you can think of anything else in the world but the horrid way we're situated."

Translation

"I can't believe," Marian said to her at this moment, "how you can think about anything other than the awful situation we're in."

"And, pray, how do you know," Kate inquired in reply, "anything about my thoughts? It seems to me I give you sufficient proof of how much I think of you. I don't, really, my dear, know what else you've to do with!"

Translation

"And, seriously, how do you know," Kate asked in response, "anything about what I'm thinking? It seems to me I've shown you enough how much I care about you. Honestly, I don't know what else you want from me!"

Marian's retort, on this, was a stroke as to which she had supplied herself with several kinds of preparation, but there was, none the less, something of an unexpected note in its promptitude. She had foreseen her sister's general fear; but here, ominously, was the special one. "Well, your own business is of course your own business, and you may say there's no one less in a position than I to preach to you. But, all the same, if you wash your hands of me for ever for it, I won't, for this once, keep back that I don't consider you've a right, as we all stand, to throw yourself away."

Translation

Marian responded with a statement she'd carefully planned, although its quickness still surprised her. She'd anticipated her sister's usual anxieties, but this specific fear felt especially threatening. "Okay, what you do is your business, and I'm probably the last person who should be giving you advice. But even so, if you cut me out of your life completely because of this, I'm going to say, just this once, that I don't think you have the right, considering our situation, to ruin your life."

It was after the children's dinner, which was also their mother's, but which their aunt mostly contrived to keep from ever becoming her own luncheon; and the two young women were still in the presence of the crumpled table-cloth, the dispersed pinafores, the scraped dishes, the lingering odour of boiled food. Kate had asked, with ceremony, if she might put up a window a little, and Mrs. Condrip had replied without it that she might do as she liked. She often received such inquiries as if they reflected in a manner on the pure essence of her little ones. The four had retired, with much movement and noise, under imperfect control of the small Irish governess whom their aunt had hunted out for them and whose brooding resolve not to prolong so uncrowned a martyrdom she already more than suspected. Their mother had become for Kate—who took it just for the effect of being their mother—quite a different thing from the mild Marian of the past: Mr. Condrip's widow expansively obscured that image. She was little more than a ragged relic, a plain, prosaic result of him, as if she had somehow been pulled through him as through an obstinate funnel, only to be left crumpled and useless and with nothing in her but what he accounted for. She had grown red and almost fat, which were not happy signs of mourning; less and less like any Croy, particularly a Croy in trouble, and sensibly like her husband's two unmarried sisters, who came to see her, in Kate's view, much too often and stayed too long, with the consequence of inroads upon the tea and bread-and-butter—matters as to which Kate, not unconcerned with the tradesmen's books, had feelings. About them, moreover, Marian was touchy, and her nearer relative, who observed and weighed things, noted as an oddity that she would have taken any reflection on them as a reflection on herself. If that was what marriage necessarily did to you, Kate Croy would have questioned marriage. It was a grave example, at any rate, of what a man—and such a man!—might make of a woman. She could see how the Condrip pair pressed their brother's widow on the subject of Aunt Maud—who wasn't, after all, their aunt; made her, over their interminable cups, chatter and even swagger about Lancaster Gate, made her more vulgar than it had seemed written that any Croy could possibly become on such a subject. They laid it down, they rubbed it in, that Lancaster Gate was to be kept in sight, and that she, Kate, was to keep it; so that, curiously, or at all events sadly, our young woman was sure of being, in her own person, more permitted to them as an object of comment than they would in turn ever be permitted to herself. The beauty of which, too, was that Marian didn't love them. But they were Condrips—they had grown near the rose; they were almost like Bertie and Maudie, like Kitty and Guy. They talked of the dead to her, which Kate never did; it being a relation in which Kate could but mutely listen. She couldn't indeed too often say to herself that if that was what marriage did to you——! It may easily be guessed, therefore, that the ironic light of such reserves fell straight across the field of Marian's warning. "I don't quite see," she answered, "where, in particular, it strikes you that my danger lies. I'm not conscious, I assure you, of the least 'disposition' to throw myself anywhere. I feel as if, for the present, I have been quite sufficiently thrown."

Translation

It was after the children and their mother had eaten dinner. Their aunt usually avoided eating the same meal. The two young women were still surrounded by the messy table, the discarded children's aprons, the dirty dishes, and the lingering smell of cooked food. Kate had formally asked if she could open a window a little, and Mrs. Condrip had replied, without much enthusiasm, that she could do as she liked. She often reacted to such questions as if they questioned the purity of her children. The four children had retreated, making a lot of noise, under the not-very-effective supervision of the young Irish governess their aunt had hired. Kate suspected the governess was already planning to quit her miserable job. For Kate, their mother—who she viewed simply as "the mother"—had become very different from the gentle Marian of the past. Mr. Condrip's widow completely overshadowed that image. She was reduced to a tired, unremarkable version of herself, almost as if she’d been forced through a difficult experience and left crumpled and useless, defined only by her husband. She had become red-faced and almost fat, which wasn't a good sign for someone in mourning. She resembled the husband's two unmarried sisters less and less, especially a Croy in trouble, and instead, took on more of their appearance. Those sisters visited her, in Kate's opinion, far too often and stayed too long, which resulted in them eating a lot of tea and bread-and-butter—something Kate, who was familiar with the household accounts, cared about. Moreover, Marian was sensitive about her sisters-in-law, and Kate, who observed and judged things, found it strange that Marian would take any criticism of her sisters-in-law as a criticism of herself. If marriage did that to you, Kate Croy would have thought twice about getting married. It was a clear example of what a man—especially a man like him!—could do to a woman. She could see how the Condrip sisters pressured their brother's widow about Aunt Maud—who wasn't actually their aunt. They made her, over their endless cups of tea, gossip and even boast about Lancaster Gate, making her more vulgar than any Croy should ever become on the subject. They insisted that Lancaster Gate should remain a goal, and that she, Kate, should keep it in mind. Therefore, strangely, or at least sadly, Kate realized that she was more of a subject of gossip for them than they would ever be for her. The ironic part was that Marian didn't even like them. But they were Condrips—they were connected to wealth and privilege; they were almost like Bertie and Maudie, like Kitty and Guy. They talked about the deceased Mr. Condrip to Marian, which Kate never did. She could only listen silently. She couldn't help but think to herself, if that was what marriage did to you…! It is easy to guess, therefore, that Marian’s warning fell on deaf ears. "I don't understand," she replied, "what specific danger you think I'm in. I assure you, I'm not at all inclined to throw myself into anything. I feel like I've already been through quite enough."

"You don't feel"—Marian brought it all out—"as if you would like to marry Merton Densher?"

Translation

"Do you feel," Marian asked, spelling it out, "like you want to marry Merton Densher?"

Kate took a moment to meet this inquiry. "Is it your idea that if I should feel so I would be bound to give you notice, so that you might step in and head me off? Is that your idea?" the girl asked. Then, as her sister also had a pause, "I don't know what makes you talk of Mr. Densher," she observed.

Translation

Kate paused to consider the question. "Do you think I'd be obligated to tell you if I was interested, so you could interfere? Is that what you're getting at?" she asked. Then, after her sister also hesitated, she added, "I don't understand why you're bringing up Mr. Densher."

"I talk of him just because you don't. That you never do, in spite of what I know—that's what makes me think of him. Or rather perhaps it's what makes me think of you. If you don't know by this time what I hope for you, what I dream of—my attachment being what it is—it's no use my attempting to tell you." But Marian had in fact warmed to her work, and Kate was sure she had discussed Mr. Densher with the Miss Condrips. "If I name that person I suppose it's because I'm so afraid of him. If you want really to know, he fills me with terror. If you want really to know, in fact, I dislike him as much as I dread him."

Translation

I only mention him because you don't. The fact that you never talk about him, even though I know things—that's what makes me think of him. Or maybe it's what makes me think of you. If you still don't understand what I want for you, what I hope for, given how much I care—there's no point in me explaining it. But Marian was clearly getting into her work, and Kate was certain she had talked about Mr. Densher with the Miss Condrips. "If I say his name, I guess it's because I'm so scared of him. If you really want to know, he terrifies me. If you really want to know, I actually dislike him as much as I fear him."

"And yet don't think it dangerous to abuse him to me?"

Translation

And yet, do you think it's unsafe to insult him in front of me?

"Yes," Mrs. Condrip confessed, "I do think it dangerous; but how can I speak of him otherwise? I dare say, I admit, that I shouldn't speak of him at all. Only I do want you for once, as I said just now, to know."

Translation

"Yes," Mrs. Condrip admitted, "I do think it's dangerous, but how can I talk about him differently? I guess, I mean, I shouldn't talk about him at all. But I really want you to know, just this once, like I said."

"To know what, my dear?"

Translation

"What do you mean?"

"That I should regard it," Marian promptly returned, "as far and away the worst thing that has happened to us yet."

Translation

"I think," Marian immediately replied, "that's by far the worst thing that's happened to us."

"Do you mean because he hasn't money?"

Translation

You mean because he's broke?

"Yes, for one thing. And because I don't believe in him."

Translation

Yes, for one reason. And because I don't believe in him.

Kate was civil, but perfunctory. "What do you mean by not believing in him?"

Translation

Kate was polite, but not very enthusiastic. "What do you mean you don't believe in him?"

"Well, being sure he'll never get it. And you must have it. You shall have it."

Translation

Well, he's definitely not going to get it. And you, you need to have it. You will have it.

"To give it to you?"

Translation

You want it?

Marian met her with a readiness that was practically pert. "To have it, first. Not, at any rate, to go on not having it. Then we should see."

Translation

Marian greeted her with an almost cheeky eagerness. "Get it first. At the very least, stop not having it. Then we'll figure things out."

"We should indeed!" said Kate Croy. It was talk of a kind she loathed, but if Marian chose to be vulgar what was one to do? It made her think of the Miss Condrips with renewed aversion. "I like the way you arrange things—I like what you take for granted. If it's so easy for us to marry men who want us to scatter gold, I wonder we any of us do anything else. I don't see so many of them about, nor what interest I might ever have for them. You live, my dear," she presently added, "in a world of vain thoughts."

Translation

"We really should!" said Kate Croy. She hated this kind of conversation, but if Marian wanted to be crass, what could she do? It reminded her, with renewed annoyance, of the Miss Condrips. "I like your way of planning things—I like your assumptions. If it were truly easy for us to marry rich men who would shower us with money, I'm surprised we don't all do that. I don't see so many of those men around, or what they'd find interesting about me. You, my dear," she added after a moment, "live in a world of unrealistic fantasies."

"Not so much as you, Kate; for I see what I see, and you can't turn it off that way." The elder sister paused long enough for the younger's face to show, in spite of superiority, an apprehension. "I'm not talking of any man but Aunt Maud's man, nor of any money, even, if you like, but Aunt Maud's money. I'm not talking of anything but your doing what she wants. You're wrong if you speak of anything that I want of you; I want nothing but what she does. That's good enough for me!"—and Marian's tone struck her companion as dreadful. "If I don't believe in Merton Densher, I do at least in Mrs. Lowder."

Translation

Not like you, Kate; because I see things clearly, and you can't dismiss it with that attitude. The older sister paused, letting the younger's face reveal a hint of worry, despite her air of being better than everyone else. "I'm not talking about a man, except Aunt Maud's man, and not about money either, if you prefer, but about Aunt Maud's money. I'm only talking about you doing what she wants. You're mistaken if you think I want something from you personally; I only want what she wants. That's good enough for me!"—and Marian's voice sounded terrible to her sister. "Even if I don't trust Merton Densher, I certainly trust Mrs. Lowder."

"Your ideas are the more striking," Kate returned, "that they're the same as papa's. I had them from him, you may be interested to know—and with all the brilliancy you may imagine—yesterday."

Translation

"It's even more interesting," Kate replied, "that your ideas are exactly the same as my father's. I got them from him, just so you know—and he explained them with incredible flair—yesterday."

Marian clearly was interested to know. "He has been to see you?"

Translation

"Marian definitely wanted to know. 'Did he come see you?'"

"No, I went to him."

Translation

No, I went to see him.

"Really?" Marian wondered. "For what purpose?"

Translation

"Really?" Marian thought. "Why?"

"To tell him I'm ready to go to him."

Translation

Tell him I'm ready to come over.

Marian stared. "To leave Aunt Maud——?"

Translation

Marian stared, "Leave Aunt Maud?"

"For my father, yes."

Translation

"Yes, for my dad."

She had fairly flushed, poor Mrs. Condrip, with horror. "You're ready——?"

Translation

Mrs. Condrip, poor thing, was quite red in the face with shock. "You're ready...?"

"So I told him. I couldn't tell him less."

Translation

I told him everything.

"And, pray, could you tell him more?" Marian gasped in her distress. "What in the world is he to us? You bring out such a thing as that this way?"

Translation

"And please, could you tell him more?" Marian gasped, distressed. "What on earth does he have to do with us? Why would you bring something like that up now?"

They faced each other—the tears were in Marian's eyes. Kate watched them there a moment and then said: "I had thought it well over—over and over. But you needn't feel injured. I'm not going. He won't have me."

Translation

They stood facing each other, and Marian was crying. Kate watched her for a moment and then said, "I've thought about this a lot, over and over. But you don't need to feel bad. I'm not going. He doesn't want me."

Her companion still panted—it took time to subside. "Well, I wouldn't have you—wouldn't receive you at all, I can assure you—if he had made you any other answer. I do feel injured—at your having been willing. If you were to go to papa, my dear, you would have to stop coming to me." Marian put it thus, indefinably, as a picture of privation from which her companion might shrink. Such were the threats she could complacently make, could think herself masterful for making. "But if he won't take you," she continued, "he shows at least his sharpness."

Translation

Her friend was still catching her breath—it took a while to calm down. "Look, I wouldn't want you—I wouldn't accept you at all, I promise you—if he had responded any other way. I'm actually offended—that you were even considering it. If you went to your father, you wouldn't be able to see me anymore." Marian presented it this way, making it sound like a hardship she hoped her friend would avoid. These were the kinds of threats she was comfortable making, and she considered herself clever for doing so. "But if he refuses you," she continued, "at least it shows he's smart."

Marian had always her views of sharpness; she was, as her sister privately commented, great on it. But Kate had her refuge from irritation. "He won't take me," she simply repeated. "But he believes, like you, in Aunt Maud. He threatens me with his curse if I leave her."

Translation

Marian always had strong opinions; she, as her sister whispered to herself, was really good at being critical. But Kate had a way of coping with annoyance. "He won't marry me," she just kept saying. "But he believes, just like you, in Aunt Maud. He's threatening to curse me if I leave her."

"So you won't?" As the girl at first said nothing her companion caught at it. "You won't, of course? I see you won't. But I don't see why, nevertheless, I shouldn't insist to you once for all on the plain truth of the whole matter. The truth, my dear, of your duty. Do you ever think about that? It's the greatest duty of all."

Translation

"So you're not going to?" Her friend pounced on her silence. "You won't, right? I can see that. But I still think I should tell you the absolute truth about this whole thing, once and for all. The truth, darling, about your responsibility. Do you ever consider that? It's the most important thing you have to do."

"There you are again," Kate laughed. "Papa's also immense on my duty."

Translation

"There you are again," Kate laughed. "Papa's also really big on my responsibilities."

"Oh, I don't pretend to be immense, but I pretend to know more than you do of life; more even perhaps than papa." Marian seemed to see that personage at this moment, nevertheless, in the light of a kinder irony. "Poor old papa!"

Translation

"Oh, I'm not saying I'm some kind of expert, but I do pretend

that I know more about life than you do; maybe

even more than Dad." Marian seemed to picture

him right then, but with a kind of gentle teasing in her mind.

"Poor old Dad!"

She sighed it with as many condonations as her sister's ear had more than once caught in her "Dear old Aunt Maud!" These were things that made Kate, for the time, turn sharply away, and she gathered herself now to go. They were the note again of the abject; it was hard to say which of the persons in question had most shown how little they liked her. The younger woman proposed, at any rate, to let discussion rest, and she believed that, for herself, she had done so during the ten minutes that, thanks to her wish not to break off short, elapsed before she could gracefully withdraw. It then appeared, however, that Marian had been discussing still, and there was something that, at the last, Kate had to take up. "Whom do you mean by Aunt Maud's young man?"

Translation

She said it with all the pity her sister had often heard in her voice when she said, "Dear old Aunt Maud!" Those kinds of things always made Kate want to leave the conversation immediately, and she was ready to go now. It was that feeling of being pathetic again; it was hard to say who disliked her more in this situation. The younger woman decided to stop talking, and she thought she had, for the last ten minutes. That's how long it had taken her to politely excuse herself because she didn't want to abruptly end the conversation. But then it turned out Marian was still talking, and Kate had to say something. "Who are you talking about when you say 'Aunt Maud's young man'?"

"Whom should I mean but Lord Mark?"

Translation

Who else could I be talking about but Lord Mark?

"And where do you pick up such vulgar twaddle?" Kate demanded with her clear face. "How does such stuff, in this hole, get to you?"

Translation

"And where did you hear such trash?" Kate asked, her expression serious. "How does that kind of garbage even reach you in a place like this?"

She had no sooner spoken than she asked herself what had become of the grace to which she had sacrificed. Marian certainly did little to save it, and nothing indeed was so inconsequent as her ground of complaint. She desired her to "work" Lancaster Gate as she believed that scene of abundance could be worked; but she now didn't see why advantage should be taken of the bloated connection to put an affront on her own poor home. She appeared in fact for the moment to take the position that Kate kept her in her "hole" and then heartlessly reflected on her being in it. Yet she didn't explain how she had picked up the report on which her sister had challenged her—so that it was thus left to her sister to see in it, once more, a sign of the creeping curiosity of the Miss Condrips. They lived in a deeper hole than Marian, but they kept their ear to the ground, they spent their days in prowling, whereas Marian, in garments and shoes that seemed steadily to grow looser and larger, never prowled. There were times when Kate wondered if the Miss Condrips were offered her by fate as a warning for her own future—to be taken as showing her what she herself might become at forty if she let things too recklessly go. What was expected of her by others—and by so many of them—could, all the same, on occasion, present itself as beyond a joke; and this was just now the aspect it particularly wore. She was not only to quarrel with Merton Densher to oblige her five spectators—with the Miss Condrips there were five; she was to set forth in pursuit of Lord Mark on some preposterous theory of the premium attached to success. Mrs. Lowder's hand had attached it, and it figured at the end of the course as a bell that would ring, break out into public clamour, as soon as touched. Kate reflected sharply enough on the weak points of this fond fiction, with the result at last of a certain chill for her sister's confidence; though Mrs. Condrip still took refuge in the plea—which was after all the great point—that their aunt would be munificent when their aunt should be pleased. The exact identity of her candidate was a detail; what was of the essence was her conception of the kind of match it was open to her niece to make with her aid. Marian always spoke of marriages as "matches," but that was again a detail. Mrs. Lowder's "aid" meanwhile awaited them—if not to light the way to Lord Mark, then to somebody better. Marian would put up, in fine, with somebody better; she only wouldn't put up with somebody so much worse. Kate had, once more, to go through all this before a graceful issue was reached. It was reached by her paying with the sacrifice of Mr. Densher for her reduction of Lord Mark to the absurd. So they separated softly enough. She was to be let off hearing about Lord Mark so long as she made it good that she wasn't underhand about anybody else. She had denied everything and every one, she reflected as she went away—and that was a relief; but it also made rather a clean sweep of the future. The prospect put on a bareness that already gave her something in common with the Miss Condrips.

Translation

No sooner had she spoken than she questioned the sense of the sacrifice she had made. Marian certainly wasn't helping the situation, and her complaints were completely illogical. Marian wanted her to "work" Lancaster Gate, believing that area of wealth could be exploited, but now she didn't see why they should use that wealthy connection to insult her own modest home. In fact, she seemed to momentarily believe that Kate was keeping her down and then callously criticized her for it. Yet, she didn't explain how she'd gotten the information that her sister had confronted her with, so it fell to Kate to see it as another sign of the nosy Miss Condrips' creeping curiosity. They lived in a worse situation than Marian, but they kept their ears open and spent their days spying, while Marian, in clothes and shoes that seemed to get bigger and baggier, never bothered. Sometimes, Kate wondered if the Miss Condrips were a warning from fate about her own future—a picture of what she herself might become at forty if she let things get out of control. What was expected of her by others—and by so many of them—could, at times, become unbearable, and that was exactly how it felt now. Not only was she expected to break up with Merton Densher to please her five onlookers—with the Miss Condrips, there were five; she was also supposed to chase after Lord Mark based on some absurd theory about the advantages of success. Mrs. Lowder had created this idea, and it was now like a bell at the end of the race that would ring and cause a public outcry the moment it was touched. Kate considered the flaws in this ridiculous plan, which ultimately made her lose some faith in her sister's confidence. However, Mrs. Condrip took comfort in the fact that their aunt would be generous when she was pleased, which was the most important point. The exact person she chose didn't matter; the key was her idea of the kind of match her niece could make with her help. Marian always called marriages "matches," but that was just another detail. Mrs. Lowder's "help" was waiting for them—if not to lead them to Lord Mark, then to someone better. Marian would be okay with someone better; she just wouldn't accept someone worse. Kate had to go through all of this again before finding a graceful way out. She found it by sacrificing Mr. Densher to make Lord Mark seem ridiculous. So they parted quietly. She wouldn't have to hear about Lord Mark as long as she was honest about everyone else. She had denied everything and everyone, she reflected as she left—and that was a relief; but it also made the future feel very uncertain. The prospect became so bleak that she already felt like she had something in common with the Miss Condrips.

BOOK SECOND

### EXTRACTED HEADER: BOOK SECOND

Chapter III

Chapter Summary & Character Study
Summary

Merton Densher, who works nights at a newspaper, often spends time during the day in Kensington Gardens. He walks around without a clear destination, stopping, sitting, and walking again.

On several of these days, Kate Croy comes out of her aunt's house, crosses the road, and meets him in the Gardens. They then walk together or sit on chairs away from others.

They first met at a party in a gallery. After being introduced, they talked and looked at each other intently. Six months later, they saw each other on the Underground Railway. They exchanged looks, and Densher stayed on the train past his stop. He moved to sit next to her when a seat became available, and when she got off, he followed her. They walked together.

After this, Densher asked to visit her, and she agreed. He began visiting her at her aunt's, Mrs. Lowder's, house. Mrs. Lowder invited him to dinner and continued to receive his visits.

During one of their meetings in the park, Kate tells Densher she is sure her aunt will write to him and that he should be prepared. Densher asks if the aunt thinks he is not good enough for Kate, and Kate clarifies that the aunt thinks he is not good enough for her.

Kate then tells Densher about her family’s misfortunes, including her father's dishonor, the deaths of her two brothers, and her sister's unhappy marriage. She recounts how she learned of her father's disgrace as a girl without ever knowing the specific details. She tells Densher that she recently offered to go and live with her father to escape her aunt, but he refused her. Both her father and sister insist she must stay with her aunt to be of value to them.

Densher asks Kate to marry him the next day. She tells him to wait until after he has seen her aunt. He questions her, and she says he is also afraid of her aunt. She states that she will "try for everything" and not sacrifice him. She suggests they should wait and see what they can get from her aunt. Densher asks if his role is to win over the aunt. Kate impatiently tells him to "See her." He asks if he should grovel to her. In response, Kate tells him to do what he likes and walks away.

Character Study

Based on the text, here is a concise character study:

  • *Merton Densher** is presented as a young journalist whose professional life at night affords him an "appearance of leisure" by day. He is physically described as a "longish, leanish, fairish" Englishman who is difficult to classify by profession or social type; he appears "vague without looking weak—idle without looking empty." He is self-aware of his "strength merely for thought" and his perceived inability to become wealthy. His situation shifts from a routine of aimless-seeming meetings with Kate in Kensington Gardens to an impending confrontation. He is informed by Kate that her aunt will be contacting him, forcing his private relationship into a more formal and challenging context where his "want of means" will be scrutinized.
  • *Kate Croy** is presented as a sharp, self-aware, and strategic young woman burdened by a disgraced father and a needy family. She is described as "handsome, no doubt, but as hard, and... clever but as cold." She values Densher for his intellect—what she calls "the high, dim things... of the mind"—which her own life has lacked. Her situation is one of calculated risk: she lives under the watch of her powerful aunt while conducting a semi-public romance with Densher. The immediate shift is her decision to precipitate a confrontation between Densher and her aunt, moving their relationship from a private understanding to a direct negotiation with the powerful forces controlling her life.
  • *Mrs. Lowder (Aunt Maud)** is presented indirectly, through the perceptions of Kate and Densher, as a formidable and wealthy matriarch. She is described as "deep," manipulative, and powerful, a figure who has been "giving them rope." Densher sees her as "magnificently vulgar" and "dangerous," while Kate uses the metaphor of an "eagle with gilded claws." Her situation shifts from that of a passive but knowing observer to an active participant. Her impending decision to formally contact Densher signals the end of her observational period and the beginning of her direct intervention in the couple's affairs.

Merton Densher, who passed the best hours of each night at the office of his newspaper, had at times, during the day, to make up for it, a sense, or at least an appearance, of leisure, in accordance with which he was not infrequently to be met, in different parts of the town, at moments when men of business are hidden from the public eye. More than once, during the present winter's end, he had deviated, toward three o'clock, or toward four, into Kensington Gardens, where he might for a while, on each occasion, have been observed to demean himself as a person with nothing to do. He made his way indeed, for the most part, with a certain directness, over to the north side; but once that ground was reached his behaviour was noticeably wanting in point. He moved seemingly at random from alley to alley; he stopped for no reason and remained idly agaze; he sat down in a chair and then changed to a bench; after which he walked about again, only again to repeat both the vagueness and the vivacity. Distinctly, he was a man either with nothing at all to do or with ever so much to think about; and it was not to be denied that the impression he might often thus easily make had the effect of causing the burden of proof, in certain directions, to rest on him. It was a little the fault of his aspect, his personal marks, which made it almost impossible to name his profession.

Translation

Merton Densher, who spent most of his nights working at the newspaper office, sometimes had to compensate during the day. He gave the impression of having free time, and as a result, he was often seen in various parts of the city at times when businessmen were usually out of sight. Several times this winter, around three or four in the afternoon, he had gone to Kensington Gardens, where he could be observed acting like someone with nothing to do. He usually went directly to the north side of the park, but once he got there, his actions became aimless. He wandered from path to path, stopped for no particular reason, and stared blankly. He sat in a chair, then moved to a bench, after which he resumed wandering, repeating the same aimlessness and energy. Clearly, he was either completely idle or deeply lost in thought. There was no denying that the impression he often created this way made people question his purpose. This was partly due to his appearance and his distinctive features, which made it difficult to guess his profession.

He was a longish, leanish, fairish young Englishman, not unamenable, on certain sides, to classification—as for instance by being a gentleman, by being rather specifically one of the educated, one of the generally sound and generally pleasant; yet, though to that degree neither extraordinary nor abnormal, he would have failed to play straight into an observer's hands. He was young for the House of Commons, he was loose for the army. He was refined, as might have been said, for the city, and, quite apart from the cut of his cloth, he was sceptical, it might have been felt, for the church. On the other hand he was credulous for diplomacy, or perhaps even for science, while he was perhaps at the same time too much in his mere senses for poetry, and yet too little in them for art. You would have got fairly near him by making out in his eyes the potential recognition of ideas; but you would have quite fallen away again on the question of the ideas themselves. The difficulty with Densher was that he looked vague without looking weak—idle without looking empty. It was the accident, possibly, of his long legs, which were apt to stretch themselves; of his straight hair and his well-shaped head, never, the latter, neatly smooth, and apt, into the bargain, at the time of quite other calls upon it, to throw itself suddenly back and, supported behind by his uplifted arms and interlocked hands, place him for unconscionable periods in communion with the ceiling, the tree-tops, the sky. He was in short visibly absent-minded, irregularly clever, liable to drop what was near and to take up what was far; he was more a respecter, in general, than a follower of custom. He suggested above all, however, that wondrous state of youth in which the elements, the metals more or less precious, are so in fusion and fermentation that the question of the final stamp, the pressure that fixes the value, must wait for comparative coolness. And it was a mark of his interesting mixture that if he was irritable it was by a law of considerable subtlety—a law that, in intercourse with him, it might be of profit, though not easy, to master. One of the effects of it was that he had for you surprises of tolerance as well as of temper.

Translation

He was a somewhat tall, thin, and rather pale young English man, who was fairly easy to categorize based on certain characteristics. For example, he was a gentleman and clearly educated, with a generally good and agreeable personality. However, despite being relatively ordinary, he wouldn't fit neatly into any preconceived box. He was considered young for a member of Parliament and didn't seem suited for the military. He was too sophisticated, you might say, for a career in finance, and, regardless of his appearance, he was probably too skeptical for the church. Conversely, he seemed trusting enough for a career in diplomacy, or perhaps even in science. He also seemed too focused on physical sensation to appreciate poetry, but not quite focused enough to be truly passionate about art. You could come close to understanding him by noticing in his eyes a potential for understanding ideas, but you would be disappointed by his actual views on those ideas. The problem with Densher was that he appeared to be absent-minded without appearing weak, and lazy without appearing unintelligent. This might have been due to his long legs, which he often stretched out; his straight hair, and his well-shaped head, which never looked perfectly neat. He had a habit of throwing his head back, supported by his raised arms and clasped hands, and gazing at the ceiling, the trees, or the sky for long periods. In short, he was visibly distracted, irregularly intelligent, and tended to forget about what was close at hand while focusing on things that were far away. He generally respected tradition more than he followed it. Above all, he embodied that extraordinary state of youth, where the different aspects of a person, like valuable metals, are in a constant state of flux, and the final shaping, the thing that gives them their true value, has to wait until things settle down. And a sign of his fascinating complexity was that his irritability followed a subtle and complex pattern – a pattern that, in interacting with him, could be rewarding to understand, although not easy to do so. One result of this was that he could surprise you with his tolerance just as easily as he could with his temper.

He loitered, on the best of the relenting days, the several occasions we speak of, along the part of the Gardens nearest to Lancaster Gate, and when, always, in due time, Kate Croy came out of her aunt's house, crossed the road and arrived by the nearest entrance, there was a general publicity in the proceeding which made it slightly anomalous. If their meeting was to be bold and free it might have taken place within doors; if it was to be shy or secret it might have taken place almost anywhere better than under Mrs. Lowder's windows. They failed indeed to remain attached to that spot; they wandered and strolled, taking in the course of more than one of these interviews a considerable walk, or else picked out a couple of chairs under one of the great trees and sat as much apart—apart from every one else—as possible. But Kate had, each time, at first, the air of wishing to expose herself to pursuit and capture if those things were in question. She made the point that she was not underhand, any more than she was vulgar; that the Gardens were charming in themselves and this use of them a matter of taste; and that, if her aunt chose to glare at her from the drawing-room or to cause her to be tracked and overtaken, she could at least make it convenient that this should be easily done. The fact was that the relation between these young persons abounded in such oddities as were not inaptly symbolised by assignations that had a good deal more appearance than motive. Of the strength of the tie that held them we shall sufficiently take the measure; but it was meanwhile almost obvious that if the great possibility had come up for them it had done so, to an exceptional degree, under the protection of the famous law of contraries. Any deep harmony that might eventually govern them would not be the result of their having much in common—having anything, in fact, but their affection; and would really find its explanation in some sense, on the part of each, of being poor where the other was rich. It is nothing new indeed that generous young persons often admire most what nature hasn't given them—from which it would appear, after all, that our friends were both generous.

Translation

He lingered, on the most pleasant days, on the several occasions we're talking about, near the part of the Gardens closest to Lancaster Gate. Every time, at the right time, Kate Croy came out of her aunt's house, crossed the road, and entered through the nearest gate. This public display made their meetings seem a little strange. If they wanted to be open and bold, they could have met indoors. If they wanted to be discreet or secretive, they could have chosen almost any other place besides under Mrs. Lowder's windows.

They didn't actually stay in that spot. They wandered and strolled, sometimes taking a long walk during their conversations, or else they'd choose a couple of chairs under a large tree and sit as far away from everyone else as possible. But each time, Kate initially acted as if she wanted to be seen and caught, if that's what was going to happen. She made it clear that she wasn't being sneaky, any more than she was being common. She felt the Gardens were lovely, and using them was simply a matter of preference. And if her aunt wanted to glare at her from the drawing-room or have her followed and confronted, Kate was at least making it easy to do so.

The truth was that their relationship was full of oddities, perfectly represented by these meetings that seemed to be more about appearances than actual reasons for meeting. We'll understand the strength of their connection later, but for now, it was almost obvious that if a great opportunity had arisen for them, it was because of the famous principle of opposites attracting. Any deep compatibility that might eventually unite them wouldn't come from them having much in common—actually, they didn’t have anything in common except their affection. It would be explained by a sense, in each of them, of being lacking something that the other had. It's not unusual for generous young people to admire what they themselves don't possess, which suggests that, after all, our friends were both generous.

Merton Densher had repeatedly said to himself—and from far back—that he should be a fool not to marry a woman whose value would be in her differences; and Kate Croy, though without having quite so philosophised, had quickly recognised in the young man a precious unlikeness. He represented what her life had never given her and certainly, without some such aid as his, never would give her; all the high, dim things she lumped together as of the mind. It was on the side of the mind that Densher was rich for her, and mysterious and strong; and he had rendered her in especial the sovereign service of making that element real. She had had, all her days, to take it terribly on trust; no creature she had ever encountered having been able in any degree to testify for it directly. Vague rumours of its existence had made their precarious way to her; but nothing had, on the whole, struck her as more likely than that she should live and die without the chance to verify them. The chance had come—it was an extraordinary one—on the day she first met Densher; and it was to the girl's lasting honour that she knew on the spot what she was in the presence of. That occasion indeed, for everything that straightway flowered in it, would be worthy of high commemoration; Densher's perception went out to meet the young woman's and quite kept pace with her own recognition. Having so often concluded on the fact of his weakness, as he called it, for life—his strength merely for thought—life, he logically opined, was what he must somehow arrange to annex and possess. This was so much a necessity that thought by itself only went on in the void; it was from the immediate air of life that it must draw its breath. So the young man, ingenious but large, critical but ardent too, made out both his case and Kate Croy's. They had originally met before her mother's death—an occasion marked for her as the last pleasure permitted by the approach of that event; after which the dark months had interposed a screen and, for all Kate knew, made the end one with the beginning.

Translation

Merton Densher had told himself repeatedly, and for a long time, that he'd be foolish not to marry a woman whose worth lay in her unique qualities. Kate Croy, although she hadn't analyzed it quite so deeply, had quickly recognized a valuable difference in the young man. He represented what her life had never offered her and certainly never would, without his help—all the abstract, intellectual things she thought of as "the mind." It was in the realm of the mind that Densher was rich for her, mysterious and powerful; and he'd done her the enormous favor of making that aspect of life feel real. Throughout her life, she'd had to accept it entirely on faith; no one she'd ever met had been able to provide any concrete proof of it. She'd heard vague whispers of its existence, but it seemed highly likely that she would live and die without ever getting the chance to confirm them.

That chance had arrived—it was an extraordinary one—the day she first met Densher. And it was to her lasting credit that she understood immediately what she'd encountered. That meeting, in fact, deserved to be remembered for everything that quickly followed. Densher's understanding met hers, keeping pace with her own realization.

Having often concluded that his weakness lay in his appreciation for life—his strength was for thought—he logically decided that he needed to somehow acquire and experience life. It was such a necessity that thought alone felt empty; it needed the immediate influence of life to thrive. So the young man, intelligent but expansive, critical but also passionate, figured out what was in it for him, and for Kate Croy.

They had initially met before her mother died—an event that marked her last moments of happiness before her mother's death. After that, the dark months that followed created a barrier, and, for all Kate knew, made the end of it indistinguishable from the beginning.

The beginning—to which she often went back—had been a scene, for our young woman, of supreme brilliancy; a party given at a "gallery" hired by a hostess who fished with big nets. A Spanish dancer, understood to be at that moment the delight of the town, an American reciter, the joy of a kindred people, an Hungarian fiddler, the wonder of the world at large—in the name of these and other attractions the company in which, by a rare privilege, Kate found herself had been freely convoked. She lived under her mother's roof, as she considered, obscurely, and was acquainted with few persons who entertained on that scale; but she had had dealings with two or three connected, as appeared, with such—two or three through whom the stream of hospitality, filtered or diffused, could thus now and then spread to outlying receptacles. A good-natured lady in fine, a friend of her mother and a relative of the lady of the gallery, had offered to take her to the party in question and had there fortified her, further, with two or three of those introductions that, at large parties, lead to other things—that had at any rate, on this occasion, culminated for her in conversation with a tall, fair, slightly unbrushed and rather awkward, but on the whole not dreary, young man. The young man had affected her as detached, as—it was indeed what he called himself—awfully at sea, as much more distinct from what surrounded them than any one else appeared to be, and even as probably quite disposed to be making his escape when pulled up to be placed in relation with her. He gave her his word for it indeed, that same evening, that only their meeting had prevented his flight, but that now he saw how sorry he should have been to miss it. This point they had reached by midnight, and though in respect to such remarks everything was in the tone, the tone was by midnight there too. She had had originally her full apprehension of his coerced, certainly of his vague, condition—full apprehensions often being with her immediate; then she had had her equal consciousness that, within five minutes, something between them had—well, she couldn't call it anything but come. It was nothing, but it was somehow everything—it was that something for each of them had happened.

Translation

The beginning – which she often revisited in her mind – was a dazzling experience for our young woman. It was a party at a rented art gallery, thrown by a hostess known for her lavish events. There was a Spanish dancer, considered the city’s favorite at the time, an American comedian, a hit with his countrymen, and a Hungarian violinist, who was celebrated worldwide. These, along with other performers, were the main attractions, and the party was easily filled with guests, including Kate, who was fortunate enough to have received an invitation.

She lived at home with her mother, feeling rather unnoticed by society. She only knew a few people who were connected with lavish parties like this one, people who helped the hostess spread her invitations to a wider circle. A kind woman, a friend of her mother and related to the gallery hostess, had offered to take Kate to the party. She also arranged a few introductions that, at large gatherings, could lead to new acquaintances. And on this particular occasion, those introductions led to a conversation with a tall, fair-haired, slightly unkempt, and somewhat clumsy, but overall interesting, young man.

Kate found him intriguing. He seemed detached, as he himself put it, completely lost at sea. He seemed to stand apart from the party more than anyone else and possibly wanted to escape it entirely until he was introduced to her. He even admitted that very evening that their meeting had stopped him from leaving, and he was happy he hadn't missed it.

They’d reached this point by midnight, and while such declarations were delivered in the appropriate casual tone, that tone was also quite present and meaningful at that hour. She had initially understood his uneasy and, yes, vague state of mind, as her insights often came quickly. Then, within five minutes, she realized something significant had developed between them – well, she couldn't quite define it, but something had definitely happened. It was subtle, but in some ways, it was everything; a new connection had been forged for both of them.

They had found themselves looking at each other straight, and for a longer time on end than was usual even at parties in galleries; but that, after all, would have been a small affair, if there hadn't been something else with it. It wasn't, in a word, simply that their eyes had met; other conscious organs, faculties, feelers had met as well, and when Kate afterwards imaged to herself the sharp, deep fact she saw it, in the oddest way, as a particular performance. She had observed a ladder against a garden wall, and had trusted herself so to climb it as to be able to see over into the probable garden on the other side. On reaching the top she had found herself face to face with a gentleman engaged in a like calculation at the same moment, and the two inquirers had remained confronted on their ladders. The great point was that for the rest of that evening they had been perched—they had not climbed down; and indeed, during the time that followed, Kate at least had had the perched feeling—it was as if she were there aloft without a retreat. A simpler expression of all this is doubtless but that they had taken each other in with interest; and without a happy hazard six months later the incident would have closed in that account of it. The accident, meanwhile, had been as natural as anything in London ever is: Kate had one afternoon found herself opposite Mr. Densher on the Underground Railway.
