He knew, with the question put, that the hint was just what he had taken; knew that she had made him quickly forgive her the display of her power; knew that if he didn't take care he should understand her, and the strength of her purpose, to say nothing of that of her imagination, nothing of the length of her purse, only too well. Yet he pulled himself up with the thought, too, that he was not going to be afraid of understanding her; he was just going to understand and understand without detriment to the feeblest, even, of his passions. The play of one's mind let one in, at the best, dreadfully, in action, in the need of action, where simplicity was all; but when one couldn't prevent it the thing was to make it complete. There would never be mistakes but for the original fun of mistakes. What he must use his fatal intelligence for was to resist. Mrs. Lowder, meanwhile, might use it for whatever she liked.

Translation

His slow pacing back and forth seemed to measure the space for him. As he walked, the distance became like a desert representing his poverty. Seeing this emptiness, he couldn't pretend, any more than before, that the desert could be made habitable. Lancaster Gate looked wealthy—that was the only effect it had. It was impossible for his own situation to ever remotely resemble it. He observed and analyzed the things around him more critically, as has been hinted, and this only made him question his aesthetic reactions. He hadn't realized—despite Kate's repeated talk of her own differing tastes—that he would "mind" so much how an independent woman might decorate her house. It was the house itself that spoke to him, describing with remarkable breadth and freedom, the associations, concepts, ideals, and desires of its owner. He flattered himself that he had never seen anything so overwhelmingly ugly—in a way that was functional and ominously cruel. He was glad to have finally found this term for the entire character of the place; "cruel" somehow fit with the idea for an article—which immediately formed in his mind. He would write about the heavy horrors that could still thrive, that raised their heads defiantly, in an era that was so proud of how quickly it dismissed false idols. It would be funny if what he got from Mrs. Lowder was ultimately just a small amount of material for the article. Yet the big, dark truth was that even as he thought about quickly writing his column, he found it less easy to laugh at the heavy horrors than to be intimidated by them. He couldn't describe them all and dismiss them, calling them either Mid-Victorian or Early Victorian, not being sure they could be categorized under a single label. It was obvious, however, that they were grand and definitively British. They represented a certain standard and were full of luxurious materials—precious woods, metals, fabrics, and stones. He had never seen anything so fringed and scalloped, so buttoned and corded, so tightly drawn and thickly curled everywhere. He had never seen so much gold and glass, so much satin and plush, so much rosewood and marble and malachite. But above all, it was the solid forms, the excessive ornamentation, the misplaced cost, and the overall declaration of morality and wealth, a clear conscience, and a large bank account. These things represented a significant contrast to his own world of thought, of which, in their presence, he became hopelessly aware for the first time. They revealed it to him through their stark difference.

However, his meeting with Aunt Maud didn't go as expected. While Mrs. Lowder was undoubtedly passionate by nature, she neither threatened nor pleaded on this occasion. Her tools of aggression and defense were presumably close at hand, but she left them untouched and unmentioned. She was, in fact, so pleasant that he only realized afterward how cleverly she had acted. He also realized something else, which complicated things; he wouldn't have known what to call it if he hadn't called it her genuinely imprudent kindness. In other words, her pleasantness wasn't just a tactic—he wasn't dangerous enough for her to need to use tactics. He could see that it was the result of her actually liking him a little. From that moment, she herself became more interesting. And who knew what might happen if he started to like her? It was a risk he had to face, of course. She was fighting him, but only with one hand, using a few loose grains of stray powder. He realized after ten minutes, even without her explaining it, that if she had kept him waiting, it wasn't to hurt him. They had essentially agreed on her intentions. She wanted him to figure out for himself what she was going to say to him—not having announced it directly. She wanted him to understand it on the spot, as she cleverly believed he would. Her first question, on appearing, was practically whether he had understood her hint, and this question assumed so many things that it immediately made the discussion open and broad. He knew that the question implied that he had understood the hint, that she had made him forgive her the display of her power, and that if he wasn't careful, he would understand her, the strength of her purpose, not to mention her imagination and the size of her fortune, far too well. Yet he also reminded himself that he wasn't going to be afraid of understanding her. He was simply going to understand, without hindering even the weakest of his passions. Using one's mind can make a person disastrously complicated when it comes to action, and the need for simplicity. But when you can't prevent it, the thing to do is embrace it fully. Mistakes are the source of all the original fun. What he must use his dangerous intelligence for was to resist. Meanwhile, Mrs. Lowder could use her intelligence however she wanted.

It was after she had begun her statement of her own idea about Kate that he began, on his side, to reflect that—with her manner of offering it as really sufficient if he would take the trouble to embrace—it she couldn't half hate him. That was all, positively, she seemed to show herself for the time as attempting; clearly, if she did her intention justice, she would have nothing more disagreeable to do. "If I hadn't been ready to go very much further, you understand, I wouldn't have gone so far. I don't care what you repeat to her—the more you repeat to her, perhaps the better; and, at any rate, there's nothing she doesn't already know. I don't say it for her; I say it for you—when I want to reach my niece I know how to do it straight." So Aunt Maud delivered herself—as with homely benevolence, in the simplest, but the clearest terms; virtually conveying that, though a word to the wise was, doubtless, in spite of the advantage, not always enough, a word to the good could never fail to be. The sense our young man read into her words was that she liked him because he was good—was really, by her measure, good enough: good enough, that is, to give up her niece for her and go his way in peace. But was he good enough—by his own measure? He fairly wondered, while she more fully expressed herself, if it might be his doom to prove so. "She's the finest possible creature—of course you flatter yourself that you know it. But I know it, quite as well as you possibly can—by which I mean a good deal better yet; and the tune to which I'm ready to prove my faith compares favourably enough, I think, with anything you can do. I don't say it because she's my niece—that's nothing to me: I might have had fifty nieces, and I wouldn't have brought one of them to this place if I hadn't found her to my taste. I don't say I wouldn't have done something else, but I wouldn't have put up with her presence. Kate's presence, by good fortune, I marked early; Kate's presence—unluckily for you—is everything I could possibly wish; Kate's presence is, in short, as fine as you know, and I've been keeping it for the comfort of my declining years. I've watched it long; I've been saving it up and letting it, as you say of investments, appreciate, and you may judge whether, now it has begun to pay so, I'm likely to consent to treat for it with any but a high bidder. I can do the best with her, and I've my idea of the best."

Translation

After she'd started explaining her thoughts about Kate, he began to realize, on his end, that she seemed to think he should simply accept her ideas. She seemed to really hate him for it. That was all she appeared to be trying to do at the moment; clearly, if she truly got her way, she wouldn't have anything more unpleasant to deal with. "If I wasn't prepared to go pretty far, understand, I wouldn't have gone this far. I don't care what you tell her—the more you tell her, the better, perhaps; and at any rate, she already knows everything. I'm not saying this for her; I'm saying it for you—I know how to reach my niece directly when I want to."

That's how Aunt Maud spoke—with simple, clear kindness, as if to say that while a wise person might not always understand, a good person would never fail.

Our young man interpreted her words as meaning she liked him because he was a good person—good enough, in her opinion: good enough, that is, to give up her niece for her and let him go his own way. But was he good enough, according to his own standards? He wondered if he was destined to prove it, as she continued to speak. "She's the most wonderful person—of course you think you realize that. But I know it just as well as you do, maybe even better; and I'm as committed to proving my love as you are. I'm not saying this because she's my niece—that doesn't matter to me: I could have had fifty nieces, and I wouldn't have brought any of them here if I hadn't liked them. I won't say I wouldn't have done something else, but I wouldn't have put up with her being around. Luckily for me, I noticed Kate's presence early on; unfortunately for you, Kate's presence is everything I could want; Kate's presence is, in short, as amazing as you know, and I've been keeping it for myself. I've watched her for a long time; I've been saving her up, letting her, as you would say of investments, appreciate in value, and you can imagine whether I'm likely to let her go for anything less than a very high price now that she's finally started paying off. I can make the most of her, and I know what that is."

"Oh, I quite conceive," said Densher, "that your idea of the best isn't me."

Translation

"Oh, I totally get it," Densher said. "I understand that you don't think I'm the best choice."

It was an oddity of Mrs. Lowder's that her face in speech was like a lighted window at night, but that silence immediately drew the curtain. The occasion for reply allowed by her silence was never easy to take; yet she was still less easy to interrupt. The great glaze of her surface, at all events, gave her visitor no present help. "I didn't ask you to come to hear what it isn't—I asked you to come to hear what it is."

Translation

Mrs. Lowder had a peculiar habit: when she spoke, her face lit up like a window at night, but as soon as she stopped talking, it was as if a curtain had been drawn. It was always difficult to know when you could respond to her silence; however, it was even harder to interrupt her. Her blank expression didn't offer her visitor any clues. "I didn't invite you here to listen to what something isn't—I invited you to hear what it actually *is*."

"Of course," Densher laughed, "it's very great indeed."

Translation

"Absolutely," Densher laughed, "it's really wonderful."

His hostess went on as if his contribution to the subject were barely relevant. "I want to see her high, high up—high up and in the light."

Translation

His hostess continued speaking, acting like his input didn't matter. "I want to see her at the top, way up high—high up where she's visible."

"Ah, you naturally want to marry her to a duke, and are eager to smooth away any hitch."

Translation

Oh, of course, you want her to marry a duke, and you're anxious to fix any problems.

She gave him so, on this, the mere effect of the drawn blind that it quite forced him, at first, into the sense, possibly just, of having affected her as flippant, perhaps even as low. He had been looked at so, in blighted moments of presumptuous youth, by big cold public men, but never, so far as he could recall, by any private lady. More than anything yet it gave him the measure of his companion's subtlety, and thereby of Kate's possible career. "Don't be too impossible!"—he feared from his friend, for a moment, some such answer as that; and then felt, as she spoke otherwise, as if she were letting him off easily. "I want her to marry a great man." That was all; but, more and more, it was enough; and if it hadn't been her next words would have made it so. "And I think of her what I think. There you are."

Translation

Her reaction to this – just the way she looked at him, as if he were an annoying detail, like a drawn window shade – immediately made him worry that he’d seemed shallow or even crude. He'd been judged like that before, in humiliating moments of his youth, by important, distant men, but never, as far as he could remember, by a woman. More than anything, this gave him a clear understanding of her intelligence, and thus, of what Kate’s future might be.

“Don’t be ridiculous!” He almost expected her to say something like that. But when she spoke, it was as if she were letting him off easy. “I want her to marry a powerful man.” That was it, but it was enough. And if it hadn’t been, her next words would have sealed it. “And I think of her what I think. That’s all.”

They sat for a little face to face upon it, and he was conscious of something deeper still, of something she wished him to understand if he only would. To that extent she did appeal—appealed to the intelligence she desired to show she believed him to possess. He was meanwhile, at all events, not the man wholly to fail of comprehension. "Of course I'm aware how little I can answer to any fond, proud dream. You've a view—a magnificent one; into which I perfectly enter. I thoroughly understand what I'm not, and I'm much obliged to you for not reminding me of it in any rougher way." She said nothing—she kept that up; it might even have been to let him go further, if he was capable of it, in the way of poorness of spirit. It was one of those cases in which a man couldn't show, if he showed at all, save for poor; unless indeed he preferred to show for asinine. It was the plain truth: he was—on Mrs. Lowder's basis, the only one in question—a very small quantity, and he did know, damnably, what made quantities large. He desired to be perfectly simple; yet in the midst of that effort a deeper apprehension throbbed. Aunt Maud clearly conveyed it, though he couldn't later on have said how. "You don't really matter, I believe, so much as you think, and I'm not going to make you a martyr by banishing you. Your performances with Kate in the Park are ridiculous so far as they're meant as consideration for me; and I had much rather see you myself—since you're, in your way, my dear young man, delightful—and arrange with you, count with you, as I easily, as I perfectly should. Do you suppose me so stupid as to quarrel with you if it's not really necessary? It won't—it would be too absurd!—be necessary. I can bite your head off any day, any day I really open my mouth; and I'm dealing with you now, see—and successfully judge—without opening it. I do things handsomely all round—I place you in the presence of the plan with which, from the moment it's a case of taking you seriously, you're incompatible. Come then as near it as you like, walk all round it—don't be afraid you'll hurt it!—and live on with it before you."

Translation

They sat facing each other for a bit, and he sensed something more profound, something she wanted him to grasp if he would only try. In a way, she was appealing to him – appealing to the intelligence she wanted to believe he possessed. He, for his part, wasn't entirely oblivious. "Of course, I realize how little I can live up to any grand, idealistic expectations. You have a vision – a magnificent one; and I totally get it. I fully understand what I'm not, and I appreciate you not pointing it out in a harsher way." She didn't say anything, which she continued to do; maybe it was to let him say more, if he was capable of being even more humble. It was one of those situations where a person could only come across as insignificant, unless, of course, they wanted to appear foolish. The simple truth was that he – according to Mrs. Lowder’s standards, the only ones that mattered – was a nobody, and he knew, damn it, what made people important. He wanted to be completely straightforward, but even in trying to do so, a deeper concern resonated. Aunt Maud made it clear, although he couldn't later pinpoint how. "I don't believe you're as significant as you think, and I'm not going to punish you by sending you away. Your little escapades with Kate in the park are ridiculous if you think they're some kind of consideration for me; and I'd much rather see you myself – since, in your own way, you're, my dear young man, quite charming – and deal with you, involve you, as I easily and perfectly can. Do you think I'm so foolish as to argue with you if it's not absolutely necessary? It won't be – it would be too silly! – necessary. I can dismiss you anytime, the moment I actually speak my mind; and I'm dealing with you now, see? And I’m succeeding – without saying a word. I do things elegantly – I’m putting you right in front of the plan, with which, from the moment I start taking you seriously, you can’t possibly fit in. So come as close as you like, walk all around it – don't worry about damaging it! – and live with it now."

He afterwards felt that if she hadn't absolutely phrased all this it was because she so soon made him out as going with her far enough. He was so pleasantly affected by her asking no promise of him, her not proposing he should pay for her indulgence by his word of honour not to interfere, that he gave her a kind of general assurance of esteem. Immediately afterwards, then, he spoke of these things to Kate, and what then came back to him first of all was the way he had said to her—he mentioned it to the girl—very much as one of a pair of lovers says in a rupture by mutual consent: "I hope immensely, of course, that you'll always regard me as a friend." This had perhaps been going far—he submitted it all to Kate; but really there had been so much in it that it was to be looked at, as they might say, wholly in its own light. Other things than those we have presented had come up before the close of his scene with Aunt Maud, but this matter of her not treating him as a peril of the first order easily predominated. There was moreover plenty to talk about on the occasion of his subsequent passage with our young woman, it having been put to him abruptly, the night before, that he might give himself a lift and do his newspaper a service—so flatteringly was the case expressed—by going, for fifteen or twenty weeks, to America. The idea of a series of letters from the United States from the strictly social point of view had for some time been nursed in the inner sanctuary at whose door he sat, and the moment was now deemed happy for letting it loose. The imprisoned thought had, in a word, on the opening of the door, flown straight out into Densher's face, or perched at least on his shoulder, making him look up in surprise from his mere inky office-table. His account of the matter to Kate was that he couldn't refuse—not being in a position, as yet, to refuse anything; but that his being chosen for such an errand confounded his sense of proportion. He was definite as to his scarce knowing how to measure the honour, which struck him as equivocal; he had not quite supposed himself the man for the class of job. This confused consciousness, he intimated, he had promptly enough betrayed to his manager; with the effect, however, of seeing the question surprisingly clear up. What it came to was that the sort of twaddle that was not in his chords was, unexpectedly, just what they happened this time not to want. They wanted his letters, for queer reasons, about as good as he could let them come; he was to play his own little tune and not be afraid; that was the whole point.

Translation

Later, he realized that if she hadn't explicitly said everything, it was because she quickly understood he was willing to go along with her. He was so pleased that she didn't ask him for a commitment, that she didn't expect him to promise not to interfere with her, that he gave her a general expression of his respect. Immediately afterward, he discussed these things with Kate. What he remembered first was the way he’d spoken to the woman—he told Kate about it—much like one lover says to another at the end of a relationship, by mutual agreement: “I certainly hope you’ll always think of me as a friend.” Maybe that was too much, he told Kate, but really, it had to be seen on its own terms. Other things had been said before he left Aunt Maud, but the fact that she didn’t treat him as a serious threat was what stuck out most. Moreover, there was plenty to talk about when he later spoke with Kate, because he’d been asked suddenly the night before if he’d consider boosting his career and helping the newspaper—that's how flattering the offer was phrased—by going to America for fifteen or twenty weeks. The idea of a series of social letters from the United States had been brewing in secret for a while, and the time was now right to release it. The hidden thought, once the door opened, had, in other words, flown straight into Densher's face, or at least landed on his shoulder, making him look up in surprise from his desk. He told Kate that he couldn't refuse—he wasn't in a position to refuse anything at the moment—but being chosen for the job felt disproportionate. He was clear that he wasn’t sure how to measure the honor, which seemed uncertain. He hadn't quite thought of himself as the right person for the job. He said he'd been confused, which he'd made clear to his boss. But this had the surprising effect of making everything clearer. It turned out that the kind of superficial writing that he wasn't good at was, unexpectedly, exactly what they didn't want this time. They wanted his letters, for strange reasons, to be as good as he could make them; he should do his own thing and not worry; that was the whole point.

It would have been the whole, that is, had there not been a sharper one still in the circumstance that he was to start at once. His mission, as they called it at the office, would probably be over by the end of June, which was desirable; but to bring that about he must now not lose a week; his inquiries, he understood, were to cover the whole ground, and there were reasons of State—reasons operating at the seat of empire in Fleet Street—why the nail should be struck on the head. Densher made no secret to Kate of his having asked for a day to decide; and his account of that matter was that he felt he owed it to her to speak to her first. She assured him on this that nothing so much as that scruple had yet shown her how they were bound together; she was clearly proud of his letting a thing of such importance depend on her; but she was clearer still as to his instant duty. She rejoiced in his prospect and urged him to his task; she should miss him intensely—of course she should miss him; but she made so little of it that she spoke with jubilation of what he would see and would do. She made so much of this last quantity that he laughed at her innocence, though also with scarce the heart to give her the real size of his drop in the daily bucket. He was struck at the same time with her happy grasp of what had really occurred in Fleet Street—all the more that it was his own final reading. He was to pull the subject up—that was just what they wanted; and it would take more than all the United States together, visit them each as he might, to let him down. It was just because he didn't nose about and wasn't the usual gossipmonger that they had picked him out; it was a branch of their correspondence with which they evidently wished a new tone associated, such a tone as, from now on, it would have always to take from his example.

Translation

He would have accepted the entire offer, that is, if it hadn't been made even more pressing by the fact that he had to leave immediately. His assignment, as they called it at the office, would likely be finished by the end of June, which was good; but to make that happen, he couldn't waste a week. He understood that his investigation needed to be comprehensive, and there were serious matters – matters concerning the highest levels of power in Fleet Street – that required a definitive answer. Densher told Kate without hesitation that he'd requested a day to think it over, and his reason was that he felt he had to discuss it with her first. She assured him that this hesitation showed her how strong their relationship was; she was clearly pleased that he'd let something so important depend on her, but she was even clearer about his immediate responsibility. She was happy for him and encouraged him to take on the task; she would miss him terribly – of course she would; but she downplayed it so much that she spoke enthusiastically about what he would see and do. She focused so much on the good aspects of it that he laughed at her naivete, though he was reluctant to tell her the full extent of his own disappointment at leaving. He was also impressed by her understanding of what had really happened in Fleet Street – especially since it matched his own understanding. He was supposed to dig up the story – that was precisely what they wanted; and it would take more than all the United States combined, even if he visited every one of them, to let him off the hook. They'd chosen him precisely because he wasn't nosy and wasn't a typical gossip; this was a part of their communication that they clearly wanted to be handled with a fresh approach, an approach that, from now on, would always be modeled on his example.

"How you ought indeed, when you understand so well, to be a journalist's wife!" Densher exclaimed in admiration, even while she struck him as fairly hurrying him off.

Translation

"You really should be, given how well you understand things, a journalist's wife!" Densher said admiringly, even though she seemed to be subtly pushing him away.

But she was almost impatient of the praise. "What do you expect one not to understand when one cares for you?"

Translation

But she was almost annoyed by the compliments.

"What else would I do when I care about you?"

"Ah then, I'll put it otherwise and say 'How much you care for me!'"

Translation

"Wow, so you do care about me!"

"Yes," she assented; "it fairly redeems my stupidity. I shall, with a chance to show it," she added, "have some imagination for you."

Translation

"Yes," she agreed, "it makes up for my being so dense. If I get the chance to show it," she added, "I'll be imaginative for you."

She spoke of the future this time as so little contingent, that he felt a queerness of conscience in making her the report that he presently arrived at on what had passed for him with the real arbiter of their destiny. The way for that had been blocked a little by his news from Fleet Street; but in the crucible of their happy discussion this element soon melted into the other, and in the mixture that ensued the parts were not to be distinguished. The young man moreover, before taking his leave, was to see why Kate had just spoken of the future as if they now really possessed it, and was to come to the vision by a devious way that deepened the final cheer. Their faces were turned to the illumined quarter as soon as he had answered her question in respect to the appearance of their being able to play a waiting game with success. It was for the possibility of that appearance that she had, a few days before, so earnestly pressed him to see her aunt; and if after his hour with that lady it had not struck Densher that he had seen her to the happiest purpose the poor facts flushed with a better meaning as Kate, one by one, took them up.

Translation

This time, she talked about the future as if it was barely dependent on anything else. He felt a pang of guilt about giving her the news he'd just gotten regarding what had happened to him with the person truly in charge of their fate. His news from Fleet Street had initially created a small obstacle. But during their joyful conversation, that obstacle quickly dissolved into everything else, and the different parts of the situation were indistinguishable in the end. Before leaving, the young man also wanted to understand why Kate had just talked about the future as if they already controlled it. He was going to reach this understanding through a roundabout way that ultimately increased their happiness. They both looked towards the bright future as soon as he had answered her question about whether they could successfully wait things out. She had strongly urged him to visit her aunt a few days earlier because of the possibility of creating that impression. And if Densher hadn't realized after meeting her aunt that he'd had the best possible outcome, the discouraging facts suddenly took on a more positive meaning as Kate addressed them one by one.

"If she consents to your coming, why isn't that everything?"

Translation

If she says it's okay for you to come, isn't that all that matters?

"It is everything; everything she thinks it. It's the probability—I mean as Mrs. Lowder measures probability—that I may be prevented from becoming a complication for her by some arrangement, any arrangement, through which you shall see me often and easily. She's sure of my want of money, and that gives her time. She believes in my having a certain amount of delicacy, in my wishing to better my state before I put the pistol to your head in respect to sharing it. The time that will take figures for her as the time that will help her if she doesn't spoil her chance by treating me badly. She doesn't at all wish moreover," Densher went on, "to treat me badly, for I believe, upon my honour, funny as it may sound to you, that she personally rather likes me, and that if you weren't in question I might almost become her pet young man. She doesn't disparage intellect and culture—quite the contrary; she wants them to adorn her board and be named in her programme; and I'm sure it has sometimes cost her a real pang that I should be so desirable, at once, and so impossible." He paused a moment, and his companion then saw that a strange smile was in his face—a smile as strange even as the adjunct, in her own, of this informing vision. "I quite suspect her of believing that, if the truth were known, she likes me literally better than—deep down—you yourself do: wherefore she does me the honour to think that I may be safely left to kill my own cause. There, as I say, comes in her margin. I'm not the sort of stuff of romance that wears, that washes, that survives use, that resists familiarity. Once in any degree admit that, and your pride and prejudice will take care of the rest! the pride fed full, meanwhile, by the system she means to practise with you, and the prejudice excited by the comparison she'll enable you to make, from which I shall come off badly. She likes me, but she'll never like me so much as when she succeeded a little better in making me look wretched. For then you'll like me less."

Translation

It's all about what she thinks it is. It's the likelihood – the way Mrs. Lowder sees it – that she can stop me from becoming a problem for her. She could use any plan, as long as it ensures you see me frequently and easily. She's certain I'm broke, and that buys her time. She thinks I have a certain level of decency and that I’ll want to improve my situation before I pressure you into sharing your money. That amount of time is helpful to her, if she doesn't ruin her chances by treating me poorly. Also, Densher continued, "she really doesn't want to treat me badly. I honestly believe, and it may sound strange, that she actually likes me, and if you weren’t involved, I might almost become her favorite young man. She values intelligence and culture – quite the opposite; she wants them around her and mentioned in her social circle. I'm sure it's sometimes been a real problem for her that I'm so appealing, yet so unavailable." He paused, and his companion noticed a peculiar smile on his face, as unusual as the revelation he was offering her. "I suspect she actually believes that, if the truth were known, she likes me, deep down, more than *you* do. So, she's flattering me by thinking I can be trusted to ruin my own chances. That's where her wiggle room is. I'm not the kind of romantic figure that lasts, that withstands the test of time, that remains desirable after familiarity. Once you admit that, your pride and prejudice will do the rest! Her strategy will feed your pride, and she’ll encourage you to compare us, and I'll come out looking bad. She likes me, but she'll like me most when she succeeds in making me look miserable. Because then, you'll like me less."

Kate showed for this evocation a due interest, but no alarm; and it was a little as if to pay his tender cynicism back in kind that she after an instant replied: "I see, I see; what an immense affair she must think me! One was aware, but you deepen the impression."

Translation

Kate showed appropriate interest in this discussion, but wasn't worried. As if to playfully return his gentle cynicism, she replied after a moment: "I understand. She must think I'm incredibly important! I knew, but you're really emphasizing the point."

"I think you'll make no mistake," said Densher, "in letting it go as deep as it will."

Translation

"I think you should fully commit to this," said Densher.

He had given her indeed, she made no scruple of showing, plenty to consider. "Her facing the music, her making you boldly as welcome as you say—that's an awfully big theory, you know, and worthy of all the other big things that, in one's acquaintance with people, give her a place so apart."

Translation

She definitely had a lot to think about, and she didn't hesitate to show it. "The fact that she's facing the consequences, that she's making you feel so welcome, just like you said – that's a pretty significant idea, you know, and fits right in with all the other remarkable things that make her such a unique person in my experience."

"Oh, she's grand," the young man conceded; "she's on the scale, altogether, of the car of Juggernaut which was a kind of image that came to me yesterday while I waited for her at Lancaster Gate. The things in your drawing-room there were like the forms of the strange idols, the mystic excrescences, with which one may suppose the front of the car to bristle."

Translation

"Oh, she's amazing," the young man admitted. "She's like, really overwhelming, like that giant cart of Juggernaut – that image just popped into my head yesterday when I was waiting for her at Lancaster Gate. The stuff in your living room reminds me of the weird, mystical decorations you'd find on the front of that cart."

"Yes, aren't they?" the girl returned; and they had, over all that aspect of their wonderful lady, one of those deep and free interchanges that made everything but confidence a false note for them. There were complications, there were questions; but they were so much more together than they were anything else. Kate uttered for a while no word of refutation of Aunt Maud's "big" diplomacy, and they left it there, as they would have left any other fine product, for a monument to her powers. But, Densher related further, he had had in other respects too the car of Juggernaut to face; he omitted nothing from his account of his visit, least of all the way Aunt Maud had frankly at last—though indeed only under artful pressure—fallen foul of his very type, his want of the right marks, his foreign accidents, his queer antecedents. She had told him he was but half a Briton, which, he granted Kate, would have been dreadful if he hadn't so let himself in for it.

Translation

"Yes, they are," the girl replied. They shared a connection, looking at their amazing friend, that was so open and trusting that anything less felt wrong. There were issues and questions, but they were much more in sync with each other than anything else. Kate didn't argue against Aunt Maud's "grand" scheme, and they left it at that, admiring it as a testament to her abilities. But, Densher continued, he'd also faced a major obstacle. He described his visit in detail, especially how Aunt Maud had finally and honestly—though only after some clever prodding—criticized him, his lack of the right social standing, his foreign background, and his past. She’d told him he wasn't fully British, which, he admitted to Kate, would have been terrible if he hadn't brought it on himself.

"I was really curious, you see," he explained, "to find out from her what sort of queer creature, what sort of social anomaly, in the light of such conventions as hers, such an education as mine makes one pass for."

Translation

"I was really interested, you know," he said,

"to hear from her what kind of weird person,

what kind of social misfit, someone like me seems to be

in her eyes, considering her values and upbringing and mine."

Kate said nothing for a little; but then, "Why should you care?" she asked.

Translation

Kate was quiet for a moment. Then, she asked, "Why would you even care?"

"Oh," he laughed, "I like her so much; and then, for a man of my trade, her views, her spirit, are essentially a thing to get hold of; they belong to the great public mind that we meet at every turn and that we must keep setting up 'codes' with. Besides," he added, "I want to please her personally."

Translation

"Oh," he chuckled, "I really like her. And, for someone in my line of work, her opinions and her attitude are exactly what I need to understand and use. They represent the popular ideas that everyone's talking about, the ones we have to keep shaping into rules and guidelines. Plus," he added, "I want to make her happy."

"Ah, yes, we must please her personally!" his companion echoed; and the words may represent all their definite recognition, at the time, of Densher's politic gain. They had in fact between this and his start for New York many matters to handle, and the question he now touched upon came up for Kate above all. She looked at him as if he had really told her aunt more of his immediate personal story than he had ever told herself. That, if it were so, was an accident, and it put him, for half an hour, on as much of the picture of his early years abroad, his migratory parents, his Swiss schools, his German university, as she had easy attention for. A man, he intimated, a man of their world, would have spotted him straight as to many of these points; a man of their world, so far as they had a world, would have been through the English mill. But it was none the less charming to make his confession to a woman; women had, in fact, for such differences, so much more imagination. Kate showed at present all his case could require; when she had had it from beginning to end she declared that she now made out more than ever yet of what she loved him for. She had herself, as a child, lived with some continuity in the world across the Channel, coming home again still a child; and had participated after that, in her teens, in her mother's brief but repeated retreats to Dresden, to Florence, to Biarritz, weak and expensive attempts at economy from which there stuck to her—though in general coldly expressed, through the instinctive avoidance of cheap raptures—the religion of foreign things. When it was revealed to her how many more foreign things were in Merton Densher than he had hitherto taken the trouble to catalogue, she almost faced him as if he were a map of the continent or a handsome present of a delightful new "Murray." He hadn't meant to swagger, he had rather meant to plead, though with Mrs. Lowder he had meant also a little to explain. His father had been, in strange countries, in twenty settlements of the English, British chaplain, resident or occasional, and had had for years the unusual luck of never wanting a billet. His career abroad had therefore been unbroken, and, as his stipend had never been great, he had educated his children at the smallest cost, in the schools nearest; which was also a saving of railway fares. Densher's mother, it further appeared, had practised on her side a distinguished industry, to the success of which—so far as success ever crowned it—this period of exile had much contributed: she copied, patient lady, famous pictures in great museums, having begun with a happy natural gift and taking in betimes the scale of her opportunity. Copyists abroad of course swarmed, but Mrs. Densher had had a sense and a hand of her own, had arrived at a perfection that persuaded, that even deceived, and that made the disposal of her work blissfully usual. Her son, who had lost her, held her image sacred, and the effect of his telling Kate all about her, as well as about other matters until then mixed and dim, was to render his history rich, his sources full, his outline anything but common. He had come round, he had come back, he insisted abundantly, to being a Briton: his Cambridge years, his happy connection, as it had proved, with his father's college, amply certified to that, to say nothing of his subsequent plunge into London, which filled up the measure. But brave enough though his descent to English earth, he had passed, by the way, through zones of air that had left their ruffle on his wings, had been exposed to initiations ineffaceable. Something had happened to him that could never be undone.

Translation

"Oh yes, we definitely need to keep her happy!" his friend agreed. Those words probably summarized their immediate understanding of the strategic advantage Densher had gained. They had a lot to deal with before he left for New York, and the situation he was discussing now was primarily relevant to Kate. She looked at him as if he'd revealed more about his personal history to her aunt than he'd ever shared with her. If that was the case, it was unintentional, and it led him to describe his early years abroad—his nomadic parents, his Swiss schools, his German university—for about half an hour, to the extent that she was interested. He suggested that someone from their social circle would immediately recognize those aspects of his background, someone who had gone through the established English education system. However, it was still enjoyable to confide in a woman; women, in his experience, had a greater capacity for understanding those kinds of differences. Kate showed the appropriate level of interest, and after hearing the whole story, she said she now understood even more why she loved him. She herself had spent time living in Europe as a child, returning to England while still young. Later, during her teens, she had joined her mother on several short trips to places like Dresden, Florence, and Biarritz. These were financially limited attempts at travel, but they instilled in her—although she generally avoided expressing excessive enthusiasm—a fondness for foreign cultures. When she realized how many more foreign influences there were in Merton Densher than he'd previously mentioned, she almost looked at him as if he were a map of Europe or an appealing new "Murray's Guidebook." He hadn't intended to boast; he'd actually wanted to explain himself, though he had also wanted to provide some context for Mrs. Lowder. His father had been a British chaplain in various foreign locations, both as a resident and on occasion, and had been fortunate enough to have a consistent income for many years. His career abroad was therefore continuous, and since his salary wasn't high, he educated his children in the most affordable schools nearby, which also saved money on transportation. Densher's mother had also been remarkably industrious. Her success—to the extent that she achieved it—was largely due to this period of living abroad. She was a patient woman who copied famous paintings in major museums, using a natural talent and recognizing the opportunities available to her. Copyists were common abroad, but Mrs. Densher had skill and artistry, achieving a level of perfection that was convincing, even deceptive, and made selling her work easy. His son, who had lost her, cherished her memory, and the effect of telling Kate all this about her, as well as about other things previously vague and unclear, was to make his background richer, his origins more interesting, and his story anything but ordinary. He had become a true Briton again, he insisted repeatedly; his time at Cambridge, and his fortunate association with his father's college, proved that, not to mention his subsequent immersion in London life, which completed the process. Although he was fully English now, he had also experienced influences that left their mark on him, exposures that would never be erased. Something had happened to him that could never be undone.

When Kate Croy said to him as much he besought her not to insist, declaring that this indeed was what was too much the matter with him, that he had been but too probably spoiled for native, for insular use. On which, not unnaturally, she insisted the more, assuring him, without mitigation, that if he was complicated and brilliant she wouldn't for the world have had him any thing less; so that he was reduced in the end to accusing her of putting the dreadful truth to him in the hollow guise of flattery. She was making out how abnormal he was in order that she might eventually find him impossible; and, as she could fully make it out but with his aid, she had to bribe him by feigned delight to help her. If her last word for him, in the connection, was that the way he saw himself was just a precious proof the more of his having tasted of the tree and being thereby prepared to assist her to eat, this gives the happy tone of their whole talk, the measure of the flight of time in the near presence of his settled departure. Kate showed, however, that she was to be more literally taken when she spoke of the relief Aunt Maud would draw from the prospect of his absence.

Translation

When Kate Croy told him this, he begged her to drop it, saying that was exactly the problem: he was probably too damaged to fit in, to be a regular guy. Naturally, she pushed harder, telling him flatly that she wouldn't want him any other way if he wasn't complex and fascinating. He ended up accusing her of using flattery to tell him the awful truth. She was painting him as abnormal so she could eventually reject him. Since she couldn't fully understand it without his help, she was trying to trick him into helping by pretending to be pleased. When she finally said that his self-awareness was just proof that he'd "tasted of the tree" and was ready to help her "eat," that perfectly captured the lighthearted tone of their entire conversation, and showed how quickly time was passing before he left. However, Kate also proved she was being serious when she mentioned how relieved Aunt Maud would be when he was gone.

"Yet one can scarcely see why," he replied, "when she fears me so little."

Translation

"But I don't really understand," he responded, "since she's not afraid of me at all."

His friend weighed his objection. "Your idea is that she likes you so much that she'll even go so far as to regret losing you?"

Translation

His friend considered his point. "So, you're saying she likes you so much that she'd actually miss you if you were gone?"

Well, he saw it in their constant comprehensive way. "Since what she builds on is the gradual process of your alienation, she may take the view that the process constantly requires me. Mustn't I be there to keep it going? It's in my exile that it may languish."

Translation

He understood it from the way they always acted. "Because what she's building on is your slow separation from everything, she might think she needs me all the time. Doesn't she need me to keep it going? It could fall apart if I'm not pushed away."

He went on with that fantasy, but at this point Kate ceased to attend. He saw after a little that she had been following some thought of her own, and he had been feeling the growth of something determinant even through the extravagance of much of the pleasantry, the warm, transparent irony, into which their livelier intimacy kept plunging like a confident swimmer. Suddenly she said to him with extraordinary beauty: "I engage myself to you for ever."

Translation

He kept going with his made-up story, but Kate stopped paying attention. He realized after a bit that she was lost in her own thoughts, and he'd been sensing something real developing, despite all the joking around, the warm, clear teasing they used to do, like a confident swimmer diving into water. Suddenly, she said to him, looking absolutely beautiful, "I promise to be with you forever."

The beauty was in everything, and he could have separated nothing—couldn't have thought of her face as distinct from the whole joy. Yet her face had a new light. "And I pledge you—I call God to witness!—every spark of my faith; I give you every drop of my life." That was all, for the moment, but it was enough, and it was almost as quiet as if it were nothing. They were in the open air, in an alley of the Gardens; the great space, which seemed to arch just then higher and spread wider for them, threw them back into deep concentration. They moved by a common instinct to a spot, within sight, that struck them as fairly sequestered, and there, before their time together was spent, they had extorted from concentration every advance it could make them. They had exchanged vows and tokens, sealed their rich compact, solemnized, so far as breathed words and murmured sounds and lighted eyes and clasped hands could do it, their agreement to belong only, and to belong tremendously, to each other. They were to leave the place accordingly an affianced couple; but before they left it other things still had passed. Densher had declared his horror of bringing to a premature end her happy relation with her aunt; and they had worked round together to a high level of wisdom and patience. Kate's free profession was that she wished not to deprive him of Mrs. Lowder's countenance, which, in the long run, she was convinced he would continue to enjoy; and as, by a blessed turn, Aunt Maud had demanded of him no promise that would tie his hands, they should be able to cultivate their destiny in their own way and yet remain loyal. One difficulty alone stood out, which Densher named.

Translation

Everything was beautiful, and he couldn't separate anything—he couldn't think of her face as separate from all the happiness. Still, her face seemed to glow with a new light. "And I promise you—I call on God to witness it!—every bit of my faith; I give you my whole life." That was all, for now, but it was enough, and it was almost as silent as if nothing had been said. They were outside, in a path in the Gardens; the vast space seemed to arch higher and spread wider just for them, drawing them into deep focus. They were drawn together by a shared feeling to a spot they thought was secluded, and there, before their time together was up, they had squeezed every benefit possible out of their focused conversation. They had exchanged promises and gifts, sealed their agreement, and declared, with their words and whispers and shining eyes and clasped hands, that they were committed to belonging to each other completely. They were to leave the Gardens as an engaged couple; but before they left, other things had happened. Densher had said he didn't want to ruin her happy relationship with her aunt, and they had worked things out together with great understanding and patience. Kate freely stated that she didn't want to deprive him of Mrs. Lowder's support, which she was sure he would continue to have; and since, fortunately, Aunt Maud hadn't made him promise anything that would limit him, they could pursue their future as they pleased while still being loyal. Only one problem remained, which Densher pointed out.

"Of course it will never do—we must remember that—from the moment you allow her to found hopes of you for any one else in particular. So long as her view is content to remain as general as at present appears, I don't see that we deceive her. At a given moment, you see, she must be undeceived: the only thing therefore is to be ready for the moment and to face it. Only, after all, in that case," the young man observed, "one doesn't quite make out what we shall have got from her."

Translation

"Of course, this won't work – we have to keep in mind that the minute you let her start hoping for a relationship with you, specifically, it's a problem. As long as she's happy keeping things vague, the way they seem to be now, I don't think we're really lying to her. Eventually, she's going to need to know the truth. The only thing to do is be prepared for that moment and deal with it. But," the young man added, "when that happens, I'm not sure what we'll have gotten out of it."

"What she'll have got from us?" Kate inquired with a smile. "What she'll have got from us," the girl went on, "is her own affair—it's for her to measure. I asked her for nothing," she added; "I never put myself upon her. She must take her risks, and she surely understands them. What we shall have got from her is what we've already spoken of," Kate further explained; "it's that we shall have gained time. And so, for that matter, will she."

Translation

"What did she get from us?" Kate asked with a smile. "What she got from us is her own business—she has to decide that. I didn't ask her for anything," she added; "I never imposed on her. She needs to understand the consequences of her actions, and I'm sure she does. What *we* will get from her is what we already discussed," Kate explained. "It's that we will have gained time. And actually, so will she."

Densher gazed a little at all this clearness; his gaze was not at the present hour into romantic obscurity. "Yes; no doubt, in our particular situation, time's everything. And then there's the joy of it."

Translation

Densher looked at the situation clearly; he wasn't trying to romanticize anything. "Yeah, definitely, in our situation, time is crucial. And also, there's the excitement of it all."

She hesitated. "Of our secret?"

Translation

She paused. "About our secret?"

"Not so much perhaps of our secret in itself, but of what's represented and, as we must somehow feel, protected and made deeper and closer by it." And his fine face, relaxed into happiness, covered her with all his meaning. "Our being as we are."

Translation

Perhaps not the secret itself, but what it symbolizes. What it protects, deepens, and brings us closer to.

He looked at her, his face relaxed and happy, and communicated everything he felt. "Our very existence."

It was as if for a moment she let the meaning sink into her. "So gone?"

Translation

She seemed to pause, letting the information really hit her. "So, he's really gone?"

"So gone. So extremely gone. However," he smiled, "we shall go a good deal further." Her answer to which was only the softness of her silence—a silence that looked out for them both at the far reach of their prospect. This was immense, and they thus took final possession of it. They were practically united and they were splendidly strong; but there were other things—things they were precisely strong enough to be able successfully to count with and safely to allow for; in consequence of which they would, for the present, subject to some better reason, keep their understanding to themselves. It was not indeed, however, till after one more observation of Densher's that they felt the question completely straightened out. "The only thing of course is that she may any day absolutely put it to you."

Translation

"It's over. Absolutely over," he smiled. "But," he continued, "we're going to get even further." Her response was just quiet – a silence that acknowledged their shared future. It was a vast future, and they were finally embracing it. They were essentially together and incredibly strong, but there were other factors – things they were just strong enough to consider and manage. Therefore, for now, unless there was a better reason, they would keep their agreement private. It wasn't until Densher made another comment that they felt they had the situation completely figured out. "The only real issue, of course, is that she might ask you directly any day now."

Kate considered. "Ask me where, on my honour, we are? She may, naturally; but I doubt if in fact she will. While you're away she'll make the most of it. She'll leave me alone."

Translation

Kate thought for a moment. "Ask me where we are, I swear. She probably will, but I don't think she actually will. While you're gone, she'll take full advantage. She'll leave me alone."

"But there'll be my letters."

Translation

But my letters will still be around.

The girl faced his letters. "Very, very many?"

Translation

The girl looked at his letters. "A lot, like, a *lot*?"

"Very, very, very many—more than ever; and you know what that is! And then," Densher added, "there'll be yours."

Translation

A huge, gigantic number - more than we've ever seen; you know what I mean! And then, Densher added, there'll be yours.

"Oh, I shan't leave mine on the hall-table. I shall post them myself."

Translation

Oh, I won't leave mine on the hall table. I'll mail them myself.

He looked at her a moment. "Do you think then I had best address you elsewhere?" After which, before she could quite answer, he added with some emphasis: "I'd rather not, you know. It's straighter."

Translation

He looked at her for a second. "So, do you think I should talk to you somewhere else?" Then, before she could reply, he added, stressing the point, "I'd really rather not. It's more straightforward this way."

She might again have just waited. "Of course it's straighter. Don't be afraid I shan't be straight. Address me," she continued, "where you like. I shall be proud enough of its being known you write to me."

Translation

She could have just waited again. "Of course

it's more direct. Don't worry, I won't be formal.

Write to me," she continued, "however you want. I

would be proud if people knew you were writing

to me."

He turned it over for the last clearness. "Even at the risk of its really bringing down the inquisition?"

Translation

He examined it one last time to be absolutely sure. "Even if it means causing real trouble with the authorities?"

Well, the last clearness now filled her. "I'm not afraid of the inquisition. If she asks if there's anything definite between us, I know perfectly what I shall say."

Translation

Okay, she finally understood everything clearly. "I'm not scared of the investigation. If she asks if there's anything serious between us, I know exactly what I'll say."

"That I am, of course, 'gone' for you?"

Translation

Are you saying I'm "out of the picture" for you now?

"That I love you as I shall never in my life love any one else, and that she can make what she likes of that." She said it out so splendidly that it was like a new profession of faith, the fulness of a tide breaking through; and the effect of that, in turn, was to make her companion meet her with such eyes that she had time again before he could otherwise speak. "Besides, she's just as likely to ask you."

Translation

I love you more than I'll ever love anyone, and you can take that however you want. She declared this with such passion; it was like a new belief being shouted out, like a rising tide breaking free. The way she said it made her friend look at her so intensely that she had a moment to react before he could speak. "Besides, she’s probably going to ask you, too."

"Not while I'm away."

Translation

"Not while I'm gone."

"Then when you come back."

Translation

And then, when you return.

"Well then," said Densher, "we shall have had our particular joy. But what I feel is," he candidly added, "that, by an idea of her own, her superior policy, she won't ask me. She'll let me off. I shan't have to lie to her."

Translation

"Okay," Densher said, "we'll have experienced our special happiness. But what I really think," he added honestly, "is that, because of something she's planned, her smart approach, she won't ask me about it. She'll let me off the hook. I won't have to lie to her."

"It will be left all to me?" asked Kate.

Translation

"So, it's all up to me?" Kate asked.

"All to you!" he tenderly laughed.

Translation

"All yours!" he chuckled softly.

But it was, oddly, the very next moment as if he had perhaps been a shade too candid. His discrimination seemed to mark a possible, a natural reality, a reality not wholly disallowed by the account the girl had just given of her own intention. There was a difference in the air—even if none other than the supposedly usual difference in truth between man and woman; and it was almost as if the sense of this provoked her. She seemed to cast about an instant, and then she went back a little resentfully to something she had suffered to pass a minute before. She appeared to take up rather more seriously than she need the joke about her freedom to deceive. Yet she did this too in a beautiful way. "Men are too stupid—even you. You didn't understand just now why, if I post my letters myself, it won't be for any thing so vulgar as to hide them."

Translation

But, strangely, the very next second, it was as if he had been a little too honest. His assessment seemed to identify a real possibility, a natural outcome, a reality that wasn't completely contradicted by the story the girl had just told about what she wanted to do.

There was a subtle change in the atmosphere—perhaps just the usual difference in honesty between men and women. It was almost as if she was annoyed by this. She seemed to hesitate for a moment, and then she returned, a bit resentfully, to something she'd let slide a minute earlier. She seemed to take the joke about her freedom to lie more seriously than necessary. But even this she did with grace. "Men are so dense—even you. You didn't understand why, if I mail my letters myself, it's not because I'm trying to hide them in some obvious way."

"Oh, you said—for the pleasure."

Translation

Oh, you said it was for fun.

"Yes; but you didn't, you don't understand what the pleasure may be. There are refinements——!" she more patiently dropped. "I mean of consciousness, of sensation, of appreciation," she went on. "No," she sadly insisted—"men don't know. They know, in such matters, almost nothing but what women show them."

Translation

"Yes, but you just don't get it, you don't understand the potential for pleasure. There are subtle nuances..." she said, becoming more patient. "I'm talking about refinements of awareness, of feeling, of enjoyment," she continued. "No," she said sadly, "men just don't know. When it comes to these things, they barely understand anything beyond what women show them."

This was one of the speeches, frequent in her, that, liberally, joyfully, intensely adopted and, in itself, as might be, embraced, drew him again as close to her, and held him as long, as their conditions permitted. "Then that's exactly why we've such an abysmal need of you!"

Translation

This was a speech, typical of her, that she embraced fully, enthusiastically, and passionately. It drew him back to her, held him close for as long as they could. "That's precisely why we need you so badly!"

BOOK THIRD

### EXTRACTED HEADER: BOOK THIRD

Chapter V

Chapter Summary & Character Study
Summary

Two ladies, Mrs. Stringham and Milly Theale, travel together through the Brünig pass in Switzerland. They had previously met in Boston, after which Mrs. Stringham visited Milly in New York. Following the visit, Milly sent a telegram proposing an immediate, unconditional trip to Europe, which Mrs. Stringham accepted. They traveled by sea to Naples and then made their way through Italy and over the Alps.

While on the Brünig, they stop for lunch and agree to prolong their stay. Milly leaves Mrs. Stringham to make the arrangements for lodging and their carriage. Milly then takes a book and strolls off. After an hour, Mrs. Stringham goes to find her. She follows a path up a hillside and past some chalets, where an old woman indicates the direction Milly took. Mrs. Stringham continues on and finds Milly's book lying on a rock.

From her position, she sees Milly sitting on a rock slab at the edge of a precipice. Mrs. Stringham watches her for several minutes without revealing her presence. She then quietly withdraws. After waiting for some time, she returns to the path where the book is, writes "à bientôt!" on its cover with a pencil, and goes back to the inn. Late in the afternoon, Milly reappears.

Character Study

Based on the text, here is a concise character study.

### Mrs. Susan Stringham

  • **Initial Presentation:** Mrs. Stringham is a middle-aged, childless New England widow and a writer of modest reputation. She presents herself as a "woman of the world" due to a European education in her youth, and she leads a structured, intellectually-inclined life in Boston. She is self-aware, observant, and prone to "shy conceits," living a life more of refined observation than of direct, passionate experience.
  • **Immediate Shift:** Her situation shifts dramatically upon meeting Milly Theale. Her quiet, ordered life is completely upended. She renounces her own ambitions to become Milly’s devoted companion, shifting her role from an independent woman to a self-appointed "confidant." This new relationship forces her into a state of constant, "secretive" observation and analysis, which she recognizes is contrary to her nature. Her perception culminates in a moment of terror on the mountain, which then resolves into a "revelation": she no longer sees Milly as merely restless but as a grand figure confronting a profound and complex destiny.

    • ### Milly Theale

  • **Initial Presentation:** Milly is presented almost exclusively through Mrs. Stringham’s admiring and bewildered eyes. She is a young, strikingly unconventional New Yorker, described as "slim, pale, delicately haggard" with exceptional red hair and dressed in mourning. She is an orphan of immense wealth who has suffered numerous bereavements. Characterized by a "charming, ambiguous oddity," she is at once restlessly impatient, inexplicably sad, and charmingly gay. To Mrs. Stringham, she is a "princess" who seems tragically inexperienced and "starved for culture."
  • **Immediate Shift:** The narrative begins with Milly successfully undertaking a European tour against advice. Her situation, however, shifts from that of a wealthy, melancholy tourist to something far more serious. Her solitary contemplation on a dangerous cliff edge transforms her from a figure of romantic restlessness into one of immense gravity. The ambiguity surrounding her "unpacified state" sharpens into the impression that she is consciously facing "the whole assault of life," and is reserved for a "complicated passage" rather than a simple resolution.

The two ladies who, in advance of the Swiss season, had been warned that their design was unconsidered, that the passes would not be clear, nor the air mild, nor the inns open—the two ladies who, characteristically, had braved a good deal of possibly interested remonstrance were finding themselves, as their adventure turned out, wonderfully sustained. It was the judgment of the head-waiters and other functionaries on the Italian lakes that approved itself now as interested; they themselves had been conscious of impatiences, of bolder dreams—at least the younger had; so that one of the things they made out together—making out as they did an endless variety—was that in those operatic palaces of the Villa d'Este, of Cadenabbia, of Pallanza and Stresa, lone women, however reinforced by a travelling-library of instructive volumes, were apt to be beguiled and undone. Their flights of fancy moreover had been modest; they had for instance risked nothing vital in hoping to make their way by the Brünig. They were making it in fact happily enough as we meet them, and were only wishing that, for the wondrous beauty of the early high-climbing spring, it might have been longer and the places to pause and rest more numerous.

Translation

The two women, who had been warned before their trip to Switzerland that their plans were ill-advised, that the mountain passes wouldn't be clear, the weather wouldn't be mild, and the inns wouldn't be open—the two women who, as usual, had ignored a lot of potentially helpful advice—were finding their adventure to be surprisingly enjoyable. The negative opinions of the head waiters and staff at the Italian lakes were now proving to be self-serving; the women suspected they’d been jealous, had bigger ambitions of their own—at least the younger one had. One of the things they discussed together, among many other topics, was how single women, even those armed with a traveling library of educational books, were often deceived and taken advantage of in the opulent settings of the Villa d'Este, Cadenabbia, Pallanza, and Stresa. Their goals had been relatively simple; for example, they hadn't risked anything serious by hoping to travel through the Brünig Pass. They were actually having a great time as we find them, and only wished that the stunning beauty of the early spring in the mountains could have lasted longer, and that there had been more places to stop and rest.

Such at least had been the intimated attitude of Mrs. Stringham, the elder of the companions, who had her own view of the impatiences of the younger, to which, however, she offered an opposition but of the most circuitous. She moved, the admirable Mrs. Stringham, in a fine cloud of observation and suspicion; she was in the position, as she believed, of knowing much more about Milly Theale than Milly herself knew, and yet of having to darken her knowledge as well as make it active. The woman in the world least formed by nature, as she was quite aware, for duplicities and labyrinths, she found herself dedicated to personal subtlety by a new set of circumstances, above all by a new personal relation; had now in fact to recognise that an education in the occult—she could scarce say what to call it—had begun for her the day she left New York with Mildred. She had come on from Boston for that purpose; had seen little of the girl—or rather had seen her but briefly, for Mrs. Stringham, when she saw anything at all, saw much, saw everything—before accepting her proposal; and had accordingly placed herself, by her act, in a boat that she more and more estimated as, humanly speaking, of the biggest, though likewise, no doubt, in many ways, by reason of its size, of the safest. In Boston, the winter before, the young lady in whom we are interested had, on the spot, deeply, yet almost tacitly, appealed to her, dropped into her mind the shy conceit of some assistance, some devotion to render. Mrs. Stringham's little life had often been visited by shy conceits—secret dreams that had fluttered their hour between its narrow walls without, for any great part, so much as mustering courage to look out of its rather dim windows. But this imagination—the fancy of a possible link with the remarkable young thing from New York—had mustered courage: had perched, on the instant, at the clearest look-out it could find, and might be said to have remained there till, only a few months later, it had caught, in surprise and joy, the unmistakable flash of a signal.

Translation

At least, that's what Mrs. Stringham, the older of the two, seemed to think. She had her own opinions about the younger woman's impatience, but she only resisted it in very subtle ways. Mrs. Stringham was a keen observer, always suspicious; she believed she knew far more about Milly Theale than Milly knew herself, yet she had to keep her knowledge hidden and also use it carefully. Though she knew she wasn't naturally inclined towards deceit or complicated schemes, she found herself forced to be subtly manipulative because of a new situation, especially a new relationship. She realized that her education in the mysterious – she didn't know how else to describe it – had started the day she left New York with Mildred. She'd come from Boston specifically for that reason, having barely met the girl – or rather, having only known her briefly, because when Mrs. Stringham saw something, she saw everything – before accepting her offer. By doing so, she'd put herself in a situation she increasingly saw as enormously important, although also, because of its significance, probably quite safe. The previous winter in Boston, the young woman we're interested in had immediately and quietly appealed to her, planting in her mind the hopeful idea of offering some help, some devotion. Mrs. Stringham's life had often been filled with such hopes – secret dreams that had briefly flourished in her limited life, rarely daring to look outside her rather dull existence. But this particular idea – the fantasy of a connection with the extraordinary young woman from New York – had been bolder: it had immediately positioned itself at the best vantage point it could find and could be said to have stayed there until, just a few months later, it had been surprised and delighted by a clear sign of confirmation.

Milly Theale had Boston friends, such as they were, and of recent making; and it was understood that her visit to them—a visit that was not to be meagre—had been undertaken, after a series of bereavements, in the interest of the particular peace that New York could not give. It was recognised, liberally enough, that there were many things—perhaps even too many—New York could give; but this was felt to make no difference in the constant fact that what you had most to do, under the discipline of life, or of death, was really to feel your situation as grave. Boston could help you to that as nothing else could, and it had extended to Milly, by every presumption, some such measure of assistance. Mrs. Stringham was never to forget—for the moment had not faded, nor the infinitely fine vibration it set up in any degree ceased—her own first sight of the striking apparition, then unheralded and unexplained: the slim, constantly pale, delicately haggard, anomalously, agreeably angular young person, of not more than two-and-twenty in spite of her marks, whose hair was some how exceptionally red even for the real thing, which it innocently confessed to being, and whose clothes were remarkably black even for robes of mourning, which was the meaning they expressed. It was New York mourning, it was New York hair, it was a New York history, confused as yet, but multitudinous, of the loss of parents, brothers, sisters, almost every human appendage, all on a scale and with a sweep that had required the greater stage; it was a New York legend of affecting, of romantic isolation, and, beyond everything, it was by most accounts, in respect to the mass of money so piled on the girl's back, a set of New York possibilities. She was alone, she was stricken, she was rich, and, in particular, she was strange—a combination in itself of a nature to engage Mrs. Stringham's attention. But it was the strangeness that most determined our good lady's sympathy, convinced as she was that it was much greater than any one else—any one but the sole Susan Stringham—supposed. Susan privately settled it that Boston was not in the least seeing her, was only occupied with her seeing Boston, and that any assumed affinity between the two characters was delusive and vain. She was seeing her, and she had quite the deepest moment of her life in now obeying the instinct to conceal the vision. She couldn't explain it—no one would understand. They would say clever Boston things—Mrs. Stringham was from Burlington, Vermont, which she boldly upheld as the real heart of New England, Boston being "too far south"—but they would only darken counsel.

Translation

Milly Theale had recently made some friends in Boston, and it was understood that her visit there—a visit that would be well-funded—was intended to find a sense of peace that New York couldn't offer, after a series of personal tragedies. It was generally accepted that New York had many opportunities, maybe even too many, but that didn't change the fact that the most important thing to do in life, or in the face of death, was to accept the seriousness of your situation. Boston could help with that like nothing else, and it was believed that Milly was receiving that kind of support. Mrs. Stringham would never forget the moment she first saw this striking figure, who was, at the time, unexpected and unexplained. It was the slim, consistently pale, subtly worn, and unusually attractive young woman, maybe no older than twenty-two despite her hardship, whose hair was an especially vibrant red, even for natural red hair, and whose clothing was exceptionally black, as in mourning clothes.

It was New York mourning, New York hair, a New York story, still unclear but filled with losses: parents, siblings, almost every close family member, all on a scale that demanded a larger setting. It was a New York legend of moving, romantic isolation, and, most importantly, according to most people, given the vast wealth the girl possessed, it was a collection of New York possibilities. She was alone, grieving, wealthy, and, in particular, peculiar – a combination that immediately captured Mrs. Stringham's attention. But it was the strangeness that most strongly drew our kind Mrs. Stringham's sympathy, as she was convinced that Milly's strangeness was much greater than anyone else—anyone but Susan Stringham herself—realized.

Privately, Susan decided that Boston wasn't really *seeing* Milly at all. Boston was just preoccupied with Milly observing it, and any perceived connection between the two was false and pointless. Susan, on the other hand, *was* seeing her, and had her most significant moment in her life by obeying the instinct to hide what she saw. She couldn't explain it – no one would understand. They would make their clever Boston remarks—Mrs. Stringham was from Burlington, Vermont, which she proudly claimed was the true heart of New England, Boston being "too far south"—but they would only cloud the truth.

There could be no better proof, than this quick intellectual split, of the impression made on our friend, who shone, herself, she was well aware, with but the reflected light of the admirable city. She too had had her discipline, but it had not made her striking; it had been prosaically usual, though doubtless a decent dose; and had only made her usual to match it—usual, that is, as Boston went. She had lost first her husband, and then her mother, with whom, on her husband's death, she had lived again; so that now, childless, she was but more sharply single than before.
