But she sat rather coldly light, having, as she called it, enough to live on—so far, that is, as she lived by bread alone: how little indeed she was regularly content with that diet appeared from the name she had made—Susan Shepherd Stringham—as a contributor to the best magazines. She wrote short stories, and she fondly believed she had her "note," the art of showing New England without showing it wholly in the kitchen. She had not herself been brought up in the kitchen; she knew others who had not; and to speak for them had thus become with her a literary mission. To be in truth literary had ever been her dearest thought, the thought that kept her bright little nippers perpetually in position. There were masters, models, celebrities, mainly foreign, whom she finely accounted so and in whose light she ingeniously laboured; there were others whom, however chattered about, she ranked with the inane, for she was full of discrimination; but all categories failed her—they ceased at least to signify—as soon as she found herself in presence of the real thing, the romantic life itself. That was what she saw in Mildred—what positively made her hand a while tremble too much for the pen. She had had, it seemed to her, a revelation—such as even New England refined and grammatical couldn't give; and, all made up as she was of small neat memories and ingenuities, little industries and ambitions, mixed with something moral, personal, that was still more intensely responsive, she felt her new friend would have done her an ill turn if their friendship shouldn't develop, and yet that nothing would be left of anything else if it should. It was for the surrender of everything else that she was, however, quite prepared, and while she went about her usual Boston business with her usual Boston probity she was really all the while holding herself. She wore her "handsome" felt hat, so Tyrolese, yet some how, though feathered from the eagle's wing, so truly domestic, with the same straightness and security; she attached her fur boa with the same honest precautions; she preserved her balance on the ice-slopes with the same practised skill; she opened, each evening, her "Transcript" with the same interfusion of suspense and resignation; she attended her almost daily concert with the same expenditure of patience and the same economy of passion; she flitted in and out of the Public Library with the air of conscientiously returning or bravely carrying off in her pocket the key of knowledge itself; and finally—it was what she most did—she watched the thin trickle of a fictive "love-interest" through that somewhat serpentine channel, in the magazines, which she mainly managed to keep clear for it. But the real thing, all the while, was elsewhere; the real thing had gone back to New York, leaving behind it the two unsolved questions, quite distinct, of why it was real, and whether she should ever be so near it again.

Translation

The fact that our friend immediately changed her mind so quickly proved how impressed she was. She knew she was only shining because of the great city that she lived in. She had also followed a strict routine, but it hadn't made her stand out. Her life had been ordinary, but acceptable, which was typical for someone from Boston. She had lost her husband first, and then her mother, with whom she had lived after her husband died. Now, without children, she felt even more alone than before. However, she was financially comfortable, as she put it. She was living on enough money to survive on, but her true desires were evident from her pen name, Susan Shepherd Stringham, and her contributions to the most popular magazines. She wrote short stories, and she was convinced she had her own "voice," which involved portraying New England life without focusing solely on the kitchen. She herself hadn't grown up in a kitchen, and she knew others who hadn't either. So, she felt it was her literary duty to speak for them. To be a true writer had always been her greatest aspiration, and it kept her small, meticulous mind constantly focused. There were influential figures, role models, and celebrities, mostly from other countries, whom she greatly admired and whose techniques she studied. There were others, however, who she considered unimportant, regardless of their popularity, because she was good at recognizing quality. But all categories became meaningless as soon as she encountered something authentic, the exciting experience of real life. That was what she saw in Mildred—it was so powerful that her hand shook too much to write for a while. It seemed to her like a revelation, something that even the refined, intellectual world of New England couldn't provide. She was made up of neat memories, clever ideas, small projects, and ambitions. These were mixed with something moral and personal that was even more deeply felt. She thought her new friendship would be a disservice if it didn't develop, and yet she felt that everything else in her life would be lost if it did. She was ready to give up everything else, and while she went about her usual Boston routine with her usual Boston integrity, she was really just biding her time. She wore her "handsome" felt hat, which looked Tyrolean, yet somehow, despite being decorated with feathers, it seemed incredibly practical. She always tied her fur boa with the same caution. She kept her balance on the icy sidewalks with the same practiced skill. She opened her newspaper each evening with the same mixture of anticipation and acceptance. She attended her almost daily concert with the same display of patience and the same restraint of emotion. She went in and out of the public library as if she were conscientiously returning or bravely carrying off the key to knowledge itself. Finally—and this was what she did most—she watched the thin flow of fictional romance through the somewhat winding path of the magazines, which she mostly managed to keep open for it. But the real experience, meanwhile, was somewhere else. The real thing had returned to New York, leaving behind two unanswered questions, completely separate, about why it was genuine, and whether she would ever experience it again.

For the figure to which these questions attached themselves she had found a convenient description—she thought of it for herself, always, as that of a girl with a background. The great reality was in the fact that, very soon, after but two or three meetings, the girl with the background, the girl with the crown of old gold and the mourning that was not as the mourning of Boston, but at once more rebellious in its gloom and more frivolous in its frills, had told her she had never seen any one like her. They had met thus as opposed curiosities, and that simple remark of Milly's—if simple it was—became the most important thing that had ever happened to her; it deprived the love-interest, for the time, of actuality and even of pertinence; it moved her first, in short, in a high degree, to gratitude, and then to no small compassion. Yet in respect to this relation at least it was what did prove the key of knowledge; it lighted up as nothing else could do the poor young woman's history. That the potential heiress of all the ages should never have seen any one like a mere typical subscriber, after all, to the "Transcript" was a truth that—in especial as announced with modesty, with humility, with regret—described a situation. It laid upon the elder woman, as to the void to be filled, a weight of responsibility; but in particular it led her to ask whom poor Mildred had then seen, and what range of contacts it had taken to produce such queer surprises. That was really the inquiry that had ended by clearing the air: the key of knowledge was felt to click in the lock from the moment it flashed upon Mrs. Stringham that her friend had been starved for culture. Culture was what she herself represented for her, and it was living up to that principle that would surely prove the great business. She knew, the clever lady, what the principle itself represented, and the limits of her own store; and a certain alarm would have grown upon her if something else hadn't grown faster.

Translation

For the person this whole thing revolved around, she'd come up with a convenient label – she always thought of her as "the girl with the background." The truly significant thing was that, very quickly, after only a few meetings, this girl, the one with the crown of antique gold and mourning that was different from the usual Boston kind, more rebellious in its sadness and more extravagant in its ornamentation, had told her she’d never met anyone like her. They’d begun their relationship as opposing oddities, and that simple comment from Milly – if simple it was – became the most important thing that had ever happened to her. It made the romantic interest, for the moment, seem unimportant, even irrelevant. It first moved her deeply to gratitude, and then to a good deal of sympathy. Yet, at least concerning this relationship, it actually unlocked understanding; it illuminated the young woman's past in a way nothing else could. The fact that this potential heiress, from a lineage stretching back through the ages, had never seen anyone like a typical "Transcript" reader was a truth that, particularly when expressed with modesty, humility, and regret, defined a situation. It placed a burden of responsibility on the older woman, concerning the emptiness she could fill; but, more specifically, it led her to wonder whom poor Mildred *had* seen, and what kind of encounters had caused such surprising opinions. That was the question that ultimately cleared everything up: the key to understanding clicked into place the moment it dawned on Mrs. Stringham that her friend was starved for "culture." She herself represented culture to Milly, and living up to that principle would surely become her main focus. The clever lady knew what the principle itself signified, and the limitations of her own knowledge; and a certain unease would have grown within her if something else hadn't grown faster.

This was, fortunately for her—and we give it in her own words—the sense of a harrowing pathos. That, primarily, was what appealed to her, what seemed to open the door of romance for her still wider than any, than a still more reckless, connection with the "picture-papers." For such was essentially the point: it was rich, romantic, abysmal, to have, as was evident, thousands and thousands a year, to have youth and intelligence and if not beauty, at least, in equal measure, a high, dim, charming, ambiguous oddity, which was even better, and then on top of all to enjoy boundless freedom, the freedom of the wind in the desert—it was unspeakably touching to be so equipped and yet to have been reduced by fortune to little humble-minded mistakes.

Translation

Luckily for her (and we'll let her tell it), this was a deeply moving and tragic feeling. That, above all, was what she loved – what made the idea of romance even more exciting than her wild obsession with tabloid magazines. Basically, that was the appeal: it was glamorous, romantic, and devastating to have a fortune, youth, intelligence, and even if not beauty, then at least a strange, subtle, and captivating quality (which was arguably better), plus complete freedom. It was incredibly touching to be so privileged and yet to have made insignificant, humble errors.

It brought our friend's imagination back again to New York, where aberrations were so possible in the intellectual sphere, and it in fact caused a visit she presently paid there to overflow with interest. As Milly had beautifully invited her, so she would hold out if she could against the strain of so much confidence in her mind; and the remarkable thing was that even at the end of three weeks she had held out. But by this time her mind had grown comparatively bold and free; it was dealing with new quantities, a different proportion altogether—and that had made for refreshment: she had accordingly gone home in convenient possession of her subject. New York was vast, New York was startling, with strange histories, with wild cosmopolite backward generations that accounted for anything; and to have got nearer the luxuriant tribe of which the rare creature was the final flower, the immense, extravagant, unregulated cluster, with free-living ancestors, handsome dead cousins, lurid uncles, beautiful vanished aunts, persons all busts and curls, preserved, though so exposed, in the marble of famous French chisels—all this, to say nothing of the effect of closer growths of the stem, was to have had one's small world-space both crowded and enlarged. Our couple had at all events effected an exchange; the elder friend had been as consciously intellectual as possible, and the younger, abounding in personal revelation, had been as unconsciously distinguished. This was poetry—it was also history—Mrs. Stringham thought, to a finer tune even than Maeterlink and Pater, than Marbot and Gregorovius. She appointed occasions for the reading of these authors with her hostess, rather perhaps than actually achieved great spans; but what they managed and what they missed speedily sank for her into the dim depths of the merely relative, so quickly, so strongly had she clutched her central clue. All her scruples and hesitations, all her anxious enthusiasms, had reduced themselves to a single alarm—the fear that she really might act on her companion clumsily and coarsely. She was positively afraid of what she might do to her, and to avoid that, to avoid it with piety and passion, to do, rather, nothing at all, to leave her untouched because no touch one could apply, however light, however just, however earnest and anxious, would be half good enough, would be anything but an ugly smutch upon perfection—this now imposed itself as a consistent, an inspiring thought.

Translation

It brought our friend's imagination back to New York. In New York, anything felt possible in the world of ideas. This inspired a visit she took there, which turned out to be incredibly interesting. Milly had gracefully invited her, and she had tried to resist the pressure of so much trust placed in her. The surprising thing was that she succeeded for three weeks. But by then, her mind had become more confident and open. It was dealing with new concepts and a completely different perspective, which was refreshing. She ultimately returned home, ready to understand her subject. New York was huge and surprising, filled with strange stories and wild, diverse generations that could explain anything. To get closer to the fascinating group of which this rare person was the ultimate representative—the huge, unrestrained collection with free-spirited ancestors, attractive deceased relatives, scandalous uncles, beautiful deceased aunts, people who were like statues preserved in famous French sculptures—all this, not to mention the impact of more intimate connections, had both filled and expanded her own world.

In any case, the two friends had made an exchange: the older friend had been as intellectual and thoughtful as possible, while the younger friend, overflowing with personal revelations, was naturally remarkable. This was poetry, and it was also history—Mrs. Stringham thought, even more beautifully than Maeterlink and Pater, than Marbot and Gregorovius. She planned to read these authors with her hostess, though perhaps she didn't read for very long. But what they did manage to read, and what they missed, quickly became insignificant to her, lost in the realm of relativity. She had grasped her central understanding so quickly and firmly. All her doubts, hesitations, and enthusiastic worries had narrowed down to one fear: that she might act awkwardly and clumsily towards her companion. She was genuinely afraid of what she might do to her. To avoid that, to avoid it with deep respect and passion, to do nothing at all, to leave her untouched because no action, however gentle, however fair, however sincere and worried, would be good enough, would be anything but a blemish on perfection—this had become her driving and inspiring thought.

Less than a month after the event that had so determined Mrs. Stringham's attitude—close upon the heels, that is, of her return from New York—she was reached by a proposal that brought up for her the kind of question her delicacy might have to contend with. Would she start for Europe with her young friend at the earliest possible date, and should she be willing to do so without making conditions? The inquiry was launched by wire; explanations, in sufficiency, were promised; extreme urgency was suggested, and a general surrender invited. It was to the honour of her sincerity that she made the surrender on the spot, though it was not perhaps altogether to that of her logic. She had wanted, very consciously, from the first, to give something up for her new acquaintance, but she had now no doubt that she was practically giving up all. What settled this was the fulness of a particular impression, the impression that had throughout more and more supported her and which she would have uttered so far as she might by saying that the charm of the creature was positively in the creature's greatness. She would have been content so to leave it; unless indeed she had said, more familiarly, that Mildred was the biggest impression of her life. That was at all events the biggest account of her, and none but a big, clearly, would do. Her situation, as such things were called, was on the grand scale; but it still was not that. It was her nature, once for all—a nature that reminded Mrs. Stringham of the term always used in the newspapers about the great new steamers, the inordinate number of "feet of water" they drew; so that if, in your little boat, you had chosen to hover and approach, you had but yourself to thank, when once motion was started, for the way the draught pulled you. Milly drew the feet of water, and odd though it might seem that a lonely girl, who was not robust and who hated sound and show, should stir the stream like a leviathan, her companion floated off with the sense of rocking violently at her side. More than prepared, however, for that excitement, Mrs. Stringham mainly failed of ease in respect to her own consistency. To attach herself for an indefinite time seemed a roundabout way of holding her hands off. If she wished to be sure of neither touching nor smutching, the straighter plan would doubtless have been not to keep her friend within reach. This in fact she fully recognised, and with it the degree to which she desired that the girl should lead her life, a life certain to be so much finer than that of anybody else. The difficulty, however, by good fortune, cleared away as soon as she had further recognised, as she was speedily able to do, that she, Susan Shepherd—the name with which Milly for the most part amused herself—was not anybody else. She had renounced that character; she had now no life to lead; and she honestly believed that she was thus supremely equipped for leading Milly's own. No other person whatever, she was sure, had to an equal degree this qualification, and it was really to assert it that she fondly embarked.

Translation

Less than a month after the incident that had profoundly shaped Mrs. Stringham's feelings—shortly after her return from New York—she received a proposition that forced her to confront a question her own sense of propriety might struggle with. Would she depart for Europe with her young friend as soon as possible, and would she be willing to do so without any reservations or demands?

The inquiry arrived by telegram; explanations would follow, they promised; the situation was described as extremely urgent, and a complete, unconditional agreement was requested. To her credit, she agreed immediately, though perhaps not entirely based on rational thought. From the beginning, she had consciously wanted to sacrifice something for her new friend, but now she felt she was essentially giving up everything. This decision was cemented by a powerful, recurring feeling, an impression that had increasingly sustained her. She would have explained it by saying that her friend's charm stemmed from her inherent greatness. That would have sufficed, unless she had phrased it more casually, by saying Mildred was the most significant presence in her life. That was, at any rate, the most accurate description, and anything less would simply not do.

Her role in this situation, as it was understood, was on a large scale; but that wasn’t quite it. It was her very nature, her fundamental being—a nature that reminded Mrs. Stringham of the phrase often used in the newspapers about the huge new ships, the enormous "feet of water" they drew; so that, if you had decided to approach her in a small boat, you only had yourself to blame, once the ship began to move, for the way the current pulled you along. Milly drew the "feet of water," and, strange as it seemed that a solitary girl, not physically strong and averse to noise and display, should create such a powerful current, her companion felt herself rocking violently alongside.

Though she was more than ready for this kind of upheaval, Mrs. Stringham was primarily uneasy about maintaining her own principles. Committing herself for an unspecified period seemed a convoluted way of maintaining distance. If she wanted to ensure she neither interfered nor caused problems, the more straightforward solution would undoubtedly have been to avoid staying close to her friend. In fact, she fully acknowledged this, along with the degree to which she wanted the girl to live her life—a life destined to be far more extraordinary than anyone else's.

However, thankfully, the problem resolved itself as soon as she further realized, which she quickly did, that she, Susan Shepherd—the name Milly often playfully used for her—was not just anyone. She had relinquished that role; she now had no life of her own to live; and she genuinely believed that she was, in this way, ideally suited to guide Milly's. She was certain that no one else possessed this qualification to the same degree, and it was primarily to establish this fact that she enthusiastically embarked on this journey.

Many things, though not in many weeks, had come and gone since then, and one of the best of them, doubtless, had been the voyage itself, by the happy southern course, to the succession of Mediterranean ports, with the dazzled wind-up at Naples. Two or three others had preceded this; incidents, indeed rather lively marks, of their last fortnight at home, and one of which had determined on Mrs. Stringham's part a rush to New York, forty-eight breathless hours there, previous to her final rally. But the great sustained sea-light had drunk up the rest of the picture, so that for many days other questions and other possibilities sounded with as little effect as a trio of penny whistles might sound in a Wagner overture. It was the Wagner overture that practically prevailed, up through Italy, where Milly had already been, still further up and across the Alps, which were also partly known to Mrs. Stringham; only perhaps "taken" to a time not wholly congruous, hurried in fact on account of the girl's high restlessness. She had been expected, she had frankly promised, to be restless—that was partly why she was "great"—or was a consequence, at any rate, if not a cause; yet she had not perhaps altogether announced herself as straining so hard at the cord. It was familiar, it was beautiful to Mrs. Stringham that she had arrears to make up, the chances that had lapsed for her through the wanton ways of forefathers fond of Paris, but not of its higher sides, and fond almost of nothing else; but the vagueness, the openness, the eagerness without point and the interest without pause—all a part of the charm of her oddity as at first presented—had become more striking in proportion as they triumphed over movement and change. She had arts and idiosyncrasies of which no great account could have been given, but which were a daily grace if you lived with them; such as the art of being almost tragically impatient and yet making it as light as air; of being inexplicably sad and yet making it as clear as noon; of being unmistakably gay, and yet making it as soft as dusk. Mrs. Stringham by this time understood everything, was more than ever confirmed in wonder and admiration, in her view that it was life enough simply to feel her companion's feelings; but there were special keys she had not yet added to her bunch, impressions that, of a sudden, were apt to affect her as new.

Translation

A lot of things had happened since then, even though it hadn't been that long. One of the best experiences, no doubt, was the voyage itself. They’d taken the pleasant southern route, visiting a series of Mediterranean ports, culminating in the dazzling experience in Naples. A couple of other significant events had occurred before this: lively memories of their last two weeks at home. One of these events caused Mrs. Stringham to rush to New York for forty-eight frantic hours before her final travel plans solidified. However, the expansive, sustained beauty of the sea had overshadowed everything else. For a long time, other concerns and possibilities seemed insignificant, like the sound of penny whistles against a Wagner overture. It was, in a way, like the Wagner overture that prevailed, particularly through Italy, where Milly had already been. She had also traveled further into the Alps, which Mrs. Stringham was also familiar with, although maybe not at a time that suited the present, as the travels were hurried due to the girl's high level of anxiety. It was expected and frankly promised that she would be restless—that was partly why she was considered "great"—or, at the very least, a consequence, if not the cause. Yet she hadn't completely revealed how much she was struggling. It was familiar and lovely to Mrs. Stringham that there were experiences to be had, opportunities that had been missed because of her ancestors' love for Paris and not its more sophisticated aspects, or their passion for anything else. But the vagueness, the openness, the fervent but directionless eagerness, and the continuous interest—all aspects of the charm of her unusual nature, as initially presented—had become more noticeable as they withstood movement and change. She possessed skills and unique traits that were hard to describe but were a daily delight if you lived with her. She had the art of being almost tragically impatient yet making it seem lighthearted. She had the skill of being inexplicably sad but making it as clear as daylight. She had the ability to be undeniably cheerful but making it as gentle as twilight. By this time, Mrs. Stringham understood everything, and her admiration and amazement were stronger than ever. She thought it was enough to experience her companion's feelings, but there were specific understandings she hadn't yet grasped, impressions that suddenly seemed new to her.

This particular day on the great Swiss road had been, for some reason, full of them, and they referred themselves, provisionally, to some deeper depth than she had touched—though into two or three such depths, it must be added, she had peeped long enough to find herself suddenly draw back. It was not Milly's unpacified state, in short, that now troubled her—though certainly, as Europe was the great American sedative, the failure was to some extent to be noted: it was the suspected presence of something behind it—which, however, could scarcely have taken its place there since their departure. What any fresh motive of unrest could suddenly have sprung from was, in short, not to be divined. It was but half an explanation to say that excitement, for each of them, had naturally dropped, and that what they had left behind, or tried to—the great serious facts of life, as Mrs. Stringham liked to call them—was once more coming into sight as objects loom through smoke when smoke begins to clear; for these were general appearances from which the girl's own aspect, her really larger vagueness, seemed rather to disconnect itself. The nearest approach to a personal anxiety indulged in as yet by the elder lady was on her taking occasion to wonder if what she had more than anything else got hold of mightn't be one of the finer, one of the finest, one of the rarest—as she called it so that she might call it nothing worse—cases of American intensity. She had just had a moment of alarm—asked herself if her young friend were merely going to treat her to some complicated drama of nerves. At the end of a week, however, with their further progress, her young friend had effectively answered the question and given her the impression, indistinct indeed as yet, of something that had a reality compared with which the nervous explanation would have been coarse. Mrs. Stringham found herself from that hour, in other words, in presence of an explanation that remained a muffled and intangible form, but that, assuredly, should it take on sharpness, would explain everything and more than everything, would become instantly the light in which Milly was to be read.

Translation

That particular day on the famous Swiss road, for some reason, had been full of these things, and they seemed to originate from a level of depth she hadn't explored—although, it's true, she'd glanced into a couple of those depths long enough to quickly pull back. In short, it wasn't Milly's unsettled mood that was bothering her now—though, certainly, since Europe was supposed to calm Americans, that failure was somewhat noticeable. It was the suspicion that something was lurking behind it all, something that couldn't possibly have appeared since they left home. What any new source of anxiety could have suddenly emerged from was, simply, a mystery. It was only a partial explanation to say that the excitement had naturally faded for both of them, and that the things they'd left behind, or tried to—the big serious issues of life, as Mrs. Stringham liked to call them—were coming back into view like objects emerging from smoke as it clears. These were general observations, and the girl's own condition, her broader sense of unease, seemed rather separate from them. The closest the older woman had come to a personal worry was when she wondered if what she'd discovered might be one of the more subtle, one of the finest, one of the rarest—she used that language so she wouldn't have to use anything worse—cases of intense American behavior. She'd briefly been concerned, wondering if her young friend was just going to put on some complicated act based on her nerves. After a week, however, as they continued traveling, her young friend had effectively answered that question and given her the still-vague impression of something truly real, something compared to which the nervous explanation seemed crude. From that point on, in other words, Mrs. Stringham found herself facing an explanation that remained vague and undefined, but which, if it ever sharpened, would undoubtedly explain everything and more, and would immediately become the key to understanding Milly.

Such a matter as this may at all events speak of the style in which our young woman could affect those who were near her, may testify to the sort of interest she could inspire. She worked—and seemingly quite without design—upon the sympathy, the curiosity, the fancy of her associates, and we shall really ourselves scarce otherwise come closer to her than by feeling their impression and sharing, if need be, their confusion. She reduced them, Mrs. Stringham would have said, reduced them to a consenting bewilderment; which was precisely, for that good lady, on a last analysis, what was most in harmony with her greatness. She exceeded, escaped measure, was surprising only because they were so far from great. Thus it was that on this wondrous day on the Brünig the spell of watching her had grown more than ever irresistible; a proof of what—or of a part of what—Mrs. Stringham had, with all the rest, been reduced to. She had almost the sense of tracking her young friend as if at a given moment to pounce. She knew she shouldn't pounce, she hadn't come out to pounce; yet she felt her attention secretive, all the same, and her observation scientific. She struck herself as hovering like a spy, applying tests, laying traps, concealing signs. This would last, however, only till she should fairly know what was the matter; and to watch was, after all, meanwhile, a way of clinging to the girl, not less than an occupation, a satisfaction in itself. The pleasure of watching, moreover, if a reason were needed, came from a sense of her beauty. Her beauty hadn't at all originally seemed a part of the situation, and Mrs. Stringham had, even in the first flush of friendship, not named it, grossly, to any one; having seen early that, for stupid people—and who, she sometimes secretly asked herself, wasn't stupid?—it would take a great deal of explaining. She had learned not to mention it till it was mentioned first—which occasionally happened, but not too often; and then she was there in force. Then she both warmed to the perception that met her own perception, and disputed it, suspiciously, as to special items; while, in general, she had learned to refine even to the point of herself employing the word that most people employed. She employed it to pretend that she was also stupid and so have done with the matter; spoke of her friend as plain, as ugly even, in a case of especially dense insistence; but as, in appearance, so "awfully full of things." This was her own way of describing a face that, thanks, doubtless, to rather too much forehead, too much nose and too much mouth, together with too little mere conventional colour and conventional line, was expressive, irregular, exquisite, both for speech and for silence. When Milly smiled it was a public event—when she didn't it was a chapter of history. They had stopped, on the Brünig, for luncheon, and there had come up for them under the charm of the place the question of a longer stay.

Translation

This whole thing gives us a sense of how this young woman affected the people around her, and the kind of interest she could spark. She seemed to effortlessly influence the sympathy, curiosity, and imagination of her friends. Honestly, the best way for us to understand her is to feel their reactions and, if necessary, share in their confusion. Mrs. Stringham would say she reduced them, reduced them to a state of willing bewilderment. And for that good woman, that was the ultimate indication of this woman's greatness. She was exceptional, defied expectations, and was surprising simply because they weren't particularly remarkable themselves. So, on this amazing day on the Brünig, the pull of watching her was stronger than ever. It proved—or at least partially proved—what Mrs. Stringham, along with everyone else, had been reduced to. She almost felt like she was secretly following her young friend, ready to pounce. She knew she shouldn't, she hadn't come out looking to pounce, but her attention felt hidden, almost scientific. She felt like a spy, setting up tests, laying traps, and hiding clues. However, that would only last until she figured out what was really going on. But for now, watching her was a way of staying connected to the girl, and it was also something to do and enjoy. The pleasure of watching her, if a reason were needed, was rooted in her beauty. Her beauty hadn't initially seemed to be a key element, and Mrs. Stringham, even early in their friendship, hadn't explicitly mentioned it to anyone. She knew early on that for some people—and secretly, she sometimes wondered, who *wasn't* stupid?—it would take a lot of explanation. She learned not to bring it up until someone else did—which happened occasionally, but not often. Then she would jump in. She would embrace the other person's observation, but also argue with them about specific aspects of it. Generally, she had learned to be subtle enough to use the same word most people used. She would use it to pretend she was also dense and to get the topic over with. She’d describe her friend as plain, even ugly, when someone was being particularly insistent. But in reality, she said the woman was "awfully full of things." That was her way of describing a face that, perhaps because of a rather prominent forehead, nose, and mouth, along with a lack of conventional color and features, was expressive, unusual, and exquisite, both in moments of speech and silence. When Milly smiled, it was a major event. When she didn't, it was a historical moment. They had stopped on the Brünig for lunch, and under the spell of the place, they began to consider staying longer.

Mrs. Stringham was now on the ground of thrilled recognitions, small sharp echoes of a past which she kept in a well-thumbed case, but which, on pressure of a spring and exposure to the air, still showed itself ticking as hard as an honest old watch. The embalmed "Europe" of her younger time had partly stood for three years of Switzerland, a term of continuous school at Vevey, with rewards of merit in the form of silver medals tied by blue ribbons and mild mountain-passes attacked with alpenstocks. It was the good girls who, in the holidays, were taken highest, and our friend could now judge, from what she supposed her familiarity with the minor peaks, that she had been one of the best. These reminiscences, sacred to-day because prepared in the hushed chambers of the past, had been part of the general train laid for the pair of sisters, daughters early fatherless, by their brave Vermont mother, who struck her at present as having apparently, almost like Columbus, worked out, all unassisted, a conception of the other side of the globe. She had focussed Vevey, by the light of nature, and with extraordinary completeness, at Burlington; after which she had embarked, sailed, landed, explored and, above all, made good her presence. She had given her daughters the five years in Switzerland and Germany that were to leave them ever afterwards a standard of comparison for all cycles of Cathay, and to stamp the younger in especial—Susan was the younger—with a character that, as Mrs. Stringham had often had occasion, through life, to say to herself, made all the difference. It made all the difference for Mrs. Stringham, over and over again and in the most remote connections, that, thanks to her parent's lonely, thrifty, hardy faith, she was a woman of the world. There were plenty of women who were all sorts of things that she wasn't, but who, on the other hand, were not that, and who didn't know she was (which she liked—it relegated them still further) and didn't know, either, how it enabled her to judge them. She had never seen herself so much in this light as during the actual phase of her associated, if slightly undirected, pilgrimage; and the consciousness gave perhaps to her plea for a pause more intensity than she knew. The irrecoverable days had come back to her from far off; they were part of the sense of the cool upper air and of everything else that hung like an indestructible scent to the torn garment of youth—the taste of honey and the luxury of milk, the sound of cattle-bells and the rush of streams, the fragrance of trodden balms and the dizziness of deep gorges.

Translation

Mrs. Stringham was now reminiscing, reliving moments from her past that she kept carefully guarded. These memories, though tucked away, were still vibrant and active, like a well-maintained antique watch. Her "Europe" of youth primarily consisted of three years in Switzerland, including continuous schooling in Vevey, where she earned silver medals tied with blue ribbons and hiked through mountain passes with alpenstocks. She realized now that, based on her familiarity with the smaller mountains, she must have been a very successful student, as the best girls got to go on the most impressive hikes during holidays.

These memories, precious because they were born in the past, were part of the foundation laid for her and her sister by their courageous Vermont-born mother. Mrs. Stringham now saw her mother as someone who, like Columbus, had independently conceived of and planned their journey to Europe. Her mother, without formal guidance, had envisioned Vevey from Burlington, Vermont. She then traveled, explored, and, most importantly, established her daughters' presence in Europe.

Her mother provided the five years in Switzerland and Germany that would give them a standard of comparison for everything, especially for her younger sister, Susan, whose character was shaped in a way that, as Mrs. Stringham often thought, made all the difference.

It consistently made all the difference for Mrs. Stringham that, thanks to her mother's independent, frugal, and determined belief, she was a woman of the world. Many other women possessed qualities she didn't, but, in turn, lacked this global perspective. They also didn't realize she had it (which she liked, as it put her above them), and they couldn't grasp how it allowed her to assess them.

She had never been more aware of this aspect of herself than during this current, somewhat aimless journey. This realization perhaps made her request for a break even more urgent than she realized. The unforgettable past was returning to her; it was tied to the crisp mountain air and everything else that clung to the remnants of her youth—the taste of honey and the pleasure of milk, the sound of cowbells and rushing streams, the scent of crushed plants and the vertigo of deep ravines.

Milly clearly felt these things too, but they affected her companion at moments—that was quite the way Mrs. Stringham would have expressed it—as the princess in a conventional tragedy might have affected the confidant if a personal emotion had ever been permitted to the latter. That a princess could only be a princess was a truth with which, essentially, a confidant, however responsive, had to live. Mrs. Stringham was a woman of the world, but Milly Theale was a princess, the only one she had yet had to deal with, and this in its way, too, made all the difference. It was a perfectly definite doom for the wearer—it was for every one else a perfectly palpable quality. It might have been, possibly, with its involved loneliness and other mysteries, the weight under which she fancied her companion's admirable head occasionally, and ever so submissively, bowed. Milly had quite assented at luncheon to their staying over, and had left her to look at rooms, settle questions, arrange about their keeping on their carriage and horses; cares that had now moreover fallen to Mrs. Stringham as a matter of course and that yet for some reason, on this occasion particularly, brought home to her—all agreeably, richly, almost grandly—what it was to live with the great. Her young friend had, in a sublime degree, a sense closed to the general question of difficulty, which she got rid of, furthermore, not in the least as one had seen many charming persons do, by merely passing it on to others. She kept it completely at a distance: it never entered the circle; the most plaintive confidant couldn't have dragged it in; and to tread the path of a confidant was accordingly to live exempt. Service was in other words so easy to render that the whole thing was like court life without the hardships. It came back of course to the question of money, and our observant lady had by this time repeatedly reflected that if one were talking of the "difference," it was just this, this incomparably and nothing else, that when all was said and done most made it. A less vulgarly, a less obviously purchasing or parading person she couldn't have imagined; but it was, all the same, the truth of truths that the girl couldn't get away from her wealth. She might leave her conscientious companion as freely alone with it as possible and never ask a question, scarce even tolerate a reference; but it was in the fine folds of the helplessly expensive little black frock that she drew over the grass as she now strolled vaguely off; it was in the curious and splendid coils of hair, "done" with no eye whatever to the mode du jour, that peeped from under the corresponding indifference of her hat, the merely personal tradition that suggested a sort of noble inelegance; it lurked between the leaves of the uncut but antiquated Tauchnitz volume of which, before going out, she had mechanically possessed herself. She couldn't dress it away, nor walk it away, nor read it away, nor think it away; she could neither smile it away in any dreamy absence nor blow it away in any softened sigh. She couldn't have lost it if she had tried—that was what it was to be really rich. It had to be the thing you were. When at the end of an hour she had not returned to the house Mrs. Stringham, though the bright afternoon was yet young, took, with precautions, the same direction, went to join her in case of her caring for a walk. But the purpose of joining her was in truth less distinct than that of a due regard for a possibly preferred detachment: so that, once more, the good lady proceeded with a quietness that made her slightly "underhand" even in her own eyes. She couldn't help that, however, and she didn't care, sure as she was that what she really wanted was not to overstep, but to stop in time. It was to be able to stop in time that she went softly, but she had on this occasion further to go than ever yet, for she followed in vain, and at last with some anxiety, the footpath she believed Milly to have taken. It wound up a hillside and into the higher Alpine meadows in which, all these last days, they had so often wanted, as they passed above or below, to stray; and then it obscured itself in a wood, but always going up, up, and with a small cluster of brown old high-perched chalets evidently for its goal. Mrs. Stringham reached in due course the chalets, and there received from a bewildered old woman, a very fearful person to behold, an indication that sufficiently guided her. The young lady had been seen not long before passing further on, over a crest and to a place where the way would drop again, as our unappeased inquirer found it, in fact, a quarter of an hour later, markedly and almost alarmingly to do. It led somewhere, yet apparently quite into space, for the great side of the mountain appeared, from where she pulled up, to fall away altogether, though probably but to some issue below and out of sight. Her uncertainty moreover was brief, for she next became aware of the presence on a fragment of rock, twenty yards off, of the Tauchnitz volume that the girl had brought out, and that therefore pointed to her shortly previous passage. She had rid herself of the book, which was an encumbrance, and meant of course to pick it up on her return; but as she hadn't yet picked it up what on earth had become of her? Mrs. Stringham, I hasten to add, was within a few moments to see; but it was quite an accident that she had not, before they were over, betrayed by her deeper agitation the fact of her own nearness.

Translation

Milly clearly felt things, but they affected her companion at certain moments—that’s how Mrs. Stringham would have phrased it—the same way a princess in a classic tragedy might affect her confidante if the latter were allowed to express personal emotions. The simple fact was that a princess could only be a princess, and a confidante, however sympathetic, had to accept that. Mrs. Stringham was worldly, but Milly Theale was a princess, the only one she’d ever dealt with. That made all the difference too. It was a definite fate for the princess, and for everyone else, a clear characteristic. Mrs. Stringham imagined it was the burden that made her companion’s admirable head bow occasionally, always respectfully. Milly had agreed to stay over for lunch and had left Mrs. Stringham to look at rooms, sort out arrangements, and take care of keeping their carriage and horses. These responsibilities had naturally fallen to Mrs. Stringham, and yet, on this occasion, they brought home to her—pleasantly, richly, almost grandly—what it meant to live with the wealthy. Her young friend had a remarkable ability to avoid difficulty, and she didn’t pass it on to others, as many charming people do. She kept it completely separate, never letting it interfere. The most complaining confidante couldn’t have dragged it into their conversation. Thus, being a confidante meant living an easy life. In other words, serving was so effortless that it felt like court life without the hardship. It came back to the question of money, and Mrs. Stringham had repeatedly realized that if there was a "difference," it was exactly this, and nothing else, that made the biggest impact. She couldn’t imagine a less vulgar or showy person, but the truth was that the girl couldn’t escape her wealth. She might leave her conscientious companion alone with it and never ask a question, hardly even acknowledge it, but it was in the elegant folds of the expensive black dress she wore while strolling across the grass; it was in the curious and beautiful hairstyle, styled without regard to current fashion, peeking from under the similarly casual hat, the personal tradition suggesting a sort of noble lack of elegance; it lingered between the pages of the uncut, antiquated Tauchnitz book she had picked up before going out. She couldn't dress it away, or walk it away, or read it away, or think it away. She couldn’t smile it away in absent-mindedness or blow it away in a soft sigh. She couldn't have lost it if she tried—that's what being truly rich meant. It was just who she was. When Milly hadn't returned after an hour, Mrs. Stringham, although it was still early afternoon, took precautions and followed the same path, intending to join her in case she wanted company on her walk. But the intention to join her was less clear than a desire to respect a possibly preferred solitude, so the good lady proceeded quietly, which made her feel slightly "underhanded," even to herself. She couldn't help it, and she didn’t care, because she was sure that she really wanted not to overstep her boundaries, but to stop in time. She went softly to be able to stop in time, but on this occasion she needed to go further than ever before, as she searched in vain for Milly, following the footpath she believed her to have taken. It wound up a hillside and into the high Alpine meadows where they had often wanted to wander, then disappeared into a wood, always going up, up, and toward a small group of brown, old, high-perched chalets. Mrs. Stringham eventually reached the chalets and was guided by a bewildered old woman, a very frightening sight. The young lady had recently been seen passing further on, over a crest, to a place where the path dropped down again, as Mrs. Stringham realized a quarter of an hour later. The path led somewhere, but seemingly nowhere, because the side of the mountain appeared to fall away altogether, although likely to some point below and out of sight. Her uncertainty was brief, because she then noticed the Tauchnitz book on a rock twenty yards away, which meant Milly had recently passed that way. She had gotten rid of the book, which was a burden, and meant to pick it up on her return. But since she hadn't yet picked it up, what had happened to her? Mrs. Stringham was about to find out, but by chance, she hadn't revealed her inner turmoil before.

The whole place, with the descent of the path and as a sequel to a sharp turn that was masked by rocks and shrubs, appeared to fall precipitously and to become a "view" pure and simple, a view of great extent and beauty, but thrown forward and vertiginous. Milly, with the promise of it from just above, had gone straight down to it, not stopping till it was all before her; and here, on what struck her friend as the dizzy edge of it, she was seated at her ease. The path somehow took care of itself and its final business, but the girl's seat was a slab of rock at the end of a short promontory or excrescence that merely pointed off to the right into gulfs of air and that was so placed by good fortune, if not by the worst, as to be at last completely visible. For Mrs. Stringham stifled a cry on taking in what she believed to be the danger of such a perch for a mere maiden; her liability to slip, to slide, to leap, to be precipitated by a single false movement, by a turn of the head—how could one tell? into whatever was beneath. A thousand thoughts, for the minute, roared in the poor lady's ears, but without reaching, as happened, Milly's. It was a commotion that left our observer intensely still and holding her breath. What had first been offered her was the possibility of a latent intention—however wild the idea—in such a posture; of some betrayed accordance of Milly's caprice with a horrible hidden obsession. But since Mrs. Stringham stood as motionless as if a sound, a syllable, must have produced the start that would be fatal, so even the lapse of a few seconds had a partly reassuring effect. It gave her time to receive the impression which, when she some minutes later softly retraced her steps, was to be the sharpest she carried away. This was the impression that if the girl was deeply and recklessly meditating there, she was not meditating a jump; she was on the contrary, as she sat, much more in a state of uplifted and unlimited possession that had nothing to gain from violence. She was looking down on the kingdoms of the earth, and though indeed that of itself might well go to the brain, it wouldn't be with a view of renouncing them. Was she choosing among them, or did she want them all? This question, before Mrs. Stringham had decided what to do, made others vain; in accordance with which she saw, or believed she did, that if it might be dangerous to call out, to sound in any way a surprise, it would probably be safe enough to withdraw as she had come. She watched a while longer, she held her breath, and she never knew afterwards what time had elapsed.

Translation

The entire area, with the path sloping downwards and following a sharp bend hidden by rocks and bushes, seemed to plunge downwards dramatically, becoming purely a "view." It was a vast and beautiful panorama, but also overwhelming and dizzying. Milly, having been shown the promise of it from above, had immediately descended to it, not stopping until she was completely immersed in it. Now, perched on what seemed to her friend like the precarious edge of it, she sat comfortably. The path seemed to manage itself and its final descent, but the girl's seat was a rock slab at the end of a short, protruding ledge that jutted out to the right, into open air. Luckily, or perhaps unfortunately, the ledge was completely visible. Mrs. Stringham suppressed a gasp, terrified by what she perceived as the danger of such a position for a young woman. The risk of slipping, sliding, jumping, or being thrown off by a single wrong move, a turn of the head—who could say?—into whatever lay below. A thousand panicked thoughts raced through the poor woman's mind for a moment, but none of them reached Milly. It was a turmoil that left our observer intensely still and holding her breath. The initial thought that came to her was the possibility of a hidden intention—however wild the idea—behind that posture; some secret agreement between Milly's whim and a horrifying, secret obsession. But since Mrs. Stringham stood as still as if any sound would trigger a fatal start, even the passage of a few seconds had a partly reassuring effect. It gave her time to receive an impression which, when she slowly retraced her steps a few minutes later, would be the most vivid she took away with her. This was the impression that if the girl was deeply and recklessly contemplating something there, she wasn’t contemplating a jump; on the contrary, as she sat, she was more in a state of elevated and limitless possession that had nothing to gain from a violent act. She was looking down on all the world, and while that in itself could be overwhelming, she wasn't considering renouncing it. Was she choosing among the kingdoms of the earth, or did she want them all? This question, before Mrs. Stringham had decided what to do, made all others irrelevant. So she realized, or thought she did, that while it might be dangerous to call out, to in any way startle her, it would probably be safe enough to leave as she had come. She watched a little longer, held her breath, and never afterward knew how much time had passed.

Not many minutes probably, yet they had not seemed few, and they had given her so much to think of, not only while creeping home, but while waiting afterwards at the inn, that she was still busy with them when, late in the afternoon, Milly reappeared. She had stopped at the point of the path where the Tauchnitz lay, had taken it up and, with the pencil attached to her watch-guard, had scrawled a word—à bientôt!—across the cover; then, even under the girl's continued delay, had measured time without a return of alarm. For she now saw that the great thing she had brought away was precisely a conviction that the future was not to exist for her princess in the form of any sharp or simple release from the human predicament. It wouldn't be for her a question of a flying leap and thereby of a quick escape. It would be a question of taking full in the face the whole assault of life, to the general muster of which indeed her face might have been directly presented as she sat there on her rock. Mrs. Stringham was thus able to say to herself, even after another interval of some length, that if her young friend still continued absent it wouldn't be because—whatever the opportunity—she had cut short the thread. She wouldn't have committed suicide; she knew herself unmistakably reserved for some more complicated passage; this was the very vision in which she had, with no little awe, been discovered. The image that thus remained with the elder lady kept the character of revelation. During the breathless minutes of her watch she had seen her companion afresh; the latter's type, aspect, marks, her history, her state, her beauty, her mystery, all unconsciously betrayed themselves to the Alpine air, and all had been gathered in again to feed Mrs. Stringham's flame. They are things that will more distinctly appear for us, and they are meanwhile briefly represented by the enthusiasm that was stronger on our friend's part than any doubt. It was a consciousness she was scarce yet used to carrying, but she had as beneath her feet a mine of something precious. She seemed to herself to stand near the mouth, not yet quite cleared. The mine but needed working and would certainly yield a treasure. She was not thinking, either, of Milly's gold.

Translation

It probably wasn't many minutes, but they felt long. Those minutes had given her so much to ponder, not only on her walk home but also while waiting at the inn afterward. She was still preoccupied with them when Milly returned late in the afternoon. Milly had stopped at the path where she’d left the book, picked it up, and written "See you soon!" on the cover with the pencil attached to her watch. Even though the girl was taking a while, Mrs. Stringham wasn't worried. She realized the most important thing she'd taken away was the firm belief that the future wouldn't offer her princess a quick or easy escape from life's challenges. It wouldn't be a matter of a sudden leap and freedom. It would be about bravely facing everything life threw at her, and in fact, her face, as she sat there on the rock, might have been the perfect representation of that general struggle. Mrs. Stringham could tell herself, even after another delay, that if her young friend continued to be absent, it wouldn't be because—whatever the chance—she had ended things. She wouldn't have killed herself. She knew she was destined for something more complex. This was the very image she had, with a touch of awe, come to realize. The image that stayed with the older woman had the quality of a revelation. During those tense minutes of waiting, she had seen her friend anew. Her type, appearance, characteristics, her past, her situation, her beauty, and her mystery all revealed themselves unconsciously in the mountain air and had all been absorbed again to fuel Mrs. Stringham's excitement. These things will become clearer to us, and they are briefly represented by the stronger enthusiasm of our friend than any doubt. It was a feeling she wasn't used to carrying yet, but she felt like she had something incredibly valuable at her feet. She felt like she was standing near the entrance of a mine, which wasn’t quite cleared yet. The mine only needed to be worked and would certainly produce a treasure. She wasn't thinking about Milly's actual wealth, either.

Chapter VI

Chapter Summary & Character Study
Summary

Milly meets Mrs. Stringham and asks if they can leave their current location the next morning instead of stopping there. Mrs. Stringham agrees.

Later, Milly asks Mrs. Stringham what Dr. Finch said to her in a private meeting in New York. Mrs. Stringham replies that the doctor said nothing of consequence. Milly admits she only guessed that the meeting took place. A conversation follows in which Mrs. Stringham asks if Milly is unwell. Milly says she is not in pain but makes several cryptic comments about her life and happiness. When Mrs. Stringham offers to find a doctor, Milly says she will decide on their destination at supper, and then leaves the room.

At supper, Milly announces she wants to go to London. Mrs. Stringham mentions a potential acquaintance there, Mr. Merton Densher, but Milly says he is still in America. Mrs. Stringham then speaks of her own estranged school friend, Maud Manningham (now Mrs. Lowder), who lives in London and suggests she might try to contact her. Milly encourages her to do so and then goes to bed. Alone, Mrs. Stringham gets out her portfolio and writes a letter.

Character Study

Based on the text, here is a concise character study.

### Milly Theale

  • **Presentation:** Milly is introduced as deeply preoccupied and forgetful, signs of a significant internal state that soon surfaces. She is enigmatic and speaks in evasive, almost poetic metaphors when questioned about her well-being, describing her potential ailment as an inability to "resist the bliss of what I have." This behavior perplexes and concerns her companion. She has a "constant white face" but also a "mocking light" in her expression, suggesting a complex mix of physical fragility and sharp intelligence.
  • **Situational Shift:** Milly abruptly moves from a state of passive unease to decisive action. She engineers an immediate change in their travel plans, first urging a departure and then, after a tense and indirect conversation about her health, declaring a specific destination: London. Her stated reason is a sudden, urgent desire for "people," which she connects to a sense that her time may be limited. Her feigned forgetfulness and subsequent contradictory statements about Mr. Densher suggest he is an unstated, significant motive for this shift.

    • ### Mrs. Stringham (Susan Shepherd)

  • **Presentation:** Mrs. Stringham is presented as an intensely observant, intuitive, and accommodating companion. She instantly perceives Milly's distress and agrees to her wishes without question, attempting to ease the situation with gentle humor. She is startled and frightened by Milly’s abrupt questions about the doctor, revealing a protective and deeply caring nature. While she is often "put off" and confused by Milly's cryptic manner, her primary response is always one of earnest, tender concern.
  • **Situational Shift:** Initially a responsive caretaker reacting to Milly's moods, Mrs. Stringham is spurred into a proactive role by the decision to go to London. She seizes the opportunity to propose reconnecting with a long-lost school friend, Maud Lowder. This practical suggestion is revealed to be driven by a more personal motivation: a desire for "poetic justice" after feeling socially "shunted" by Maud years ago. Milly becomes her "trophy," and Mrs. Stringham ends the scene by immediately taking action and writing a letter, shifting from follower to facilitator.

The girl said nothing, when they met, about the words scrawled on the Tauchnitz, and Mrs. Stringham then noticed that she had not the book with her. She had left it lying and probably would never remember it at all. Her comrade's decision was therefore quickly made not to speak of having followed her; and within five minutes of her return, wonderfully enough, the preoccupation denoted by her forgetfulness further declared itself. "Should you think me quite abominable if I were to say that after all——?"

Translation

The girl didn't mention the words written in the Tauchnitz book when they met. Mrs. Stringham then realized the girl didn't even have the book with her. She'd left it somewhere and probably wouldn't even remember it. So, Mrs. Stringham quickly decided not to say anything about having followed her. Amazingly, within five minutes of the girl returning, her forgetfulness indicated she was still preoccupied. "Would you think I'm awful if I said that, after all...?"

Mrs. Stringham had already thought, with the first sound of the question, everything she was capable of thinking, and had immediately made such a sign that Milly's words gave place to visible relief at her assent. "You don't care for our stop here—you'd rather go straight on? We'll start then with the peep of to-morrow's dawn—or as early as you like; it's only rather late now to take the road again." And she smiled to show how she meant it for a joke that an instant onward rush was what the girl would have wished. "I bullied you into stopping," she added; "so it serves me right."

Translation

As soon as Mrs. Stringham heard the question, she'd already considered everything she possibly could, and quickly signaled her agreement. Milly's expression visibly relaxed when she saw this. "You don't want to stay here – you'd rather go straight on? We can leave at dawn tomorrow – or whenever you like. It's just a little late to travel now." And she smiled, as if to suggest that the girl actually wanted to rush off immediately. "I forced you to stop," she added, "so I deserve this."

Milly made in general the most of her good friend's jokes; but she humoured this one a little absently. "Oh yes, you do bully me." And it was thus arranged between them, with no discussion at all, that they would resume their journey in the morning. The younger tourist's interest in the detail of the matter—in spite of a declaration from the elder that she would consent to be dragged anywhere—appeared almost immediately afterwards quite to lose itself; she promised, however, to think till supper of where, with the world all before them, they might go—supper having been ordered for such time as permitted of lighted candles. It had been agreed between them that lighted candles at wayside inns, in strange countries, amid mountain scenery, gave the evening meal a peculiar poetry—such being the mild adventures, the refinements of impression, that they, as they would have said, went in for. It was now as if, before this repast, Milly had designed to "lie down"; but at the end of three minutes more she was not lying down, she was saying instead, abruptly, with a transition that was like a jump of four thousand miles: "What was it that, in New York, on the ninth, when you saw him alone, Dr. Finch said to you?"

Translation

Milly usually enjoyed her friend's jokes, but she responded to this one with a bit of a distracted air. "Oh yes, you do pick on me." And that's how it was settled between them, without any argument, that they'd continue their trip the next day. The younger woman's curiosity about the specifics of their plans – even though the older woman had said she'd go anywhere – seemed to vanish almost instantly. However, she promised to consider where they might go, with the whole world open to them, until dinner. Dinner had been scheduled for when they could have candles. They'd agreed that lit candles in country inns, in foreign lands, surrounded by mountains, added a special beauty to their evening meals – these were the subtle thrills, the heightened experiences they loved. Now, as if before the meal, Milly had been about to "lie down" for a nap, but three minutes later, she wasn't lying down. Instead, she said suddenly, shifting topics as if she’d teleported across the world: "What did Dr. Finch say to you in New York on the ninth, when you saw him alone?"

It was not till later that Mrs. Stringham fully knew why the question had startled her still more than its suddenness explained; though the effect of it even at the moment was almost to frighten her into a false answer. She had to think, to remember the occasion, the "ninth," in New York, the time she had seen Dr. Finch alone, and to recall what he had then said to her; and when everything had come back it was quite, at first, for a moment, as if he had said something that immensely mattered. He hadn't, however, in fact; it was only as if he might perhaps after all have been going to. It was on the sixth—within ten days of their sailing—that she had hurried from Boston under the alarm, a small but a sufficient shock, of hearing that Mildred had suddenly been taken ill, had had, from some obscure cause, such an upset as threatened to stay their journey. The bearing of the accident had happily soon announced itself as slight, and there had been, in the event, but a few hours of anxiety; the journey had been pronounced again not only possible, but, as representing "change," highly advisable; and if the zealous guest had had five minutes by herself with the doctor, that was, clearly, no more at his instance than at her own. Almost nothing had passed between them but an easy exchange of enthusiasms in respect to the remedial properties of "Europe"; and this assurance, as the facts came back to her, she was now able to give. "Nothing whatever, on my word of honour, that you mayn't know or mightn't then have known. I've no secret with him about you. What makes you suspect it? I don't quite make out how you know I did see him alone."

Translation

Mrs. Stringham didn't understand why the question had surprised her so much, even more than its unexpectedness had. The question almost made her give the wrong answer out of fear. She had to pause, think back to the situation, the "ninth" in New York. That's when she had seen Dr. Finch by himself, and had to remember what he'd said to her then. When everything came back to her, it was as if he had said something incredibly important. But he hadn't, not really. It was only as if he possibly might have, in the end. It was on the sixth – within ten days of their departure – that she had rushed from Boston, alarmed, a small but significant shock, to hear that Mildred had suddenly fallen ill. Mildred had been hit with some mysterious sickness that threatened to make them cancel their trip. Luckily, the problem quickly proved not serious, and there were only a few hours of worry. The trip was declared possible again, and even highly recommended as a “change of scenery”. If the eager guest had had five minutes alone with the doctor, it was clearly because she wanted to, just as much as he did. Almost nothing was said between them, just an easy discussion of how amazing "Europe" was for recovery, and as she remembered, she could now confirm that. “Honestly, there was nothing you don’t know, or that you couldn’t have known back then. I have no secrets with him about you. Why do you suspect it? I'm not sure how you know I saw him alone.”

"No—you never told me," said Milly. "And I don't mean," she went on, "during the twenty-four hours while I was bad, when your putting your heads together was natural enough. I mean after I was better—the last thing before you went home."

Translation

"No, you never told me," Milly said. "And I don't mean during the twenty-four hours when I was sick, when you all probably needed to talk. I mean after I got better – right before you left."

Mrs. Stringham continued to wonder. "Who told you I saw him then?"

Translation

"Mrs. Stringham kept wondering. "So, who told you I saw him?"

"He didn't himself—nor did you write me it afterwards. We speak of it now for the first time. That's exactly why!" Milly declared—with something in her face and voice that, the next moment, betrayed for her companion that she had really known nothing, had only conjectured and, chancing her charge, made a hit. Yet why had her mind been busy with the question? "But if you're not, as you now assure me, in his confidence," she smiled, "it's no matter."

Translation

"You didn't tell me, and you didn't write to me about it later. This is the first time we're talking about it. That's the whole reason!" Milly said, her expression and tone revealing to her friend in the next moment that she actually didn't know anything for sure. She had only guessed and, by chance, gotten it right. But why had she been thinking about it? "But if, as you're telling me now, he didn't confide in you, then it doesn't matter," she smiled.

"I'm not in his confidence, and he had nothing to confide. But are you feeling unwell?"

Translation

I don't know his secrets, and he didn't share anything with me. But are you feeling sick?

The elder woman was earnest for the truth, though the possibility she named was not at all the one that seemed to fit—witness the long climb Milly had just indulged in. The girl showed her constant white face, but that her friends had all learned to discount, and it was often brightest when superficially not bravest. She continued for a little mysteriously to smile. "I don't know—haven't really the least idea. But it might be well to find out."

Translation

The older woman was genuinely seeking the truth, even though the scenario she suggested didn't seem to make sense, considering the long, tiring climb Milly had just done. The girl's face was always pale, something her friends were used to, and it often looked its best when she appeared outwardly unconfident. She kept smiling mysteriously for a moment. "I don't know – I truly have no idea. But it might be worth investigating."

Mrs. Stringham, at this, flared into sympathy. "Are you in trouble—in pain?"

Translation

Mrs. Stringham immediately felt sympathetic.

"Are you having a problem – are you hurting?"

"Not the least little bit. But I sometimes wonder——!"

Translation

Not at all. But sometimes I do wonder!

"Yes"—she pressed: "wonder what?"

Translation

"Yes," she insisted, "I'm curious, what?"

"Well, if I shall have much of it."

Translation

Okay, if I get a lot of it.

Mrs. Stringham stared. "Much of what? Not of pain?"

Translation

Mrs. Stringham stared. "What do you mean? Not about the pain?"

"Of everything. Of everything I have."

Translation

Everything. Everything I own.

Anxiously again, tenderly, our friend cast about. "You 'have' everything; so that when you say 'much' of it——"

Translation

Our friend looked around anxiously and then with tenderness.

"You have everything, so when you talk about

how much of it--"

"I only mean," the girl broke in, "shall I have it for long? That is if I have got it."

Translation

"I just mean," the girl interrupted, "will I have it for a long time? That is, if I even have it."

She had at present the effect, a little, of confounding, or at least of perplexing her comrade, who was touched, who was always touched, by something helpless in her grace and abrupt in her turns, and yet actually half made out in her a sort of mocking light. "If you've got an ailment?"

Translation

Right now, she was kind of confusing, or at least making her friend uneasy. He was moved, always moved, by the vulnerability in her elegance and the sudden changes in her moods. But he also sensed a mocking attitude in her. "Are you sick or something?"

"If I've got everything," Milly laughed.

Translation

"If I have everything," Milly laughed.

"Ah, that—like almost nobody else."

Translation

Oh, he's basically one of a kind.

"Then for how long?"

Translation

So, for how long?

Mrs. Stringham's eyes entreated her; she had gone close to her, half enclosed her with urgent arms. "Do you want to see some one?" And then as the girl only met it with a slow headshake, though looking perhaps a shade more conscious: "We'll go straight to the best near doctor." This too, however, produced but a gaze of qualified assent and a silence, sweet and vague, that left everything open. Our friend decidedly lost herself. "Tell me, for God's sake, if you're in distress."

Translation

Mrs. Stringham's eyes pleaded with her; she'd gotten right up close, almost embracing her with worried arms. "Do you need to see someone?" And then, when the girl just shook her head slowly, though she seemed a little more aware: "We'll go straight to the best doctor nearby." But that also just got a hesitant nod and a silence, pleasant and unclear, that left everything uncertain. Our friend was clearly at a loss. "Tell me, please, are you in trouble?"

"I don't think I've really everything," Milly said as if to explain—and as if also to put it pleasantly.

Translation

"I don't think I've really *done* everything," Milly said, trying to explain and also trying to sound nice about it.

"But what on earth can I do for you?" The girl hesitated, then seemed on the point of being able to say; but suddenly changed and expressed herself otherwise. "Dear, dear thing—I'm only too happy!"

Translation

"But what can I do for you?"

The girl paused, as if she was about to speak, but then changed her mind and said something different. "Oh, that's so kind – I'm just thrilled!"

It brought them closer, but it rather confirmed Mrs. Stringham's doubt. "Then what's the matter?"

Translation

It made them more intimate, but it actually reinforced Mrs. Stringham's suspicions. "So, what's wrong?"

"That's the matter—that I can scarcely bear it."

Translation

That's the problem - I can hardly stand it.

"But what is it you think you haven't got?"

Translation

But what do you think you're missing?

Milly waited another moment; then she found it, and found for it a dim show of joy. "The power to resist the bliss of what I have!"

Translation

Milly hesitated a moment longer, then found the thing she was looking for and feigned a small amount of happiness. "The strength to refuse the pleasure of what I possess!"

Mrs. Stringham took it in—her sense of being "put off" with it, the possible, probable irony of it—and her tenderness renewed itself in the positive grimness of a long murmur. "Whom will you see?"—for it was as if they looked down from their height at a continent of doctors. "Where will you first go?"

Translation

Mrs. Stringham understood – her feeling of being "put off" by the situation, the likely, even probable sarcasm behind it – and her affection for him welled up again, expressed in a long, quiet, determined grumble. "Who are you going to see?" – as if they were looking down from a great height at a whole world of doctors. "Where will you go first?"

Milly had for the third time her air of consideration; but she came back with it to her plea of some minutes before. "I'll tell you at supper—good-bye till then."
