And she left the room with a lightness that testified for her companion to something that again particularly pleased her in the renewed promise of motion. The odd passage just concluded, Mrs. Stringham mused as she once more sat alone with a hooked needle and a ball of silk, the "fine" work with which she was always provided—this mystifying mood had simply been precipitated, no doubt, by their prolonged halt, with which the girl hadn't really been in sympathy. One had only to admit that her complaint was in fact but the excess of the joy of life, and everything did then fit. She couldn't stop for the joy, but she could go on for it, and with the sense of going on she floated again, was restored to her great spaces. There was no evasion of any truth—so at least Susan Shepherd hoped—in one's sitting there while the twilight deepened and feeling still more finely that the position of this young lady was magnificent. The evening at that height had naturally turned to cold, and the travellers had bespoken a fire with their meal; the great Alpine road asserted its brave presence through the small panes of the low, clean windows, with incidents at the inn-door, the yellow diligence, the great waggons, the hurrying, hooded, private conveyances, reminders, for our fanciful friend, of old stories, old pictures, historic flights, escapes, pursuits, things that had happened, things indeed that by a sort of strange congruity helped her to read the meanings of the greatest interest into the relation in which she was now so deeply involved. It was natural that this record of the magnificence of her companion's position should strike her as, after all, the best meaning she could extract; for she herself was seated in the magnificence as in a court-carriage—she came back to that, and such a method of progression, such a view from crimson cushions, would evidently have a great deal more to give. By the time the candles were lighted for supper and the short, white curtains were drawn, Milly had reappeared, and the little scenic room had then all its romance. That charm moreover was far from broken by the words in which she, without further loss of time, satisfied her patient mate. "I want to go straight to London."

Translation

Milly adopted her thoughtful expression for the third time, but she immediately returned to her earlier request. "I'll tell you at supper—goodbye until then." She left the room with a carefree energy that suggested to her companion that something about the renewed promise of movement particularly pleased her. Mrs. Stringham pondered the strange conversation she'd just had as she sat alone again with her needle and silk, her "fine" needlework that she always kept with her. This puzzling mood, she thought, was probably just caused by their extended stop, which the girl hadn't really liked. You just had to accept that Milly's restlessness was actually an overflow of her joy for life, and then everything made sense. She couldn't pause for the joy, but she could continue moving for it, and the feeling of continuing allowed her to float again, returning her to a sense of freedom. There was no avoiding the truth—at least, that's what Susan Shepherd hoped—as she sat there while twilight deepened, feeling even more acutely that this young lady was in an extraordinary situation.

The evening had naturally turned cold at that altitude, and the travelers had requested a fire with their meal. The grand Alpine road made its presence known through the small panes of the low, clean windows. The activity at the inn door—the yellow stagecoach, the large wagons, the hurried, covered private carriages—reminded our imaginative friend of old stories, old pictures, historic escapes, chases, and things that had happened. These events, strangely enough, helped her to find the most interesting meanings in the relationship in which she was now deeply involved. It was natural that this record of her companion's magnificent situation should strike her as the best meaning she could find. She herself was seated in this magnificence, as if in a fancy carriage—she kept returning to that image, and this method of travel, this view from luxurious cushions, would obviously offer her much more.

By the time the candles were lit for supper and the short, white curtains were drawn, Milly had returned, and the small, picturesque room was filled with romance. That charm was not diminished by the words with which she, without delay, satisfied her patient friend. "I want to go straight to London."

It was unexpected, corresponding with no view positively taken at their departure; when England had appeared, on the contrary, rather relegated and postponed—seen for the moment, as who should say, at the end of an avenue of preparations and introductions. London, in short, might have been supposed to be the crown, and to be achieved like a siege by gradual approaches. Milly's actual fine stride was therefore the more exciting, as any simplification almost always was to Mrs. Stringham; who, besides, was afterwards to recall as the very beginning of a drama the terms in which, between their smoky candles, the girl had put her preference and in which still other things had come up, come while the clank of waggon-chains in the sharp air reached their ears, with the stamp of hoofs, the rattle of buckets and the foreign questions, foreign answers, that were all alike a part of the cheery converse of the road. The girl brought it out in truth as she might have brought a huge confession, something she admitted herself shy about and that would seem to show her as frivolous; it had rolled over her that what she wanted of Europe was "people," so far as they were to be had, and that if her friend really wished to know, the vision of this same equivocal quantity was what had haunted her during their previous days, in museums and churches, and what was again spoiling for her the pure taste of scenery. She was all for scenery—yes; but she wanted it human and personal, and all she could say was that there would be in London—wouldn't there? more of that kind than anywhere else. She came back to her idea that if it wasn't for long—if nothing should happen to be so for her—why, the particular thing she spoke of would probably have most to give her in the time, would probably be less than anything else a waste of her remainder. She produced this last consideration indeed with such gaiety that Mrs. Stringham was not again disconcerted by it, was in fact quite ready—if talk of early dying was in order—to match it from her own future. Good, then; they would, eat and drink because of what might happen to-morrow; and they would direct their course from that moment with a view to such eating and drinking. They ate and drank that night, in truth, as if in the spirit of this decision; whereby the air, before they separated, felt itself the clearer.

Translation

It was surprising, because it wasn't what they'd planned when they left. England had seemed, in fact, to be put off, delayed—something that would come later, after all the preliminary steps. In other words, London was supposed to be the ultimate goal, something they'd reach gradually, like a city under siege. So, Milly's sudden, direct move there was even more exciting, as any shortcut always was to Mrs. Stringham. Mrs. Stringham also remembered this as the very beginning of a story, recalling the way the girl, by the light of their flickering candles, had expressed her preference. Other things came up too, as the sounds of wagon chains, horses' hooves, and buckets filled the cold air, along with the foreign questions and answers that were just part of the lively chatter of the road. The girl revealed it all almost as if it were a major confession, something she felt embarrassed about, as though it made her seem superficial. It had suddenly hit her that what she wanted from Europe, as much as possible, was "people." If her friend really wanted to know, the thought of these people was what had been on her mind during their earlier days, in museums and churches, and what was now ruining her enjoyment of the scenery. She did love the scenery, yes, but she wanted it to be connected to people, and all she could say was that there would be more of that in London—wouldn't there?—than anywhere else. She returned to her belief that if her time was short—if something happened to her—then this particular thing she was talking about would probably give her the most in the time she had left, and would probably be less of a waste of her remaining time than anything else. She said this last part so cheerfully that Mrs. Stringham wasn't upset by it, and, in fact, was ready—if talking about dying young was the subject—to offer her own similar thoughts about her own future. Fine, then; they would eat and drink because of what might happen tomorrow; and from that moment on, they would plan their trip with that goal in mind. They did eat and drink that night, as if they were truly committed to this decision; and before they separated, the air felt lighter.

It had cleared perhaps to a view only too extensive—extensive, that is, in proportion to the signs of life presented. The idea of "people" was not so entertained on Milly's part as to connect itself with particular persons, and the fact remained for each of the ladies that they would, completely unknown, disembark at Dover amid the completely unknowing. They had no relation already formed; this plea Mrs. Stringham put forward to see what it would produce. It produced nothing at first but the observation on the girl's side that what she had in mind was no thought of society nor of scraping acquaintance; nothing was further from her than to desire the opportunities represented for the compatriot in general by a trunkful of "letters." It wasn't a question, in short, of the people the compatriot was after; it was the human, the English picture itself, as they might see it in their own way—the world imagined always in what one had read and dreamed. Mrs. Stringham did every justice to this world, but when later on an occasion chanced to present itself, she made a point of not omitting to remark that it might be a comfort to know in advance even an individual. This still, however, failed in vulgar parlance, to "fetch" Milly, so that she had presently to go all the way. "Haven't I understood from you, for that matter, that you gave Mr. Densher something of a promise?"

Translation

The view had cleared, maybe a little *too* much. It was expansive, I mean, considering how few signs of life there were. Milly wasn't thinking about "people" in a way that involved specific individuals. The fact remained for both women: they would arrive in Dover, completely strangers, among people who didn't know them at all. They didn't have any connections yet. That was Mrs. Stringham's point, to see what would come of it. At first, it produced nothing except Milly's remark that she wasn't thinking about socializing or making small talk. Nothing could be further from her mind than pursuing the social opportunities that having a suitcase full of "letters" would bring to the average American. In short, she wasn't looking for the kinds of people an American might be after. She was interested in the human, English experience itself, how they might see it their own way—the world always imagined through what they had read and dreamed. Mrs. Stringham appreciated this perspective. But later, when the opportunity arose, she made it a point to say that it might be helpful to know even one person beforehand. This still, to put it plainly, didn't "click" with Milly. So Mrs. Stringham had to go further: "Didn't you tell me that you gave Mr. Densher some sort of a promise?"

There was a moment, on this, when Milly's look had to be taken as representing one of two things—either that she was completely vague about the promise or that Mr. Densher's name itself started no train. But she really couldn't be so vague about the promise, her interlocutress quickly saw, without attaching it to something; it had to be a promise to somebody in particular to be so repudiated. In the event, accordingly, she acknowledged Mr. Merton Densher, the so unusually clever young Englishman who had made his appearance in New York on some special literary business—wasn't it?—shortly before their departure, and who had been three or four times in her house during the brief period between her visit to Boston and her companion's subsequent stay with her; but she required much reminding before it came back to her that she had mentioned to this companion just afterwards the confidence expressed by the personage in question in her never doing so dire a thing as to come to London without, as the phrase was, looking a fellow up. She had left him the enjoyment of his confidence, the form of which might have appeared a trifle free—that she now reasserted; she had done nothing either to impair or to enhance it; but she had also left Mrs. Stringham, in the connection and at the time, rather sorry to have missed Mr. Densher. She had thought of him again after that, the elder woman; she had likewise gone so far as to notice that Milly appeared not to have done so—which the girl might easily have betrayed; and, interested as she was in everything that concerned her, she had made out for herself, for herself only and rather idly, that, but for interruptions, the young Englishman might have become a better acquaintance. His being an acquaintance at all was one of the signs that in the first days had helped to place Milly, as a young person with the world before her, for sympathy and wonder. Isolated, unmothered, unguarded, but with her other strong marks, her big house, her big fortune, her big freedom, she had lately begun to "receive," for all her few years, as an older woman might have done—as was done, precisely, by princesses who had public considerations to observe and who came of age very early. If it was thus distinct to Mrs. Stringham then that Mr. Densher had gone off somewhere else in connection with his errand before her visit to New York, it had been also not undiscoverable that he had come back for a day or two later on, that is after her own second excursion—that he had in fine reappeared on a single occasion on his way to the West: his way from Washington as she believed, though he was out of sight at the time of her joining her friend for their departure. It had not occurred to her before to exaggerate—it had not occurred to her that she could; but she seemed to become aware to-night that there had been just enough in this relation to meet, to provoke, the free conception of a little more.

Translation

For a moment, it seemed Milly's reaction could mean one of two things: either she completely forgot about the promise, or the name "Mr. Densher" didn't ring any bells. However, her friend quickly realized Milly couldn't be so vague without linking the promise to something. It had to be a promise to a specific person to be rejected like that. So, Milly acknowledged Mr. Merton Densher, the exceptionally intelligent young Englishman who had arrived in New York for some literary work shortly before they left, and who had visited her several times during the short time between her trip to Boston and her companion's subsequent stay. But she needed a lot of prompting to remember that she'd mentioned to her companion afterward that Mr. Densher was confident she wouldn't do something so awful as come to London without, as they said, looking him up. Milly had let him enjoy that confidence, the casualness of which she now acknowledged. She hadn't done anything to encourage or discourage it. However, she also remembered that Mrs. Stringham, at the time, had been a bit disappointed to have missed Mr. Densher. The older woman had thought about him again later, and she had also noticed that Milly didn't seem to have given him any thought—something the girl could easily have revealed. Mrs. Stringham, being interested in everything related to Milly, had privately and somewhat casually concluded that, without interruptions, the young Englishman might have become a better friend. His being an acquaintance at all was one of the signs that had helped establish Milly as a young woman with a world of possibilities before her, someone to be admired and pitied. Alone, without a mother, unprotected, but with her other advantages—her large house, her great wealth, her freedom—she had recently begun "receiving," as older women did, like princesses who had public duties and matured very quickly. If Mrs. Stringham understood that Mr. Densher had left for another location for his work before her trip to New York, she also realized that he had returned for a day or two afterward—that is, after her second trip—and had, in short, reappeared only once on his way West: on his way from Washington, she believed, though she didn't see him when she met her friend to leave. She hadn't thought to overstate the situation before tonight, or thought she could. But tonight she realized there had been just enough in their relationship to invite, to encourage, the idea of something more.

She presently put it that, at any rate, promise or no promise, Milly would, at a pinch, be able, in London, to act on his permission to make him a sign; to which Milly replied with readiness that her ability, though evident, would be none the less quite wasted, inasmuch as the gentleman would, to a certainty, be still in America. He had a great deal to do there—which he would scarce have begun; and in fact she might very well not have thought of London at all if she hadn't been sure he wasn't yet near coming back. It was perceptible to her companion that the moment our young woman had so far committed herself she had a sense of having overstepped; which was not quite patched up by her saying the next minute, possibly with a certain failure of presence of mind, that the last thing she desired was the air of running after him. Mrs. Stringham wondered privately what question there could be of any such appearance—the danger of which thus suddenly came up; but she said, for the time, nothing of it—she only said other things: one of which was, for instance, that if Mr. Densher was away he was away, and that this was the end of it; also that of course they must be discreet at any price. But what was the measure of discretion, and how was one to be sure? So it was that, as they sat there, she produced her own case: she had a possible tie with London, which she desired as little to disown as she might wish to risk presuming on it. She treated her companion, in short, for their evening's end, to the story of Maud Manningham, the odd but interesting English girl who had formed her special affinity in the old days at the Vevey school; whom she had written to, after their separation, with a regularity that had at first faltered and then altogether failed, yet that had been for the time quite a fine case of crude constancy; so that it had in fact flickered up again of itself on the occasion of the marriage of each. They had then once more fondly, scrupulously written—Mrs. Lowder first; and even another letter or two had afterwards passed. This, however, had been the end—though with no rupture, only a gentle drop: Maud Manningham had made, she believed, a great marriage, while she herself had made a small; on top of which, moreover, distance, difference, diminished community and impossible reunion had done the rest of the work. It was but after all these years that reunion had begun to show as possible—if the other party to it, that is, should be still in existence. That was exactly what it now struck our friend as interesting to ascertain, as, with one aid and another, she believed she might. It was an experiment she would at all events now make if Milly didn't object.

Translation

She then stated that, regardless of any promises, Milly could, if necessary, use his permission to signal him in London. Milly readily replied that, although she could do it, it wouldn't matter because he would definitely still be in America. He had a lot to do there, which he probably hadn't even started. In fact, she might not have even thought about London if she wasn't certain he wasn't coming back soon. Her friend noticed that as soon as Milly said this, she seemed to realize she'd said too much. Her next comment, maybe a little flustered, didn't really fix it: that the last thing she wanted was to seem like she was chasing after him. Mrs. Stringham privately wondered why there was any concern about appearing that way, but she said nothing about it then. She just said other things: for instance, that if Mr. Densher was away, he was away, and that was that. Also, that they of course had to be discreet. But how discreet was discreet, and how could they be sure? So, as they sat there, she told her own story: she had a possible connection to London that she didn't want to deny, but also didn't want to presume upon. She shared the story of Maud Manningham, the peculiar but interesting English girl who had been her close friend at school in Vevey. After they parted, she had written to her regularly, though it had eventually stopped, but it was a sign of real devotion at the time; in fact, the letters had started up again around each of their weddings. They had then written to each other again with affection and care—Mrs. Lowder first—and even sent a couple more letters after that. But then it ended, though not with a fight, just a gradual fade. Maud Manningham had, she thought, married into wealth, while she herself had married into less; and on top of that, distance, different lives, less in common, and no chance of getting back together had finished it off. But after all these years, a reunion seemed possible—if the other person, that is, was still alive. That was exactly what she now found interesting to find out, and she believed she could with some help. She was going to try it now, unless Milly objected.

Milly in general objected to nothing, and, though she asked a question or two, she raised no present plea. Her questions—or at least her own answers to them—kindled, on Mrs. Stringham's part, a backward train: she hadn't known till tonight how much she remembered, or how fine it might be to see what had become of large, high-coloured Maud, florid, exotic and alien—which had been just the spell—even to the perceptions of youth. There was the danger—she frankly touched it—that such a temperament mightn't have matured, with the years, all in the sense of fineness; it was the sort of danger that, in renewing relations after long breaks, one had always to look in the face. To gather in strayed threads was to take a risk—for which, however, she was prepared if Milly was. The possible "fun," she confessed, was by itself rather tempting; and she fairly sounded, with this—wound up a little as she was—the note of fun as the harmless final right of fifty years of mere New England virtue. Among the things she was afterwards to recall was the indescribable look dropped on her, at this, by her companion; she was still seated there between the candles and before the finished supper, while Milly moved about, and the look was long to figure for her as an inscrutable comment on her notion of freedom. Challenged, at any rate, as for the last wise word, Milly showed perhaps, musingly, charmingly, that, though her attention had been mainly soundless, her friend's story—produced as a resource unsuspected, a card from up the sleeve—half surprised, half beguiled her. Since the matter, such as it was, depended on that, she brought out, before she went to bed, an easy, a light "Risk everything!"

Translation

Milly was generally agreeable and didn't object to anything, though she asked a few questions. She didn't voice any immediate concerns. Her questions – or at least her own answers – triggered a flood of memories in Mrs. Stringham. She hadn't realized until that evening how much she remembered, or how interesting it would be to see what had become of the vibrant, exotic, and different Maud. That difference had been part of her allure, even when they were young. There was a risk, she admitted frankly, that such a fiery personality might not have developed gracefully with age. It was a risk you had to face when reconnecting with someone after a long time apart. Reconnecting and gathering up old friendships always carried a chance of disappointment, but she was willing to take that chance if Milly was. The potential "fun," she confessed, was quite tempting in itself, and she almost reveled in this – fueled by a little excitement – as the harmless final reward of a lifetime of simple, moral living. One of the things she would later remember was the indescribable look Milly gave her at this moment. Mrs. Stringham was still sitting there between the candles, the supper finished, while Milly moved around. That look would linger in her memory as a mysterious comment on her idea of freedom. It was as if Milly was offering the final, wise word. Milly seemed to show, thoughtfully and charmingly, that although she'd been mostly quiet, her friend's story—presented as an unexpected option, a secret weapon—had partly surprised and partly charmed her. Since the whole thing depended on Milly's willingness, she said easily and lightly, before going to bed, "Risk everything!"

This quality in it seemed possibly a little to deny weight to Maud Lowder's evoked presence—as Susan Stringham, still sitting up, became, in excited reflection, a trifle more conscious. Something determinant, when the girl had left her, took place in her—nameless but, as soon as she had given way, coercive. It was as if she knew again, in this fulness of time, that she had been, after Maud's marriage, just sensibly outlived or, as people nowadays said, shunted. Mrs. Lowder had left her behind, and on the occasion, subsequently, of the corresponding date in her own life—not the second, the sad one, with its dignity of sadness, but the first, with the meagreness of its supposed felicity—she had been, in the same spirit, almost patronisingly pitied. If that suspicion, even when it had ceased to matter, had never quite died out for her, there was doubtless some oddity in its now offering itself as a link, rather than as another break, in the chain; and indeed there might well have been for her a mood in which the notion of the development of patronage in her quondam schoolmate would have settled her question in another sense. It was actually settled—if the case be worth our analysis—by the happy consummation, the poetic justice, the generous revenge, of her having at last something to show. Maud, on their parting company, had appeared to have so much, and would now—for wasn't it also, in general, quite the rich law of English life?—have, with accretions, promotions, expansions, ever so much more. Very good; such things might be; she rose to the sense of being ready for them. Whatever Mrs. Lowder might have to show—and one hoped one did the presumptions all justice—she would have nothing like Milly Theale, who constituted the trophy producible by poor Susan. Poor Susan lingered late—till the candles were low, and as soon as the table was cleared she opened her neat portfolio. She had not lost the old clue; there were connections she remembered, addresses she could try; so the thing was to begin. She wrote on the spot.

Translation

This aspect of it seemed perhaps to diminish the significance of Maud Lowder's presence in her memory—as Susan Stringham, still awake and sitting up, became a little more aware of it, and a bit excited, as she reflected. Something decisive, which she couldn't name, took hold of her as soon as the girl had left—but it was compelling. It was as if, now, at this moment, she understood again that after Maud's marriage, she had just been, in a sensible way, left behind, or, as people say today, sidelined. Mrs. Lowder had outpaced her, and on the occasion of the anniversary of her own life—not the second, sad one, with its dignified sadness, but the first, with its supposedly meager happiness—she had been, in a similar spirit, almost condescendingly pitied. Even though that feeling had faded, it had never completely vanished; and there was probably something strange in it now appearing as a connection, rather than another barrier, in their relationship. Indeed, she might well have been in a frame of mind where the idea of her former schoolmate gaining power would have answered her question in a different way. But the matter was actually settled—if it's worth our examining—by the joyful fulfillment, the poetic justice, the satisfying revenge, of having something to show for herself. Maud, when they had last met, seemed to have so much, and now—because wasn't it also, generally, the rich pattern of English life?—she would have, with added wealth, advancement, and influence, even more. Very well; those things might be; Susan felt ready to face them. Whatever Mrs. Lowder might have to show—and she hoped she was fairly assessing the situation—she wouldn't have anything like Milly Theale, who represented the achievement that poor Susan could now display. Poor Susan stayed up late—until the candles were low, and as soon as the table was cleared she opened her neat portfolio. She hadn't lost the old idea; there were connections she remembered, addresses she could try; so the task was to begin. She wrote immediately.

BOOK FOURTH

### EXTRACTED HEADER: BOOK FOURTH

Chapter VII

Chapter Summary & Character Study
Summary

Milly and her companion, Susie Stringham, are at a dinner party at Lancaster Gate, hosted by Mrs. Lowder. Milly is seated next to a gentleman, Lord Mark, and tells him she barely knows where she is. There are twenty people at the table.

Before dinner, Mrs. Lowder's niece, Kate Croy, introduced Lord Mark to Milly, and he escorted her to the table. During the meal, Milly observes Kate across the table, and their eyes meet.

Milly and Lord Mark have a long conversation. He tells her that London society has no real "sets," calls Mrs. Lowder an "extraordinary woman," and says Kate is "tremendously... good-looking." Milly recounts to him that Mrs. Lowder invited them to dine soon after their arrival and visited their hotel with Kate.

Lord Mark tells Milly that she is a social success and is being "jumped at." He asks what Mrs. Lowder knows about her, and says he will observe what Mrs. Lowder "does with" her. When Milly asks what their hostess knows about him, he says "Nothing," and that Milly is now Mrs. Lowder's best new acquisition. Milly asks what he meant by Mrs. Lowder doing something with her, and he replies that she will "get her money back" because "nobody here, you know, does anything for nothing."

Milly calls Mrs. Lowder an idealist. She tells Lord Mark that he and the others are familiar with everything but have no imagination. She then asks him what Kate has to gain from being welcoming to her. As she asks, Kate looks over at them. Lord Mark replies that Kate gains Milly’s acquaintance. Milly suggests Kate's motive is pity. Lord Mark says he is not sorry for Milly at all. He admits he does not understand Kate and asks Milly to tell him about her when she knows more. Milly concludes that Kate must be difficult, while she herself is easy.

Character Study

Based on the text, here is a concise character study:

  • *Milly Theale**
    • Milly is presented as a highly sensitive and observant American, newly thrust into a sophisticated English social scene. Her situation has shifted with dizzying speed from that of a tourist to the center of attention at a formal dinner, leaving her feeling disoriented yet exhilarated. She is acutely conscious of being evaluated, analyzing everyone around her while aware that she herself is being "jumped at." She is prone to seeing her situation in romantic terms ("fairy-tale") but is also immediately perceptive of complex social dynamics and "possibly sinister motive."
  • *Susie (Mrs. Stringham)**
    • Milly's companion, Susie, is presented through Milly's eyes as a triumphant "fairy godmother." Her situation has shifted from being a traveling friend to the successful orchestrator of Milly's social debut. She now "glitters" with a sense of success, content with the results of her efforts.
  • *Lord Mark**
    • Lord Mark is Milly's dinner partner and is presented as a collection of contradictions: he looks both old and young, seems both "intellectual" and "frivolous," and acts both clever and indifferent. As a member of the aristocracy, he is world-weary and speaks cynically of London society, yet he is also perceptive. He immediately categorizes Milly as a predictable American "type" but also declares her a "success," engaging her in a probing, almost intimate conversation.
  • *Kate Croy**
    • Referred to as "the handsome girl," Kate is presented primarily through her striking beauty and "eminence." She is positioned as a figure of great interest and mystery. Though she appears "charming" and "frankly conscious" of friendship, Milly senses she is a complex individual whom even insiders like Lord Mark cannot "make out." Her situation is that of an established social figure who immediately fascinates the newcomer, Milly.
  • *Mrs. Lowder**
The hostess is presented as a powerful and substantial figure, described as "massive" and a "great reality." Her situation has shifted from being a distant acquaintance of Susie's to the formidable architect of the evening. She is perceived by Milly as an "idealist," but there are immediate hints that she is a pragmatic social operator who is using Lord Mark to assess Milly's "value."

It had all gone so fast after this that Milly uttered but the truth nearest to hand in saying to the gentleman on her right—who was, by the same token, the gentleman on her hostess's left—that she scarce even then knew where she was: the words marking her first full sense of a situation really romantic. They were already dining, she and her friend, at Lancaster Gate, and surrounded, as it seemed to her, with every English accessory; though her consciousness of Mrs. Lowder's existence, and still more of her remarkable identity, had been of so recent and so sudden a birth. Susie, as she was apt to call her companion for a lighter change, had only had to wave a neat little wand for the fairy-tale to begin at once; in consequence of which Susie now glittered—for, with Mrs. Stringham's new sense of success, it came to that—in the character of a fairy godmother. Milly had almost insisted on dressing her, for the present occasion, as one; and it was no fault of the girl's if the good lady had not now appeared in a peaked hat, a short petticoat and diamond shoe-buckles, brandishing the magic crutch. The good lady, in truth, bore herself not less contentedly than if these insignia had marked her work; and Milly's observation to Lord Mark had just been, doubtless, the result of such a light exchange of looks with her as even the great length of the table had not baffled. There were twenty persons between them, but this sustained passage was the sharpest sequel yet to that other comparison of views during the pause on the Swiss pass. It almost appeared to Milly that their fortune had been unduly precipitated—as if, properly, they were in the position of having ventured on a small joke and found the answer out of proportion grave. She could not at this moment, for instance, have said whether, with her quickened perceptions, she were more enlivened or oppressed; and the case might in fact have been serious had she not, by good fortune, from the moment the picture loomed, quickly made up her mind that what finally most concerned her was neither to seek nor to shirk, was not even to wonder too much, but was to let things come as they would, since there was little enough doubt of how they would go.

Translation

Everything happened so quickly after that that Milly simply blurted out the first thing that came to mind to the man on her right – who also happened to be sitting on her hostess’s left – saying that she hardly even knew where she was. Those words were her first real acknowledgement of how incredibly romantic the situation felt. They were already at dinner, she and her friend, at Lancaster Gate, surrounded, as it seemed to her, by all things English. Even though she’d only just become aware of Mrs. Lowder’s presence, and even more so of her striking personality, it had all happened so suddenly. Susie, as she often called her friend to be more casual, had only had to wave her hand, and the fairytale began at once. As a result, Susie now glowed, because, with Mrs. Stringham’s newfound success, it really came down to that – in the role of a fairy godmother. Milly had almost insisted on dressing her, for this occasion, as one, and it was only through no fault of Susie’s that the good lady wasn’t currently wearing a pointed hat, a short petticoat, diamond shoe buckles, and waving a magic crutch.

In truth, the good lady seemed as pleased as if she were wearing those things to signify her efforts. Milly’s comment to Lord Mark had surely been prompted by a quick exchange of glances with Susie, a connection that the long table hadn’t managed to interrupt. Even though there were twenty people between them, this subtle conversation was the most obvious result of their earlier discussion while they paused on the Swiss pass.

Milly almost felt as though their fortunes had been rushed, as if they’d made a small joke and received a disproportionately serious response. She couldn’t say at that moment, with her sharper awareness, whether she was more excited or overwhelmed. It might actually have been a serious issue, if she hadn’t, luckily, decided from the moment the situation became clear that the most important thing was neither to seek nor to avoid, not even to overthink it. Instead, she chose to let things unfold as they would, since she had little doubt how they would turn out.

Lord Mark had been brought to her before dinner—not by Mrs. Lowder, but by the handsome girl, that lady's niece, who was now at the other end and on the same side as Susie; he had taken her in, and she meant presently to ask him about Miss Croy, the handsome girl, actually offered to her sight—though now in a splendid way—but for the second time. The first time had been the occasion—only three days before—of her calling at their hotel with her aunt and then making, for our other two heroines, a great impression of beauty and eminence. This impression had remained so with Milly that, at present, and although her attention was aware at the same time of everything else, her eyes were mainly engaged with Kate Croy when not engaged with Susie. That wonderful creature's eyes moreover readily met them—she ranked now as a wonderful creature; and it seemed a part of the swift prosperity of the American visitors that, so little in the original reckoning, she should yet appear conscious, charmingly, frankly conscious, of possibilities of friendship for them. Milly had easily and, as a guest, gracefully generalised: English girls had a special, strong beauty, and it particularly showed in evening dress—above all when, as was strikingly the case with this one, the dress itself was what it should be. That observation she had all ready for Lord Mark when they should, after a little, get round to it. She seemed even now to see that there might be a good deal they would get round to; the indication being that, taken up once for all with her other neighbour, their hostess would leave them much to themselves. Mrs. Lowder's other neighbour was the Bishop of Murrum—a real bishop, such as Milly had never seen, with a complicated costume, a voice like an old-fashioned wind instrument, and a face all the portrait of a prelate; while the gentleman on our young lady's left, a gentleman thick-necked, large and literal, who looked straight before him and as if he were not to be diverted by vain words from that pursuit, clearly counted as an offset to the possession of Lord Mark. As Milly made out these things—with a shade of exhilaration at the way she already fell in—she saw how she was justified of her plea for people and her love of life. It wasn't then, as the prospect seemed to show, so difficult to get into the current, or to stand, at any rate, on the bank. It was easy to get near—if they were near; and yet the elements were different enough from any of her old elements, and positively rich and strange.

Translation

Lord Mark had been introduced to her before dinner—not by Mrs. Lowder, but by the beautiful girl, Mrs. Lowder's niece, who was now seated at the far end of the table on the same side as Susie. He had escorted her to her seat, and Milly intended to ask him about Miss Croy, the attractive girl who was actually present—though in a glamorous way—for the second time. The first time had been just three days earlier, when she and her aunt had visited their hotel and made a strong impression of beauty and importance on the other two women. This impression had remained so strong with Milly that, even though she was aware of everything else happening, her attention was mostly focused on Kate Croy when she wasn't looking at Susie. That stunning woman's eyes readily met hers—she now seemed to be a truly remarkable person; and it seemed to be part of the American visitors' quick rise to success that, despite being so unexpected, she appeared aware, charmingly and openly, of the possibility of becoming friends with them. Milly had easily and gracefully generalized, as a guest does: English girls had a special, strong beauty, and it was particularly evident in evening gowns—especially when, as was very clear in this case, the dress itself was perfect. She already had that observation prepared to share with Lord Mark when they eventually got around to talking about it. She even felt that there might be a lot they would end up discussing; the implication being that their hostess, already absorbed with her other dinner partner, would leave them to themselves. Mrs. Lowder's other dinner partner was the Bishop of Murrum—a real bishop, the likes of whom Milly had never seen, with a complex outfit, a voice like an old-fashioned wind instrument, and a face straight out of a portrait of a prelate. Meanwhile, the gentleman on Milly's left, a thick-necked, large, and literal man who stared straight ahead and as if he couldn't be distracted by idle conversation from his own thoughts, seemed to balance out the presence of Lord Mark. As Milly understood all of this—with a touch of excitement at how easily she was fitting in—she realized that her faith in people and her love of life were justified. It wasn't as difficult as it seemed to get involved, or at least to stay on the periphery. It was easy to get close—if they were close; and yet the whole environment was different from anything she was used to, and positively rich and strange.

She asked herself if her right-hand neighbour would understand what she meant by such a description of them, should she throw it off; but another of the things to which, precisely, her sense was awakened was that no, decidedly, he wouldn't. It was nevertheless by this time open to her that his line would be to be clever; and indeed, evidently, no little of the interest was going to be in the fresh reference and fresh effect both of people's cleverness and of their simplicity. She thrilled, she consciously flushed, and turned pale with the certitude—it had never been so present—that she should find herself completely involved: the very air of the place, the pitch of the occasion, had for her so positive a taste and so deep an undertone. The smallest things, the faces, the hands, the jewels of the women, the sound of words, especially of names, across the table, the shape of the forks, the arrangement of the flowers, the attitude of the servants, the walls of the room, were all touches in a picture and denotements in a play; and they marked for her, moreover, her alertness of vision. She had never, she might well believe, been in such a state of vibration; her sensibility was almost too sharp for her comfort: there were, for example, more indications than she could reduce to order in the manner of the friendly niece, who struck her as distinguished and interesting, as in fact surprisingly genial. This young woman's type had, visibly, other possibilities; yet here, of its own free movement, it had already sketched a relation. Were they, Miss Croy and she, to take up the tale where their two elders had left it off so many years before?—were they to find they liked each other and to try for themselves if a scheme of constancy on more modern lines could be worked? She had doubted, as they came to England, of Maud Manningham, had believed her a broken reed and a vague resource, had seen their dependence on her as a state of mind that would have been shamefully silly—so far as it was dependence—had they wished to do any thing so inane as "get into society." To have made their pilgrimage all for the sake of such society as Mrs. Lowder might have in reserve for them—that didn't bear thinking of at all, and she herself had quite chosen her course for curiosity about other matters. She would have described this curiosity as a desire to see the places she had read about, and that description of her motive she was prepared to give her neighbour—even though, as a consequence of it, he should find how little she had read. It was almost at present as if her poor prevision had been rebuked by the majesty—she could scarcely call it less—of the event, or at all events by the commanding character of the two figures—she could scarcely call that less either—mainly presented. Mrs. Lowder and her niece, however dissimilar, had at least in common that each was a great reality. That was true, primarily, of the aunt—so true that Milly wondered how her own companion had arrived, in other days, at so odd an alliance; yet she none the less felt Mrs. Lowder as a person of whom the mind might in two or three days roughly make the circuit. She would sit there massive, at least, while one attempted it; whereas Miss Croy, the handsome girl, would indulge in incalculable movements that might interfere with one's tour. She was real, none the less, and everything and everybody were real; and it served them right, no doubt, the pair of them, for having rushed into their adventure.

Translation

She wondered if the person sitting next to her would understand what she was implying if she were to say it out loud. But, the thing that was really clear to her was that, no, definitely not, he wouldn't. Nevertheless, she now realized that he would probably try to be witty. And in fact, it seemed as if a lot of the excitement would come from the new meaning and impact of both people's cleverness and their simplicity. She felt a thrill, she blushed and then went pale with the certainty – which had never been so clear – that she would be totally caught up in it all. The atmosphere of the place, the nature of the event, had a very specific flavor and a deep underlying tone for her.

The smallest things – the faces, the hands, the women's jewelry, the sound of words, especially names, spoken across the table, the shape of the forks, the flower arrangements, the servers’ demeanor, the walls of the room – were all details in a painting and clues in a play. They also showed her how alert she was. She had never, she believed, been in such a heightened state of awareness. Her sensitivity was almost too intense for her comfort. For example, there were more things than she could easily organize in the manner of the friendly niece, who struck her as sophisticated and interesting, in fact, surprisingly warm and friendly. This young woman’s personality had, obviously, other potential directions, but here, she had already established a connection.

Were she and Miss Croy going to pick up where their elders had left off so many years ago? Were they going to discover that they liked each other and see if they could make a modern version of a lasting relationship? She had doubted Maud Manningham when they came to England, thinking of her as unreliable and a vague resource. She had seen their reliance on her as a shameful and silly state – if it could be called reliance – if they had wanted to do something as foolish as "get into society." To have made their trip only for the sake of the kind of society Mrs. Lowder might have to offer – that was not even worth considering, and she herself had chosen her path out of curiosity about other things. She would have described this curiosity as a desire to see the places she had read about, and she was prepared to tell her neighbor that, even if it meant he'd see how little she had read.

It was almost as if her previous doubts had been challenged by the grandeur – she could hardly call it less – of the event, or at least by the commanding presence of the two main figures – she could hardly call them less either. Mrs. Lowder and her niece, however different, at least had one thing in common: they were both very real. That was especially true of the aunt – so true that Milly wondered how her friend had formed such a strange alliance in the past. Yet she still felt Mrs. Lowder was someone whose mind she could quickly get to know in a few days. She would sit there, imposing at least, while one tried to understand her. Miss Croy, the beautiful girl, would engage in unpredictable actions that could disrupt one's analysis. She was real, nonetheless, and everything and everyone was real. And no doubt, that was good for them, for having jumped into their adventure.

Lord Mark's intelligence meanwhile, however, had met her own quite sufficiently to enable him to tell her how little he could clear up her situation. He explained, for that matter—or at least he hinted—that there was no such thing, to-day in London, as saying where any one was. Every one was everywhere—nobody was anywhere. He should be put to it—yes, frankly—to give a name of any sort or kind to their hostess's "set." Was it a set at all, or wasn't it, and were there not really no such things as sets, in the place, any more?—was there any thing but the senseless shifting tumble, like that of some great greasy sea in mid-Channel, of an overwhelming melted mixture? He threw out the question, which seemed large; Milly felt that at the end of five minutes he had thrown out a great many, though he followed none more than a step or two; perhaps he would prove suggestive, but he helped her as yet to no discriminations: he spoke as if he had given them up from too much knowledge. He was thus at the opposite extreme from herself, but, as a consequence of it, also wandering and lost; and he was furthermore, for all his temporary incoherence, to which she guessed there would be some key, as great a reality as either Mrs. Lowder or Kate. The only light in which he placed the former of these ladies was that of an extraordinary woman—a most extraordinary woman, and "the more extraordinary the more one knows her," while of the latter he said nothing, for the moment, but that she was tremendously, yes, quite tremendously, good-looking. It was some time, she thought, before his talk showed his cleverness, and yet each minute she believed in it more, quite apart from what her hostess had told her on first naming him. Perhaps he was one of the cases she had heard of at home—those characteristic cases of people in England who concealed their play of mind so much more than they showed it. Even Mr. Densher a little did that. And what made Lord Mark, at any rate, so real either, when this was a thing he so definitely insisted on? His type some how, as by a life, a need, an intention of its own, insisted for him; but that was all. It was difficult to guess his age—whether he were a young man who looked old or an old man who looked young; it seemed to prove nothing, as against other things, that he was bald and, as might have been said, slightly stale, or, more delicately perhaps, dry: there was such a fine little fidget of preoccupied life in him, and his eyes, at moments—though it was an appearance they could suddenly lose—were as candid and clear as those of a pleasant boy. Very neat, very light, and so fair that there was little other indication of his moustache than his constantly feeling it—which was again boyish—he would have affected her as the most intellectual person present if he had not affected her as the most frivolous. The latter quality was rather in his look than in anything else, though he constantly wore his double eyeglass, which was, much more, Bostonian and thoughtful.

Translation

Meanwhile, Lord Mark's intelligence had matched Milly's well enough for him to make it clear that he couldn't clarify her situation much. In fact—or at least, he implied—that in modern London, you couldn't actually pinpoint where anyone was. Everyone was everywhere; nobody was truly anywhere. He’d struggle, frankly, to even define their hostess's social circle. Was it a "set" at all, or not? Were actual social circles even a thing anymore? Was it just a chaotic, ever-shifting mess, like a churning, greasy sea in the middle of the Channel? He posed the question, which seemed significant. Milly felt he'd posed a lot of questions in five minutes, though he didn't follow up on any of them closely. He might be thought-provoking, but he wasn't helping her understand anything yet. He spoke as though he'd given up on understanding things because he knew too much.

He was the complete opposite of her, but as a result, he was also lost and uncertain. Despite his temporary incoherence, which she suspected had some meaning, he felt as real as either Mrs. Lowder or Kate. The only way he described Mrs. Lowder was as an extraordinary woman – a most extraordinary woman, and "the more extraordinary, the more you get to know her." He didn't say anything about Kate at that moment, except that she was incredibly, undeniably attractive. Milly thought it took a while for his intelligence to shine through his conversation, yet she believed in it more with each passing minute, regardless of what her hostess had initially told her about him. Perhaps he was one of those people she'd heard about back home – those typical English types who hid their intelligence more than they showed it. Even Mr. Densher did that, a little bit. And what made Lord Mark so real, especially when he insisted on it so strongly? His "type" somehow, as if driven by some internal need and purpose, asserted itself, but that was all. It was hard to guess his age—was he a young man who looked old or an old man who looked young? The fact that he was bald and, perhaps, slightly worn-out or, more delicately, dry, seemed to prove nothing. He had such a subtle, restless energy about him, and his eyes, at times—though it was an appearance they could lose suddenly—were as open and clear as a pleasant boy's. He was very neat, very light-featured, and fair-skinned. His mustache was barely visible, except for the fact that he was constantly touching it, a boyish habit. He would have seemed like the most intellectual person in the room, if he hadn't also seemed like the most frivolous. The latter quality was more apparent in his demeanor than anything else, although he always wore his double eyeglass, which, ironically, made him appear more like a thoughtful Bostonian.

The idea of his frivolity had, no doubt, to do with his personal designation, which represented—as yet, for our young woman, a little confusedly—a connection with an historic patriciate, a class that, in turn, also confusedly, represented an affinity with a social element that she had never heard otherwise described than as "fashion." The supreme social element in New York had never known itself but as reduced to that category, and though Milly was aware that, as applied to a territorial and political aristocracy, the label was probably too simple, she had for the time none other at hand. She presently, it is true, enriched her idea with the perception that her interlocutor was indifferent; yet this, indifferent as aristocracies notoriously were, saw her but little further, inasmuch as she felt that, in the first place, he would much rather get on with her than not, and in the second was only thinking of too many matters of his own. If he kept her in view on the one hand and kept so much else on the other—the way he crumbed up his bread was a proof—why did he hover before her as a potentially insolent noble? She couldn't have answered the question, and it was precisely one of those that swarmed. They were complicated, she might fairly have said, by his visibly knowing, having known from afar off, that she was a stranger and an American, and by his none the less making no more of it than if she and her like were the chief of his diet. He took her, kindly enough, but imperturbably, irreclaimably, for granted, and it wouldn't in the least help that she herself knew him, as quickly, for having been in her country and threshed it out. There would be nothing for her to explain or attenuate or brag about; she could neither escape nor prevail by her strangeness; he would have, for that matter, on such a subject, more to tell her than to learn from her. She might learn from him why she was so different from the handsome girl—which she didn't know, being merely able to feel it; or at any rate might learn from him why the handsome girl was so different from her.

Translation

His reputation for being frivolous probably stemmed from his title. For Milly, who was still trying to figure things out, that title seemed to connect him to a historical upper class. That class, in turn, also somewhat vaguely, represented a connection to something she only knew as "fashion." New York's elite society only understood itself in those terms. Even though Milly knew that label was probably too simplistic for a hereditary aristocracy, she didn't have a better one at the moment. She soon realized that he seemed indifferent, and although aristocrats were notoriously so, it didn't really help her understand him better. She felt, first, that he actually enjoyed her company, and second, that he was preoccupied with his own thoughts.

If he was keeping her in mind, while also dealing with so much else – the way he crumbled his bread was a clue – then why did he present himself as a potentially arrogant nobleman? She couldn't answer that question, and it was just one of many that were swirling around in her mind. They were made more complex, she realized, by the fact that he clearly knew she was a foreigner and an American, but he didn't seem to care any more than if she and people like her were the main focus of his attention. He accepted her, kindly enough, but also with an unwavering, undeniable assumption that she belonged there. And it wouldn't help that she, too, had quickly realized he'd spent time in her country and understood it.

There would be nothing for her to explain, downplay, or boast about. She couldn't use her foreignness to escape or gain an advantage. On that topic, he would likely have more to tell her than to learn from her. She might learn from him why she was so different from the beautiful girl—something she could only feel, not explain. Or at least, she might learn from him why the beautiful girl was so different from her.

On these lines, however, they would move later; the lines immediately laid down were, in spite of his vagueness for his own convenience, definite enough. She was already, he observed to her, thinking what she should say on her other side—which was what Americans were always doing. She needn't in conscience say anything at all; but Americans never knew that, nor ever, poor creatures, yes (she had interposed the "poor creatures!") what not to do. The burdens they took on—the things, positively, they made an affair of! This easy and, after all, friendly jibe at her race was really for her, on her new friend's part, the note of personal recognition so far as she required it; and she gave him a prompt and conscious example of morbid anxiety by insisting that her desire to be, herself, "lovely" all round was justly founded on the lovely way Mrs. Lowder had met her. He was directly interested in that, and it was not till afterwards that she fully knew how much more information about their friend he had taken than given. Here again, for instance, was a pertinent note for her: she had, on the spot, with her first plunge into the obscure depths of a society constituted from far back, encountered the interesting phenomenon of complicated, of possibly sinister motive. However, Maud Manningham (her name, even in her presence, somehow still fed the fancy) had, all the same, been lovely, and one was going to meet her now quite as far on as one had one's self been met. She had been with them at their hotel—they were a pair—before even they had supposed she could have got their letter. Of course indeed they had written in advance, but they had followed that up very fast. She had thus engaged them to dine but two days later, and on the morrow again, without waiting for a return visit, waiting for anything, she had called with her niece. It was as if she really cared for them, and it was magnificent fidelity—fidelity to Mrs. Stringham, her own companion and Mrs. Lowder's former schoolmate, the lady with the charming face and the rather high dress down there at the end.

Translation

However, they'd address those points later. The details of the situation that were immediately clear, despite his tendency to be vague when it suited him, were quite specific. He remarked to her that she was already preoccupied with what she should say to the people on the other side of her—a typical American trait, he noted. In truth, she didn't *need* to say anything, but Americans never understood that, nor, unfortunately, did they know what *not* to do (she had interjected "poor things!"). The things they worried about—the things they deliberately made complicated! This good-natured, and ultimately friendly, teasing of her nationality was, for her new friend, a sign of personal connection and acknowledgment, at least as far as she needed it. She promptly and consciously displayed her own tendency toward overthinking by claiming that her desire to be universally "charming" was justified by the welcoming way Mrs. Lowder had greeted her. He was immediately intrigued by that, and it wasn’t until later that she realized how much more information about their friend he had gleaned than he had offered. For example, here was another relevant point for her: upon her initial foray into the murky world of a long-established social circle, she’d encountered the fascinating phenomenon of hidden, possibly suspicious, motives. Still, Maud Manningham (her name, even as she said it, somehow still sparked the imagination) had been lovely, and she was now going to meet her with a similar degree of openness. Maud had been at their hotel with them—they were a pair—before they even expected her to have received their letter. Of course, they had written in advance, but she had followed up very quickly. She had invited them to dinner just two days later, and the very next day, without waiting for them to reciprocate or anything else, she’d called with her niece. It was as if she genuinely cared about them, and it was a magnificent display of loyalty—loyalty to Mrs. Stringham, her own companion and Mrs. Lowder's former school friend, the woman with the charming face and the rather formal dress standing over there at the end.

Lord Mark took in through his nippers these balanced attributes of Susie. "But isn't Mrs. Stringham's fidelity then equally magnificent?"

Translation

Lord Mark looked at Susie's well-balanced qualities. "But isn't Mrs. Stringham just as loyal and wonderful?"

"Well, it's a beautiful sentiment; but it isn't as if she had anything to give."

Translation

That's a nice thought, but she didn't actually have anything to offer.

"Hasn't she got you?" Lord Mark presently asked.

Translation

"Isn't she got you?" Lord Mark asked soon after.

"Me—to give Mrs. Lowder?" Milly had clearly not yet seen herself in the light of such an offering. "Oh, I'm rather a poor present; and I don't feel as if, even at that, I've as yet quite been given."

Translation

"Me – be a gift for Mrs. Lowder?" Milly obviously hadn't considered herself that way. "Oh, I'm not a very good present. And I don't even feel like I've really been 'given' yet."

"You've been shown, and if our friend has jumped at you it comes to the same thing." He made his jokes, Lord Mark, without amusement for himself; yet it wasn't that he was grim. "To be seen you must recognise, is, for you, to be jumped at; and, if it's a question of being shown, here you are again. Only it has now been taken out of your friend's hands; it's Mrs. Lowder, already, who's getting the benefit. Look round the table and you'll make out, I think, that you're being, from top to bottom, jumped at."

Translation

You've been exposed, and if our friend has attacked you, it's essentially the same thing. Lord Mark made these remarks without finding them funny, but he wasn't being serious. "For you, being seen is the same as being attacked; and if we're talking about being shown, well, here you are again. Only now it's not your friend doing it; Mrs. Lowder is the one benefiting. Look around the table and you'll probably realize that you're being, from start to finish, targeted."

"Well, then," said Milly, "I seem also to feel that I like it better than being made fun of."

Translation

Okay, so," Milly said, "I guess I'd rather like this than be laughed at."

It was one of the things she afterwards saw—Milly was for ever seeing things afterwards—that her companion had here had some way of his own, quite unlike any one's else, of assuring her of his consideration. She wondered how he had done it, for he had neither apologised nor protested. She said to herself, at any rate, that he had led her on; and what was most odd was the question by which he had done so. "Does she know much about you?"

Translation

Later, Milly would always look back and notice things—she was always noticing things later on. This was one of them. She realized her friend had a unique way of showing her he cared, unlike anyone else. She was curious how he'd managed it, because he hadn't apologized or even said he was sorry. She thought to herself that he'd tricked her, and what was most strange was the way he'd done it. The question he'd asked was, "Does she know much about you?"

"No, she just likes us."

Translation

No, she's just into us.

Even for this his travelled lordship, seasoned and saturated, had no laugh. "I mean you particularly. Has that lady with the charming face, which is charming, told her?"

Translation

Even a worldly and experienced man like him didn't find this amusing. "I'm talking to you directly. Has that woman with the lovely face – the one who *is* lovely – told her?"

Milly hesitated. "Told her what?"

Translation

Milly paused. "Told who what?"

"Everything."

Translation

That's all.

This, with the way he dropped it, again considerably moved her—made her feel for a moment that, as a matter of course, she was a subject for disclosures. But she quickly found her answer. "Oh, as for that, you must ask her."

Translation

His gesture, combined with the way he said it, really affected her again. It made her feel, for a second, like she was supposed to be sharing something personal. But she quickly figured it out. "Oh, you'll have to ask *her* about that."

"Your clever companion?"

Translation

Your smart friend?

"Mrs. Lowder."

Translation

"Hello, Mrs. Lowder."

He replied to this that their hostess was a person with whom there were certain liberties one never took, but that he was none the less fairly upheld, inasmuch as she was for the most part kind to him and as, should he be very good for a while, she would probably herself tell him. "And I shall have, at any rate, in the meantime, the interest of seeing what she does with you. That will teach me more or less, you see, how much she knows."

Translation

He responded to this by saying that their hostess was someone with whom you simply didn't take certain liberties. However, he also felt reasonably secure because she was generally nice to him, and if he behaved himself for a while, she would likely explain things to him herself. "And anyway, I'll be entertained in the meantime by seeing what she does with you. That will show me how much she really knows."

Milly followed this—it was lucid; but it suggested something apart. "How much does she know about you?"

Translation

Milly followed what he said – it was clear, but it hinted at something hidden. "How much does she know about you, really?"

"Nothing," said Lord Mark serenely. "But that doesn't matter—for what she does with me." And then, as to anticipate Milly's question about the nature of such doing: "This, for instance—turning me straight on for you."

Translation

"Nothing," said Lord Mark calmly. "But that's not important—because of what she does *with* me." And then, as if to head off Milly's question about what he meant by that: "This, for example – she uses me to push me directly towards you."

The girl thought. "And you mean she wouldn't if she did know——?"

Translation

The girl thought, "So you're saying she wouldn't... even if she knew?"

He met it as if it were really a point. "No. I believe, to do her justice, she still would. So you can be easy."

Translation

He handled the situation as if it were a crucial decision. "No. I think, to be fair to her, she'd still do it. So you don't need to worry."

Milly had the next instant, then, acted on the permission. "Because you're even at the worst the best thing she has?"

Translation

Milly acted immediately. "Because even at your worst, you're the best thing she has?"

With this he was at last amused. "I was till you came. You're the best now."

Translation

Finally, he was entertained. "I wasn't until you showed up. You're the most fun now."

It was strange his words should have given her the sense of his knowing, but it was positive that they did so, and to the extent of making her believe them, though still with wonder. That, really, from this first of their meetings, was what was most to abide with her: she accepted almost helplessly, she surrendered to the inevitability of being the sort of thing, as he might have said, that he at least thoroughly believed he had, in going about, seen here enough of for all practical purposes. Her submission was naturally, moreover, not to be impaired by her learning later on that he had paid at short intervals, though at a time apparently just previous to her own emergence from the obscurity of extreme youth, three separate visits to New York, where his nameable friends and his contrasted contacts had been numerous. His impression, his recollection of the whole mixed quantity, was still visibly rich. It had helped him to place her, and she was more and more sharply conscious of having—as with the door sharply slammed upon her and the guard's hand raised in signal to the train—been popped into the compartment in which she was to travel for him. It was a use of her that many a girl would have been doubtless quick to resent; and the kind of mind that thus, in our young lady, made all for mere seeing and taking is precisely one of the charms of our subject. Milly had practically just learned from him, had made out, as it were, from her rumbling compartment, that he gave her the highest place among their friend's actual properties. She was a success, that was what it came to, he presently assured her, and that was what it was to be a success: it always happened before one could know it. One's ignorance was in fact often the greatest part of it. "You haven't had time yet," he said; "this is nothing. But you'll see. You'll see everything. You can, you know—everything you dream of."

Translation

It was odd that his words gave her the impression that he knew her, but it definitely did, to the point where she believed them, though still with a sense of bewilderment. That, really, from their first meeting, was what would stay with her the longest: she accepted almost without resistance, she gave in to the idea that she was the kind of person, as he might have said, that he had seen enough of to be sure of his assessment. Her acceptance wouldn't be diminished by her later finding out that he had, at short intervals, though apparently just before she emerged from her extreme youth, made three trips to New York, where he had many friends and acquaintances with different backgrounds. His impression, his memory of this whole varied group, was still clearly vivid. It had helped him figure her out, and she was increasingly aware of being—like a door slammed shut on her and the guard signaling the train—thrust into the situation in which she was going to be involved with him. Many a girl would likely be quick to resent being used like that; and the kind of mind that, in our young lady, was entirely receptive and passive is precisely one of the things that makes her interesting. Milly had essentially just learned from him, had understood, as if looking out from her confined space, that he considered her to be the most valuable thing among her friend's possessions. She was a success, that’s what it came down to, he soon assured her, and that was what being a success was: it always happened before you realized it. Your ignorance was, in fact, often the biggest part of it. "You haven't had time yet," he said; "this is nothing. But you'll see. You'll see everything. You can have—everything you dream of."

He made her more and more wonder; she almost felt as if he were showing her visions while he spoke; and strangely enough, though it was visions that had drawn her on, she hadn't seen them in connection—that is in such preliminary and necessary connection—with such a face as Lord Mark's, such eyes and such a voice, such a tone and such a manner. He had for an instant the effect of making her ask herself if she were after all going to be afraid; so distinct was it for fifty seconds that a fear passed over her. There they were again—yes, certainly: Susie's overture to Mrs. Lowder had been their joke, but they had pressed in that gaiety an electric bell that continued to sound. Positively, while she sat there, she had the loud rattle in her ears, and she wondered, during these moments, why the others didn't hear it. They didn't stare, they didn't smile, and the fear in her that I speak of was but her own desire to stop it. That dropped, however, as if the alarm itself had ceased; she seemed to have seen in a quick, though tempered glare that there were two courses for her, one to leave London again the first thing in the morning, the other to do nothing at all. Well, she would do nothing at all; she was already doing it; more than that, she had already done it, and her chance was gone. She gave herself up—she had the strangest sense, on the spot, of so deciding; for she had turned a corner before she went on again with Lord Mark. Inexpressive, but intensely significant, he met as no one else could have done the very question she had suddenly put to Mrs. Stringham on the Brünig. Should she have it, whatever she did have, that question had been, for long? "Ah, so possibly not," her neighbour appeared to reply; "therefore, don't you see? I'm the way." It was vivid that he might be, in spite of his absence of flourish; the way being doubtless just in that absence. The handsome girl, whom she didn't lose sight of and who, she felt, kept her also in view—Mrs. Lowder's striking niece would, perhaps, be the way as well, for in her too was the absence of flourish, though she had little else, so far as one could tell, in common with Lord Mark. Yet how indeed could one tell, what did one understand, and of what was one, for that matter, provisionally conscious but of their being somehow together in what they represented? Kate Croy, fine but friendly, looked over at her as really with a guess at Lord Mark's effect on her. If she could guess this effect what then did she know about it and in what degree had she felt it herself? Did that represent, as between them, anything particular, and should she have to count with them as duplicating, as intensifying by a mutual intelligence, the relation into which she was sinking? Nothing was so odd as that she should have to recognise so quickly in each of these glimpses of an instant the various signs of a relation; and this anomaly itself, had she had more time to give to it, might well, might almost terribly have suggested to her that her doom was to live fast. It was queerly a question of the short run and the consciousness proportionately crowded.

Translation

He made her increasingly curious. She almost felt as though he was showing her visions as he spoke. Strangely enough, even though visions had drawn her in, she hadn't seen them connected—specifically, in such a crucial and necessary way—with a face like Lord Mark's, or with his eyes, voice, tone, and manner. For a moment, he made her wonder if she was going to be afraid; so distinct was the feeling, even if only for a short time, that fear washed over her. There they were again – yes, definitely: Susie's introduction to Mrs. Lowder had been their inside joke, but in that moment of levity, they had triggered an alarm bell that continued to ring. Honestly, as she sat there, she heard the loud ringing in her ears, and she wondered why the others didn’t hear it. They didn't stare, they didn't smile, and the fear I'm describing was only her own desire to make it stop. That fear, however, vanished, as if the alarm itself had ceased. She seemed to have realized in a flash of understanding that she had two options: leave London first thing in the morning, or do absolutely nothing. Well, she would do nothing; she was already doing it. More than that, she had already done it, and her opportunity was gone. She gave up – she had the strange feeling that she'd made that decision in that moment, because she'd changed her mind before she continued talking with Lord Mark. His expression was blank, but his impact was intense; he understood the very question she'd suddenly asked Mrs. Stringham on the Brünig. Should she have it, whatever she had – that had been the question for a long time. "Ah, maybe not," her neighbor seemed to reply. "Therefore, don't you see? I'm the way." It was clear that he might be, even without trying to be; the way, undoubtedly, was in that lack of effort. The beautiful girl whom she didn't take her eyes off of, and who, she felt, was also watching her—Mrs. Lowder's striking niece—might also be the way, because she too lacked effort, though, as far as one could tell, she had little else in common with Lord Mark. Yet, how could one know? What did one understand? What was she, for that matter, tentatively aware of, except for the fact that they were somehow connected in what they represented? Kate Croy, elegant but approachable, looked over at her as though she could guess the effect Lord Mark had on her. If she could guess that effect, then what did she know about it, and to what extent had she felt it herself? Did that represent anything specific between them, and should she have to consider them as duplicating and intensifying their shared understanding of the situation she was getting involved in?
