It was so odd that she had to recognize so quickly the various signs of their connection in each of these brief moments. This very strangeness, if she'd had more time to think about it, might have suggested to her—almost frighteningly—that her fate was to live life quickly. It was a strange question of the short term and a correspondingly compressed consciousness.

These were immense excursions for the spirit of a young person at Mrs. Lowder's mere dinner-party; but what was so significant and so admonitory as the fact of their being possible? What could they have been but just a part, already, of the crowded consciousness? And it was just a part, likewise, that while plates were changed and dishes presented and periods in the banquet marked; while appearances insisted and phenomena multiplied and words reached her from here and there like plashes of a slow, thick tide; while Mrs. Lowder grew somehow more stout and more instituted and Susie, at her distance and in comparison, more thinly improvised and more different—different, that is, from every one and everything: it was just a part that while this process went forward our young lady alighted, came back, taking up her destiny again as if she had been able by a wave or two of her wings to place herself briefly in sight of an alternative to it. Whatever it was it had showed in this brief interval as better than the alternative; and it now presented itself altogether in the image and in the place in which she had left it. The image was that of her being, as Lord Mark had declared, a success. This depended more or less of course on his idea of the thing—into which at present, however, she wouldn't go. But, renewing soon, she had asked him what he meant then that Mrs. Lowder would do with her, and he had replied that this might safely be left. "She'll get back," he pleasantly said, "her money." He could say it too—which was singular—without affecting her either as vulgar or as "nasty "; and he had soon explained himself by adding: "Nobody here, you know, does anything for nothing."

Translation

These dinner parties at Mrs. Lowder's were incredibly stimulating for a young person. But what was so striking and insightful was the fact that these experiences were even happening. They were already becoming part of her complex thoughts and feelings. And it was also true that as plates were replaced, food served, and the meal progressed; as social expectations and situations became more complex, and conversation flowed around her; as Mrs. Lowder became increasingly imposing and established, and Susie, in comparison, seemed less prepared and more distinct – different from everyone and everything; it was also true that during this process, our young lady momentarily escaped, retreated, and then returned, taking up her life again as if she'd briefly glimpsed an alternative future. Whatever that alternative was, it had, for a brief moment, seemed better than her current reality. And now, it presented itself in the same form and place she had left it. This alternative was the idea that, as Lord Mark had said, she was a success. This, of course, depended on his definition of success, which she didn't want to think about right now.

But, later, she'd asked him what Mrs. Lowder would do with her, and he'd replied that it was best to leave that to Mrs. Lowder. "She'll get back her money," he'd said cheerfully. He could say it without sounding vulgar or unpleasant, which was odd. He then clarified, "Nobody here does anything without getting something in return."

"Ah, if you mean that we shall reward her as hard as ever we can, nothing is more certain. But she's an idealist," Milly continued, "and idealists, in the long run, I think, don't feel that they lose."

Translation

Oh, if you're asking if we'll compensate her as much as possible, absolutely. But she's an idealist," Milly went on, "and I think idealists don't feel like they've really lost in the end."

Lord Mark seemed, within the limits of his enthusiasm, to find this charming. "Ah, she strikes you as an idealist?"

Translation

Lord Mark, as enthusiastic as he could be, seemed to like this. "Oh, you think she's an idealist?"

"She idealises us, my friend and me, absolutely. She sees us in a light," said Milly. "That's all I've got to hold on by. So don't deprive me of it."

Translation

She puts us on a pedestal, my friend and me, completely. She thinks we're amazing," Milly said. "That's the only thing I have to keep me going. So please, don't take that away from me."

"I wouldn't for the world. But do you think," he continued as if it were suddenly important for him—"do you think she sees me in a light?"

Translation

No way. But do you think," he continued, as if it suddenly mattered to him, "do you think she's interested in me?"

She neglected his question for a little, partly because her attention attached itself more and more to the handsome girl, partly because, placed so near their hostess, she wished not to show as discussing her too freely. Mrs. Lowder, it was true, steering in the other quarter a course in which she called at subjects as if they were islets in an archipelago, continued to allow them their ease, and Kate Croy, at the same time, steadily revealed herself as interesting. Milly in fact found, of a sudden, her ease—found it all—as she bethought herself that what Mrs. Lowder was really arranging for was a report on her quality and, as perhaps might be said, her value from Lord Mark. She wished him, the wonderful lady, to have no pretext for not knowing what he thought of Miss Theale. Why his judgment so mattered remained to be seen; but it was this divination, in any case, that now determined Milly's rejoinder. "No. She knows you. She has probably reason to. And you all, here, know each other—I see that—so far as you know anything. You know what you're used to, and it's your being used to it—that, and that only—that makes you. But there are things you don't know."

Translation

She avoided his question for a moment, partially because she was increasingly fascinated by the attractive woman, and partly because she didn't want to seem like she was gossiping about their hostess, since she was sitting so close to her. Mrs. Lowder, actually, was casually bringing up different topics, like they were islands in an ocean, and continued to let them talk freely. Meanwhile, Kate Croy was steadily proving to be a compelling person. Milly suddenly felt comfortable, realizing that Mrs. Lowder was really trying to gather information about her character and, maybe, her worth, for Lord Mark. She wanted the wonderful Mrs. Lowder to have no excuse for not knowing what he thought of Miss Theale. Why his opinion was so important was still unclear, but this realization determined Milly's response. "No. She knows you. She probably has a reason to. And all of you here know each other – I can see that – as much as you know anything. You know what you're accustomed to, and it's your comfort with that – and only that – that defines you. But there are things you don't know."

He took it in as if it might fairly, to do him justice, be a point. "Things that I don't—with all the pains I take and the way I've run about the world to leave nothing unlearned?"

Translation

He considered it carefully, as if it could actually be important, to be fair. "Things that I *don't* know—despite all my effort and how I've traveled the world to learn everything possible?"

Milly thought, and it was perhaps the very truth of his claim—its not being negligible—that sharpened her impatience and thereby her wit. "You're blasé, but you're not enlightened. You're familiar with everything, but conscious, really of nothing. What I mean is that you've no imagination."

Translation

Milly thought about it, and maybe the truth of what he said – that it was actually a big deal – made her more impatient, which made her sharper. "You act like you've seen it all, but you're not actually insightful. You know about everything, but you don't really understand anything. You just don't have any imagination."

Lord Mark, at this, threw back his head, ranging with his eyes the opposite side of the room and showing himself at last so much more completely as diverted that it fairly attracted their hostess's notice. Mrs. Lowder, however, only smiled on Milly for a sign that something racy was what she had expected, and resumed, with a splash of her screw, her cruise among the islands. "Oh, I've heard that," the young man replied, "before!"

Translation

Lord Mark laughed and looked around the room, clearly amused. He seemed so entertained that their hostess noticed. Mrs. Lowder, however, just smiled at Milly, as if she knew something interesting was about to happen. Then, stirring her drink, she continued her story. "Oh, I've heard that one before," Lord Mark said.

"There it is then. You've heard everything before. You've heard me of course before, in my country, often enough."

Translation

Okay, here it is:

So, that's it. You've heard this all before.

And of course, you've heard me before, in my

country, many times.

"Oh, never too often," he protested; "I'm sure I hope I shall still hear you again and again."

Translation

"Oh, not at all," he insisted. "I really hope I'll get to hear you again soon."

"But what good then has it done you?" the girl went on as if now frankly to amuse him.

Translation

"So what good did it do you, then?" the girl asked, as if she was just trying to entertain him.

"Oh, you'll see when you know me."

Translation

Just wait until you get to know me.

"But, most assuredly, I shall never know you."

Translation

I definitely won't know you.

"Then that will be exactly," he laughed, "the good!"

Translation

"Then that's perfect!" he laughed. "Great!"

If it established thus that they couldn't, or Wouldn't, mix, why, none the less, did Milly feel, through it, a perverse quickening of the relation to which she had been, in spite of herself, appointed?

Translation

If it was proven they couldn't or wouldn't get along, why did Milly still feel, despite it all, a strange excitement about the relationship she was involved in, even though she hadn't chosen it?

What queerer consequence of their not mixing than their talking—for it was what they had arrived at—almost intimately? She wished to get away from him, or indeed, much rather, away from herself so far as she was present to him. She saw already—wonderful creature, after all, herself too—that there would be a good deal more of him to come for her, and that the special sign of their intercourse would be to keep herself out of the question. Everything else might come in—only never that; and with such an arrangement they might even go far. This in fact might quite have begun, on the spot, with her returning again to the topic of the handsome girl. If she was to keep herself out she could naturally best do so by putting in somebody else. She accordingly put in Kate Croy, being ready to that extent—as she was not at all afraid for her—to sacrifice her if necessary. Lord Mark himself, for that matter, had made it easy by saying a little while before that no one among them did anything for nothing. "What then"—she was aware of being abrupt—"does Miss Croy, if she's so interested, do it for? What has she to gain by her lovely welcome? Look at her now!" Milly broke out with characteristic freedom of praise, though pulling herself up also with a compunctious "Oh!" as the direction thus given to their eyes happened to coincide with a turn of Kate's face to them. All she had meant to do was to insist that this face was fine; but what she had in fact done was to renew again her effect of showing herself to its possessor as conjoined with Lord Mark for some interested view of it. He had, however, promptly met her question.

Translation

Isn't it odd that the only result of them *not* being close was that they were actually talking – and almost like they were best friends? She wanted to escape him, or rather, to escape the feeling of herself that she was presenting to him. She realized – and she was quite amazing, even to herself – that she'd be seeing a lot more of him, and that the key to their relationship would be to keep her own feelings out of it. Anything else could be discussed, but never her own emotions. With that kind of agreement, they could actually go far. In fact, she could have started right then, by going back to the subject of the beautiful girl.

If she wanted to avoid talking about herself, the best way was to bring up someone else. So she introduced Kate Croy, and was willing to use her as a distraction, since she wasn't worried about Kate at all. Lord Mark had made this easier by saying a little while ago that no one in their circle ever did anything for free. "So then," she said abruptly, "what does Miss Croy, if she's so interested, get out of it? What's her reason for being so welcoming? Look at her now!" Milly gushed with her usual enthusiasm, though she also stopped herself with a quick "Oh!" because the direction of their gaze happened to coincide with Kate turning her head towards them. All she'd meant to do was to emphasize that Kate's face was beautiful, but what she'd actually done was reinforce the impression that she and Lord Mark were somehow connected and looking at Kate with some ulterior motive. However, he immediately answered her question.

"To gain? Why, your acquaintance."

Translation

To what end? To get to know you.

"Well, what's my acquaintance to her? She can care for me—she must feel that—only by being sorry for me; and that's why she's lovely: to be already willing to take the trouble to be. It's the height of the disinterested."

Translation

Why should she care about me? She can only take care of me out of pity, and that's what makes her so wonderful: she's already willing to go to the trouble. That's the ultimate act of selfless kindness.

There were more things in this than one that Lord Mark might have taken up; but in a minute he had made his choice. "Ah then, I'm nowhere, for I'm afraid I'm not sorry for you in the least. What do you make then," he asked, "of your success?"

Translation

He had several options to consider, but he made his decision quickly. "Well, I guess I'm out of luck, because I'm not sorry for you at all. So, what do you think of your victory?"

"Why, just the great reason of all. It's just because our friend there sees it that she pities me. She understands," Milly said; "she's better than any of you. She's beautiful."

Translation

Oh, it's the simplest thing. It's only because our friend here sees my situation that she feels sorry for me. She understands, Milly said. She's better than all of you. She's beautiful.

He appeared struck with this at last—with the point the girl made of it; to which she came back even after a diversion created by a dish presented between them. "Beautiful in character, I see. Is she so? You must tell me about her."

Translation

He finally seemed to get it – the point the girl was making. She even returned to it after they were distracted by a new dish being served. "So, she's a good person, is she? Really? Tell me about her."

Milly wondered. "But haven't you known her longer than I? Haven't you seen her for yourself?"

Translation

Milly wondered, "But haven't you known her longer than I have? Haven't you seen her yourself?"

"No—I've failed with her. It's no use. I don't make her out. And I assure you I really should like to." His assurance had in fact for his companion a positive suggestion of sincerity; he affected her as now saying something that he felt; and she was the more struck with it as she was still conscious of the failure even of curiosity he had just shown in respect to herself. She had meant something—though indeed for herself almost only—in speaking of their friend's natural pity; it had been a note, doubtless, of questionable taste, but it had quavered out in spite of her; and he had not so much as cared to inquire "Why 'natural'?" Not that it wasn't really much better for her that he shouldn't: explanations would in truth have taken her much too far. Only she now perceived that, in comparison, her word about this other person really "drew" him; and there were things in that, probably, many things, as to which she would learn more and which glimmered there already as part and parcel of that larger "real" with which, in her new situation, she was to be beguiled. It was in fact at the very moment, this element, not absent from what Lord Mark was further saying. "So you're wrong, you see, as to our knowing all about each other. There are cases where we break down. I at any rate give her up—up, that is, to you. You must do her for me—tell me, I mean, when you know more. You'll notice," he pleasantly wound up, "that I've confidence in you."

Translation

"No, I've messed up with her. It's pointless. I can't understand her. And I swear, I really wish I could." His sincerity was actually quite convincing to her companion; he seemed to be saying something genuine, and she was more affected by it because she was still aware of the lack of even curiosity he had just shown about her. She had intended something—though mostly for herself—when she mentioned their friend's natural compassion; it was probably a bit tactless, but it had slipped out anyway, and he hadn't even bothered to ask "Why 'natural'?" Not that it was necessarily bad for her that he didn't: explaining would have been too complicated. But she realized that her comment about this other person actually interested him; and there were things in that, probably many things, that she'd learn more about, and which were already hinting at the bigger "reality" that was supposed to consume her in her new situation. In fact, that very element was present even as Lord Mark continued speaking.

"So you're mistaken, you see, about us knowing everything about each other. There are situations where we fail. I'm giving up on her—handing her over to you. You have to figure her out for me—tell me, I mean, when you know more. You'll notice," he concluded cheerfully, "that I trust you."

"Why shouldn't you have?" Milly asked, observing in this, as she thought, a fine, though, for such a man, a surprisingly artless, fatuity. It was as if there might have been a question of her falsifying for the sake of her own show—that is of her honesty not being proof against her desire to keep well with him herself. She didn't, none the less, otherwise protest against his remark; there was something else she was occupied in seeing. It was the handsome girl alone, one of his own species and his own society, who had made him feel uncertain; of his certainties about a mere little American, a cheap exotic, imported almost wholesale, and whose habitat, with its conditions of climate, growth, and cultivation, its immense profusion, but its few varieties and thin development, he was perfectly satisfied. The marvel was, too, that Milly understood his satisfaction—feeling that she expressed the truth in presently saying: "Of course; I make out that she must be difficult; just as I see that I myself must be easy." And that was what, for all the rest of this occasion, remained with her—as the most interesting thing that could remain. She was more and more content herself to be easy; she would have been resigned, even had it been brought straighter home to her, to passing for a cheap exotic. Provisionally, at any rate, that protected her wish to keep herself, with Lord Mark, in abeyance. They had all affected her as inevitably knowing each other, and if the handsome girl's place among them was something even their initiation couldn't deal with—why, then, she would indeed be a quantity.

Translation

"Why wouldn't you?" Milly asked, noticing what she considered a naive, almost shockingly simple, self-deception in him, especially for someone like him. It was as if he suspected she might be pretending, just to make a good impression – that her honesty might not be strong enough to overcome her desire to stay on his good side. But she didn't object to his comment; she was focused on something else. She was looking at the beautiful woman, one of his own kind and from his social circle, who had made him feel insecure. He had been so sure about a little American like her—a cheap, foreign import, almost mass-produced, whose background, with its specific environment, upbringing, and limited development, he fully understood. The surprising thing was that Milly understood his satisfaction, and she expressed the truth when she said, "Of course. I can see she must be challenging, just as I can see I must be easygoing." And that statement stayed with her for the rest of their conversation, as the most interesting thing to come from it. She was increasingly happy to be easygoing. She would have accepted, even if it had been made clearer, being seen as a cheap exotic. For the time being, at least, that allowed her to postpone any further involvement with Lord Mark. They all seemed to know each other intimately, and if the beautiful woman's place among them was something they couldn't even explain—well, then, she would be a valuable and significant person.

Chapter VIII

Chapter Summary & Character Study
Summary

For a week following a dinner, an American pair, Milly Theale and her companion Mrs. Stringham (Susan Shepherd), are in London. Milly and Mrs. Stringham frequently remark to each other that they have only themselves to thank. Mrs. Stringham is pleased because an appeal she made to her old schoolmate, Mrs. Lowder (Maud Manningham), was met positively.

During this week, the two elder women, Mrs. Stringham and Mrs. Lowder, spend time together. Mrs. Stringham tells Mrs. Lowder about Milly, and Mrs. Lowder tells Mrs. Stringham about her niece, Kate Croy.

At the same time, Milly and Kate Croy become friends and spend their days together. They explore London's shops, streets, suburbs, museums, and monuments. Milly gives Mrs. Stringham accounts of her time with Kate. She tells Mrs. Stringham she thinks Kate has a secret trouble and is using their friendship as a diversion.

Kate tells Milly about her family situation. In turn, Milly tells Kate about her American background, her family's financial history, and her deceased relatives. Each tells the other she finds her more remarkable than herself.

During their outings, Milly gives Kate several presents, including precious ornaments. Kate tells Milly she must avoid shops unless Milly promises not to buy things for her.

By the end of the week, Milly asks Kate for information about Lord Mark and to be promised a visit to Kate's sister, Mrs. Condrip. Kate explains that Lord Mark's value is based on his future potential, which her aunt believes in. She says he was briefly in Parliament but lost his seat. Kate also explains to Milly that in London society, relationships are like bargains where everyone gives something to get something in return. She says that both she and Milly have been "taken up" by Mrs. Lowder.

In another conversation, Milly observes to Kate that she is surprised Mrs. Lowder is not bored by Mrs. Stringham. Kate agrees, and Milly sees that Kate finds Mrs. Stringham uninteresting.

Character Study

Based on the text, here is a concise character study:

  • *Milly Theale**
  • **Presentation:** An immensely wealthy, curious, and imaginative American, Milly is initially presented as a "slightly gasping" newcomer, likened to a "wandering princess." She perceives the world through a romantic and literary lens, immediately casting Kate as a "heroine." She is perceptive, guessing Kate has a secret trouble, yet naive about social dangers. She is extremely generous and possesses a freedom from financial anxiety that Kate finds remarkable.
  • **Situational Shift:** She moves from being a passive observer "caught up by a wave" to an active and engaged participant in London life. Her initial awe shifts to a deep fascination, and she quickly forms an intense friendship with Kate, even beginning to see her own powerful status through Kate’s eyes.
  • *Mrs. Stringham (Susan "Susie" Shepherd)**
  • **Presentation:** Milly’s older companion, a "pilgrim from Boston." She is analytical and values understanding the reasons behind actions. She is initially in a state of "exaltation" that her social faith in Mrs. Lowder has been justified. This gives way to a feeling of being "carried away" by the "vast, obscure, lurid" London world, which gives her a "bad conscience."
  • **Situational Shift:** Her situation shifts from one of simple, triumphant success to a more complex state of being both fascinated and morally unnerved by her new environment. She is simultaneously thrilled for Milly and overwhelmed herself.
  • *Kate Croy**
  • **Presentation:** A "handsome English girl," she is presented as pragmatic, worldly, and observant. Milly sees her as the archetype of the "wondrous London girl," but Kate sees herself as part of a transactional social system where people are either "working" or "being worked." She has an unspoken "smothered trouble." She is described as having a defensive "brutality" and a quickness to judge what she will not like.
  • **Situational Shift:** Initially positioned as a guide for Milly, Kate quickly becomes an intimate friend and a powerful influence. She shifts from being an object of Milly’s romantic imagination to an active force who provides a cynical but frank education in the ways of her world.
  • *Mrs. Lowder (Maud Manningham)**
  • **Presentation:** A formidable and powerful London hostess. She is described as "large" not because she is empty but because she is "full," like a "projectile... loaded and ready for use." She is a woman of action who operates on instinct rather than articulated reasons. She is a social force who "takes people up" and in whom others, like Kate, place their belief.
  • **Situational Shift:** Her primary shift occurred just before this text begins by unexpectedly and graciously welcoming her old American friends. Within the passage, she is a stable center of power, actively managing her social circle and setting events in motion for the other characters.

That sense of quantities, separate or mixed, was indeed doubtless what most prevailed at first for our slightly gasping American pair; it found utterance for them in their frequent remark to each other that they had no one but themselves to thank. It dropped from Milly more than once that if she had ever known it was so easy—! though her exclamation mostly ended without completing her idea. This, however, was a trifle to Mrs. Stringham, who cared little whether she meant that in this case she would have come sooner. She couldn't have come sooner, and she perhaps, on the contrary, meant—for it would have been like her—that she wouldn't have come at all; why it was so easy being at any rate a matter as to which her companion had begun quickly to pick up views. Susie kept some of these lights for the present to herself, since, freely communicated, they might have been a little disturbing; with which, moreover, the quantities that we speak of as surrounding the two ladies were, in many cases, quantities of things—and of other things—to talk about. Their immediate lesson, accordingly, was that they just had been caught up by the incalculable strength of a wave that was actually holding them aloft and that would naturally dash them wherever it liked. They meanwhile, we hasten to add, make the best of their precarious position, and if Milly had had no other help for it she would have found not a little in the sight of Susan Shepherd's state. The girl had had nothing to say to her, for three days, about the "success" announced by Lord Mark—which they saw, besides, otherwise established; she was too taken up, too touched, by Susie's own exaltation. Susie glowed in the light of her justified faith; everything had happened that she had been acute enough to think least probable; she had appealed to a possible delicacy in Maud Manningham—a delicacy, mind you, but barely possible—and her appeal had been met in a way that was an honour to human nature. This proved sensibility of the lady of Lancaster Gate performed verily, for both our friends, during these first days, the office of a fine floating gold-dust, something that threw over the prospect a harmonising blur. The forms, the colours behind it were strong and deep—we have seen how they already stood out for Milly; but nothing, comparatively, had had so much of the dignity of truth as the fact of Maud's fidelity to a sentiment. That was what Susie was proud of, much more than of her great place in the world, which she was moreover conscious of not as yet wholly measuring. That was what was more vivid even than her being—in senses more worldly and in fact almost in the degree of a revelation—English and distinct and positive, with almost no inward, but with the finest outward resonance.

Translation

The understanding of quantities, whether separate or combined, was undoubtedly the initial focus for our slightly bewildered American pair. They frequently remarked to each other that they were entirely responsible for their situation. Milly often mentioned that if she'd known it would be this easy—! though she rarely finished the thought. However, this didn't bother Mrs. Stringham, who didn't care whether Milly meant she would have come sooner. She couldn't have come sooner, and perhaps, on the contrary, she meant—as was typical of her—that she wouldn't have come at all. The ease of the situation was a concept Milly was quickly grasping. Susie kept some of her insights to herself for the time being, as sharing them freely might have been unsettling. Besides, the "quantities" surrounding the two women were, in many cases, things—and other things—to discuss. Their immediate lesson was that they'd been swept up by the overwhelming power of a wave, which was lifting them up and would naturally carry them wherever it chose. Meanwhile, they made the best of their precarious situation, and if Milly had nothing else to rely on, she would have found solace in observing Susan Shepherd's state. Susie hadn't mentioned Lord Mark's announced "success" for three days—which they also knew had been accomplished in other ways. She was too preoccupied and moved by Susie's own elation. Susie radiated with the joy of her confirmed beliefs; everything had happened that she'd thought least likely. She'd appealed to a possible sense of decency in Maud Manningham—a barely possible decency, mind you—and her appeal had been answered in a way that honored human nature. This demonstrated sensitivity from the woman of Lancaster Gate acted, for both friends, like a fine, floating gold dust during those first few days, softening the overall view with a harmonious blur. The shapes and colors behind it were strong and deep—as we've seen they already were for Milly; but nothing, in comparison, possessed as much the dignity of truth as Maud's loyalty to a feeling. That was what Susie was proud of, more than her high social standing, which she was still getting used to. That was more vivid even than her being—in a more worldly sense and to a degree that felt almost like a revelation—English and distinct and confident, with little introspection but the finest outward charm.

Susan Shepherd's word for her, again and again, was that she was "large"; yet it was not exactly a case, as to the soul, of echoing chambers: she might have been likened rather to a capacious receptacle, originally perhaps loose, but now drawn as tightly as possible over its accumulated contents—a packed mass, for her American admirer, of curious detail. When the latter good lady, at home, had handsomely figured her friends as not small—which was the way she mostly figured them—there was a certain implication that they were spacious because they were empty. Mrs. Lowder, by a different law, was spacious because she was full, because she had something in common, even in repose, with a projectile, of great size, loaded and ready for use. That indeed, to Susie's romantic mind, announced itself as half the charm of their renewal—a charm as of sitting in springtime, during a long peace, on the daisied, grassy bank of some great slumbering fortress. True to her psychological instincts, certainly, Mrs. Stringham had noted that the "sentiment" she rejoiced in on her old schoolmate's part was all a matter of action and movement, was not, save for the interweaving of a more frequent plump "dearest" than she would herself perhaps have used, a matter of much other embroidery. She brooded, with interest, on this further remark of race, feeling in her own spirit a different economy. The joy, for her, was to know why she acted—the reason was half the business; whereas with Mrs. Lowder there might have been no reason: "why" was the trivial seasoning-substance, the vanilla or the nutmeg, omittable from the nutritive pudding without spoiling it. Mrs. Lowder's desire was clearly sharp that their young companions should also prosper together; and Mrs. Stringham's account of it all to Milly, during the first days, was that when, at Lancaster Gate, she was not occupied in telling, as it were, about her, she was occupied in hearing much of the history of her hostess's brilliant niece.

Translation

Susan Shepherd repeatedly described her as "large," but it wasn't like she had an empty, echoing personality. She was more like a huge container. It might have been initially loose, but now it was tightly packed with everything she'd accumulated—a dense collection of interesting details for her American admirer. When that nice American woman would describe her friends as "not small" (which was her usual way of putting it), she implied they were spacious because they were empty. Mrs. Lowder, however, was spacious because she was full. She had something inside, even when she was still, like a massive, loaded projectile, ready to be launched. To Susie, this was half the appeal of their renewed connection—it was like sitting peacefully on a grassy bank covered in daisies during springtime, next to a huge, sleeping fortress.

Following her instincts, Mrs. Stringham had noticed that the "affection" her old friend felt was expressed through action and behavior. It wasn't about flowery language, except for the frequent use of "dearest," a term she herself wouldn't use as often. She thought about this difference with interest, because her own personality worked differently. For her, the joy was in understanding her own motives—the reasons behind her actions were essential. But with Mrs. Lowder, there might be no reason at all: the "why" was just a trivial detail, like vanilla or nutmeg, that could be left out of a nourishing pudding without changing it.

Mrs. Lowder clearly wanted their young friends to succeed together. Mrs. Stringham told Milly during their first few days that when she wasn't talking about Mrs. Lowder, she was listening to the history of her brilliant niece.

They had plenty, on these lines, the two elder women, to give and to take, and it was even not quite clear to the pilgrim from Boston that what she should mainly have arranged for in London was not a series of thrills for herself. She had a bad conscience, indeed almost a sense of immorality, in having to recognise that she was, as she said, carried away. She laughed to Milly when she also said that she didn't know where it would end; and the principal of her uneasiness was that Mrs. Lowder's life bristled for her with elements that she was really having to look at for the first time. They represented, she believed, the world, the world that, as a consequence of the cold shoulder turned to it by the Pilgrim Fathers, had never yet boldly crossed to Boston—it would surely have sunk the stoutest Cunarder—and she couldn't pretend that she faced the prospect simply because Milly had had a caprice. She was in the act herself of having one, directed precisely to their present spectacle. She could but seek strength in the thought that she had never had one—or had never yielded to one, which came to the same thing—before. The sustaining sense of it all, moreover, as literary material—that quite dropped from her. She must wait, at any rate, she should see: it struck her, so far as she had got, as vast, obscure, lurid. She reflected in the watches of the night that she was probably just going to love it for itself—that is for itself and Milly. The odd thing was that she could think of Milly's loving it without dread—or with dread, at least not on the score of conscience, only on the score of peace. It was a mercy, at all events, for the hour, that their fancies jumped together.

Translation

The two older women had lots to talk about and discuss, and the visitor from Boston wasn't even sure that the main thing she should have been doing in London wasn't just chasing exciting experiences for herself. She felt guilty, almost like she was doing something wrong, admitting that she was, as she put it, getting swept away. She laughed to Milly when she also said she didn't know where it would lead. Her main worry was that Mrs. Lowder's life was filled with things she was really seeing for the first time. She thought these things represented the world, the world that, because the Pilgrim Fathers had rejected it, had never boldly gone to Boston—it would probably sink the biggest ship—and she couldn't pretend that she was facing this situation just because Milly had a whim. She was having a whim of her own, specifically directed at what they were experiencing. She could only find comfort in the idea that she had never had a whim—or had never given in to one, which amounted to the same thing—before. The idea that all this could be used as material for writing—that completely disappeared. She had to wait, anyway, and she would see: it seemed to her, at this stage, vast, unclear, and shocking. She realized during the night that she was probably going to love it just for what it was—that is, for itself and for Milly. The strange thing was that she could imagine Milly loving it without fear—or with fear, but not because she felt guilty, only because she worried about their peace of mind. It was a good thing, for now at least, that their imaginations were running in the same direction.

While, for this first week that followed their dinner, she drank deep at Lancaster Gate, her companion was no less happily, appeared to be indeed on the whole quite as romantically, provided for. The handsome English girl from the heavy English house had been as a figure in a picture stepping by magic out of its frame: it was a case, in truth, for which Mrs. Stringham presently found the perfect image. She had lost none of her grasp, but quite the contrary, of that other conceit in virtue of which Milly was the wandering princess: so what could be more in harmony now than to see the princess waited upon at the city gate by the worthiest maiden, the chosen daughter of the burgesses? It was the real again, evidently, the amusement of the meeting for the princess too; princesses living for the most part, in such an appeased way, on the plane of mere elegant representation. That was why they pounced, at city gates, on deputed flower-strewing damsels; that was why, after effigies, processions, and other stately games, frank human company was pleasant to them. Kate Croy really presented herself to Milly—the latter abounded for Mrs. Stringham in accounts of it—as the wondrous London girl in person, by what she had conceived, from far back, of the London girl; conceived from the tales of travellers and the anecdotes of New York, from old porings over Punch and a liberal acquaintance with the fiction of the day. The only thing was that she was nicer, for the creature in question had rather been, to our young woman, an image of dread. She had thought of her, at her best, as handsome just as Kate was, with turns of head and tones of voice, felicities of stature and attitude, things "put on" and, for that matter, put off, all the marks of the product of a packed society who should be at the same time the heroine of a strong story. She placed this striking young person from the first in a story, saw her, by a necessity of the imagination, for a heroine, felt it the only character in which she wouldn't be wasted; and this in spite of the heroine's pleasant abruptness, her forbearance from gush, her umbrellas and jackets and shoes—as these things sketched themselves to Milly—and something rather of a breezy boy in the carriage of her arms and the occasional freedom of her slang.

Translation

For the week after their dinner, while Milly was enjoying herself at Lancaster Gate, her friend seemed equally happy, maybe even more romantically content. The beautiful English woman from the wealthy English family was like a character stepping out of a painting; Mrs. Stringham found the perfect metaphor for it. Milly still held onto the idea of being a wandering princess, so it was fitting to see her met at the city gate by the most deserving woman, the chosen daughter of the townspeople. It was reality again, obviously, and amusing for the princess as well, since princesses usually lived in a world of formal appearances. That’s why they loved meeting the flower-bearing girls at city gates, and why they enjoyed genuine company after the ceremonies and displays.

Kate Croy genuinely came across to Milly—as Mrs. Stringham heard repeatedly—as the amazing "London girl" in the flesh, a person based on what Milly had imagined from her early days: the London girl she’d read about in travelers’ stories and New York anecdotes, from old issues of Punch magazine, and a good understanding of contemporary fiction. The only difference was that Kate was even nicer. Milly had previously pictured her as intimidating, at best, beautiful like Kate, with a similar way of turning her head and speaking, a similar posture, a look that was both deliberate and easily discarded; all the hallmarks of a product of high society who should be the heroine of a powerful story. Milly immediately saw this striking young woman as a character in a story, a heroine by necessity, the only role where she wouldn’t be wasted. This was despite the heroine's friendly directness, her lack of emotional outbursts, and the practical clothes she wore—umbrellas, jackets, shoes—as Milly imagined them, and the slightly tomboyish way she carried herself and the occasional use of slang.

When Milly had settled that the extent of her goodwill itself made her shy, she had found for the moment quite a sufficient key, and they were by that time thoroughly afloat together. This might well have been the happiest hour they were to know, attacking in friendly independence their great London—the London of shops and streets and suburbs oddly interesting to Milly, as well as of museums, monuments, "sights" oddly unfamiliar to Kate, while their elders pursued a separate course, both rejoicing in their intimacy and each thinking the other's young woman a great acquisition for her own. Milly expressed to Susan Shepherd more than once that Kate had some secret, some smothered trouble, besides all the rest of her history; and that if she had so good-naturedly helped Mrs. Lowder to meet them this was exactly to create a diversion, to give herself something else to think about. But on the case thus postulated our young American had as yet had no light: she only felt that when the light should come it would greatly deepen the colour; and she liked to think she was prepared for anything. What she already knew, moreover, was full to her vision, of English, of eccentric, of Thackerayan character, Kate Croy having gradually become not a little explicit on the subject of her situation, her past, her present, her general predicament, her small success, up to the present hour, in contenting at the same time her father, her sister, her aunt and herself. It was Milly's subtle guess, imparted to her Susie, that the girl had somebody else as well, as yet unnamed, to content, it being manifest that such a creature couldn't help having; a creature not perhaps, if one would, exactly formed to inspire passions, since that always implied a certain silliness, but essentially seen, by the admiring eye of friendship, under the clear shadow of some probably eminent male interest. The clear shadow, from whatever source projected, hung, at any rate, over Milly's companion the whole week, and Kate Croy's handsome face smiled out of it, under bland skylights, in the presence alike of old masters passive in their glory and of thoroughly new ones, the newest, who bristled restlessly with pins and brandished snipping shears.

Translation

Milly, having decided that her own friendly nature made her shy, had found a way to connect with Kate, and they were really enjoying each other's company. This might have been the best time they ever had together, exploring London on their own – the London of stores, streets, and suburbs that Milly found fascinating, and the museums, monuments, and "sights" that were new to Kate. Meanwhile, their parents were occupied elsewhere, both happy about the girls' friendship, each thinking the other's daughter was a wonderful friend. Milly told Susan Shepherd more than once that Kate was hiding something, some kind of hidden worry, on top of everything else she'd been through. She thought that if Kate had helped Mrs. Lowder meet them, it was just to distract herself, to give herself something else to focus on. But Milly, as a young American, didn't know the full story yet. She just felt that when the truth came out, it would be much more complicated than she thought. And she liked to believe she was ready for anything. What she *did* know was that Kate Croy's situation was full of the kind of English, quirky, and slightly old-fashioned things you'd find in a novel. Kate had slowly told Milly about her life, her past, her current problems, her general difficult situation, and how little she'd succeeded in pleasing her father, her sister, her aunt, and herself up to that point. Milly subtly guessed, and told her friend Susie, that Kate also had someone else to please, someone she hadn't mentioned yet. It was obvious that someone like Kate would have someone like that; someone who perhaps wasn't meant to inspire passionate love, since that always seemed a bit silly, but who was clearly very important, likely a prominent man, from the perspective of their friendship. That sense of something important in the background, no matter where it came from, hung over Milly's friend all week. Kate Croy's attractive face smiled out from under the soft light of the city, in the company of both classic, respected paintings and the newest artists, who were bustling with activity and wielding scissors.

It was meanwhile a pretty part of the intercourse of these young ladies that each thought the other more remarkable than herself—that each thought herself, or assured the other she did, a comparatively dusty object and the other a favourite of nature and of fortune. Kate was amused, amazed at the way her friend insisted on "taking" her, and Milly wondered if Kate were sincere in finding her the most extraordinary—quite apart from her being the most charming—person she had come across. They had talked, in long drives, and quantities of history had not been wanting—in the light of which Mrs. Lowder's niece might superficially seem to have had the best of the argument. Her visitor's American references, with their bewildering immensities, their confounding moneyed New York, their excitements of high pressure, their opportunities of wild freedom, their record of used-up relatives, parents, clever, eager, fair, slim brothers—these the most loved—all engaged, as well as successive superseded guardians, in a high extravagance of speculation and dissipation that had left this exquisite being her black dress, her white face and her vivid hair as the mere last broken link: such a picture quite threw into the shade the brief biography, however sketchily amplified, of a mere middle-class nobody in Bayswater. And though that indeed might be but a Bayswater way of putting it, in addition to which Milly was in the stage of interest in Bayswater ways, this critic so far prevailed that, like Mrs. Stringham herself, she fairly got her companion to accept from her that she was quite the nearest approach to a practical princess Bayswater could hope ever to know. It was a fact—it became one at the end of three days—that Milly actually began to borrow from the handsome girl a sort of view of her state; the handsome girl's impression of it was clearly so sincere. This impression was a tribute, a tribute positively to power, power the source of which was the last thing Kate treated as a mystery. There were passages, under all their skylights, the succession of their shops being large, in which the latter's easy, yet the least bit dry manner sufficiently gave out that if she had had so deep a pocket——!

Translation

The interesting thing about their friendship was that each of these young women thought the other was more extraordinary than herself. Each one considered herself, or pretended to consider herself, rather ordinary, while she believed the other was favored by both nature and good luck. Kate was amused and surprised by how her friend insisted on admiring her, and Milly wondered if Kate was sincere in thinking her the most fascinating person she’d ever met, aside from being the most charming. They had talked during long drives, and they’d discussed a lot of history—in light of which, Mrs. Lowder’s niece might have superficially seemed to have the upper hand in their discussions. Kate's American background, with its overwhelming scale, its bewilderingly wealthy New York, its fast-paced excitement, its freedom, and its history of relatives who had been exhausted—parents, clever, enthusiastic, attractive, slim brothers (who were most beloved)—all of whom were involved, along with a string of replaced guardians, in an extravagant lifestyle of risky investments and overindulgence. This picture left Kate with just her black dress, her pale face, and her striking hair as the only remaining evidence of her past. This kind of background completely overshadowed the short, even if well-detailed, biography of an average middle-class woman in Bayswater. Although that might have simply been a Bayswater way of looking at it, and Milly was currently quite interested in Bayswater ways, this assessment was so convincing that, like Mrs. Stringham herself, Milly actually got Kate to accept that she was the closest thing to a real princess that Bayswater could ever hope to have. It was a fact—established after just three days—that Milly actually began to adopt Kate’s perspective on her own situation, because Kate’s view of it was clearly so sincere. This impression was a tribute, a tribute to power, and Kate made no secret of where she believed that power came from. There were moments, in all the brightly lit shopping areas, given the size of the shops, when Kate’s easygoing, slightly detached manner was enough to suggest that if she had access to such deep pockets…!

It was not moreover by any means with not having the imagination of expenditure that she appeared to charge her friend, but with not having the imagination of terror, of thrift, the imagination or in any degree the habit of a conscious dependence on others. Such moments, when all Wigmore Street, for instance, seemed to rustle about and the pale girl herself to be facing the different rustlers, usually so undiscriminated, as individual Britons too, Britons personal, parties to a relation and perhaps even intrinsically remarkable—such moments in especial determined in Kate a perception of the high happiness of her companion's liberty. Milly's range was thus immense; she had to ask nobody for anything, to refer nothing to any one; her freedom, her fortune and her fancy were her law; an obsequious world surrounded her, she could sniff up at every step its fumes. And Kate, in these days, was altogether in the phase of forgiving her so much bliss; in the phase moreover of believing that, should they continue to go on together, she would abide in that generosity. She had, at such a point as this, no suspicion of a rift within the lute—by which we mean not only none of anything's coming between them, but none of any definite flaw in so much clearness of quality. Yet, all the same, if Milly, at Mrs. Lowder's banquet, had described herself to Lord Mark as kindly used by the young woman on the other side because of some faintly-felt special propriety in it, so there really did match with this, privately, on the young woman's part, a feeling not analysed but divided, a latent impression that Mildred Theale was not, after all, a person to change places, to change even chances with. Kate, verily, would perhaps not quite have known what she meant by this reservation, and she came near naming it only when she said to herself that, rich as Milly was, one probably wouldn't—which was singular—ever hate her for it. The handsome girl had, with herself, these felicities and crudities: it wasn't obscure to her that, without some very particular reason to help, it might have proved a test of one's philosophy not to be irritated by a mistress of millions, or whatever they were, who, as a girl, so easily might have been, like herself, only vague and fatally female. She was by no means sure of liking Aunt Maud as much as she deserved, and Aunt Maud's command of funds was obviously inferior to Milly's. There was thus clearly, as pleading for the latter, some influence that would later on become distinct; and meanwhile, decidedly, it was enough that she was as charming as she was queer and as queer as she was charming—all of which was a rare amusement; as well, for that matter, as further sufficient that there were objects of value she had already pressed on Kate's acceptance. A week of her society in these conditions—conditions that Milly chose to sum up as ministering immensely, for a blind, vague pilgrim, to aid and comfort—announced itself from an early hour as likely to become a week of presents, acknowledgments, mementos, pledges of gratitude and admiration that were all on one side. Kate as promptly embraced the propriety of making it clear that she must forswear shops till she should receive some guarantee that the contents of each one she entered as a humble companion should not be placed at her feet; yet that was in truth not before she had found herself in possession, under whatever protests, of several precious ornaments and other minor conveniences.

Translation

It wasn't that she accused her friend of being extravagant, but rather of lacking the imagination to be afraid, or economical, or the imagination—or even the habit—of relying on others. In those moments, when all of Wigmore Street, for example, seemed to buzz around them, and the pale girl herself was facing the various people—usually indistinguishable, but also individual, unique people—involved in their relationship and perhaps even intrinsically interesting, those moments especially made Kate recognize how happy her friend was to be so free. Milly’s possibilities were vast; she didn’t have to ask anyone for anything, or defer to anyone; her freedom, her wealth, and her whims were her only rules. An attentive world surrounded her, and she could inhale its offerings at every turn. And in those days, Kate was completely in the process of forgiving Milly for having so much joy, and she also believed that if they stayed together, she would continue to be that generous. She had no suspicion at this point of any trouble, meaning not only that nothing would come between them, but also that there was no noticeable flaw in their apparently perfect relationship. However, even so, if Milly, at Mrs. Lowder’s party, had described herself to Lord Mark as being treated kindly by the young woman on the other side of her because she felt a certain subtle sense of appropriateness in it, then in truth there was something similar happening privately on the young woman's part, a feeling that wasn't fully understood but was divided, a hidden impression that Mildred Theale was not, after all, someone Kate would want to trade places or chances with. Kate wouldn't quite have known what she meant by this reservation, and she almost clarified it when she told herself that, rich as Milly was, one probably wouldn't—and this was strange—ever hate her for it. The beautiful girl had these good and bad qualities: it wasn't a secret that, without some very specific reason to help, it might have been a test of one's philosophy not to be annoyed by a woman who had millions, or whatever, who, as a girl, could so easily have been just as vague and inevitably female as she was. She definitely wasn't sure she liked Aunt Maud as much as she deserved, and Aunt Maud's wealth was obviously less than Milly's. Therefore, there was a clear advantage to Milly's position that would become more distinct later on; and for the time being, it was enough that she was as delightful as she was strange, and as strange as she was delightful—which was all very entertaining. Additionally, it was also sufficient that there were valuable gifts she had already given to Kate. A week of her company in these circumstances—circumstances that Milly chose to describe as tremendously helping and comforting a blind, vague pilgrim—was turning out to be a week of presents, acknowledgments, souvenirs, pledges of gratitude and admiration all coming from one side. Kate quickly agreed that she must stop shopping until she could be sure that the items in any store she entered as a humble companion wouldn't be offered to her; yet that was really only after she had found herself in possession, despite her protests, of several precious ornaments and other small conveniences.

Great was the absurdity, too, that there should have come a day, by the end of the week, when it appeared that all Milly would have asked in definite "return," as might be said, was to be told a little about Lord Mark and to be promised the privilege of a visit to Mrs. Condrip. Far other amusements had been offered her, but her eagerness was shamelessly human, and she seemed really to count more on the revelation of the anxious lady of Chelsea than on the best nights of the opera. Kate admired, and showed it, such an absence of fear: to the fear of being bored, in such a connection, she would have been so obviously entitled. Milly's answer to this was the plea of her curiosities—which left her friend wondering as to their odd direction. Some among them, no doubt, were rather more intelligible, and Kate had heard without wonder that she was blank about Lord Mark. This young lady's account of him, at the same time, professed itself as frankly imperfect; for what they best knew him by at Lancaster Gate was a thing difficult to explain. One knew people in general by something they had to show, something that, either for them or against, could be touched or named or proved; and she could think of no other case of a value taken as so great and yet flourishing untested. His value was his future, which had somehow got itself as accepted by Aunt Maud as if it had been his good cook or his steam-launch. She, Kate, didn't mean she thought him a humbug; he might do great things—but they were all, as yet, so to speak, he had done. On the other hand it was of course something of an achievement, and not open to every one, to have got one's self taken so seriously by Aunt Maud. The best thing about him, doubtless, on the whole, was that Aunt Maud believed in him. She was often fantastic, but she knew a humbug, and—no, Lord Mark wasn't that. He had been a short time in the House, on the Tory side, but had lost his seat on the first opportunity, and this was all he had to point to. However, he pointed to nothing; which was very possibly just a sign of his real cleverness, one of those that the really clever had in common with the really void. Even Aunt Maud frequently admitted that there was a good deal, for her view of him, to come up in the rear. And he wasn't meanwhile himself indifferent—indifferent to himself—for he was working Lancaster Gate for all it was worth: just as it was, no doubt, working him, and just as the working and the worked were in London, as one might explain, the parties to every relation.

Translation

It was also pretty absurd that, by the end of the week, it seemed all Milly wanted in exchange for everything was to hear a bit about Lord Mark and be promised a visit to Mrs. Condrip. She'd been offered other things, but her enthusiasm was completely normal, and she seemed more excited about getting information from the worried lady in Chelsea than attending the best opera performances. Kate admired this lack of fear, and made it clear; Milly, in her position, would have been completely justified in being afraid of being bored. Milly's explanation was her curiosity, which made her friend wonder why she was interested in those particular things. Some of her curiosities were easier to understand, and Kate wasn’t surprised to hear that Milly knew very little about Lord Mark. Kate’s own description of him was also honestly incomplete because it was hard to describe him based on what they knew at Lancaster Gate. One usually knew people by what they had to show, something that could be seen, named, or proven. But she couldn't think of another instance where someone's worth was so high and yet unproven. His worth was based on his future, which Aunt Maud had somehow accepted as fact, just as if he had a good cook or a steam-powered boat. Kate wasn’t suggesting he was a fraud; he might do great things—but as of now, he hadn’t done anything. On the other hand, getting Aunt Maud to take you so seriously was certainly an accomplishment that not everyone could achieve. The best thing about him, no doubt, was that Aunt Maud believed in him. She was often eccentric, but she could spot a fake, and, no, Lord Mark wasn't that. He’d briefly been a member of Parliament, a Conservative, but had lost his seat right away, and that was all he could point to. However, he didn't point to anything, which might be a sign of his intelligence, one of those traits that the truly clever people shared with those who were empty-headed. Even Aunt Maud often admitted that there was a lot about him that remained to be seen. And in the meantime, he wasn’t indifferent—indifferent to himself—as he was actively trying to exploit Lancaster Gate: just as, no doubt, it was exploiting him, and just as the one who does the exploiting and the one who is exploited are, in London, the two sides of every relationship.

Kate did explain, for her listening friend: every one who had anything to give—it was true they were the fewest—made the sharpest possible bargain for it, got at least its value in return. The strangest thing, furthermore, was that this might be, in cases, a happy understanding. The worker in one connection was the worked in another; it was as broad as it was long—with the wheels of the system, as might be seen, wonderfully oiled. People could quite like each other in the midst of it, as Aunt Maud, by every appearance, quite liked Lord Mark, and as Lord Mark, it was to be hoped, liked Mrs. Lowder, since if he didn't he was a greater brute than one could believe. She, Kate, had not yet, it was true, made out what he was doing for her—besides which the dear woman needed him, even at the most he could do, much less than she imagined; so far as all of which went, moreover, there were plenty of things on every side she had not yet made out. She believed, on the whole, in any one Aunt Maud took up; and she gave it to Milly as worth thinking of that, whatever wonderful people this young lady might meet in the land, she would meet no more extraordinary woman. There were greater celebrities by the million, and of course greater swells, but a bigger person, by Kate's view, and a larger natural handful every way, would really be far to seek. When Milly inquired with interest if Kate's belief in her was primarily on the lines of what Mrs. Lowder "took up," her interlocutress could handsomely say yes, since by the same principle she believed in herself. Whom but Aunt Maud's niece, pre-eminently, had Aunt Maud taken up, and who was thus more in the current, with her, of working and of being worked? "You may ask," Kate said, "what in the world I have to give; and that indeed is just what I'm trying to learn. There must be something, for her to think she can get it out of me. She will get it—trust her; and then I shall see what it is; which I beg you to believe I should never have found out for myself." She declined to treat any question of Milly's own "paying" power as discussable; that Milly would pay a hundred per cent.—and even to the end, doubtless, through the nose—was just the beautiful basis on which they found themselves.

Translation

Kate explained to her friend Milly: everyone who had something to offer – and those people were the fewest – drove the hardest possible bargain, getting at least its value in return. The strangest thing was that this could, in some cases, be a mutually beneficial arrangement. The person using someone else was also being used by someone else; it was a fair exchange – with the gears of the system, as you could see, running smoothly. People could genuinely like each other within it, just as Aunt Maud, seemingly, liked Lord Mark, and hopefully, Lord Mark liked Mrs. Lowder. Otherwise, he was a bigger jerk than one would imagine.

Kate hadn't yet figured out what Lord Mark was doing for her – and the dear woman needed him, even with what he was doing, which was less than she realized. Besides that, there were plenty of things she hadn't figured out on all sides. She generally trusted anyone Aunt Maud approved of. And she told Milly that it was worth considering that, no matter how many impressive people Milly might meet, she wouldn't meet a more extraordinary woman than Aunt Maud. There were millions of more famous people, and of course, more wealthy people, but Kate thought it would be difficult to find anyone more impressive, or with more natural strength.

When Milly asked if Kate's belief in her was based primarily on Aunt Maud's approval, Kate could honestly say yes, because she believed in herself based on the same principle. Who else had Aunt Maud taken under her wing, more than her own niece? Who was more involved in this system of using and being used, alongside her? "You might ask," Kate said, "what I have to offer. That’s exactly what I’m trying to figure out. There must be something, for her to think she can get something from me. She will get it – trust her. And then I’ll see what it is, which I swear I would never have figured out on my own." She refused to discuss the idea of Milly "paying" for anything; that Milly would pay generously – and likely be taken advantage of in the end – was the very foundation of their relationship.

These were fine facilities, pleasantries, ironies, all these luxuries of gossip and philosophies of London and of life, and they became quickly, between the pair, the common form of talk, Milly professing herself delighted to know that something was to be done with her. If the most remarkable woman in England was to do it, so much the better, and if the most remarkable woman in England had them both in hand together, why, what could be jollier for each? When she reflected indeed a little on the oddity of her wanting two at once, Kate had the natural reply that it was exactly what showed her sincerity. She invariably gave way to feeling, and feeling had distinctly popped up in her on the advent of her girlhood's friend. The way the cat would jump was always, in presence of anything that moved her, interesting to see; visibly enough, moreover, for a long time, it hadn't jumped anything like so far. This, in fact, as we already know, remained the marvel for Milly Theale, who, on sight of Mrs. Lowder, found fifty links in respect to Susie absent from the chain of association. She knew so herself what she thought of Susie that she would have expected the lady of Lancaster Gate to think something quite different; the failure of which endlessly mystified her. But her mystification was the cause for her of another fine impression, inasmuch as when she went so far as to observe to Kate that Susan Shepherd—and especially Susan Shepherd emerging so uninvited from an irrelevant past—ought, by all the proprieties, simply to have bored Aunt Maud, her confidant agreed with her without a protest and abounded in the sense of her wonder. Susan Shepherd at least bored the niece—that was plain; this young woman saw nothing in her—nothing to account for anything, not even for Milly's own indulgence: which little fact became in turn to the latter's mind a fact of significance. It was a light on the handsome girl—representing more than merely showed—that poor Susie was simply as nought to her. This was, in a manner too, a general admonition to poor Susie's companion, who seemed to see marked by it the direction in which she had best most look out.

Translation

These were all great things to have – the nice surroundings, the jokes, the witty remarks. They were the little luxuries of gossip, London life, and intellectual discussions, and they quickly became the everyday topic between the two women. Milly was thrilled to know that something was planned for her. If the most important woman in England was involved, that was even better. And if that important woman had them both working together, well, how fun for everyone!

When Kate thought about the unusualness of wanting both of them involved at once, she had the ready answer that it showed her genuine feelings. She always acted on her feelings, and those feelings had definitely intensified when her childhood friend arrived. It was always interesting to see how she would react when something moved her; obviously, she hadn't reacted so strongly in a long time.

That, in fact, was still the amazing thing for Milly Theale. Seeing Mrs. Lowder, Milly realized that her previous connection to Susie was gone. She knew what she thought of Susie and expected the woman from Lancaster Gate to disagree. This disagreement baffled her endlessly.

But her confusion gave her another positive impression, because when she pointed out to Kate that Susan Shepherd – and especially her unexpected re-emergence from the past – should have, by all rights, bored Aunt Maud, Kate agreed without question and shared her surprise. At least Susan Shepherd bored the niece – that much was clear. Kate saw nothing in her – nothing to explain anything, not even Milly’s interest in her. This became significant to Milly. It revealed something about Kate – that she was more than she seemed – because poor Susie meant nothing to her.

In a way, it was also a warning to poor Susie's friend, who probably realized that the best course of action was to be on her guard.

It just faintly rankled in her that a person who was good enough and to spare for Milly Theale shouldn't be good enough for another girl; though, oddly enough, she could easily have forgiven Mrs. Lowder herself the impatience. Mrs. Lowder didn't feel it, and Kate Croy felt it with ease; yet in the end, be it added, she grasped the reason, and the reason enriched her mind. Wasn't it sufficiently the reason that the handsome girl was, with twenty other splendid qualities, the least bit brutal too, and didn't she suggest, as no one yet had ever done for her new friend, that there might be a wild beauty in that, and even a strange grace? Kate wasn't brutally brutal—which Milly had hitherto benightedly supposed the only way; she wasn't even aggressively so, but rather indifferently, defensively and, as might be said, by the habit of anticipation. She simplified in advance, was beforehand with her doubts, and knew with singular quickness what she wasn't, as they said in New York, going to like. In that way at least people were clearly quicker in England than at home; and Milly could quite see, after a little, how such instincts might become usual in a world in which dangers abounded. There were more dangers, clearly, round about Lancaster Gate than one suspected in New York or could dream of in Boston. At all events, with more sense of them, there were more precautions, and it was a remarkable world altogether in which there could be precautions, on whatever ground, against Susie.

Translation

It bothered her a little that someone considered "good enough" for Milly Theale wouldn't be considered good enough for another girl. Oddly enough, she could easily have understood Mrs. Lowder's impatience if Mrs. Lowder *had* felt it. Kate Croy easily felt the impatience, but ultimately she understood the reason, and that understanding made her smarter. Wasn't the reason obvious? The beautiful girl, along with many other amazing qualities, was also a little insensitive. Didn't this girl, for the first time, hint to Kate's new friend that there might be something wild and beautiful, even graceful, in that insensitivity? Kate wasn't overtly cruel, which Milly had mistakenly thought was the only kind of cruelty. She wasn't even aggressively cruel, but rather indifferent, defensive, and as though she'd developed the habit of anticipating negativity. She made assumptions in advance, preempted her own doubts, and knew almost immediately what she wouldn't like. In that way, at least, people in England seemed faster to judge than people back home. Milly could quickly see how such instincts might be common in a world full of threats. There were clearly more dangers around Lancaster Gate than anyone in New York even suspected or in Boston could imagine. At the very least, because of this heightened awareness of danger, there were more precautions. It was a remarkable world, indeed, where precautions could be taken, for any reason, against Susie.

Chapter IX

Chapter Summary & Character Study
Summary

During a drive in Battersea Park, Susan (Susie) Shepherd learns from Mrs. Lowder that Mrs. Lowder and her niece, Kate Croy, are acquainted with Milly's friend, Mr. Merton Densher. Later, Susie tells Milly this news. Milly acts surprised. Susie explains that Mrs. Lowder mentioned a young journalist who had gone to America, and Susie confirmed it was Mr. Densher, an acquaintance of Milly's.

Milly tells Susie that she did the right thing in revealing the connection. Susie then relays a message from Mrs. Lowder: Milly should not mention Mr. Densher to Kate unless Kate brings him up first. Milly asks if there is something between Kate and Mr. Densher. Susie says she thinks not, but Mrs. Lowder is being cautious. Susie adds that Mrs. Lowder wants her niece to marry Lord Mark.

For the next few days, Milly observes Kate, knowing that Kate also knows Mr. Densher, but says nothing to her about it.

Milly and Kate visit Kate’s sister, Mrs. Condrip. Later that evening, Milly tells Susie what happened during the visit. While Kate was out of the room, Mrs. Condrip told Milly that Mr. Densher is in love with Kate, which she considers a dreadful situation because of his poverty. Mrs. Condrip asked Milly to help do something about it and also asked Milly not to tell Kate about their conversation. Milly did not tell Mrs. Condrip that she herself knew Mr. Densher.

Milly tells Susie that according to Mrs. Condrip, Mrs. Lowder disapproves of Mr. Densher. Susie corrects this, saying Mrs. Lowder actually likes him and thinks he is very able. Milly and Susie discuss the situation. Milly believes that if Mrs. Condrip knew that Milly also knew Densher, she would tell Kate in order to make Kate jealous and turn her against him. Milly concludes the conversation by clarifying that Mrs. Condrip only said that Densher was in love with Kate, not that Kate was in love with him. She says that if Kate were in love, Mrs. Condrip would have said so.

Character Study

Based on the text, here is a concise character study:

  • *Milly Theale**
  • **Presentation:** Milly is presented as a character with a stark public/private divide. In public, she can be "detached as the occasion required," but in private, she is deeply intimate and open with her confidante, Susan Shepherd. She is wealthy, observant, and possesses a "strange gaiety" coupled with a fascination for social complexity, stating, "I want abysses." She also displays a morbid, fatalistic humor regarding a fragile health condition.
  • **Situational Shift:** Her situation shifts dramatically with the news that her new friend, Kate Croy, and her circle already know her recent acquaintance, Merton Densher. This revelation "altered all proportions" for her, turning an amusing coincidence into a "new sort of fun" containing "a small element of anxiety." She immediately becomes a participant in a social intrigue, agreeing to keep her knowledge of Densher a secret from Kate.
  • *Susan Shepherd (Susie/Mrs. Stringham)**
  • **Presentation:** She is Milly's loyal, devoted, and sometimes "venerably simple" companion. She serves as Milly's primary confidante and feels a protective, almost maternal duty towards her ("I'd die for you"). She is presented as a somewhat flustered navigator of the complex English social world she has been "rapt" into.
  • **Situational Shift:** Her situation shifts from passive companion to active agent in the plot. By relaying the news about Densher from Mrs. Lowder, and later receiving an unsolicited confession from Mrs. Condrip, she becomes the keeper of multiple secrets and a key conduit of information between the other characters.
  • *Kate Croy**
  • **Presentation:** Kate is presented almost entirely through Milly's changing perception. Initially, she is a "handsome" new friend with whom Milly shares a "deep" and "sudden" intimacy. She is also positioned as being under the social control of her aunt, "involved in her aunt's designs."
  • **Situational Shift:** With the revelation of her connection to Densher, she is immediately recast in Milly's mind as a person with a hidden, "not wholly calculable" side. Her silence on the subject of Densher transforms her from a transparent friend into an enigma, surrounded by a "great darkness."
  • *Merton Densher**
  • **Presentation:** He is an off-stage character whose identity is built through the conflicting reports of others. He is a "young journalist" who is described by Mrs. Condrip as poor and lacking prospects, but by Mrs. Lowder as "exceptionally able."
  • **Situational Shift:** He is abruptly transformed from a minor New York acquaintance of Milly's into the central figure of a complex social secret linking all the main characters. His prior silence about his English friends is suddenly rendered significant.
  • *Mrs. Lowder (Aunt Maud)**
  • **Presentation:** She is a formidable and manipulative social strategist. She is wealthy, powerful, and intent on controlling her niece's future, specifically by arranging a marriage to Lord Mark. She is presented as shrewdly precautionary, immediately moving to control the flow of information about Densher.
  • **Situational Shift:** The unexpected appearance of Milly, who also knows Densher, introduces an unknown variable into her carefully managed plans for Kate, prompting her immediate directive for silence.
  • *Mrs. Condrip (Marian)**
