There were probably ways enough, on these lines, for such a consciousness; another of them would be, for instance, to say that she was made for great social uses. Milly was not wholly sure that she herself knew what great social uses might be—unless, as a good example, exerting just that sort of glamour in just that sort of frame were one of them: she would have fallen back on knowing sufficiently that they existed at all events for her friend. It imputed a primness, all round, to be reduced but to saying, by way of a translation of one's amusement, that she was always so right—since that, too often, was what the insupportables themselves were; yet it was, in overflow to Aunt Maud, what she had to content herself withal—save for the lame enhancement of saying she was lovely. It served, all the same, the purpose, strengthened the bond that for the time held the two ladies together, distilled in short its drop of rose-colour for Mrs. Lowder's own view. That was really the view Milly had, for most of the rest of the occasion, to give herself to immediately taking in; but it didn't prevent the continued play of those swift cross-lights, odd beguilements of the mind, at which we have already glanced.

Translation

Kate had a remarkable and captivating quality that, to her new friend, was like a beautiful stranger appearing at any given moment. She could detach herself, lose her usual identity, and allow the imagination to run wild. She became a figure intriguing from afar, more and more appealing the longer one watched her, but ultimately someone to be studied with curiosity. Nothing could have given her a more refreshing quality in a relationship than this feeling—which arose unexpectedly—of being as curious about herself as if she were a complete mystery. This had appeared, we've gathered, as soon as Milly saw her after hearing from Mrs. Stringham about her relationship with Merton Densher. Kate had then appeared different, more detached, as the truly critical observer would say. Milly had immediately anticipated this behavior from her, expecting her to look that way often.

That's exactly what she was doing this afternoon. Milly, who had secret thoughts that were like the private games of a little girl playing with dolls when she was considered "too old" for such things, could almost settle into the game of imagining who Kate was and how she might be categorized if one didn't know her.

Thus, intermittently, Kate became a figure defined only by her physical appearance, a figure to be anticipated, named, and understood. This was likely just a way of feeling that it was her essential nature to be perfectly suited to whatever the situation demanded, especially when the stakes were highest.

There were probably many ways to think about it in this way, another would be, for instance, to say that she was meant for important social roles. Milly wasn't entirely sure what those important social roles were—unless, as a good example, exerting that sort of glamour in that sort of environment was one of them: she would have fallen back on knowing enough that those roles definitely existed for her friend.

It seemed a bit stuffy, all around, to reduce it simply to saying, as a translation of her amusement, that Kate was always "right"—because that, too often, was how the most unbearable people presented themselves; yet, this was what she had to ultimately tell Aunt Maud, except for the weak compliment of calling her lovely. It still served its purpose, strengthened the bond between the two ladies, and distilled a touch of rose-colored admiration for Mrs. Lowder's own view. That was really the perspective Milly had, for most of the rest of the event, to immediately take in; but it didn't stop the constant play of those rapid, complex mental insights, odd beguilements of the mind, that we have already observed.

Mrs. Lowder herself found it enough simply to reply, in respect to Kate, that she was indeed a luxury to take about the world: she expressed no more surprise than that at her "rightness" to-day. Wasn't it by this time sufficiently manifest that it was precisely as the very luxury she was proving that she had, from far back, been appraised and waited for? Crude elation, however, might be kept at bay, and the circumstance none the less demonstrated that they were all swimming together in the blue. It came back to Lord Mark again, as he seemed slowly to pass and repass and conveniently to linger before them; he was personally the note of the blue—like a suspended skein of silk within reach of the broiderer's hand. Aunt Maud's free-moving shuttle took a length of him at rhythmic intervals; and one of the intermixed truths that flickered across to Milly was that he ever so consentingly knew he was being worked in. This was almost like an understanding with her at Mrs. Lowder's expense, which she would have none of; she wouldn't for the world have had him make any such point as that he wouldn't have launched them at Matcham—or whatever it was he had done—only for Aunt Maud's beaux yeux. What he had done, it would have been guessable, was something he had for some time been desired in vain to do; and what they were all now profiting by was a change comparatively sudden, the cessation of hope delayed. What had caused the cessation easily showed itself as none of Milly's business; and she was luckily, for that matter, in no real danger of hearing from him directly that her individual weight had been felt in the scale. Why then indeed was it an effect of his diffused but subdued participation that he might absolutely have been saying to her "Yes, let the dear woman take her own tone? Since she's here she may stay," he might have been adding—"for whatever she can make of it. But you and I are different." Milly knew she was different in truth—his own difference was his own affair; but also she knew that, after all, even at their distinctest, Lord Mark's "tips" in this line would be tacit. He practically placed her—it came round again to that—under no obligation whatever. It was a matter of equal ease, moreover, her letting Mrs. Lowder take a tone. She might have taken twenty—they would have spoiled nothing.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder simply said, about Kate, that she was a luxury to have around. She wasn't surprised by Kate's "perfection" that day. Wasn't it clear by now that Kate was valued and anticipated precisely *because* she was a luxury? Any obvious excitement could be kept under wraps, but the situation still showed that they were all on the same page. Lord Mark kept circling back, lingering nearby. He was the epitome of their shared goal – like a silken thread waiting to be woven. Aunt Maud, with her constant maneuvering, was subtly incorporating him into her plan. Milly realized that he was willingly cooperating, almost as if he knew he was being used. This felt almost like a secret agreement at Mrs. Lowder's expense, and Milly wanted none of it. She wouldn't have wanted him to imply that he only helped them, by launching them at Matcham or whatever he'd done, because Aunt Maud wanted it. What he had done, one could assume, was something he'd been asked to do for a while; and what they were now benefiting from was a relatively sudden shift, the end of a long wait. What caused this change was none of Milly's business, and she was lucky not to have to hear from him directly that her influence had been noticed.

Still, it felt like his unspoken contribution was that he might as well have been saying to her, "Yes, let the dear woman have her say. Since she’s here, she can stay," and adding, "for whatever she can get out of it. But you and I are different." Milly knew that she *was* different – his own differences were his own concern. But she also knew that, even at their most discreet, Lord Mark's unspoken opinions on the matter would remain subtle. Essentially, he was making it clear, again, that she owed him nothing. It was equally easy for her to allow Mrs. Lowder to set the tone. She could have taken twenty different tones – it wouldn't have changed a thing.

"You must stay on with us; you can, you know, in any position you like; any, any, any, my dear child"—and her emphasis went deep. "You must make your home with us; and it's really open to you to make the most beautiful one in the world. You mustn't be under a mistake—under any of any sort; and you must let us all think for you a little, take care of you and watch over you. Above all you must help me with Kate, and you must stay a little for her; nothing for a long time has happened to me so good as that you and she should have become friends. It's beautiful; it's great; it's everything. What makes it perfect is that it should have come about through our dear delightful Susie, restored to me, after so many years, by such a miracle. No—that's more charming to me than even your hitting it off with Kate. God has been good to one—positively; for I couldn't, at my age, have made a new friend—undertaken, I mean, out of whole cloth, the real thing. It's like changing one's bankers—after fifty: one doesn't do that. That's why Susie has been kept for me, as you seem to keep people in your wonderful country, in lavender and pink paper—coming back at last as straight as out of a fairy-tale and with you as an attendant fairy." Milly hereupon replied appreciatively that such a description of herself made her feel as if pink paper were her dress and lavender its trimming; but Aunt Maud was not to be deterred by a weak joke from keeping it up. Her interlocutress could feel besides that she kept it up in perfect sincerity. She was somehow at this hour a very happy woman, and a part of her happiness might precisely have been that her affections and her views were moving as never before in concert. Unquestionably she loved Susie; but she also loved Kate and loved Lord Mark, loved their funny old host and hostess, loved every one within range, down to the very servant who came to receive Milly's empty iceplate—down, for that matter, to Milly herself, who was, while she talked, really conscious of the enveloping flap of a protective mantle, a shelter with the weight of an eastern carpet. An eastern carpet, for wishing-purposes of one's own, was a thing to be on rather than under; still, however, if the girl should fail of breath it wouldn't be, she could feel, by Mrs. Lowder's fault. One of the last things she was afterwards to recall of this was Aunt Maud's going on to say that she and Kate must stand together because together they could do anything. It was for Kate of course she was essentially planning; but the plan, enlarged and uplifted now, somehow required Milly's prosperity too for its full operation, just as Milly's prosperity at the same time involved Kate's. It was nebulous yet, it was slightly confused, but it was unmistakably free and genial, and it made our young woman understand things Kate had said of her aunt's possibilities as well as characterisations that had fallen from Susan Shepherd. One of the most frequent on the lips of the latter had been that dear Maud was a natural force.

Translation

"You absolutely have to stay with us. You can, you know. You can have any role you want, any, any, any, my dear. She really emphasized that. You need to make this your home, and honestly, you could make the most wonderful home imaginable. Please don't misunderstand me, not in any way. You should let us help you with some things, take care of you, and look out for you. Most importantly, you need to help me with Kate, and you have to stay for her sake. It's been the best thing to happen to me in a long time that you and she have become friends. It's beautiful, it's amazing, it's everything. What makes it perfect is that it happened because of our dear, delightful Susie, who came back to me after all these years, it was a miracle! No, that's even more delightful to me than you and Kate getting along so well. I've been blessed, truly. I couldn't, at my age, have made a new friend – I mean, have created a genuine, new friendship out of nothing. It's like changing your bank after fifty; you just don't do that. That's why Susie was kept for me, just like you seem to keep people in your wonderful country, in lavender and pink paper, returning at last, straight out of a fairy tale and with you as the attendant fairy."

Milly responded appreciatively, saying that the description made her feel like she was wearing a pink paper dress with lavender trim. But Aunt Maud wasn't going to let a silly joke stop her. Milly could also tell that Aunt Maud was being completely sincere. Somehow, at that moment, she was a very happy woman, and part of her happiness might have been that her feelings and her goals were working together like never before. She undoubtedly loved Susie, but she also loved Kate and Lord Mark, loved their funny old hosts, loved everyone around her, even the servant who took Milly's empty ice cream plate – even Milly herself, who, as she talked, felt the comforting weight of a protective shield, like being wrapped in a heavy, oriental rug. While you'd rather be on top of an oriental rug than under it, still, if the girl needed help, it wouldn't be because of Mrs. Lowder, she could feel. One of the last things Milly would later remember from this conversation was Aunt Maud saying that she and Kate needed to stick together because they could do anything together. She was essentially planning for Kate, of course, but the plan, expanded and elevated now, somehow required Milly's success as well, and Milly's success at the same time involved Kate's. It was unclear yet, a little confusing, but it was undoubtedly open and friendly, and it made Milly understand things Kate had said about her aunt's capabilities and the things that Susan Shepherd had said. One of Susan Shepherd's most common sayings had been that dear Maud was a force of nature.

Chapter XI

Chapter Summary & Character Study
Summary

Lord Mark approaches a girl, Milly, and tells her about a portrait in the house that resembles her. He leads her inside to see it. As they walk, they are repeatedly stopped by other guests who greet Lord Mark.

They arrive at the Bronzino portrait. Milly looks at it through tears and says, "I shall never be better than this." She clarifies to Lord Mark that she means the afternoon has been perfect. They discuss the resemblance between her and the woman in the painting.

Kate Croy arrives with Lord and Lady Aldershaw. They all agree on the resemblance. Kate tells Milly she looks superb. Lady Aldershaw begins to invite Milly somewhere, but Lord Mark interrupts and leads Lady Aldershaw away. Lord Aldershaw looks at the painting, then follows them, leaving Milly and Kate alone.

Milly asks Kate to do her a secret service: to go with her to a doctor's appointment the next day. She says the plan is to deceive her companion, Susan Shepherd, to avoid worrying her. Milly explains she has an appointment with a doctor, Sir Luke Strett, and asks Kate to promise absolute silence. Kate asks what is wrong, and Milly says that is what she wants to find out. After a brief discussion, Kate agrees to accompany her.

Character Study

Based on the text, here is a concise character study:

  • *Milly Theale**
  • **Initial Presentation:** Milly is presented as a passive, observant young woman who is the object of intense social curiosity. She is aware that a reputation as a "rich young American" precedes her and accepts being put on display with a detached "uplifted assurance." She is initially led by Lord Mark, trusting him and absorbing the social scene around her.
  • **Immediate Shift:** Her situation shifts dramatically upon seeing the Bronzino portrait. Her passivity gives way to a profound and sudden emotional vulnerability, moving her to tears and prompting the fatalistic declaration, "I shall never be better than this." A second shift occurs with Kate’s arrival; Milly moves from being an object of social attention to an active agent of her own affairs. She seizes the initiative, confiding in Kate about a secret visit to a doctor and arranging for her help, thus revealing a hidden, serious anxiety about her health.
  • *Lord Mark**
  • **Initial Presentation:** He is presented as a smooth, socially adept, and protective guide. He orchestrates the encounter with Milly, steers her through the crowd with practiced ease, and shields her from unwanted social overtures. He is perceptive in noticing Milly's resemblance to the portrait but completely misinterprets her deep emotional reaction to it, revealing a lack of emotional depth.
  • **Immediate Shift:** His situation shifts from being Milly’s primary companion and protector to being sidelined. After Kate Croy arrives and takes control, he is seen strolling away with another guest, his central role in the scene effectively ended.
  • *Kate Croy**
  • **Initial Presentation:** Kate appears as a confident and socially powerful figure. She arrives and immediately re-frames the scene around herself, confirming the portrait's likeness and managing the other guests with "subtle operation." Her initial reaction to Milly’s request for help is playful and worldly ("Then I'm your woman").
  • **Immediate Shift:** She quickly shifts from a social peer to a confidante entrusted with a serious secret. Her demeanor changes from light amusement to direct, concerned inquiry ("What in the world is the matter with you?"). By the end of the passage, she has displaced Lord Mark and established a new, deeply intimate and secretive relationship with Milly.

A prime reason, we must add, why sundry impressions were not to be fully present to the girl till later on was that they yielded at this stage, with an effect of sharp supersession, to a detached quarter of an hour—her only one—with Lord Mark. "Have you seen the picture in the house, the beautiful one that's so like you?"—he was asking that as he stood before her; having come up at last with his smooth intimation that any wire he had pulled and yet wanted not to remind her of wasn't quite a reason for his having no joy at all.

Translation

Another important reason why she didn't fully understand all the things she was experiencing until later was that those feelings were immediately replaced by a brief, special moment – her only one – with Lord Mark. "Have you seen that painting in the house, the beautiful one that looks so much like you?" he asked, standing in front of her. He had finally approached her, vaguely suggesting that whatever he'd done behind the scenes, which he preferred not to mention, wasn't the sole reason he seemed unhappy.

"I've been through rooms and I've seen pictures. But if I'm 'like' anything so beautiful as most of them seemed to me——!" It needed in short for Milly some evidence, which he only wanted to supply. She was the image of the wonderful Bronzino, which she must have a look at on every ground. He had thus called her off and led her away; the more easily that the house within was above all what had already drawn round her its mystic circle. Their progress, meanwhile, was not of the straightest; it was an advance, without haste, through innumerable natural pauses and soft concussions, determined for the most part by the appearance before them of ladies and gentlemen, singly, in couples, in groups, who brought them to a stand with an inveterate "I say, Mark." What they said she never quite made out; it was their all so domestically knowing him, and his knowing them, that mainly struck her, while her impression, for the rest, was but of fellow-strollers more vaguely afloat than themselves, supernumeraries mostly a little battered, whether as jaunty males or as ostensibly elegant women. They might have been moving a good deal by a momentum that had begun far back, but they were still brave and personable, still warranted for continuance as long again, and they gave her, in especial collectively, a sense of pleasant voices, pleasanter than those of actors, of friendly, empty words and kind, lingering eyes. The lingering eyes looked her over, the lingering eyes were what went, in almost confessed simplicity, with the pointless "I say, Mark "; and what was really most sensible of all was that, as a pleasant matter of course, if she didn't mind, he seemed to suggest their letting people, poor dear things, have the benefit of her.

Translation

I've seen some pretty amazing places and artwork. But if I'm even *close* to being as beautiful as most of those things seemed to me...!" Basically, Milly needed some proof, and he was happy to provide it. She was like that amazing Bronzino painting, and she needed to see it for herself. He'd pulled her away, which was easy because the house itself was already drawing her in.

Their walk wasn't exactly direct; it was a slow journey with lots of natural stops and casual bumps, mostly because they kept running into people – ladies and gentlemen, alone, in pairs, in groups – who would stop them with a casual "Hey, Mark." She never quite understood what they were saying; what struck her was how familiar they all were with him, and his familiarity with them. As for the others, they seemed like casual tourists, a bit worn, both the cheerful men and the seemingly elegant women. They might have been carried along by something that started long ago, but they were still charming and presentable, and seemed like they could keep going forever. Collectively, they gave her a feeling of pleasant voices, even nicer than actors' voices, and friendly, meaningless chatter with kind, lingering gazes. Those lingering eyes looked her over, and those lingering eyes were a part of that pointless "Hey, Mark." And what was really striking was that, in a friendly way, he seemed to suggest that if she didn't mind, they'd let these poor dears have the benefit of seeing her.

The odd part was that he made her herself believe, for amusement, in the benefit, measured by him in mere manner—for wonderful, of a truth, was, as a means of expression, his slightness of emphasis—that her present good-nature conferred. It was, as she could easily see, a mild common carnival of good-nature—a mass of London people together, of sorts and sorts, but who mainly knew each other and who, in their way, did, no doubt, confess to curiosity. It had gone round that she was there; questions about her would be passing; the easiest thing was to run the gauntlet with him—just as the easiest thing was in fact to trust him generally. Couldn't she know for herself, passively, how little harm they meant her?—to that extent that it made no difference whether or not he introduced them. The strangest thing of all for Milly was perhaps the uplifted assurance and indifference with which she could simply give back the particular bland stare that appeared in such cases to mark civilisation at its highest. It was so little her fault, this oddity of what had "gone round" about her, that to accept it without question might be as good a way as another of feeling life. It was inevitable to supply the probable description—that of the awfully rich young American who was so queer to behold, but nice, by all accounts, to know; and she had really but one instant of speculation as to fables or fantasies perchance originally launched. She asked herself once only if Susie could, inconceivably, have been blatant about her; for the question, on the spot, was really blown away for ever. She knew in fact on the spot and with sharpness just why she had "elected" Susan Shepherd: she had had from the first hour the conviction of her being precisely the person in the world least possibly a trumpeter. So it wasn't their fault, it wasn't their fault, and anything might happen that would, and everything now again melted together, and kind eyes were always kind eyes—if it were never to be worse than that! She got with her companion into the house; they brushed, beneficently, past all their accidents. The Bronzino was, it appeared, deep within, and the long afternoon light lingered for them on patches of old colour and waylaid them, as they went, in nooks and opening vistas.

Translation

The strange thing was that he’d convinced her, just for fun, to believe in the positive effects of this—effects he measured solely by her demeanor. His subtle emphasis was, truthfully, quite impressive as a way of conveying meaning. He’d made her believe that her current good mood was helpful. It was, as she could easily see, a pleasant, commonplace gathering. A large group of Londoners, of all kinds, who mostly knew each other and, undoubtedly, were curious about her.

Word had spread that she was there. People would be asking questions about her. The easiest thing was to go along with him—just as the easiest thing was, generally speaking, to trust him. Couldn’t she tell for herself, without doing anything, how little harm they meant her? It didn’t matter whether or not he introduced them.

The strangest thing for Milly was perhaps the confident and indifferent way she could simply return the blank stare that, in such situations, seemed to represent the peak of sophistication. This peculiarity—the things people were saying about her—was so little her doing that accepting it without question might be as good a way as any other of experiencing life.

It was inevitable that the description of her would circulate: the incredibly wealthy young American woman, who was strange to look at, but apparently nice to know. She only briefly considered whether there might be any lies or fantasies that had started it all. She asked herself only once if Susie could, incredibly, have blabbed about her, but the question was instantly dismissed. In fact, she knew, and quite clearly, why she had "chosen" Susan Shepherd. From the beginning, she had believed that Susie was the last person in the world to gossip.

So it wasn’t their fault, it wasn’t their fault. Anything could happen, and everything melted together again. Kind eyes were always kind eyes—as long as it never got any worse than that! She and her companion went into the house; they ignored all the awkwardness. The Bronzino painting was, apparently, deep inside, and the long afternoon light lingered on patches of old color, leading them on through hidden corners and open spaces.

It was all the while for Milly as if Lord Mark had really had something other than this spoken pretext in view; as if there were something he wanted to say to her and were only—consciously yet not awkwardly, just delicately—hanging fire. At the same time it was as if the thing had practically been said by the moment they came in sight of the picture; since what it appeared to amount to was "Do let a fellow who isn't a fool take care of you a little." The thing somehow, with the aid of the Bronzino, was done; it hadn't seemed to matter to her before if he were a fool or no; but now, just where they were, she liked his not being; and it was all moreover none the worse for coming back to something of the same sound as Mrs. Lowder's so recent reminder. She too wished to take care of her—and wasn't it, à peu près, what all the people with the kind eyes were wishing? Once more things melted together—the beauty and the history and the facility and the splendid midsummer glow: it was a sort of magnificent maximum, the pink dawn of an apotheosis, coming so curiously soon. What in fact befell was that, as she afterwards made out, it was Lord Mark who said nothing in particular—it was she herself who said all. She couldn't help that—it came; and the reason it came was that she found herself, for the first moment, looking at the mysterious portrait through tears. Perhaps it was her tears that made it just then so strange and fair—as wonderful as he had said: the face of a young woman, all magnificently drawn, down to the hands, and magnificently dressed; a face almost livid in hue, yet handsome in sadness and crowned with a mass of hair rolled back and high, that must, before fading with time, have had a family resemblance to her own. The lady in question, at all events, with her slightly Michaelangelesque squareness, her eyes of other days, her full lips, her long neck, her recorded jewels, her brocaded and wasted reds, was a very great personage—only unaccompanied by a joy. And she was dead, dead, dead. Milly recognised her exactly in words that had nothing to do with her. "I shall never be better than this."

Translation

Milly felt like Lord Mark had a hidden motive, something more than just the reason he gave for being there. It was as if he wanted to tell her something, but he was holding back, not awkwardly, but deliberately and carefully. At the same time, it was as if he’d already said what he wanted to say, simply by showing her the painting. It was as if he was saying, "Let someone who isn’t an idiot look after you a little." Somehow, with the help of the Bronzino painting, it was accomplished. It hadn't seemed to matter to her before whether he was a fool or not, but now, standing there, she was glad he wasn't. And it was all the better because it echoed Mrs. Lowder's recent offer of help. She also wanted to take care of Milly – and wasn't that what everyone with kind eyes seemed to want? Once again, everything blended together: the beauty, the history, the ease, and the gorgeous summer light. It was a kind of overwhelming peak, the start of something amazing, and it was happening so quickly. In reality, as she realized later, Lord Mark said nothing of significance. It was she who said everything. She couldn’t help it – it just came out. And the reason it came out was that, for the first time, she was looking at the mysterious portrait through tears. Perhaps it was her tears that made it seem so strange and beautiful then—just as wonderful as he had said: the face of a young woman, exquisitely painted down to the hands, dressed in magnificent clothes; a face almost pale, but handsome in its sadness, and framed by a mass of hair piled high, that, before it faded with age, must have looked a little like her own. The woman in the painting, with her slightly angular features, her eyes of another time, her full lips, her long neck, her jewels, her faded red brocade, was a very important person—but she had no joy. And she was dead, dead, dead. Milly understood her perfectly, expressing her understanding in words that had nothing to do with the painting’s subject. "I'll never be better than this," she thought.

He smiled for her at the portrait. "Than she? You'd scarce need to be better, for surely that's well enough. But you are, one feels, as it happens, better; because, splendid as she is, one doubts if she was good."

Translation

He smiled at the portrait, looking at her. "Compared to her? You hardly need to be superior, because she's perfectly fine as she is. But you are, I think, better, because, as magnificent as she is, I doubt she was a good person."

He hadn't understood. She was before the picture, but she had turned to him, and she didn't care if, for the minute, he noticed her tears. It was probably as good a moment as she should ever have with him. It was perhaps as good a moment as she should have with any one, or have in any connection whatever. "I mean that everything this afternoon has been too beautiful, and that perhaps everything together will never be so right again. I'm very glad therefore you've been a part of it."

Translation

He didn't get it. She was looking at the painting, but then she turned to him and didn't try to hide her tears. This was probably the best moment they would ever have together. Maybe it was the best moment she'd ever have with anyone, in any situation. "I just mean that everything has been perfect this afternoon, and it's possible things will never be this good again. So I'm really glad you were here."

Though he still didn't understand her he was as nice as if he had; he didn't ask for insistence, and that was just a part of his looking after her. He simply protected her now from herself, and there was a world of practice in it. "Oh, we must talk about these things!"

Translation

Even though he didn't fully get her, he acted like he did. He didn't push for explanations, which was just one way he looked out for her. He was just protecting her from her own impulses now, and he'd gotten really good at it. "Oh, we really need to discuss this stuff!"

Ah, they had already done that, she knew, as much as she ever would; and she was shaking her head at her pale sister the next moment with a world, on her side, of slowness. "I wish I could see the resemblance. Of course her complexion's green," she laughed; "but mine's several shades greener."

Translation

Oh, they'd already finished that, she realized, as much as she ever would. And then, she shook her head at her pale sister, almost exasperatedly, taking her time. "I wish I could see the family resemblance. Sure, her skin is sickly looking," she chuckled, "but mine is even worse."

"It's down to the very hands," said Lord Mark.

Translation

"It's come down to the wire," said Lord Mark.

"Her hands are large," Milly went on, "but mine are larger. Mine are huge."

Translation

"Milly continued, "Her hands are big, but mine

are bigger. Mine are enormous."

"Oh, you go her, all round, 'one better'—which is just what I said. But you're a pair. You must surely catch it," he added as if it were important to his character as a serious man not to appear to have invented his plea.

Translation

Oh, you're ganging up on her, trying to outdo each other – which is exactly what I thought. But you're in this together. You're going to get in trouble, he added, as if it was crucial for his reputation as a serious person that he hadn't just made up his argument.

"I don't know one never knows one's self. It's a funny fancy, and I don't imagine it would have occurred——"

Translation

"I don't know, you never really know yourself. It's a strange thought, and I don't think it would have occurred..."

"I see it has occurred"—he has already taken her up. She had her back, as she faced the picture, to one of the doors of the room, which was open, and on her turning, as he spoke, she saw that they were in the presence of three other persons, also, as appeared, interested inquirers. Kate Croy was one of these; Lord Mark had just become aware of her, and she, all arrested, had immediately seen, and made the best of it, that she was far from being first in the field. She had brought a lady and a gentleman to whom she wished to show what Lord Mark was showing Milly, and he took her straightway as a reinforcement. Kate herself had spoken, however, before he had had time to tell her so.

Translation

"I figured as much"—he'd already moved in on her. She was facing the painting with her back to an open doorway. When she turned around, as he spoke, she saw they were in the room with three other people, who also seemed to be curious onlookers. Kate Croy was one of them; Lord Mark had just noticed her, and she, taken aback, immediately realized, and accepted the situation, that she wasn't the first one he'd approached. She'd brought a lady and a gentleman to show them what Lord Mark was showing Milly, and he'd immediately included her as part of the group. However, Kate herself had spoken before he could tell her anything.

"You had noticed too?"—she smiled at him without looking at Milly. "Then I'm not original—which one always hopes one has been. But the likeness is so great." And now she looked at Milly—for whom again it was, all round indeed, kind, kind eyes. "Yes, there you are, my dear, if you want to know. And you're superb." She took now but a glance at the picture, though it was enough to make her question to her friends not too straight. "Isn't she superb?"

Translation

"You noticed it too?" she smiled at him, not looking at Milly. "So I'm not the first to see it – which is always disappointing. But the resemblance is so striking." Now she looked at Milly, and her eyes were kind, truly kind. "Yes, there you have it, dear, if you wanted confirmation. And you're amazing." She glanced briefly at the picture, but it was enough to make her question her friends in a playful way. "Isn't she amazing?"

"I brought Miss Theale," Lord Mark explained to the latter, "quite off my own bat."

Translation

"I brought Miss Theale here," Lord Mark explained to her, "completely on my own initiative."

"I wanted Lady Aldershaw," Kate continued to Milly, "to see for herself."

Translation

"I wanted Lady Aldershaw," Kate said to Milly, "to see it with her own eyes."

"Les grands esprits se rencontrent!" laughed her attendant gentleman, a high, but slightly stooping, shambling and wavering person, who represented urbanity by the liberal aid of certain prominent front teeth and whom Milly vaguely took for some sort of great man.

Translation

"Great minds think alike!" laughed her companion, a tall, somewhat slouching, unsteady man who seemed to wobble slightly. He tried to appear sophisticated, mostly through his prominent front teeth, and Milly vaguely assumed he was someone important.

Lady Aldershaw meanwhile looked at Milly quite as if Milly had been the Bronzino and the Bronzino only Milly. "Superb, superb. Of course I had noticed you. It is wonderful," she went on with her back to the picture, but with some other eagerness which Milly felt gathering, directing her motions now. It was enough—they were introduced, and she was saying "I wonder if you could give us the pleasure of coming——" She was not fresh, for she was not young, even though she denied at every pore that she was old; but she was vivid and much bejewelled for the midsummer daylight; and she was all in the palest pinks and blues. She didn't think, at this pass, that she could "come" anywhere—Milly didn't; and she already knew that somehow Lord Mark was saving her from the question. He had interposed, taking the words out of the lady's mouth and not caring at all if the lady minded. That was clearly the right way to treat her—at least for him; as she had only dropped, smiling, and then turned away with him. She had been dealt with—it would have done an enemy good. The gentleman still stood, a little helpless, addressing himself to the intention of urbanity as if it were a large loud whistle; he had been signing sympathy, in his way, while the lady made her overture; and Milly had, in this light, soon arrived at their identity. They were Lord and Lady Aldershaw, and the wife was the clever one. A minute or two later the situation had changed, and she knew it afterwards to have been by the subtle operation of Kate. She was herself saying that she was afraid she must go now if Susie could be found; but she was sitting down on the nearest seat to say it. The prospect, through opened doors, stretched before her into other rooms, down the vista of which Lord Mark was strolling with Lady Aldershaw, who, close to him and much intent, seemed to show from behind as peculiarly expert. Lord Aldershaw, for his part, had been left in the middle of the room, while Kate, with her back to him, was standing before her with much sweetness of manner. The sweetness was all for her; she had the sense of the poor gentleman's having somehow been handled as Lord Mark had handled his wife. He dangled there, he shambled a little; then he bethought himself of the Bronzino, before which, with his eyeglass, he hovered. It drew from him an odd, vague sound, not wholly distinct from a grunt, and a "Humph—most remarkable!" which lighted Kate's face with amusement. The next moment he had creaked away, over polished floors, after the others, and Milly was feeling as if she had been rude. But Lord Aldershaw was in every way a detail, and Kate was saying to her that she hoped she wasn't ill.

Translation

Meanwhile, Lady Aldershaw was looking at Milly as if Milly *was* the famous Bronzino painting, and the painting was *just* Milly. "Wonderful, wonderful. Of course, I've noticed you. It's marvelous," she continued, with her back to the painting, but with a different kind of enthusiasm that Milly sensed was building and directing her actions. That was enough—they were introduced, and Lady Aldershaw was saying, "I wonder if you could join us—" She wasn't youthful, because she wasn't young, even though she clearly refused to admit she was old; but she was lively and heavily jeweled for the summer afternoon, and she was dressed entirely in pale pinks and blues. Milly didn't think she could "join" anything at this point; and she already knew that somehow Lord Mark was saving her from the invitation. He had interrupted, taking the words right out of Lady Aldershaw's mouth and not caring if she minded at all. That was obviously the best way to handle her—at least for him; she just smiled briefly and then walked away with him. She’d been dealt with, which would have pleased an enemy. The gentleman, Lord Aldershaw, still stood there, a bit lost, attempting to be polite as if it were a loud whistle; he had been silently expressing sympathy while his wife made her offer; and Milly had quickly figured out who they were. They were Lord and Lady Aldershaw, and the wife was the smart one. A few minutes later, the situation had changed, and she later realized it was because of Kate’s skillful intervention. Milly herself was saying she had to leave if she could find Susie; but she was still sitting down as she said it. The view through open doorways led to other rooms, and down the hallway, Lord Mark was strolling with Lady Aldershaw, who seemed to be very focused and from behind looked particularly experienced. Lord Aldershaw, meanwhile, had been left alone in the middle of the room, while Kate, facing Milly and with her back to him, was being very charming. All the charm was directed at Milly; she got the feeling that the poor gentleman had been handled in the same way Lord Mark had handled his wife. He just stood there, a little unsteady; then he remembered the Bronzino painting, which he then examined with his monocle. It caused him to make a strange, vague sound, not quite a grunt, and a "Humph—most remarkable!" which made Kate smile. The next moment, he had shuffled away, across the polished floors, after the others, and Milly felt like she had been impolite. But Lord Aldershaw was not important, and Kate was asking Milly if she felt alright.

Thus it was that, aloft there in the great gilded historic chamber and the presence of the pale personage on the wall, whose eyes all the while seemed engaged with her own, she found herself suddenly sunk in something quite intimate and humble and to which these grandeurs were strange enough witnesses. It had come up, in the form in which she had had to accept it, all suddenly, and nothing about it, at the same time, was more marked than that she had in a manner plunged into it to escape from something else. Something else, from her first vision of her friend's appearance three minutes before, had been present to her even through the call made by the others on her attention; something that was perversely there, she was more and more uncomfortably finding, at least for the first moments and by some spring of its own, with every renewal of their meeting. "Is it the way she looks to him?" she asked herself—the perversity being that she kept in remembrance that Kate was known to him. It wasn't a fault in Kate—nor in him assuredly; and she had a horror, being generous and tender, of treating either of them as if it had been. To Densher himself she couldn't make it up—he was too far away; but her secondary impulse was to make it up to Kate. She did so now with a strange soft energy—the impulse immediately acting. "Will you render me to-morrow a great service?"

Translation

In that grand, ornate, historic room, with the portrait of the pale-faced man on the wall seemingly staring right at her, she suddenly felt a deep, personal emotion she hadn't expected. The opulence of the surroundings seemed a strange contrast to this feeling. It had hit her abruptly, in a form she had to accept, and it was clear that she'd embraced this feeling to escape something else. Ever since she'd seen her friend three minutes earlier, that "something else" had been there, even while others were demanding her attention. It was a disruptive presence, she realized with growing discomfort, especially during the initial moments and apparently operating on its own accord each time they met.

"Is this how he sees her?" she wondered, the disturbing fact being that she knew Kate was already familiar to him. It wasn't Kate's fault, and certainly not his; being kind and empathetic, she refused to treat either of them as if it were. She couldn't reason with Densher himself - he was too distant. But her immediate response was to make it up to Kate. She acted on this impulse with a strange, gentle intensity. "Will you do me a huge favor tomorrow?"

"Any service, dear child, in the world."

Translation

Anything at all, honey.

"But it's a secret one—nobody must know. I must be wicked and false about it."

Translation

But it's a secret, and no one can know. I have to pretend to be bad and dishonest about it.

"Then I'm your woman," Kate smiled, "for that's the kind of thing I love. Do let us do something bad. You're impossibly without sin, you know."

Translation

"Then I'm all yours," Kate smiled, "because

that's exactly the kind of thing I'm into. Let's be naughty.

You're ridiculously innocent, you know."

Milly's eyes, on this, remained a little with their companion's. "Ah, I shan't perhaps come up to your idea. It's only to deceive Susan Shepherd."

Translation

Milly kept her eyes on her friend after she said that. "Oh, I probably won't live up to your expectations. I'm just trying to fool Susan Shepherd."

"Oh!" said Kate as if this were indeed mild.

Translation

"Oh!" Kate said, as if that was actually a minor thing.

"But thoroughly—as thoroughly as I can."

Translation

But completely – as completely as possible.

"And for cheating," Kate asked, "my powers will contribute? Well, I'll do my best for you." In accordance with which it was presently settled between them that Milly should have the aid and comfort of her presence for a visit to Sir Luke Strett. Kate had needed a minute for enlightenment, and it was quite grand for her comrade that this name should have said nothing to her. To Milly herself it had for some days been secretly saying much. The personage in question was, as she explained, the greatest of medical lights if she had got hold, as she believed (and she had used to this end the wisdom of the serpent) of the right, the special man. She had written to him three days before, and he had named her an hour, eleven-twenty; only it had come to her, on the eve, that she couldn't go alone. Her maid, on the other hand, wasn't good enough, and Susie was too good. Kate had listened, above all, with high indulgence. "And I'm betwixt and between, happy thought! Too good for what?"

Translation

"So," Kate asked, "if I cheat, will my abilities help? Well, I'll do what I can for you." Following that, they quickly agreed that Kate would provide support and company for Milly on a visit to Sir Luke Strett. Kate needed a moment to understand, and it was great for her friend that she didn't know who he was. For Milly, however, his name had been secretly important for days. As she explained, he was the most brilliant medical expert if she had found, as she believed (and she had cleverly used her cunning), the right, the perfect doctor. She had written to him three days earlier, and he had given her an appointment at eleven-twenty; but the day before, she'd realized she couldn't go alone. Her maid wasn't suitable, and Susie was too good. Kate had listened, mostly with amusement. "And I'm the perfect choice, how convenient! Too good for what?"

Milly thought. "Why, to be worried if it's nothing. And to be still more worried—I mean before she need be—if it isn't."

Translation

Milly thought, "Why get worked up over something that might be nothing? And why get even more worked up, unnecessarily, if it *is* something?"

Kate fixed her with deep eyes. "What in the world is the matter with you?" It had inevitably a sound of impatience, as if it had been a challenge really to produce something; so that Milly felt her for the moment only as a much older person, standing above her a little, doubting the imagined ailments, suspecting the easy complaints, of ignorant youth. It somewhat checked her, further, that the matter with her was what exactly as yet she wanted knowledge about; and she immediately declared, for conciliation, that if she were merely fanciful Kate would see her put to shame. Kate vividly uttered, in return, the hope that, since she could come out and be so charming, could so universally dazzle and interest, she wasn't all the while in distress or in anxiety—didn't believe herself, in short, to be in any degree seriously menaced. "Well, I want to make out—to make out!" was all that this consistently produced. To which Kate made clear answer: "Ah then, let us by all means!"

Translation

Kate looked at her intently. "What's wrong?" Her voice sounded impatient, almost like she was daring Milly to explain. Milly felt Kate was much older and looked down on her, skeptical of her supposed problems and dismissing the complaints of someone young and inexperienced. This made Milly hesitate, because she didn't fully understand what was bothering her. She quickly tried to appease Kate by saying that if she was just imagining things, Kate would call her out on it. Kate responded eagerly, hoping that since Milly seemed so charming, captivating, and engaging, she wasn't actually suffering or worried, and that she wasn't seriously in trouble. Milly could only manage to say, "Well, I want to figure it out – to understand!" Kate simply replied, "Okay, let's do it then!"

"I thought," Milly said, "you would like to help me. But I must ask you, please, for the promise of absolute silence."

Translation

"I thought," Milly said, "you'd want to help me. But I need you to promise me you won't say a word about this."

"And how, if you are ill, can your friends remain in ignorance?"

Translation

If you're sick, how can your friends not know about it?

"Well, if I am, it must of course finally come out. But I can go for a long time." Milly spoke with her eyes again on her painted sister's—almost as if under their suggestion. She still sat there before Kate, yet not without a light in her face. "That will be one of my advantages. I think I could die without its being noticed."

Translation

"Well, if it's true, it'll eventually be obvious. But I can keep it hidden for a while." Milly said, looking back at her sister's painted face, almost as if taking cues from it. She was still sitting in front of Kate, but she seemed to have a hopeful expression. "That'll be one of my strengths. I think I could die without anyone even realizing it."

"You're an extraordinary young woman," her friend, visibly held by her, declared at last. "What a remarkable time to talk of such things!"

Translation

"You're an amazing young woman," her friend, clearly captivated, finally said. "This is a really strange time to be discussing this!"

"Well, we won't talk, precisely"—Milly got herself together again. "I only wanted to make sure of you."

Translation

"Okay, we won't actually talk," Milly composed herself. "I just wanted to check on you."

"Here in the midst of——!" But Kate could only sigh for wonder—almost visibly too for pity.

Translation

"Here, in the middle of this!" But Kate could only sigh in amazement, and you could almost see her feeling sorry for them.

It made a moment during which her companion waited on her word; partly as if from a yearning, shy but deep, to have her case put to her just as Kate was struck by it; partly as if the hint of pity were already giving a sense to her whimsical "shot," with Lord Mark, at Mrs. Lowder's first dinner. Exactly this—the handsome girl's compassionate manner, her friendly descent from her own strength—was what she had then foretold. She took Kate up as if positively for the deeper taste of it. "Here in the midst of what?"

Translation

It created a pause while her friend waited for her to speak. This was partly because he desperately wanted her to understand the situation exactly as Kate saw it, though he was hesitant and a little embarrassed. It was also partly because the hint of pity she'd shown, when she jokingly hinted at a romance with Lord Mark at Mrs. Lowder's first dinner, seemed to be taking on a new meaning. Kate's sympathetic attitude, her willingness to come down from her position of power, was precisely what she had predicted. She was drawing Kate in, almost to relish the experience. "Here, in the middle of what?"

"Of everything. There's nothing you can't have. There's nothing you can't do."

Translation

You can have anything. You can do anything.

"So Mrs. Lowder tells me."

Translation

"That's what Mrs. Lowder said."

It just kept Kate's eyes fixed as possibly for more of that; then, however, without waiting, she went on. "We all adore you."

Translation

Kate just kept staring, wanting more of that. Then, without waiting, she continued. "We all love you."

"You're wonderful—you dear things!" Milly laughed.

Translation

"You're all amazing, you sweethearts!" Milly laughed.

"No, it's you." And Kate seemed struck with the real interest of it. "In three weeks!"

Translation

"No way, it's you!" And Kate seemed genuinely surprised and intrigued. "In just three weeks!"

Milly kept it up. "Never were people on such terms! All the more reason," she added, "that I shouldn't needlessly torment you."

Translation

Milly continued. "People have never been this close! That's precisely why," she added, "I shouldn't make you suffer unnecessarily."

"But me? what becomes of me?" said Kate.

Translation

"But what about me? What's going to happen to me?" said Kate.

"Well, you—" Milly thought—"if there's anything to bear, you'll bear it."

Translation

Well, you—" Milly thought—"if anything bad happens, you'll get through it."

"But I won't bear it!" said Kate Croy.

Translation

"But I won't put up with it!" said Kate Croy.

"Oh yes, you will: all the same! You'll pity me awfully, but you'll help me very much. And I absolutely trust you. So there we are." There they were, then, since Kate had so to take it; but there, Milly felt, she herself in particular was; for it was just the point at which she had wished to arrive. She had wanted to prove to herself that she didn't horribly blame her friend for any reserve; and what better proof could there be than this quite special confidence? If she desired to show Kate that she really believed the latter liked her, how could she show it more than by asking her for help?

Translation

"Oh yes, you will do it, no matter what! You'll feel really sorry for me, but you'll help me a lot. And I completely trust you. So, that's that." And that's how it was, since Kate had to accept it. But Milly felt like *she* had especially arrived at a crucial moment. She wanted to prove to herself that she didn't blame her friend for being a little distant; and what better way to prove it than this extraordinary display of trust? If she wanted to show Kate that she truly believed Kate liked her, how better to do that than by asking for her assistance?

Chapter XII

Chapter Summary & Character Study
Summary

Kate accompanies Milly to a doctor's appointment. The doctor, Sir Luke Strett, has only ten minutes but schedules another appointment with Milly in a day or two. After the brief meeting, Milly tells Kate that the doctor is a "dear," that he will take care of her, and that she is to see him again. Milly decides to attend the next appointment by herself and asks Kate for her discretion. While waiting for their carriage, Milly reassures Kate that she is satisfied and feels "absolved."

Two days later, Milly goes to her second appointment alone. The doctor asks if she was accompanied. She explains that she is alone, with no living family members. After examining her, the doctor gives her a small prescription and says he will visit her at her home in a few days. He instructs her to leave London after his visit and says she can go to the continent. He says he will "follow you up." Before she leaves, Milly asks if she will suffer, and he answers, "Not a bit." When she asks if she will live, he replies that this is what he is trying to persuade her to do.

Character Study

Based on the text, here is a concise character study:

  • *Milly Theale**
  • **Presentation:** Milly is presented as a highly perceptive, romantic, and emotionally volatile young woman who is isolated and grappling with a serious, unnamed affliction. She interprets her experiences through a rich inner monologue, transforming a brief medical appointment into a profound, almost spiritual event. She feels she is "loosely rattling" through life and craves a sense of firmness and order, even if it comes from a grim diagnosis.
  • **Situational Shift:** Milly enters the doctor's office anxious and overwhelmed. In ten minutes, her situation shifts dramatically: she feels an immediate, deep sense of trust and relief, as if she has been "absolved." She leaves the first meeting feeling she has gained an "absolute possession" in the form of the doctor's friendship. By the second meeting, this feeling solidifies into a paradoxical comfort; she accepts that his kindness implies her situation is "bad," yet finds a strange stability in being "found out" by his genius.
  • *Sir Luke Strett (The Doctor)**
  • **Presentation:** Sir Luke is portrayed through Milly’s eyes as a "great man" who is authoritative yet gentle. He projects an aura of profound, intuitive knowledge, seeming to understand Milly’s condition and character with minimal questioning ("He can tell. He knows"). He is described as looking like a "general" and a "bishop," combining firmness with a capacity for kindness that Milly finds comforting.
  • **Situational Shift:** Initially presented as a busy professional with only ten minutes to spare, his role quickly shifts to that of a dedicated, almost paternalistic guide. He commits to seeing Milly again, visiting her, and even following her abroad, moving beyond a standard doctor-patient relationship into one of "unlimited interest."
  • *Kate Croy**
  • **Presentation:** Kate is presented as a pragmatic and skeptical friend. Her concern is direct and physical, comparing Milly’s consultation to a tooth extraction ("Is it out?"). She presses for concrete facts ("what does he say?") and is suspicious of the doctor's rapid, intuitive assessment. Her friendship has a transactional quality; she demands "the truth" in exchange for her discretion.
  • **Situational Shift:** Kate begins as Milly's close companion, accompanying her to the appointment. Her situation shifts when Milly decides to see the doctor alone the next time, effectively moving Kate from an active participant to an outsider who is now only granted information at Milly's discretion.

What it really came to, on the morrow, this first time—the time Kate went with her—was that the great man had, a little, to excuse himself; had, by a rare accident—for he kept his consulting-hours in general rigorously free—but ten minutes to give her; ten mere minutes which he yet placed at her service in a manner that she admired even more than she could meet it: so crystal-clean the great empty cup of attention that he set between them on the table. He was presently to jump into his carriage, but he promptly made the point that he must see her again, see her within a day or two; and he named for her at once another hour—easing her off beautifully too even then in respect to her possibly failing of justice to her errand. The minutes affected her in fact as ebbing more swiftly than her little army of items could muster, and they would probably have gone without her doing much more than secure another hearing, had it not been for her sense, at the last, that she had gained above all an impression. The impression—all the sharp growth of the final few moments—was neither more nor less than that she might make, of a sudden, in quite another world, another straight friend, and a friend who would moreover be, wonderfully, the most appointed, the most thoroughly adjusted of the whole collection, inasmuch as he would somehow wear the character scientifically, ponderably, proveably—not just loosely and sociably. Literally, furthermore, it wouldn't really depend on herself, Sir Luke Strett's friendship, in the least; perhaps what made her most stammer and pant was its thus queerly coming over her that she might find she had interested him even beyond her intention, find she was in fact launched in some current that would lose itself in the sea of science. At the same time that she struggled, however, she also surrendered; there was a moment at which she almost dropped the form of stating, of explaining, and threw herself, without violence, only with a supreme pointless quaver that had turned, the next instant, to an intensity of interrogative stillness, upon his general goodwill. His large, settled face, though firm, was not, as she had thought at first, hard; he looked, in the oddest manner, to her fancy, half like a general and half like a bishop, and she was soon sure that, within some such handsome range, what it would show her would be what was good, what was best for her. She had established, in other words, in this time-saving way, a relation with it; and the relation was the special trophy that, for the hour, she bore off. It was like an absolute possession, a new resource altogether, something done up in the softest silk and tucked away under the arm of memory. She hadn't had it when she went in, and she had it when she came out; she had it there under her cloak, but dissimulated, invisibly carried, when smiling, smiling, she again faced Kate Croy. That young lady had of course awaited her in another room, where, as the great man was to absent himself, no one else was in attendance; and she rose for her with such a face of sympathy as might have graced the vestibule of a dentist. "Is it out?" she seemed to ask as if it had been a question of a tooth; and Milly indeed kept her in no suspense at all.

Translation

Here’s what happened the next day, the first time Kate went with her. The important man had to apologize a little because, in a rare accident (he usually kept his appointment times strictly), he only had ten minutes to spare. He gave her those ten minutes, and she admired the way he did it. He gave her his complete, undivided attention, like a clear glass set between them. He was about to leave in his carriage, but he insisted on seeing her again within a day or two. He even immediately scheduled another meeting, subtly reassuring her that she wouldn't necessarily be able to fully explain everything in their short time. The minutes flew by faster than she could present her arguments, and she probably wouldn't have accomplished much beyond setting up another appointment, if she hadn’t gotten the strong feeling at the end that she had made an impression.

This impression, which really solidified in the last few moments, was simply that she might find a new, straightforward friend in a completely different world. Moreover, this friend would be the most suitable and well-suited of all her acquaintances, because he would understand his role scientifically, thoroughly, and demonstrably, not just casually and socially. Furthermore, her connection with Sir Luke Strett wouldn't really depend on her at all. Perhaps what made her the most nervous was the strange realization that she might have captured his interest beyond her intentions, that she was in fact being carried along in a current that would lead her to the sea of scientific research.

However, even as she struggled, she also gave in. There was a moment when she nearly stopped trying to explain herself and instead, without any force, but with a supreme, pointless trembling that instantly transformed into a deep, questioning stillness, she relied on his general kindness. His large, settled face, though strong, wasn’t, as she had first thought, harsh. To her, he looked strangely like a mix of a general and a bishop. She quickly realized that within that handsome range, he would show her what was good and what was best for her. In other words, in this quick meeting, she had established a connection with him, and that connection was the special prize she took away with her. It was like an absolute treasure, a new resource, something wrapped in the softest silk and stored away in her memory. She didn’t have it when she went in, but she had it when she came out. She carried it under her cloak, hidden but present, as she smiled and faced Kate Croy again.

Kate had, of course, been waiting for her in another room, where, because the important man was leaving, no one else was present. She rose to greet her with a sympathetic expression, like one you might see in a dentist’s waiting room. "Is it done?" she seemed to ask, as if it were a matter of a tooth. And Milly didn’t keep her waiting at all.

"He's a dear. I'm to come again."

Translation

He's lovely. I'm supposed to come back.

"But what does he say?"

Translation

What's he saying?

Milly was almost gay. "That I'm not to worry about anything in the world, and that if I'll be a good girl and do exactly what he tells me, he'll take care of me for ever and ever."

Translation

Milly was practically thrilled. "He wants me to not worry about anything at all. He promised that if I'm a good girl and do exactly as he says, he'll always look after me."

Kate wondered as if things scarce fitted. "But does he allow then that you're ill?"

Translation

Kate looked puzzled, as if something didn't quite make sense. "But does he admit that you're sick?"

"I don't know what he allows, and I don't care. I shall know, and whatever it is it will be enough. He knows all about me, and I like it. I don't hate it a bit."

Translation

I don't know what he's okay with, and frankly, I don't care.

I'll figure it out, and whatever it is will be fine.

He knows everything about me, and I'm good with that. I don't mind it at all.

Still, however, Kate stared. "But could he, in so few minutes, ask you enough——?"

Translation

Even so, Kate continued to stare. "But could he really ask you enough questions in such a short time...?"

"He asked me scarcely anything—he doesn't need to do anything so stupid," Milly said. "He can tell. He knows," she repeated; "and when I go back—for he'll have thought me over a little—it will be all right."

Translation

He barely asked me anything – he wouldn't do anything that foolish, Milly said. He can just tell. He knows, she repeated; and when I go back – because he'll have had some time to think about it – everything will be fine.

Kate, after a moment, made the best of this. "Then when are we to come?"

Translation

Kate, after a moment, decided to make the best of it.

"So, when do we go?"

It just pulled her friend up, for even while they talked—at least it was one of the reasons—she stood there suddenly, irrelevantly, in the light of her other identity, the identity she would have for Mr. Densher. This was always, from one instant to another, an incalculable light, which, though it might go off faster than it came on, necessarily disturbed. It sprang, with a perversity all its own, from the fact that, with the lapse of hours and days, the chances themselves that made for his being named continued so oddly to fail. There were twenty, there were fifty, but none of them turned up. This, in particular, was of course not a juncture at which the least of them would naturally be present; but it would make, none the less, Milly saw, another day practically all stamped with avoidance. She saw in a quick glimmer, and with it all Kate's unconsciousness; and then she shook off the obsession. But it had lasted long enough to qualify her response. No, she had shown Kate how she trusted her; and that, for loyalty, would somehow do. "Oh, dear thing, now that the ice is broken I shan't trouble you again."

Translation

It just brought her friend down because, even while they were talking—or at least that was one of the reasons—Milly suddenly stood there, unexpectedly, illuminated by her other self, the self she presented to Mr. Densher. This was always a difficult and unpredictable feeling, which, even though it could disappear quickly, was unsettling. It arose, with its own strange logic, from the fact that as time went on, the possibilities that might have led to him being mentioned continued to disappear. There were twenty possibilities, then fifty, but none of them materialized. Of course, this wasn't an occasion when any of them would normally appear, but it made, Milly realized, another day essentially marked by avoiding the topic. She understood this in a flash, along with Kate's unawareness, and then she pushed the thought away. But it had lasted long enough to change her reaction. Yes, she had shown Kate how much she trusted her, and that, as a sign of loyalty, would be enough. "Oh, darling, now that we've talked about it, I won't bother you about it anymore."

"You'll come alone?"

Translation

Are you coming by yourself?

"Without a scruple. Only I shall ask you, please, for your absolute discretion still."

Translation

Without hesitation. I just need you to promise to keep this completely confidential.

Outside, before the door, on the wide pavement of the great square, they had to wait again while their carriage, which Milly had kept, completed a further turn of exercise, engaged in by the coachman for reasons of his own. The footman was there, and had indicated that he was making the circuit; so Kate went on while they stood. "But don't you ask a good deal, darling, in proportion to what you give?"

Translation

Outside, in front of the door, on the big sidewalk of the town square, they had to wait again. Their carriage, which Milly had kept, was doing another lap. The coachman was doing this for his own reasons. The footman was there and had signaled that he was circling the block, so Kate kept walking while they waited. "But, sweetheart, aren't you expecting a lot for what you offer?"

This pulled Milly up still shorter—so short in fact that she yielded as soon as she had taken it in. But she continued to smile. "I see. Then you can tell."

Translation

This stopped Milly in her tracks—she was so taken aback that she gave in immediately. But she kept smiling. "I understand. Then you can tell me."

"I don't want to 'tell,'" said Kate. "I'll be as silent as the tomb if I can only have the truth from you. All I want is that you shouldn't keep from me how you find out that you really are."

Translation

"I don't want to reveal anything," said Kate. "I'll keep it a secret if you just tell me the truth. I just want you to tell me how you figured out who you really are."

"Well then, I won't, ever. But you see for yourself," Milly went on, "how I really am. I'm satisfied. I'm happy."

Translation

Okay, I'm never going to do that. But just look at me," Milly continued, "See how I really am. I'm content. I'm happy."

Kate looked at her long. "I believe you like it. The way things turn out for you——!"

Translation

Kate stared at her for a long time. "I can tell you like it. The way things always work out for you...!"

Milly met her look now without a thought of anything but the spoken. She had ceased to be Mr. Densher's image; she was all her own memento and she was none the less fine. Still, still, what had passed was a fair bargain, and it would do. "Of course I like it. I feel—I can't otherwise describe it—as if I had been, on my knees, to the priest. I've confessed and I've been absolved. It has been lifted off."

Translation

Milly examined her appearance now, no longer thinking about anything except what she was saying. She wasn't Mr. Densher's idea of her anymore; she was entirely herself, a memory, and she was still wonderful. Even so, what had happened was a good deal, and it was enough. "Of course, I like it. I feel—I can't explain it any other way—like I've gone to confession. I've confessed, and I've been forgiven. It's been lifted from me."

Kate's eyes never quitted her. "He must have liked you."

Translation

Kate never stopped looking at her. "He must have liked you."

"Oh—doctors!" Milly said. "But I hope," she added, "he didn't like me too much." Then as if to escape a little from her friend's deeper sounding, or as impatient for the carriage, not yet in sight, her eyes, turning away, took in the great stale square. As its staleness, however, was but that of London fairly fatigued, the late hot London with its dance all danced and its story all told, the air seemed a thing of blurred pictures and mixed echoes, and an impression met the sense—an impression that broke, the next moment, through the girl's tightened lips. "Oh, it's a beautiful big world, and everyone, yes, everyone——!" It presently brought her back to Kate, and she hoped she didn't actually look as much as if she were crying as she must have looked to Lord Mark among the portraits at Matcham.

Translation

"Oh, doctors!" Milly said. "But I hope," she added, "he wasn't too into me." Then, as if to avoid her friend's serious mood or because she was eager for the carriage that still hadn't arrived, she looked away, taking in the vast, worn-out square. The weariness of the square was just the typical tiredness of London, London worn out from the recent heat, the parties over, the stories all told. The air felt like a blur of images and a mixture of sounds. A feeling struck her—a feeling that then burst through the girl's tense lips. "Oh, it's a beautiful, big world, and everyone, yes, everyone—!" It brought her back to Kate, and she hoped she didn't actually look as tearful as she must have appeared to Lord Mark among the portraits at Matcham.

Kate at all events understood. "Everyone wants to be so nice?"

Translation

Kate understood, at least. "Is everyone trying to be so agreeable?"

"So nice," said the grateful Milly.

Translation

"That's so nice," said Milly, sounding grateful.

"Oh," Kate laughed, "we'll pull you through! And won't you now bring Mrs. Stringham?"

Translation

"Oh," Kate laughed, "we'll get you through this!

And are you going to bring Mrs. Stringham with you?"

But Milly after an instant was again clear about that. "Not till I've seen him once more."

Translation

But Milly, after a moment, was sure about that again. "Not until I see him one more time."

She was to have found this preference, two days later, abundantly justified; and yet when, in prompt accordance with what had passed between them, she reappeared before her distinguished friend—that character having, for him, in the interval, built itself up still higher—the first thing he asked her was whether she had been accompanied. She told him, on this, straightway, everything; completely free at present from her first embarrassment, disposed even—as she felt she might become—to undue volubility, and conscious moreover of no alarm from his thus perhaps wishing that she had not come alone. It was exactly as if, in the forty-eight hours that had passed, her acquaintance with him had somehow increased, and his own knowledge in particular received mysterious additions. They had been together, before, scarce ten minutes; but the relation, the one the ten minutes had so beautifully created, was there to take straight up: and this not, on his own part, from mere professional heartiness, mere bedside manner, which she would have disliked—much rather from a quiet, pleasant air in him of having positively asked about her, asked here and there and found out. Of course he couldn't in the least have asked, or have wanted to; there was no source of information to his hand, and he had really needed none: he had found out simply by his genius—and found out, she meant, literally everything. Now she knew not only that she didn't dislike this—the state of being found out about; but that, on the contrary, it was truly what she had come for, and that, for the time at least, it would give her something firm to stand on. She struck herself as aware, aware as she had never been, of really not having had from the beginning anything firm. It would be strange for the firmness to come, after all, from her learning in these agreeable conditions that she was in some way doomed; but above all it would prove how little she had hitherto had to hold her up. If she was now to be held up by the mere process—since that was perhaps on the cards—of being let down, this would only testify in turn to her queer little history. That sense of loosely rattling had been no process at all; and it was ridiculously true that her thus sitting there to see her life put into the scales represented her first approach to the taste of orderly living. Such was Milly's romantic version—that her life, especially by the fact of this second interview, was put into the scales; and just the best part of the relation established might have been, for that matter, that the great grave charming man knew, had known at once, that it was romantic, and in that measure allowed for it. Her only doubt, her only fear, was whether he perhaps wouldn't even take advantage of her being a little romantic to treat her as romantic altogether. This doubtless was her danger with him; but she should see, and dangers in general meanwhile dropped and dropped.

Translation

Two days later, she would find her choice completely validated. When she went back to see her distinguished friend—a man whose reputation had grown in the meantime—right away he asked her if she had come with anyone. She immediately told him everything, now completely over her initial awkwardness, even possibly inclined to talk too much, and not at all worried that he seemed to wish she hadn't come alone. It was as if their acquaintance had deepened in those two days, and as if he had gained some mysterious knowledge about her. They had only spent ten minutes together before, but the connection they'd formed was still strong. He wasn't just being friendly in a professional way, like a doctor with a good bedside manner, which she wouldn't have liked. Instead, he seemed genuinely interested in her, as if he'd asked around about her and found things out. Of course, he couldn't have actually asked anyone, and he didn't need to. He just knew, simply by his intuition—and by "knew," she meant literally everything. Now, she realized that she didn't mind being "found out." On the contrary, that's what she had come for, and it would give her something stable to rely on, at least for a while. She realized she had never actually had anything stable to begin with. It would be strange if this stability came from discovering that she was in some way doomed, but it would also show how little she had had to support her until now. If she were now to be supported by the very process of being brought down—since that was possibly the plan—it would just confirm her unusual past. That feeling of being adrift had been no support at all. It was ridiculous, but true, that sitting there, having her life assessed, was her first experience of a structured life. That was Milly's romantic idea: that her life was being weighed in the balance, especially because of this second meeting. The best part of their relationship might be that the great, serious, charming man knew, from the start, that it was romantic, and was taking that into account.
