Her only doubt, her only fear, was that he might take advantage of her being a little romantic, and treat her as a completely romantic person. That was probably her danger with him, but she'd see, and for the moment, any other concerns fell away.

The very place, at the end of a few minutes, the commodious, "handsome" room, far back in the fine old house, soundless from position, somewhat sallow with years of celebrity, somewhat sombre even at midsummer—the very place put on for her a look of custom and use, squared itself solidly round her as with promises and certainties. She had come forth to see the world, and this then was to be the world's light, the rich dusk of a London "back," these the world's walls, those the world's curtains and carpet. She should be intimate with the great bronze clock and mantel-ornaments, conspicuously presented in gratitude and long ago; she should be as one of the circle of eminent contemporaries, photographed, engraved, signatured, and in particular framed and glazed, who made up the rest of the decoration, and made up as well so much of the human comfort; and while she thought of all the clean truths, unfringed, unfingered, that the listening stillness, strained into pauses and waits, would again and again, for years, have kept distinct, she also wondered what she would eventually decide upon to present in gratitude. She would give something better at least than the brawny Victorian bronzes. This was precisely an instance of what she felt he knew of her before he had done with her: that she was secretly romancing at that rate, in the midst of so much else that was more urgent, all over the place. So much for her secrets with him, none of which really required to be phrased. It would have been, for example, a secret for her from any one else that without a dear lady she had picked up just before coming over she wouldn't have a decently near connection, of any sort, for such an appeal as she was making, to put forward: no one in the least, as it were, to produce for respectability. But his seeing it she didn't mind a scrap, and not a scrap either his knowing how she had left the dear lady in the dark. She had come alone, putting her friend off with a fraud: giving a pretext of shops, of a whim, of she didn't know what—the amusement of being for once in the streets by herself. The streets by herself were new to her—she had always had in them a companion, or a maid; and he was never to believe, moreover, that she couldn't take full in the face anything he might have to say. He was softly amused at her account of her courage; though he yet showed it somehow without soothing her too grossly. Still, he did want to know whom she had. Hadn't there been a lady with her on Wednesday?

Translation

Within minutes, this comfortable, "handsome" room, located at the back of the elegant old house, silent due to its position, a bit faded from years of being famous, and even somewhat gloomy in the middle of summer—this very room embraced her, familiar and welcoming, enclosing her with a sense of security and certainty. She had come to experience the world, and this, then, was to be the world's ambiance, the rich twilight of a London "back room," these the world's walls, those the world's curtains and carpet. She would become accustomed to the large bronze clock and the ornaments on the mantelpiece, prominently displayed as gifts from long ago. She would become a part of the circle of famous contemporaries, immortalized in photographs, engravings, signatures, and framed pictures, which made up the rest of the decor and provided so much of the room's comfort. And as she considered all the simple, untouched truths that the listening silence, stretched into pauses and expectations, would preserve for years to come, she also wondered what she would eventually offer in return, what she would give as her gift of gratitude. It would be something better than those bulky Victorian bronzes, at least. This was exactly the kind of thing he knew about her before he even spoke: that she was secretly indulging in fantasies, even amidst more pressing matters, a habit she embraced everywhere she went. So much for her secrets with him, none of which needed to be spoken. For example, it would have been a secret from anyone else that without a dear friend she’d met just before coming, she wouldn't have had a connection, no matter how tenuous, to help her make the request she was about to make. She had no one, so to speak, to present for appearances' sake. But he knew it, and she didn’t mind at all. She didn’t mind either that he knew she’d left the dear lady in the dark. She had come alone, using a lie to get rid of her friend: inventing a reason about shopping, a whim, or something—the fun of being in the streets by herself for once. Being alone in the streets was new to her; she had always had a companion or a maid. Furthermore, he was never to believe that she couldn't handle whatever he might have to say. He was subtly amused by her account of her bravery, though he somehow showed it without patronizing her. Still, he did want to know who she had with her. Wasn't there a lady with her on Wednesday?

"Yes—a different one. Not the one who's travelling with me. I've told her."

Translation

Yes, a different person. Not the one I'm traveling with. I've already told her.

Distinctly he was amused, and it added to his air—the greatest charm of all—of giving her lots of time. "You've told her what?"

Translation

He was clearly entertained, and it made him seem even more appealing – the best quality he had was making her feel like he had all the time in the world. "You told her what?"

"Well," said Milly, "that I visit you in secret."

Translation

"Well," said Milly, "that I'll visit you secretly."

"And how many persons will she tell?"

Translation

And how many people will she tell?

"Oh, she's devoted. Not one."

Translation

Oh, she's a total pushover. Definitely not a match for him.

"Well, if she's devoted doesn't that make another friend for you?"

Translation

Well, if she's loyal, isn't that another friend for you?

It didn't take much computation, but she nevertheless had to think a moment, conscious as she was that he distinctly would want to fill out his notion of her—even a little, as it were, to warm the air for her. That, however—and better early than late—he must accept as of no use; and she herself felt for an instant quite a competent certainty on the subject of any such warming. The air, for Milly Theale, was, from the very nature of the case, destined never to rid itself of a considerable chill. This she could tell him with authority, if she could tell him nothing else; and she seemed to see now, in short, that it would importantly simplify. "Yes, it makes another; but they all together wouldn't make—well, I don't know what to call it but the difference. I mean when one is—really alone. I've never seen anything like the kindness." She pulled up a minute while he waited—waited again as if with his reasons for letting her, for almost making her, talk. What she herself wanted was not, for the third time, to cry, as it were, in public. She had never seen anything like the kindness, and she wished to do it justice; but she knew what she was about, and justice was not wronged by her being able presently to stick to her point. "Only one's situation is what it is. It's me it concerns. The rest is delightful and useless. Nobody can really help. That's why I'm by myself to-day. I want to be—in spite of Miss Croy, who came with me last. If you can help, so much the better and also of course if one can, a little, one's self. Except for that—you and me doing our best—I like you to see me just as I am. Yes, I like it—and I don't exaggerate. Shouldn't one, at the start, show the worst—so that anything after that may be better? It wouldn't make any real difference—it won't make any, anything that may happen won't—to any one. Therefore I feel myself, this way, with you, just as I am; and—if you do in the least care to know—it quite positively bears me up." She put it as to his caring to know, because his manner seemed to give her all her chance, and the impression was there for her to take. It was strange and deep for her, this impression, and she did, accordingly, take it straight home. It showed him—showed him in spite of himself—as allowing, somewhere far within, things comparatively remote, things in fact quite, as she would have said, outside, delicately to weigh with him; showed him as interested, on her behalf, in other questions beside the question of what was the matter with her. She accepted such an interest as regular in the highest type of scientific mind—his being the even highest, magnificently because otherwise, obviously, it wouldn't be there; but she could at the same time take it as a direct source of light upon herself, even though that might present her a little as pretending to equal him. Wanting to know more about a patient than how a patient was constructed or deranged couldn't be, even on the part of the greatest of doctors, anything but some form or other of the desire to let the patient down easily. When that was the case the reason, in turn, could only be, too manifestly, pity; and when pity held up its tell-tale face like a head on a pike, in a French revolution, bobbing before a window, what was the inference but that the patient was bad? He might say what he would now—she would always have seen the head at the window; and in fact from this moment she only wanted him to say what he would. He might say it too with the greater ease to himself as there wasn't one of her divinations that—as her own—he would in any way put himself out for. Finally, if he was making her talk she was talking; and what it could, at any rate, come to for him was that she wasn't afraid. If he wanted to do the dearest thing in the world for her he would show her he believed she wasn't; which undertaking of hers—not to have misled him—was what she counted at the moment as her presumptuous little hint to him that she was as good as himself. It put forward the bold idea that he could really be misled; and there actually passed between them for some seconds a sign, a sign of the eyes only, that they knew together where they were. This made, in their brown old temple of truth, its momentary flicker; then what followed it was that he had her, all the same, in his pocket; and the whole thing wound up, for that consummation, with its kind dim smile. Such kindness was wonderful with such dimness; but brightness—that even of sharp steel—was of course for the other side of the business, and it would all come in for her in one way or another. "Do you mean," he asked, "that you've no relations at all?—not a parent, not a sister, not even a cousin nor an aunt?"

Translation

She didn't need to think hard, but she still had to pause for a moment. She knew he wanted to understand her better, even to try and make her feel more comfortable. But she knew that was pointless. She had to accept that he couldn't help her, and it was better to face it now. She felt a certain certainty about her situation. For Milly Theale, the situation was such that she would always feel a deep chill. She could tell him this, if nothing else. And she realized it would simplify things. "Yes, it creates another problem," she said. "But all those problems together don't equal... I don't know what to call it, but it's the difference. I mean when someone is truly alone. I've never experienced anything like the kindness I've received." She stopped for a moment while he waited—he seemed to be giving her space to talk. She didn't want to break down in front of him again. She'd never known such kindness, and she wanted to acknowledge it, but she knew what she was doing, and acknowledging it didn't mean she couldn't stick to the point. "My situation is what it is. It concerns me. Everything else is wonderful, but doesn't change anything. No one can truly help. That's why I'm here alone today. I want to be—despite Miss Croy being with me last time. If you can help, great, and if I can help myself a little, even better. But beyond that—just you and me doing our best—I want you to see me as I am. Yes, I like it—and I'm not exaggerating. Shouldn't you start by showing the worst—so that anything after that might be better? It won't make a difference, anything that may happen won't affect anyone. So, I feel comfortable being myself with you. And—if you care—it really helps me."

She phrased it this way because he seemed to be giving her the opportunity, and she sensed that he was listening. It was a strange and profound impression, and she took it to heart. He was allowing, deep down, for things she considered remote, things that were, in fact, outside of her situation, to influence him. He was interested, on her behalf, in things beyond her illness. She considered such interest normal for the most brilliant scientific minds—his being the most brilliant because, if it weren't, it wouldn't be there. At the same time, she could see this as shedding light on herself, even if it made her appear to be trying to equal him. Wanting to know more about a patient than just how their body or mind functions could only be, even for the greatest doctor, a way of softening the blow for the patient. In that case, the reason, too obvious, was pity. When pity showed itself, like a head on a stake from a French revolution, bobbing in the window, what could she conclude but that she was in a bad way? He could say whatever he wanted now—she would always see the head in the window. From this moment on, she just wanted him to say what he thought. He could speak freely because he wouldn't be trying to help her in any way. She was talking because he was making her talk. The main thing for him was that she wasn't afraid. If he wanted to do the best thing for her, he would show her he believed she wasn't. Her intention not to mislead him was her way of hinting to him that she was as capable as he was. It suggested he could be wrong, and for a few seconds they exchanged a look that showed they understood each other. This created a moment of truth, then it was clear that she was essentially trapped in his process. It all ended with his kind, gentle smile. That kindness was wonderful, but the harsh truth was for the other side of this situation, and it would all come into play for her eventually. "Do you mean," he asked, "that you have no family at all? No parents, siblings, cousins, or aunts?"

She shook her head as with the easy habit of an interviewed heroine or a freak of nature at a show. "Nobody whatever." But the last thing she had come for was to be dreary about it. "I'm a survivor—a survivor of a general wreck. You see," she added, "how that's to be taken into account—that everyone else has gone. When I was ten years old there were, with my father and my mother, six of us. I'm all that's left. But they died," she went on, to be fair all round, "of different things. Still, there it is. And, as I told you before, I'm American. Not that I mean that makes me worse. However, you'll probably know what it makes me."

Translation

She shook her head, as if she were a character in an interview or a sideshow attraction. "Absolutely nobody." But she didn't want to dwell on that. "I'm a survivor – a survivor of a disaster. You have to consider," she added, "that everyone else is gone. When I was ten, there were six of us, including my parents. I'm the only one left. But," she clarified, "they died of different causes. Still, that's the situation. And, as I said, I'm American. Not that I mean that's a bad thing. However, you probably know what it means."

"Yes," he discreetly indulged her; "I know perfectly what it makes you. It makes you, to begin with, a capital case."

Translation

"Yes," he said, playing along quietly. "I know exactly what it does to you. To start, it makes you someone who could be put to death."

She sighed, though gratefully, as if again before the social scene. "Ah, there you are!"

Translation

She sighed, but with relief, as if she were back in the social setting. "Oh, there you are!"

"Oh, no; there 'we' aren't at all. There I am only—but as much as you like. I've no end of American friends: there they are, if you please, and it's a fact that you couldn't very well be in a better place than in their company. It puts you with plenty of others—and that isn't pure solitude." Then he pursued: "I'm sure you've an excellent spirit; but don't try to bear more things than you need." Which after an instant he further explained. "Hard things have come to you in youth, but you mustn't think life will be for you all hard things. You've the right to be happy. You must make up your mind to it. You must accept any form in which happiness may come."

Translation

Oh, no, that's not what I meant at all. It's just me – but I'm completely available to you. I have tons of American friends, they're right here if you want to meet them, and frankly, you couldn't be in better company. It means you'd be with a lot of people – not alone.

Then he continued:

"I know you have a good spirit, but don't try to handle more than you have to." He clarified after a moment. "You've faced difficult times already, but don't assume your whole life will be like that. You deserve to be happy. You have to decide you will be. You have to welcome happiness in whatever way it comes."

"Oh, I'll accept any whatever!" she almost gaily returned. "And it seems to me, for that matter, that I'm accepting a new one every day. Now this!" she smiled.

Translation

"Oh, I'm open to anything!" she replied, almost cheerfully. "And it feels like I'm getting a new one every day, anyway. Now this!" she smiled.

"This is very well so far as it goes. You can depend on me," the great man said, "for unlimited interest. But I'm only, after all, one element in fifty. We must gather in plenty of others. Don't mind who knows. Knows, I mean, that you and I are friends."

Translation

"This is a good start. You can count on me for my full support," the important man said. "However, I'm just one person out of many. We need to get a lot more people involved. Don't worry about people finding out. Finding out, I mean, that you and I are friends."

"Ah, you do want to see some one!" she broke out. "You want to get at some one who cares for me." With which, however, as he simply met this spontaneity in a manner to show that he had often had it from young persons of her race, and that he was familiar even with the possibilities of their familiarity, she felt her freedom rendered vain by his silence, and she immediately tried to think of the most reasonable thing she could say. This would be, precisely, on the subject of that freedom, which she now quickly spoke of as complete. "That's of course by itself a great boon; so please don't think I don't know it. I can do exactly what I like—anything in all the wide world. I haven't a creature to ask—there's not a finger to stop me. I can shake about till I'm black and blue. That perhaps isn't all joy; but lots of people, I know, would like to try it." He had appeared about to put a question, but then had let her go on, which she promptly did, for she understood him the next moment as having thus taken it from her that her means were as great as might be. She had simply given it to him so, and this was all that would ever pass between them on the odious head. Yet she couldn't help also knowing that an important effect, for his judgment, or at least for his amusement—which was his feeling, since, marvellously, he did have feeling—was produced by it. All her little pieces had now then fallen together for him like the morsels of coloured glass that used to make combinations, under the hand, in the depths of one of the polygonal peepshows of childhood. "So that if it's a question of my doing anything under the sun that will help——!"

Translation

"Oh, you want to see someone!" she blurted out. "You want to find someone who cares about me." However, he just reacted as if he'd heard this kind of thing from young women like her before, and that he was used to their behavior. This made her feel like her freedom was pointless because of his silence, so she immediately tried to think of the most sensible thing to say. This was, of course, about that freedom, which she quickly described as complete. "That's a huge advantage, and please don't think I don't realize it. I can do whatever I want—anything in the whole world. I don't have anyone to answer to—no one to stop me. I can travel wherever I want. Maybe that's not always fun, but I know a lot of people would love to try it."

He seemed like he was about to ask a question, but then let her continue. She quickly understood that he was assuming she had as much money as possible. She'd simply given him that impression, and that was all that would be said about the subject. Still, she knew it would have an impact, either on his judgment or, at the very least, his amusement—which was his typical reaction, since he somehow had feelings. All her little actions had now clicked into place for him, like the pieces of colored glass that used to create images in those childhood toy kaleidoscopes. "So, if it's a matter of me doing anything that would help—!"

"You'll do anything under the sun? Good." He took that beautifully, ever so pleasantly, for what it was worth; but time was needed—ten minutes or so were needed on the spot—to deal even provisionally, with the substantive question. It was convenient, in its degree, that there was nothing she wouldn't do; but it seemed also highly and agreeably vague that she should have to do anything. They thus appeared to be taking her, together, for the moment, and almost for sociability, as prepared to proceed to gratuitous extremities; the upshot of which was in turn, that after much interrogation, auscultation, exploration, much noting of his own sequences and neglecting of hers, had duly kept up the vagueness, they might have struck themselves, or may at least strike us, as coming back from an undeterred but useless voyage to the north pole. Milly was ready, under orders, for the north pole; which fact was doubtless what made a blinding anticlimax of her friend's actual abstention from orders. "No," she heard him again distinctly repeat it, "I don't want you for the present to do anything at all; anything, that is, but obey a small prescription or two that will be made clear to you, and let me within a few days come to see you at home."

Translation

"You'll do anything? Great." He accepted that enthusiastically, but it still took about ten minutes to even begin to address the real issue. It was helpful that she was willing to do anything, but also strangely unclear that she'd actually *have* to do anything. They seemed to be, for now, treating her like they could casually ask her to do anything, no matter how extreme. After a lot of questioning, checking things out, and focusing on his own thoughts while ignoring hers, they'd maintained the ambiguity, and they might have felt, or at least we might feel, like they were returning from a pointless trip to the North Pole. Milly was ready, willing to go to the North Pole, which made her friend's ultimate refusal to give her any instructions a huge letdown. "No," she heard him repeat clearly, "I don't want you to do anything right now. Nothing except follow a couple of simple instructions that I'll give you, and let me come visit you at your place in a few days."

It was at first heavenly. "Then you'll see Mrs. Stringham." But she didn't mind a bit now.

Translation

It was wonderful at first. "Then you'll meet Mrs. Stringham." But she wasn't bothered at all anymore.

"Well, I shan't be afraid of Mrs. Stringham." And he said it once more as she asked once more: "Absolutely not; I 'send' you nowhere. England's all right—anywhere that's pleasant, convenient, decent, will be all right. You say you can do exactly as you like. Oblige me therefore by being so good as to do it. There's only one thing: you ought of course, now, as soon as I've seen you again, to get out of London."

Translation

"Well, I won't be scared of Mrs. Stringham."

And he repeated it when she asked again:

"Absolutely not; I'm not sending you anywhere. England is fine—anywhere that's enjoyable, convenient, and respectable will be fine. You said you could do whatever you want. So please, do that for me. There's just one thing: of course, now that I've seen you again, you should leave London."

Milly thought. "May I then go back to the continent?"

Translation

Milly wondered. "Can I go back to Europe, then?"

"By all means back to the continent. Do go back to the continent."

Translation

Absolutely, go back to Europe. Please, go back to Europe.

"Then how will you keep seeing me? But perhaps," she quickly added, "you won't want to keep seeing me."

Translation

So how are you going to keep seeing me? But maybe," she quickly added, "you won't even want to."

He had it all ready; he had really everything all ready. "I shall follow you up; though if you mean that I don't want you to keep seeing me——"

Translation

He had everything prepared, absolutely everything. "I'll keep coming after you, even though if you're trying to say you don't want to see me anymore..."

"Well?" she asked.

Translation

"So?" she asked.

It was only just here that he struck her the least bit as stumbling. "Well, see all you can. That's what it comes to. Worry about nothing. You have at least no worries. It's a great, rare chance."

Translation

He just barely touched her, barely nudging her. "Okay, look around and take it all in. That's what matters. Don't worry about anything. You have absolutely nothing to worry about. This is a fantastic, unusual opportunity."

She had got up, for she had had from him both that he would send her something and would advise her promptly of the date of his coming to her, by which she was virtually dismissed. Yet, for herself, one or two things kept her. "May I come back to England too?"

Translation

She was up now, because he had promised to send her something and to let her know right away when he was coming to see her, which basically meant he was letting her go. However, she still had a couple of things on her mind. "Can I also come back to England?"

"Rather! Whenever you like. But always, when you do come, immediately let me know."

Translation

Yes, absolutely! Whenever you want. But please, let me know as soon as you arrive.

"Ah," said Milly, "it won't be a great going to and fro."

Translation

"Oh," said Milly, "it won't be a big deal."

"Then if you'll stay with us, so much the better."

Translation

Then we'd be very happy if you stayed.

It touched her, the way he controlled his impatience of her; and the fact itself affected her as so precious that she yielded to the wish to get more from it. "So you don't think I'm out of my mind?"

Translation

She was moved by how he managed to hide his impatience with her. The very fact that he did this felt special, so she gave in to her desire to explore it further. "So, you don't think I'm crazy?"

"Perhaps that is," he smiled, "all that's the matter."

Translation

"Maybe that's," he smiled, "the whole problem."

She looked at him longer. "No, that's too good. Shall I, at any rate, suffer?"

Translation

She stared at him for a while. "No, that's too much of a good thing.

Should I just give up, no matter what?"

"Not a bit."

Translation

Not at all.

"And yet then live?"

Translation

And yet, do I still live?

"My dear young lady," said her distinguished friend, "isn't to 'live' exactly what I'm trying to persuade you to take the trouble to do?"

Translation

"Listen, sweetie," her important friend said, "isn't 'living' precisely what I'm trying to convince you to actually do?"

Chapter XIII

Chapter Summary & Character Study
Summary

After leaving a meeting, a woman walks alone through London without a set destination. She passes through unknown streets until she arrives at Regent's Park. She enters the park, finds an empty bench, and sits down to rest. After some time, she gets up and leaves.

For the next day or two, she deceives her companion, Susie.

That evening, her friend Kate Croy arrives at the hotel in a hansom cab. The woman, Milly, sees Kate arrive from a balcony, and they exchange nods and smiles. Kate comes up to the sitting-room and asks what the doctor said. Milly replies that it is "all right," that there is nothing to worry about, and that she can do as she likes. Kate kisses her. Milly elaborates that she is to travel and go to places for pleasure. She asks Kate to help her, and Kate agrees.

Character Study

Based on the text, here is a concise character study:

  • *Milly**
    • Milly is initially presented in a state of agitated excitement, energized by a "distinguished friend's" words. This propels her into a solitary walk through London, which she frames as a "great adventure," a military-like march into a new, uncertain life. Her situation shifts dramatically as she sits in Regent's Park. Her initial feeling of empowerment dissolves into physical and emotional exhaustion. Her thinking turns analytical and suspicious, leading her to reinterpret the friend's kindness not as encouragement, but as a "chilling" form of pity for a grave, unspoken condition. This realization transforms her from an adventurer into a "poor girl" facing a dire reality. In her final interaction, she undergoes another immediate shift, choosing to perform a role. Confronted with Kate’s vitality, she conceals her internal crisis and presents a facade of perfect health and freedom, actively creating a false narrative about her situation.
  • *The "Distinguished Friend" (Doctor)**
    • He is presented entirely through Milly’s shifting interpretations. Initially, he is an empowering figure whose advice to "be active" acts as a "final push" into a new life. As Milly’s mood sours, her perception of him changes. He becomes a man who is "bolstering" the weak, treating her with a "beneficent dishonesty" and a compassion she finds "divesting, denuding, exposing." He is less a character in his own right and more a catalyst for Milly's internal transformations.
  • *Susan (Susie) Shepherd**
    • Susan is portrayed as a companion whose defining characteristic is an almost reverent, "Byzantine" consideration for Milly. She is presented as someone who intentionally spares Milly from difficult questions, treating her with the deference due to a "princess." Her situation is that of an unwitting observer, kept at a distance by her own courtly manners, which Milly now uses to help conceal her true state.
  • *Kate Croy**
Kate is presented as a figure of vibrant, direct, and uncomplicated health. Her arrival is energetic and her questioning is straightforward ("Well, what?"). She is characterized by her physical splendor and what Milly perceives as a "practical impeccability." Her situation is that of a confidante who is actively deceived. She immediately and enthusiastically accepts Milly's lie, her cheerful assumptions providing the perfect audience for Milly’s new performance of well-being.

She had gone out with these last words so in her ears that when once she was well away—back this time in the great square alone—it was as if some instant application of them had opened out there before her. It was positively, this effect, an excitement that carried her on; she went forward into space under the sense of an impulse received—an impulse simple and direct, easy above all to act upon. She was borne up for the hour, and now she knew why she had wanted to come by herself. No one in the world could have sufficiently entered into her state; no tie would have been close enough to enable a companion to walk beside her without some disparity. She literally felt, in this first flush, that her only company must be the human race at large, present all round her, but inspiringly impersonal, and that her only field must be, then and there, the grey immensity of London. Grey immensity had somehow of a sudden become her element; grey immensity was what her distinguished friend had, for the moment, furnished her world with and what the question of "living," as he put it to her, living by option, by volition, inevitably took on for its immediate face. She went straight before her, without weakness, altogether with strength; and still as she went she was more glad to be alone, for nobody—not Kate Croy, not Susan Shepherd either—would have wished to rush with her as she rushed. She had asked him at the last whether, being on foot, she might go home so, or elsewhere, and he had replied as if almost amused again at her extravagance: "You're active, luckily, by nature—it's beautiful: therefore rejoice in it. Be active, without folly—for you're not foolish: be as active as you can and as you like." That had been in fact the final push, as well as the touch that most made a mixture of her consciousness—a strange mixture that tasted at one and the same time of what she had lost and what had been given her. It was wonderful to her, while she took her random course, that these quantities felt so equal: she had been treated—hadn't she?—as if it were in her power to live; and yet one wasn't treated so—was one?—unless it came up, quite as much, that one might die. The beauty of the bloom had gone from the small old sense of safety—that was distinct: she had left it behind her there forever. But the beauty of the idea of a great adventure, a big dim experiment or struggle in which she might, more responsibly than ever before, take a hand, had been offered her instead. It was as if she had had to pluck off her breast, to throw away, some friendly ornament, a familiar flower, a little old jewel, that was part of her daily dress; and to take up and shoulder as a substitute some queer defensive weapon, a musket, a spear, a battle-axe conducive possibly in a higher degree to a striking appearance, but demanding all the effort of the military posture. She felt this instrument, for that matter, already on her back, so that she proceeded now in very truth as a soldier on a march—proceeded as if, for her initiation, the first charge had been sounded. She passed along unknown streets, over dusty littery ways, between long rows of fronts not enhanced by the August light; she felt good for miles and only wanted to get lost; there were moments at corners, where she stopped and chose her direction, in which she quite lived up to his injunction to rejoice that she was active. It was like a new pleasure to have so new a reason; she would affirm, without delay, her option, her volition; taking this personal possession of what surrounded her was a fair affirmation to start with; and she really didn't care if she made it at the cost of alarms for Susie. Susie would wonder in due course "whatever," as they said at the hotel, had become of her; yet this would be nothing either, probably, to wonderments still in store. Wonderments in truth, Milly felt, even now attended her steps: it was quite as if she saw in people's eyes the reflection of her appearance and pace. She found herself moving at times in regions visibly not haunted by odd-looking girls from New York, duskily draped, sable-plumed, all but incongruously shod and gazing about them with extravagance; she might, from the curiosity she clearly excited in byways, in side-streets peopled with grimy children and costermongers carts, which she hoped were slums, literally have had her musket on her shoulder, have announced herself as freshly on the warpath. But for the fear of overdoing this character she would here and there have begun conversation, have asked her way; in spite of the fact that, as that would help the requirements of adventure, her way was exactly what she wanted not to know. The difficulty was that she at last accidentally found it; she had come out, she presently saw, at the Regent's Park, round which, on two or three occasions with Kate Croy, her public chariot had solemnly rolled. But she went into it further now; this was the real thing; the real thing was to be quite away from the pompous roads, well within the centre and on the stretches of shabby grass. Here were benches and smutty sheep; here were idle lads at games of ball, with their cries mild in the thick air; here were wanderers, anxious and tired like herself; here doubtless were hundreds of others just in the same box. Their box, their great common anxiety, what was it, in this grim breathing-space, but the practical question of life? They could live if they would; that is, like herself, they had been told so; she saw them all about her, on seats, digesting the information, feeling it altered, assimilated, recognising it again as something, in a slightly different shape, familiar enough, the blessed old truth that they would live if they could. All she thus shared with them made her wish to sit in their company; which she so far did that she looked for a bench that was empty, eschewing a still emptier chair that she saw hard by and for which she would have paid, with superiority, a fee.

Translation

She was still hearing those last words. When she got far enough away, back in the big square all alone, it was as if their meaning had suddenly become clear. In fact, this feeling was an exciting one that pushed her forward. She entered the space with a sense of purpose – a simple, clear impulse that was easy to act on. She felt energized for the moment, and now she understood why she'd wanted to be alone. No one in the world could have fully understood her situation; no close relationship could allow a companion to walk beside her without some misunderstanding. She literally felt, in this first rush of emotion, that her only company must be the entire human race, present all around her but inspiringly impersonal, and that her only arena must be the gray vastness of London. That gray vastness had suddenly become her element. It was what her distinguished friend had, for the time being, provided her with, and what the question of "living," as he put it, living by choice and will, inevitably presented as its immediate challenge.

She walked straight ahead without weakness, full of strength. She was increasingly glad to be alone, because nobody—not Kate Croy, not Susan Shepherd—would have wanted to rush with her as she was rushing. She had asked him at the end whether she could walk home or go elsewhere, since she was on foot, and he had replied almost amused by her enthusiasm: "You're naturally active, which is wonderful. So, enjoy it. Be active, without being foolish—because you aren't. Be as active as you can and as you like." That had been the final push and the thing that most mixed up her thoughts – a strange mix that tasted of both what she'd lost and what she'd been given. It was amazing to her, as she wandered along, that these things felt so equal. She had been treated – hadn't she? – as if it were in her power to live. And yet, you wouldn't be treated like that – would you? – unless it was also clear that you might die. The beauty of security was gone. She had left it behind her forever. But instead, she'd been offered the beauty of the idea of a great adventure, a big experiment or struggle in which she could take part with more responsibility than ever before. It was as if she'd had to take off and throw away some friendly ornament, a familiar flower, a little old jewel that was part of her everyday appearance, and pick up and carry instead some strange defensive weapon, a musket, a spear, or a battle-axe. Those weapons could possibly make her appear more striking, but they required a soldier's effort.

She already felt this instrument on her back. She was proceeding as a soldier on a march, as if the first attack had begun. She walked through unknown streets, over dusty and littered pathways, between long rows of buildings not improved by the August light. She felt good for miles and just wanted to get lost. There were moments at corners, where she stopped and chose her direction, in which she completely lived up to his instruction to enjoy her activity. It was a new pleasure to have such a new reason. She would immediately declare her choice and her will. Taking personal ownership of what surrounded her was a fair declaration to start with. She didn't really care if she caused worry for Susie. Susie would eventually wonder what had happened to her, as they said at the hotel. But this wouldn't be anything compared to the other things she might have to deal with. Milly felt that wonderings truly accompanied her steps even now. It was as if she saw her appearance and the pace of her actions reflected in people's eyes. She found herself moving through areas where she saw few odd-looking girls from New York, darkly dressed with sable plumes. They seemed strangely shod and gazed around with extravagance. From the curiosity she clearly aroused in side streets populated by dirty children and costermongers' carts, which she hoped were slums, she could have literally had her musket on her shoulder and announced herself as newly on the warpath.

But, for fear of overdoing it, she resisted the urge to begin conversations and ask for directions. She actually didn't want to know the way, as that would help the adventure's requirements. The problem was that she eventually found it by accident. She had come out, she realized, in Regent's Park, which she'd visited with Kate Croy a few times in her carriage. But now she went further into it. This was the real thing. The real thing was to be away from the busy roads, deep within the center and on the stretches of worn grass. Here were benches and dirty sheep. Here were idle boys playing ball, their cries softened by the thick air. Here were wanderers, anxious and tired like herself. Doubtless, hundreds of others were in the same situation. What was their shared anxiety in this somber moment but the practical question of life? They could live if they chose; that is, they'd been told as much, just like her. She saw them all around her, on seats, absorbing the information, feeling it changed, integrated, recognizing it again as something slightly familiar, the old truth that they would live if they could. All she shared with them made her want to sit with them. She looked for an empty bench, avoiding a chair nearby that was even emptier and for which she would have had to pay a fee with a feeling of superiority.

The last scrap of superiority had soon enough left her, if only because she before long knew herself for more tired than she had proposed. This and the charm, after a fashion, of the situation in itself made her linger and rest; there was a sort of spell in the sense that nobody in the world knew where she was. It was the first time in her life that this had happened; somebody, everybody appeared to have known before, at every instant of it, where she was; so that she was now suddenly able to put it to herself that that hadn't been a life. This present kind of thing therefore might be—which was where precisely her distinguished friend seemed to be wishing her to come out. He wished her also, it was true, not to make, as she was perhaps doing now, too much of her isolation; at the same time however as he clearly desired to deny her no decent source of interest. He was interested—she arrived at that—in her appealing to as many sources as possible; and it fairly filtered into her, as she sat and sat, that he was essentially propping her up. Had she been doing it herself she would have called it bolstering—the bolstering that was simply for the weak; and she thought and thought as she put together the proofs that it was as one of the weak he was treating her. It was of course as one of the weak that she had gone to him—but, oh, with how sneaking a hope that he might pronounce her, as to all indispensables, a veritable young lioness! What indeed she was really confronted with was the consciousness that he had not, after all, pronounced her anything: she nursed herself into the sense that he had beautifully got out of it. Did he think, however, she wondered, that he could keep out of it to the end?—though, as she weighed the question, she yet felt it a little unjust. Milly weighed, in this extraordinary hour, questions numerous and strange; but she had, happily, before she moved, worked round to a simplification. Stranger than anything, for instance, was the effect of its rolling over her that, when one considered it, he might perhaps have "got out" by one door but to come in with a beautiful, beneficent dishonesty by another. It kept her more intensely motionless there that what he might fundamentally be "up to" was some disguised intention of standing by her as a friend. Wasn't that what women always said they wanted to do when they deprecated the addresses of gentlemen they couldn't more intimately go on with? It was what they, no doubt, sincerely fancied they could make of men of whom they couldn't make husbands. And she didn't even reason that it was, by a similar law, the expedient of doctors in general for the invalids of whom they couldn't make patients: she was somehow so sufficiently aware that her doctor was—however fatuous it might sound—exceptionally moved. This was the damning little fact—if she could talk of damnation: that she could believe herself to have caught him in the act of irrelevantly liking her. She hadn't gone to him to be liked, she had gone to him to be judged; and he was quite a great enough man to be in the habit, as a rule, of observing the difference. She could like him, as she distinctly did—that was another matter; all the more that her doing so was now, so obviously for herself, compatible with judgment. Yet it would have been all portentously mixed had not, as we say, a final, merciful wave, chilling rather, but washing clear, come to her assistance.

Translation

Her sense of being superior quickly faded, probably because she realized she was more exhausted than she'd admitted. This, along with a certain appeal to the situation itself, made her stay put and relax. There was something magical about knowing that no one in the world knew where she was. It was a first for her; it seemed as if, up to now, someone, everyone, had always known her whereabouts. Now she could finally admit to herself that what she’d experienced until now hadn’t been a real life. This new experience, then, might be the true thing—which was precisely the goal her distinguished friend seemed to be encouraging. He also, it was true, wished her not to dwell too much on her isolation, as she might be doing now, while clearly wanting to allow her every reasonable opportunity for interest. He was interested—she realized—in her drawing on as many sources of interest as possible; and it gradually dawned on her, as she sat and sat, that he was essentially supporting her. If she were the one doing it, she’d call it coddling—the kind of support reserved for the weak. And she thought and thought as she considered the evidence, concluding that he was treating her as one of the weak. Of course, that's how she had approached him—but with a secret hope that he might declare her a formidable, young woman! In reality, she was facing the realization that he hadn't declared her anything. She began to feel he had artfully avoided doing so. Did he think, she wondered, that he could avoid it indefinitely? Even as she considered the question, she felt it was a little unfair. During this extraordinary time, Milly wrestled with many strange questions, but thankfully, she reached a simplification before she moved. What was stranger than anything, for instance, was the realization that, considering it, he might have “got out” of one commitment only to come back in through another, with a kind, dishonest intent. It kept her rooted there as she considered whether his fundamental aim was a disguised plan to befriend her. Wasn't that what women always said they wanted when they rejected the advances of men they couldn't be more intimate with? It's what they sincerely thought they could make of men they couldn't make husbands. And she didn't even reason that it was, by a similar principle, the strategy of doctors in general toward the patients they couldn't cure. She was somehow very much aware that her doctor was—however ridiculous it sounded—exceptionally moved by her. This was the damning fact—if she could speak of damnation: that she could believe she had caught him in the act of irrationally liking her. She hadn't gone to him to be liked; she had gone to him to be judged; and he was a great enough man to be in the habit, as a rule, of understanding the difference. She could like him, as she distinctly did—that was another matter; all the more so because her feeling for him was now, obviously for herself, compatible with judgment. Yet it would have all been terribly confused if a final, merciful wave hadn't come to her rescue, a wave that chilled her a bit but clarified everything.

It came, of a sudden, when all other thought was spent. She had been asking herself why, if her case was grave—and she knew what she meant by that—he should have talked to her at all about what she might with futility "do"; or why on the other hand, if it were light, he should attach an importance to the office of friendship. She had him, with her little lonely acuteness—as acuteness went during the dog-days in the Regent's Park—in a cleft stick: she either mattered, and then she was ill; or she didn't matter, and then she was well enough. Now he was "acting," as they said at home, as if she did matter—until he should prove the contrary. It was too evident that a person at his high pressure must keep his inconsistencies, which were probably his highest amusements, only for the very greatest occasions. Her prevision, in fine, of just where she should catch him furnished the light of that judgment in which we describe her as daring to indulge. And the judgment it was that made her sensation simple. He had distinguished her—that was the chill. He hadn't known—how could he?—that she was devilishly subtle, subtle exactly in the manner of the suspected, the suspicious, the condemned. He in fact confessed to it, in his way, as to an interest in her combinations, her funny race, her funny losses, her funny gains, her funny freedom, and, no doubt, above all, her funny manners—funny, like those of Americans at their best, without being vulgar, legitimating amiability and helping to pass it off. In his appreciation of these redundancies he dressed out for her the compassion he so signally permitted himself to waste; but its operation for herself was as directly divesting, denuding, exposing. It reduced her to her ultimate state, which was that of a poor girl with her rent to pay for example—staring before her in a great city. Milly had her rent to pay, her rent for her future; everything else but how to meet it fell away from her in pieces, in tatters. This was the sensation the great man had doubtless not purposed. Well, she must go home, like the poor girl, and see. There might after all be ways; the poor girl too would be thinking. It came back for that matter perhaps to views already presented. She looked about her again, on her feet, at her scattered, melancholy comrades—some of them so melancholy as to be down on their stomachs in the grass, turned away, ignoring, burrowing; she saw once more, with them, those two faces of the question between which there was so little to choose for inspiration. It was perhaps superficially more striking that one could live if one would; but it was more appealing, insinuating, irresistible, in short, that one would live if one could.

Translation

It hit her suddenly, when she’d exhausted all other thoughts. She’d been wondering why, if her situation was serious – and she knew what she meant by that – he would have talked to her at all about things she might fruitlessly “do.” Alternatively, if it wasn’t serious, why would he make so much of their friendship? Her cleverness, as sharp as it got during the lazy summer days in Regent's Park, had him trapped. Either she mattered, and was therefore ill, or she didn’t matter, and was fine. Now, he was “acting,” as they’d say back home, as if she did matter – until he proved otherwise. It was obvious someone so important saved their inconsistencies, which were probably his greatest entertainment, for the most important situations. Her ability to predict his behavior provided the foundation for her daring judgment. And it was that judgment that made her feeling simple. He'd singled her out – that was the cold truth. He didn’t know – how could he? – that she was incredibly perceptive, perceptive in the same way as someone suspicious, under suspicion, or condemned. He actually admitted it, in his own way, by showing interest in her complex personality, her quirks, her failures, her successes, her freedom, and, undoubtedly, above all, her amusing behavior – amusing, like the best Americans, without being crude, justifying friendliness and helping to gloss it over. In acknowledging these aspects, he displayed the compassion he so easily allowed himself to feel; but for her, the effect was directly stripping away everything, leaving her exposed. It reduced her to her core state, that of a poor woman with her rent to pay – staring out at the great city. Milly had to pay her rent, her rent for her future; everything else but how to manage that crumbled away. This was the sensation the great man surely hadn’t intended. Well, she had to go home, like that poor woman, and figure it out. Maybe there were options; the poor woman would be thinking too. It possibly went back to ideas that had already been brought up. She looked around again, standing, at her scattered, sad companions – some so sad they were lying face down in the grass, avoiding the world, hiding; she saw again, with them, the two sides of the dilemma, both equally uninspiring. It was perhaps more immediately striking that one could live if one tried; but it was more appealing, seductive, irresistible, that one *would* live if one could.

She found after this, for the day or two, more amusement than she had ventured to count on in the fact, if it were not a mere fancy, of deceiving Susie; and she presently felt that what made the difference was the mere fancy—as this was one—of a countermove to her great man. His taking on himself—should he do so—to get at her companion made her suddenly, she held, irresponsible, made any notion of her own all right for her; though indeed at the very moment she invited herself to enjoy this impunity she became aware of new matter for surprise, or at least for speculation. Her idea would rather have been that Mrs. Stringham would have looked at her hard—her sketch of the grounds of her long, independent excursion showing, she could feel, as almost cynically superficial. Yet the dear woman so failed, in the event, to avail herself of any right of criticism that it was sensibly tempting, for an hour, to wonder if Kate Croy had been playing perfectly fair. Hadn't she possibly, from motives of the highest benevolence, promptings of the finest anxiety, just given poor Susie what she would have called the straight tip? It must immediately be mentioned, however, that, quite apart from a remembrance of the distinctness of Kate's promise, Milly, the next thing, found her explanation in a truth that had the merit of being general. If Susie, at this crisis, suspiciously spared her, it was really that Susie was always suspiciously sparing her—yet occasionally, too, with portentous and exceptional mercies. The girl was conscious of how she dropped at times into inscrutable, impenetrable deferences—attitudes that, though without at all intending it, made a difference for familiarity, for the ease of intimacy. It was as if she recalled herself to manners, to the law of court-etiquette—which last note above all helped our young woman to a just appreciation. It was definite for her, even if not quite solid, that to treat her as a princess was a positive need of her companion's mind; wherefore she couldn't help it if this lady had her transcendent view of the way the class in question were treated. Susan had read history, had read Gibbon and Froude and Saint-Simon; she had high-lights as to the special allowances made for the class, and, since she saw them, when young, as effete and overtutored, inevitably ironic and infinitely refined, one must take it for amusing if she inclined to an indulgence verily Byzantine. If one could only be Byzantine!—wasn't that what she insidiously led one on to sigh? Milly tried to oblige her—for it really placed Susan herself so handsomely to be Byzantine now. The great ladies of that race—it would be somewhere in Gibbon—weren't, apparently, questioned about their mysteries. But oh, poor Milly and hers! Susan at all events proved scarce more inquisitive than if she had been a mosaic at Ravenna. Susan was a porcelain monument to the odd moral that consideration might, like cynicism, have abysses. Besides, the Puritan finally disencumbered——! What starved generations wasn't Mrs. Stringham, in fancy, going to make up for?

Translation

After this, for a day or two, she found more amusement than she had expected, if it wasn't just a fantasy, in the fact that she was deceiving Susie. She quickly realized the difference came from the simple idea – like this one – of a countermove against her "great man" (probably Merton Densher). If he took it upon himself to pursue her friend, she suddenly felt it made her unaccountable, making her own choices feel okay. But even as she embraced this freedom, she started noticing new things to be surprised by or at least think about.

Her expectation was that Mrs. Stringham would scrutinize her – her casual explanation for her long, independent trip must seem almost cynically superficial, she felt. But Mrs. Stringham didn't criticize her at all, making it tempting to wonder for a while if Kate Croy had been entirely honest. Hadn't Kate possibly, out of a genuine desire to help and a deep concern, given poor Susie the “straight scoop”?

However, it’s important to say that, setting aside the memory of Kate's clear promise, Milly's next thought offered a reason that was universally true. If Susie was unusually gentle with her at this time, it was really just because Susie was always suspiciously gentle with her – though sometimes also displaying remarkable, extraordinary kindness. Milly was aware of how Susie sometimes adopted impenetrable, inscrutable levels of deference – behaviors that, without meaning to, created distance from familiarity and ease. It was as if Susie was recalling herself to good manners, the rules of formal etiquette – which, more than anything else, helped Milly understand. It was clear to her, even if not fully convincing, that treating her like a princess was a need for her friend. So, she couldn’t fault Susie if she had this grand idea of how the upper class were treated. Susan had read history, including Gibbon, Froude, and Saint-Simon. She was sensitive to the special privileges of the upper class, and since she viewed them as young, as exhausted and overeducated, inevitably ironic and refined, one should find it amusing that she leaned toward a Byzantine style of indulgence.

“If only one could be Byzantine!” – wasn't that what Susie subtly encouraged her to long for? Milly tried to accommodate her – because it really made Susie look good to be Byzantine now. The great ladies of that era – somewhere in Gibbon, I believe – were apparently never questioned about their secrets. But oh, poor Milly and hers! Susie, in the end, showed no more curiosity than a mosaic at Ravenna. Susie was a delicate monument to the strange idea that consideration, like cynicism, could have its own dark depths. Besides, the Puritan finally gets rid of the…! What starved generations, in her imagination, was Mrs. Stringham going to make up for?

Kate Croy came straight to the hotel—came that evening shortly before dinner; specifically and publicly moreover, in a hansom that, driven apparently very fast, pulled up beneath their windows almost with the clatter of an accident, a "smash." Milly, alone, as happened, in the great garnished void of their sitting-room, where, a little, really, like a caged Byzantine, she had been pacing through the queer, long-drawn, almost sinister delay of night, an effect she yet liked—Milly, at the sound, one of the French windows standing open, passed out to the balcony that overhung, with pretensions, the general entrance, and so was in time for the look that Kate, alighting, paying her cabman, happened to send up to the front. The visitor moreover had a shilling back to wait for, during which Milly, from the balcony, looked down at her, and a mute exchange, but with smiles and nods, took place between them on what had occurred in the morning. It was what Kate had called for, and the tone was thus, almost by accident, determined for Milly before her friend came up. What was also, however, determined for her was, again, yet irrepressibly again, that the image presented to her, the splendid young woman who looked so particularly handsome in impatience, with the fine freedom of her signal, was the peculiar property of somebody else's vision, that this fine freedom in short was the fine freedom she showed Mr. Densher. Just so was how she looked to him, and just so was how Milly was held by her—held as by the strange sense of seeing through that distant person's eyes. It lasted, as usual, the strange sense, but fifty seconds; yet in so lasting it produced an effect. It produced in fact more than one, and we take them in their order. The first was that it struck our young woman as absurd to say that a girl's looking so to a man could possibly be without connections; and the second was that by the time Kate had got into the room Milly was in mental possession of the main connection it must have for herself.

Translation

Kate Croy went straight to the hotel that evening, shortly before dinner. She arrived publicly in a hansom cab, driven very fast, which pulled up under their windows with a near-crash, like it was about to have an accident. Milly was alone in their huge, decorated sitting room. She had been pacing, like a caged bird, through the strange, long, almost ominous delay of the evening, which she secretly enjoyed. At the sound of the cab, one of the French windows was open, and Milly went out onto the balcony overlooking the entrance. She saw Kate getting out of the cab and paying the driver, and caught the look Kate sent up to the balcony. Kate had to wait for her change, during which time Milly looked down at her. They exchanged smiles and nods, without speaking, regarding what had happened that morning. Kate's arrival was what Milly had been waiting for, and the tone of their meeting was set, almost by accident, before Kate even came inside. However, Milly also realized, again, and uncontrollably, that the image of Kate presented to her – the beautiful young woman, looking particularly handsome in her impatience, with a certain confident air – was something someone else saw as well. That same confident air was how she presented herself to Mr. Densher. This was how she looked to him, and Milly was caught up in the experience, feeling as if she was seeing the world through that distant person's eyes. This strange sensation lasted only about fifty seconds, but it still had an effect. It had more than one, in fact, and we'll take them in order. First, it struck Milly as absurd to think that a girl could look at a man that way without there being some kind of connection. Second, by the time Kate came into the room, Milly understood the most important connection it had for *her* own life.

She produced this commodity on the spot—produced it, that is, in straight response to Kate's frank "Well, what?" The inquiry bore of course, with Kate's eagerness, on the issue of the morning's scene, the great man's latest wisdom, and it doubtless affected Milly a little as the cheerful demand for news is apt to affect troubled spirits when news is not, in one of the neater forms, prepared for delivery. She couldn't have said what it was exactly that, on the instant, determined her; the nearest description of it would perhaps have been as the more vivid impression of all her friend took for granted. The contrast between this free quantity and the maze of possibilities through which, for hours, she had herself been picking her way, put on, in short, for the moment, a grossness that even friendly forms scarce lightened: it helped forward in fact the revelation to herself that she absolutely had nothing to tell. Besides which, certainly, there was something else—an influence, at the particular juncture, still more obscure. Kate had lost, on the way upstairs, the look—the look—that made her young hostess so subtly think and one of the signs of which was that she never kept it for many moments at once; yet she stood there, none the less, so in her bloom and in her strength, so completely again the "handsome girl" beyond all others, the "handsome girl" for whom Milly had at first gratefully taken her, that to meet her now with the note of the plaintive would amount somehow to a surrender, to a confession. She would never in her life be ill; the greatest doctor would keep her, at the worst, the fewest minutes; and it was as if she had asked just with all this practical impeccability for all that was most mortal in her friend. These things, for Milly, inwardly danced their dance; but the vibration produced and the dust kicked up had lasted less than our account of them. Almost before she knew it she was answering, and answering, beautifully, with no consciousness of fraud, only as with a sudden flare of the famous "will-power" she had heard about, read about, and which was what her medical adviser had mainly thrown her back on. "Oh, it's all right. He's lovely."

Translation

She provided the information immediately – that is, in direct response to Kate's blunt question, "Well, what?" The question, naturally, given Kate's eagerness, concerned the morning's event, the great man's latest pronouncements, and it probably affected Milly a little like the cheerful demand for news often affects someone feeling troubled when they don't have any convenient news to share. She couldn't say exactly what made her decide instantly. The closest way to describe it might be that she was more aware of what her friend simply assumed. The difference between this easy openness and the complex possibilities she'd been considering for hours created a sense of bluntness at that moment, which even friendly interactions couldn't entirely soften. In fact, it helped her realize that she had absolutely nothing to say.

Besides that, there was definitely something else, a more mysterious influence at that moment. Kate had lost that certain look on the way upstairs – the look that made Milly think so subtly, a look she never held for very long. Yet, Kate still stood there, so vibrant and strong, so completely the "beautiful girl" above all others, the "beautiful girl" Milly had initially been grateful for. To respond with complaints now would be like giving up, like admitting something. Kate would never be sick; the best doctor would only have to deal with her for a short time. And it was as if she'd asked, with her perfect health, for everything most vulnerable in her friend.

These thoughts danced around in Milly's mind, but the disturbance they caused and the confusion they stirred didn't last long. Almost before she knew it, she was answering, and answering beautifully, without feeling like she was lying, but instead, with a sudden surge of the famous "willpower" she had heard and read about, and which her doctor had mostly told her to rely on. "Oh, it's all right. He's lovely."

Kate was splendid, and it would have been clear for Milly now, had the further presumption been needed, that she had said no word to Mrs. Stringham. "You mean you've been absurd?"

Translation

Kate was amazing, and it would have been obvious to Milly by now – if she even needed further proof – that Kate hadn't said anything to Mrs. Stringham. "You're saying you were ridiculous?"

"Absurd." It was a simple word to say, but the consequence of it, for our young woman, was that she felt it, as soon as spoken, to have done something for her safety.

Translation

"Ridiculous." It was an easy word to say, but the impact of it, for our young woman, was that she felt safer the moment she said it.

And Kate really hung on her lips. "There's nothing at all the matter?"

Translation

And Kate was completely captivated by what he was saying. "Is there absolutely nothing wrong?"

"Nothing to worry about. I shall take a little watching, but I shan't have to do anything dreadful, or even, in the least, inconvenient. I can do in fact as I like." It was wonderful for Milly how just to put it so made all its pieces fall at present quite properly into places.

Translation

Don't worry. I'll need a little observation, but I won't have to do anything awful, or even the slightest bit troublesome. Actually, I can do whatever I want. It was amazing for Milly how just saying it like that made everything suddenly make perfect sense.

Yet even before the full effect came Kate had seized, kissed, blessed her. "My love, you're too sweet! It's too dear! But it's as I was sure." Then she grasped the full beauty. "You can do as you like?"

Translation

But even before it fully hit her, Kate grabbed, kissed, and blessed her. "My love, you're too wonderful! It's just too good! But I knew it would be this way." Then she fully understood the beauty of it. "You're free to do whatever you want?"

"Quite. Isn't it charming?"

Translation

Yes, it's lovely, isn't it?

"Ah, but catch you," Kate triumphed with gaiety, "not doing——! And what shall you do?"

Translation

"Oh, gotcha," Kate said happily. "Not doing *that*! So, what are you going to do?"

"For the moment simply enjoy it. Enjoy"—Milly was completely luminous—"having got out of my scrape."

Translation

"Just enjoy this for now. Enjoy," Milly said, looking absolutely radiant, "now that I'm out of trouble."

"Learning, you mean, so easily, that you are well."

Translation

You're saying you learn things so easily that you're fine.

It was as if Kate had but too conveniently put the words into her mouth. "Learning, I mean, so easily, that I am well."

Translation

It was like Kate had just handed her the words. "Learning, I mean, that I'm doing great."

"Only, no one's of course well enough to stay in London now. He can't," Kate went on, "want this of you."

Translation

"Anyway, no one's healthy enough to stay in London right now, obviously. He can't," Kate continued, "expect this from you."

"Mercy, no—I'm to knock about. I'm to go to places."

Translation

No way! I'm supposed to wander around. I'm going places.

"But not beastly 'climates'—Engadines, Rivieras, boredoms?"

Translation

But not terrible, predictable weather – like the Engadine and Riviera regions, which can be boring?

"No; just, as I say, where I prefer. I'm to go in for pleasure."

Translation

No, I just want to go where I want to go. I'm here to have fun.

"Oh, the duck!"—Kate, with her own shades of familiarity, abounded. "But what kind of pleasure?"

Translation

"Oh, the duck!"—Kate said, sounding casual. "But what's the fun of it?"

"The highest," Milly smiled.

Translation

"The best," Milly smiled.

Her friend met it as nobly. "Which is the highest?"

Translation

Her friend also handled it well. "What's the most important thing?"

"Well, it's just our chance to find out. You must help me."

Translation

Okay, this is our chance to figure it out. You need to help me.

"What have I wanted to do but help you," Kate asked, "from the moment I first laid eyes on you?" Yet with this too Kate had her wonder. "I like your talking, though, about that. What help, with your luck all round, do you want?"

Translation

"I've only ever wanted to help you," Kate asked, "since the day I met you." But even with that, Kate was puzzled. "Still, I like you talking about it. What kind of help do you need, considering how lucky you are?"

Chapter XIV

Chapter Summary & Character Study
Summary

Milly is waiting for a visit from her doctor, Sir Luke Strett, and has decided to allow him free access to her companion, Susan Shepherd.

The narrative focuses on an evening a few days before their departure from London. Milly, Susan, Mrs. Lowder, and Kate Croy are gathered at a hotel after dinner. It is decided that Mrs. Lowder and Susan will go on to a party, while Kate will stay behind with Milly.

After Susan leaves the room to get a shawl and Kate steps out onto a balcony, Mrs. Lowder asks Milly to mention a Mr. Densher to Kate, to find out if he has returned to London. Mrs. Lowder states that she worries he is bothering Kate, who she claims does not care for him. She explains that she cannot ask Kate herself because they never speak of him.

Milly questions this approach, noting that she has never mentioned knowing Mr. Densher to Kate before. They discuss the potential awkwardness of her raising the topic now. Milly asks if Mrs. Lowder likes Mr. Densher, and Mrs. Lowder says she does. Milly confirms that she met him in New York. The conversation continues with Milly raising further difficulties, such as what she should tell Kate about why she is asking. Finally, Milly asks if Mr. Densher has been writing to Kate, which Mrs. Lowder says is what she wants to know.

Just as Milly asks Mrs. Lowder if she believes Mr. Densher is with Kate, Susan returns to the room and Kate reappears in the window. Mrs. Lowder says "Hush!" and then leaves with Susan for the party.

Milly is left with Kate, who remains standing in the window. Milly looks at Kate and, without a word being spoken, understands that Mr. Densher has returned to London.

Character Study

Based on the text, here is a concise character study:

  • *Milly**
    • Milly is initially presented as a woman who has reached a state of grim resolution. Facing a limited number of "hours," she feels "enviably strong" and has a clear plan for an upcoming doctor's visit. She views the sympathy of others with a cynical, self-deprecating humor, labeling herself "gross, greedy, ravenous." Her situation shifts dramatically when Mrs. Lowder confronts her. This external pressure forces her out of her detached state, revealing a deep, hidden vulnerability concerning Mr. Densher. Her composure becomes a performance, requiring her to "smile hard" and carefully choose her words, one of which costs her more than any she has ever spoken. By the end of the scene, her perception has sharpened to the point where she can understand a complex truth simply by observing Kate's posture.
  • *Mrs. Lowder (Aunt Maud)**
    • Mrs. Lowder is presented as a powerful and calculating social strategist. She operates with "rich glibness" and has "fine onyx eyes" that do not blink, signifying her unreadable and determined nature. She initiates the scene's central conflict by attempting to use Milly as a tool to extract information about her niece. She frames her manipulative inquiry as a matter of concern for Kate and Mr. Densher, but her primary motivation is to enforce her own "views." When her initial approach is questioned, she shifts tactics from impatience to a disingenuous show of pity and concern, revealing her skill as a manipulator.
  • *Kate Croy**
    • Kate is presented almost entirely from the outside, as an object of discussion and observation. Initially, she is a silent, enigmatic figure hovering on a balcony. Mrs. Lowder characterizes her as a "proud young woman" who may be secretly defying her. Kate's situation shifts in the final moments as she moves from being the subject of the conversation to its unspoken resolution. Her mere presence, "handsome and upright" with "conscious eyes," is immediately interpreted by Milly as confirmation that Mr. Densher has returned. She communicates this pivotal fact without uttering a single word.
  • *Susan Shepherd (Mrs. Stringham)**
Susan is presented as a benevolent but secondary figure, a companion used by others as a social substitute. Milly is pleased to "put people off with her," and Mrs. Lowder dismisses her as "better than nothing." Her situation is static; she serves primarily as a pawn whose departure and return frame the central, private conversation between Milly and Mrs. Lowder.

Milly indeed at last couldn't say; so that she had really for the time brought it along to the point so oddly marked for her by her visitor's arrival, the truth that she was enviably strong. She carried this out, from that evening, for each hour still left her, and the more easily perhaps that the hours were now narrowly numbered. All she actually waited for was Sir Luke Strett's promised visit; as to her proceeding on which, however, her mind was quite made up. Since he wanted to get at Susie he should have the freest access, and then perhaps he would see how he liked it. What was between them they might settle as between them, and any pressure it should lift from her own spirit they were at liberty to convert to their use. If the dear man wished to fire Susan Shepherd with a still higher ideal, he would only after all, at the worst, have Susan on his hands. If devotion, in a word, was what it would come up for the interested pair to organise, she was herself ready to consume it as the dressed and served dish. He had talked to her of her "appetite" her account of which, she felt, must have been vague. But for devotion, she could now see, this appetite would be of the best. Gross, greedy, ravenous—these were doubtless the proper names for her: she was at all events resigned in advance to the machinations of sympathy. The day that followed her lonely excursion was to be the last but two or three of their stay in London; and the evening of that day practically ranked for them as, in the matter of outside relations, the last of all. People were by this time quite scattered, and many of those who had so liberally manifested in calls, in cards, in evident sincerity about visits, later on, over the land, had positively passed in music out of sight; whether as members, these latter, more especially, of Mrs. Lowder's immediate circle or as members of Lord Mark's—our friends being by this time able to make the distinction. The general pitch had thus, decidedly, dropped, and the occasions still to be dealt with were special and few. One of these, for Milly, announced itself as the doctor's call already mentioned, as to which she had now had a note from him: the single other, of importance, was their appointed leave-taking—for the shortest separation—in respect to Mrs. Lowder and Kate. The aunt and the niece were to dine with them alone, intimately and easily—as easily as should be consistent with the question of their afterwards going on together to some absurdly belated party, at which they had had it from Aunt Maud that they would do well to show. Sir Luke was to make his appearance on the morrow of this, and in respect to that complication Milly had already her plan.

Translation

Milly truly couldn't say anything more. She had, in a way, brought things to a head at the very moment her visitor arrived, highlighting the truth that she was remarkably resilient.
