From that evening onward, she maintained this composure with each passing hour, perhaps made easier because her time was now limited. She was simply waiting for Sir Luke Strett's promised visit, and she'd already made up her mind about how to handle it. Since he wanted to pursue Susie, he would have complete access, and then maybe he'd see how he liked it. Whatever was between them, they could sort out amongst themselves, and any burden it lifted from her, they were welcome to use. If he wanted to fill Susan Shepherd with an even more passionate ideal, he would only, at worst, have Susan to deal with. If they were going to organize devotion, she was prepared to embrace it fully, like a prepared and served meal. He had mentioned her "appetite," which she felt she had described vaguely. But for devotion, she now realized, this appetite would be at its best. Intense, greedy, insatiable – those were probably the right words for her; she was prepared for the manipulations of empathy. The day after her solitary outing would be one of their last two or three days in London; and the evening of that day was essentially the end of their social life. People had mostly dispersed by now, and many of those who had been so generous with their calls, cards, and apparent eagerness for future visits had completely vanished, especially those in Mrs. Lowder's circle, and also those in Lord Mark's – our friends could now tell the difference. Social activity had declined, and the remaining events were special and few. One of these, for Milly, was the doctor's visit, about which she'd received a note; the other important event was their farewell visit to Mrs. Lowder and Kate. The aunt and niece were to have a private dinner with them, as relaxed as possible, given the question of whether they would all attend a ridiculously late party, which Aunt Maud had advised them to attend. Sir Luke was due the next day, and Milly already had a plan for that situation.

The night was, at all events, hot and stale, and it was late enough by the time the four ladies had been gathered in, for their small session, at the hotel, where the windows were still open to the high balconies and the flames of the candles, behind the pink shades—disposed as for the vigil of watchers—were motionless in the air in which the season lay dead. What was presently settled among them was that Milly, who betrayed on this occasion a preference more marked than usual, should not hold herself obliged to climb that evening the social stair, however it might stretch to meet her, and that, Mrs. Lowder and Mrs. Stringham facing the ordeal together, Kate Croy should remain with her and await their return. It was a pleasure to Milly, ever, to send Susan Shepherd forth; she saw her go with complacency, liked, as it were, to put people off with her, and noted with satisfaction, when she so moved to the carriage, the further denudation—a markedly ebbing tide—of her little benevolent back. If it wasn't quite Aunt Maud's ideal, moreover, to take out the new American girl's funny friend instead of the new American girl herself, nothing could better indicate the range of that lady's merit than the spirit in which—as at the present hour for instance—she made the best of the minor advantage. And she did this with a broad, cheerful absence of illusion; she did it—confessing even as much to poor Susie—because, frankly, she was good-natured. When Mrs. Stringham observed that her own light was too abjectly borrowed and that it was as a link alone, fortunately not missing, that she was valued, Aunt Maud concurred to the extent of the remark: "Well, my dear, you're better than nothing." To-night, furthermore, it came up for Milly that Aunt Maud had something particular in mind. Mrs. Stringham, before adjourning with her, had gone off for some shawl or other accessory, and Kate, as if a little impatient for their withdrawal, had wandered out to the balcony, where she hovered, for the time, unseen, though with scarce more to look at than the dim London stars and the cruder glow, up the street, on a corner, of a small public-house, in front of which a fagged cab-horse was thrown into relief. Mrs. Lowder made use of the moment: Milly felt as soon as she had spoken that what she was doing was somehow for use.

Translation

The night was, at least, hot and stuffy. It was late by the time the four women had assembled for their private meeting at the hotel. The windows were still open to the balconies, and the candlelight behind the pink lampshades – arranged as if for a vigil – didn't flicker in the still air.

What they decided was that Milly, who showed a stronger preference than usual, wouldn't have to go out that evening. She wouldn't be obligated to navigate the social scene, no matter how much effort it took. Instead, Mrs. Lowder and Mrs. Stringham would go together, and Kate Croy would stay behind with Milly and wait for them to return. Milly always enjoyed sending Susan Shepherd out on these social missions. She watched her go with contentment, as if she liked using Susan to deflect attention, and noticed with satisfaction how Susan’s back receded from view as she got into the carriage.

Furthermore, it wasn’t exactly Aunt Maud’s first choice to take the new American girl's “funny friend” (Mrs. Stringham) out instead of the American girl herself. However, nothing demonstrated Aunt Maud’s admirable qualities more than her ability to make the best of a secondary role. She did this without any illusions; she did it – she even admitted as much to poor Susan – because she was, frankly, good-natured. When Mrs. Stringham remarked that her own importance was borrowed and that she was only valued as a useful connection, Aunt Maud agreed: "Well, darling, you're better than nothing."

Tonight, it also occurred to Milly that Aunt Maud had something specific in mind. Mrs. Stringham had stepped away to retrieve a shawl or other accessory before leaving with Aunt Maud, and Kate, seeming a little eager for them to leave, had gone out to the balcony. She stayed there, unseen for the moment, with little to look at except the faint London stars and the harsh glow from a pub on a nearby corner, which illuminated a tired cab horse.

Mrs. Lowder took advantage of the opportunity to speak. As soon as she began, Milly felt that whatever Mrs. Lowder was saying was meant to be used for a specific purpose.

"Dear Susan tells me that you saw, in America, Mr. Densher—whom I've never till now, as you may have noticed, asked you about. But do you mind at last, in connection with him, doing something for me?" She had lowered her fine voice to a depth, though speaking with all her rich glibness; and Milly, after a small sharpness of surprise, was already guessing the sense of her appeal. "Will you name him, in any way you like, to her"—and Aunt Maud gave a nod at the window; "so that you may perhaps find out whether he's back?"

Translation

"Dear Susan told me you saw Mr. Densher in America – I've never asked you about him before, as you've probably noticed. But would you mind finally doing something for me, regarding him?" Her elegant voice dropped low, even though she spoke with her usual smooth confidence. Milly, initially a little surprised, quickly understood what she wanted. "Will you mention him to Susan, in any way you choose" – and Aunt Maud gestured toward the window – "so you can maybe find out if he's returned?"

Ever so many things, for Milly, fell into line at this; it was a wonder, she afterwards thought, that she could be conscious of so many at once. She smiled hard, however, for them all. "But I don't know that it's important to me to 'find out.'" The array of things was further swollen, however, even as she said this, by its striking her as too much to say. She therefore tried as quickly to say less. "Except you mean, of course, that it's important to you." She fancied Aunt Maud was looking at her almost as hard as she was herself smiling, and that gave her another impulse. "You know I never have yet named him to her; so that if I should break out now——"

Translation

So many things suddenly made sense to Milly because of this. Later, she was amazed she could understand so much at once. She forced herself to smile at everything. "But I'm not sure it's vital for me to 'find out.'" However, the list of things kept growing, even as she said that, because it struck her as too much to say. So, she tried to say less, quickly. "Unless, of course, you mean it's important to *you*." She felt like Aunt Maud was staring at her as intently as she was smiling, and that prompted another thought. "You know I haven't mentioned him to her yet, so if I were to just blurt it out now—"

"Well?"—Mrs. Lowder waited.

Translation

"Well?"—Mrs. Lowder prompted.

"Why, she may wonder what I've been making a mystery of. She hasn't mentioned him, you know," Milly went on, "herself."

Translation

She might be wondering why I've been so secretive. She hasn't brought him up, you know," Milly continued, "on her own."

"No"—her friend a little heavily weighed it—"she wouldn't. So it's she, you see then, who has made the mystery."

Translation

"No," her friend said, a bit gloomily, "she wouldn't. So she's the one, you realize, who created the mystery."

Yes, Milly but wanted to see; only there was so much. "There has been of course no particular reason." Yet that indeed was neither here nor there. "Do you think," she asked, "he is back?"

Translation

Yes, Milly wanted to see him, but there was just so much going on. "Of course, there was no specific reason." But that didn't really matter. "Do you think," she asked, "he's back?"

"It will be about his time, I gather, and rather a comfort to me definitely to know."

Translation

I believe it will be soon, and I'll definitely feel better knowing that.

"Then can't you ask her yourself?"

Translation

Why don't you just ask her?

"Ah, we never speak of him!"

Translation

We never talk about him!

It helped Milly for the moment to the convenience of a puzzled pause. "Do you mean he's an acquaintance of whom you disapprove for her?"

Translation

The brief pause helped Milly, and she used it to collect her thoughts. "Are you saying he's someone you don't want her to know?"

Aunt Maud, as well, just hung fire. "I disapprove of her for the poor young man. She doesn't care for him."

Translation

Aunt Maud also just hesitated. "I don't approve of her for that poor young man. She doesn't like him."

"And he cares so much——?"

Translation

"And he really cares?"

"Too much, too much. And my fear is," said Mrs. Lowder, "that he privately besets her. She keeps it to herself, but I don't want her worried. Neither, in truth," she both generously and confidentially concluded, "do I want him."

Translation

"This is all too much. And I'm afraid," Mrs. Lowder said, "that he's bothering her in private. She's not telling anyone, but I don't want her to be upset. Honestly," she added, being both kind and discreet, "I don't want him around either."

Milly showed all her own effort to meet the case. "But what can I do?"

Translation

Milly really tried her best to handle the situation.

"What else can I do?"

"You can find out where they are. If I myself try," Mrs. Lowder explained, "I shall appear to treat them as if I supposed them deceiving me."

Translation

You can find out where they are. Mrs. Lowder explained, "But if I try to do it personally, it'll seem like I don't trust them."

"And you don't. You don't," Milly mused for her, "suppose them deceiving you."

Translation

And you wouldn't. You wouldn't, Milly thought to herself, imagine them deceiving you.

"Well," said Aunt Maud, whose fine onyx eyes failed to blink, even though Milly's questions might have been taken as drawing her rather further than she had originally meant to go—"well, Kate is thoroughly aware of my views for her, and that I take her being with me, at present, in the way she is with me, if you know what I mean, as a loyal assent to them. Therefore as my views don't happen to provide a place, at all, for Mr. Densher, much, in a manner, as I like him"—therefore, therefore in short she had been prompted to this step, though she completed her sense, but sketchily, with the rattle of her large fan.

Translation

"Well," Aunt Maud said, her beautiful dark eyes not even blinking, even though Milly's questions seemed to be pushing her further than she'd intended to go. "Well, Kate completely understands my expectations for her. She's living with me right now, and I see her agreement with my plans as a sign of her loyalty. So, since my plans don't really include Mr. Densher, even though I do like him—" then, in short, she'd been pushed to this point, though she finished her thought quickly, accompanied by the rustling sound of her big fan.

It assisted them perhaps, however, for the moment, that Milly was able to pick out of her sense what might serve as the clearest part of it. "You do like him then?"

Translation

It helped them, maybe, for the time being, that Milly could figure out, from her feelings, the most straightforward part. "You do like him, then?"

"Oh dear, yes. Don't you?"

Translation

Oh, right. Don't you agree?

Milly hesitated, for the question was somehow as the sudden point of something sharp on a nerve that winced. She just caught her breath, but she had ground for joy afterwards, she felt, in not really having failed to choose with quickness sufficient, out of fifteen possible answers, the one that would best serve her. She was then almost proud, as well, that she had cheerfully smiled. "I did—three times—in New York." So came and went for her, in these simple words, the speech that was to figure for her, later on, that night, as the one she had ever uttered that cost her most. She was to lie awake, at all events, half the night, for the gladness of not having taken any line so really inferior as the denial of a happy impression.

Translation

Milly paused, because the question unexpectedly hit a sensitive spot. She caught her breath, but she felt she'd have reason to be happy later, since she hadn't failed to choose the best answer quickly enough from fifteen possibilities. She was even a little proud that she'd smiled cheerfully. "I did – three times – in New York," she said. In those simple words, the conversation that would haunt her later that night, as the one she'd ever regretted saying the most, began and ended. She would lie awake for half the night, glad that she hadn’t given a response that would have denied a positive memory.

For Mrs. Lowder also, moreover, her simple words were the right ones; they were at any rate, that lady's laugh showed, in the natural note of the racy. "You dear American thing! But people may be very good, and yet not good for what one wants."

Translation

For Mrs. Lowder, too, her simple words were perfect. At least, that's what her laugh indicated, with its naturally charming tone. "You dear American! But people can be good, even if they're not what you need."

"Yes," the girl assented, "even I suppose when what one wants is something very good."

Translation

"Yes," the girl agreed, "even I guess when

what you want is something really great."

"Oh, my child, it would take too long just now to tell you all I want! I want everything at once and together—and ever so much for you too, you know. But you've seen us," Aunt Maud continued; "you'll have made out."

Translation

Oh darling, I have so much I want to say! It would take too long to explain it all right now. I want everything for you, all at once, and so much of it! You understand, don't you? You've seen us, you can figure it out.

"Ah," said Milly, "I don't make out"; for again—it came that way in rushes—she felt an obscurity in things. "Why, if our friend here doesn't like him——"

Translation

"Oh," said Milly, "I don't understand"; because again – it came to her in waves – she felt like something was unclear. "Well, if our friend here doesn't like him--"

"Should I conceive her interested in keeping things from me?" Mrs. Lowder did justice to the question. "My dear, how can you ask? Put yourself in her place. She meets me, but on her terms. Proud young women are proud young women. And proud old ones are—well, what I am. Fond of you as we both are, you can help us."

Translation

"Do you think she's trying to hide something from me?" Mrs. Lowder really considered the question. "Honestly, how can you even ask? Imagine being her. She's interacting with me, but on her own terms. Proud young women are just proud young women. And proud older women are... well, they're like me. We both care about you, and you could be helpful."

Milly tried to be inspired. "Does it come back then to my asking her straight?"

Translation

Milly tried to find some inspiration. "Does it all come down to me asking her directly?"

At this, however, finally, Aunt Maud threw her up. "Oh, if you've so many reasons not——!"

Translation

At that, Aunt Maud finally gave up. "Oh, if you have so many excuses not to——!"

"I've not so many," Milly smiled "but I've one. If I break out so suddenly as knowing him, what will she make of my not having spoken before?"

Translation

"I don't have many," Milly smiled, "but I have one. If I just suddenly reveal that I know him, what will she think of me not saying anything earlier?"

Mrs. Lowder looked blank at it. "Why should you care what she makes? You may have only been decently discreet."

Translation

Mrs. Lowder looked confused. "Why do you even care how much she earns? You should have just kept it private."

"Ah, I have been," the girl made haste to say.

Translation

"Oh, yes, I have," the girl quickly said.

"Besides," her friend went on, "I suggested to you, through Susan, your line."

Translation

"Also," her friend continued, "I told you, through Susan, what you should say."

"Yes, that reason's a reason for me."

Translation

Yes, I agree with that.

"And for me," Mrs. Lowder insisted. "She's not therefore so stupid as not to do justice to grounds so marked. You can tell her perfectly that I had asked you to say nothing."

Translation

"And for me," Mrs. Lowder insisted. "She's not so dumb that she wouldn't understand the obvious reasons. You can tell her that I asked you to keep quiet."

"And may I tell her that you've asked me now to speak?"

Translation

And can I tell her you want me to talk now?

Mrs. Lowder might well have thought, yet, oddly, this pulled her up. "You can't do it without——?"

Translation

Mrs. Lowder might have considered that, but strangely, it stopped her. "You can't do it without...?"

Milly was almost ashamed to be raising so many difficulties. "I'll do what I can if you'll kindly tell me one thing more." She faltered a little—it was so prying; but she brought it out. "Will he have been writing to her?"

Translation

Milly felt almost guilty about causing so much trouble. "I'll help if you'll just tell me one more thing, please." She hesitated, because the question felt nosy, but she asked it anyway. "Do you think he's been writing to her?"

"It's exactly, my dear, what I should like to know." Mrs. Lowder was at last impatient. "Push in for yourself, and I dare say she'll tell you."

Translation

"That's precisely what I want to know, dear," Mrs. Lowder finally said, losing patience. "Go ask her yourself, and I'm sure she'll tell you."

Even now, all the same, Milly had not quite fallen back. "It will be pushing in," she continued to smile, "for you" She allowed her companion, however, no time to take this up. "The point will be that if he has been writing she may have answered."

Translation

Even so, Milly hadn't completely given up. Still smiling, she said, "He'll be pushing it, for you." But she didn't give her companion a chance to respond. "The key thing is, if he's been writing, she might have written back."

"But what point, you subtle thing, is that?"

Translation

"But what's the use, you sneaky person, in saying that?"

"It isn't subtle, it seems to me, but quite simple," Milly said, "that if she has answered she has very possibly spoken of me."

Translation

"It's pretty obvious, I think," Milly said, "that if she replied, she probably mentioned me."

"Very certainly indeed. But what difference will it make?"

Translation

Absolutely. But what difference will it make?

The girl had a moment, at this, of thinking it natural that her interlocutress herself should so fail of subtlety. "It will make the difference that he will have written to her in answer that he knows me. And that, in turn," our young woman explained, "will give an oddity to my own silence."

Translation

The girl paused, surprised that the other woman didn't understand the situation's nuances. "The key thing is that he'll have written back to her and mentioned me. And that," she clarified, "will make my own silence seem strange."

"How so, if she's perfectly aware of having given you no opening? The only oddity," Aunt Maud lucidly professed, "is for yourself. It's in her not having spoken."

Translation

How can that be, if she knows she didn't give you any reason? The only strange thing, Aunt Maud explained clearly, is on your end. It's odd that she hasn't said anything.

"Ah, there we are!" said Milly.

Translation

"Oh, there you are!" said Milly.

And she had uttered it, evidently, in a tone that struck her friend. "Then it has troubled you?"

Translation

And she said it, clearly, in a way

that surprised her friend. "So, is it bothering

you?"

But ah, the inquiry had only to be made to bring the rare colour with fine inconsequence, to her face. "Not, really, the least little bit!" And, quickly feeling the need to abound in this sense, she was on the point, to cut short, of declaring that she cared, after all, no scrap how much she obliged. Only she felt at this instant too the intervention of still other things. Mrs. Lowder was, in the first place, already beforehand, already affected as by the sudden vision of her having herself pushed too far. Milly could never judge from her face of her uppermost motive—it was so little, in its hard, smooth sheen, that kind of human countenance. She looked hard when she spoke fair; the only thing was that when she spoke hard she likewise didn't look soft. Something, none the less, had arisen in her now—a full appreciable tide, entering by the rupture of some bar. She announced that if what she had asked was to prove in the least a bore her young friend was not to dream of it; making her young friend at the same time, by the change in her tone, dream on the spot more profusely. She spoke with a belated light, Milly could apprehend—she could always apprehend—from pity; and the result of that perception, for the girl, was singular: it proved to her as quickly that Kate, keeping her secret, had been straight with her. From Kate distinctly then, as to why she was to be pitied, Aunt Maud knew nothing, and was thereby simply putting in evidence the fine side of her own character. This fine side was that she could almost at any hour, by a kindled preference or a diverted energy, glow for another interest than her own. She exclaimed as well, at this moment, that Milly must have been thinking, round the case, much more than she had supposed; and this remark could, at once, affect the girl as sharply as any other form of the charge of weakness. It was what everyone, if she didn't look out, would soon be saying—"There's something the matter with you!" What one was therefore one's self concerned immediately to establish was that there was nothing at all. "I shall like to help you; I shall like, so far as that goes, to help Kate herself," she made such haste as she could to declare; her eyes wandering meanwhile across the width of the room to that dusk of the balcony in which their companion perhaps a little unaccountably lingered. She suggested hereby her impatience to begin; she almost overtly wondered at the length of the opportunity this friend was giving them—referring it, however, so far as words went, to the other friend, breaking off with an amused: "How tremendously Susie must be beautifying!"

Translation

But just asking the question immediately brought a rosy flush to her face, a seemingly insignificant reaction. "Not at all!" And quickly feeling the need to emphasize this, she was about to declare that she didn't care at all how much she was inconveniencing them. But at that moment, she also felt other things influencing her. First of all, Mrs. Lowder seemed to have already anticipated her, reacting as though she had suddenly realized she'd gone too far. Milly could never tell from her expression what Mrs. Lowder was really thinking—her hard, smooth face revealed so little of her true emotions. She looked severe even when she was being pleasant; the only thing was that she didn't soften her expression when she spoke harshly either. Still, something was happening in her now—a significant emotional shift, like a dam breaking. She said that if what she had asked was even slightly bothersome, Milly shouldn't even consider it; and, by the change in her tone, made her young friend suddenly consider it even more.

Milly could sense a delayed understanding in Kate's words—she always could—and it came from pity. This perception had a strange effect on Milly: it quickly proved to her that Kate, despite keeping a secret, had been honest with her. From Kate, then, Aunt Maud knew nothing about why Milly should be pitied, and was merely demonstrating the good side of her own nature. This good side was that she could almost always, through a strong preference or a redirected focus, show genuine interest in something other than herself.

She also exclaimed at that moment that Milly must have been thinking about the situation more than she had realized; and this remark could instantly sting Milly, like any accusation of weakness. It was what everyone, if she wasn't careful, would soon be saying—"There's something wrong with you!" So what she immediately needed to establish was that there was nothing wrong at all. "I'd like to help you; I'd like to help Kate herself," she quickly declared; her eyes drifting across the room to the shadowy balcony where their companion was perhaps a little inexplicably lingering. She was subtly indicating her eagerness to get started; she almost openly wondered why their friend was taking so long—referring to it, though, through words, to the other friend, and concluding with an amused, "How wonderfully Susie must be making herself beautiful!"

It only marked Aunt Maud, none the less, as too preoccupied for her allusion. The onyx eyes were fixed upon her with a polished pressure that must signify some enriched benevolence. "Let it go, my dear. We shall, after all, soon enough see."

Translation

Despite that, it only showed Aunt Maud was too distracted to understand what she meant. The dark eyes were staring at her with a calm intensity, probably indicating a kind intent. "Don't worry about it, dear. We'll find out soon enough."

"If he has come back we shall certainly see," Milly after a moment replied; "for he'll probably feel that he can't quite civilly not come to see me. Then there," she remarked, "we shall be. It wouldn't then, you see, come through Kate at all—it would come through him. Except," she wound up with a smile, "that he won't find me."

Translation

"If he's returned, we'll definitely know," Milly replied after a moment. "He'll probably feel obligated to visit me. Then we'll be together," she said. "It won't involve Kate at all – it'll be him. Except," she finished with a smile, "he won't be able to find me."

She had the most extraordinary sense of interesting her interlocutress, in spite of herself, more than she wanted; it was as if her doom so floated her on that she couldn't stop—by very much the same trick it had played her with her doctor. "Shall you run away from him?"

Translation

She had a knack for making people fascinated by her, even when she didn't mean to. It was like she was doomed, and that feeling carried her along so she couldn't stop herself – it was almost the same thing that happened with her doctor. "Are you going to leave him?"

She neglected the question, wanting only now to get off. "Then," she went on, "you'll deal with Kate directly."

Translation

She avoided the question, just wanting to leave. "So," she continued, "you'll handle Kate yourself."

"Shall you run away from her?" Mrs. Lowder profoundly inquired, while they became aware of Susie's return through the room, opening out behind them, in which they had dined.

Translation

"Are you going to run away from her?" Mrs. Lowder asked seriously, as they heard Susie come back into the dining room behind them.

This affected Milly as giving her but an instant; and suddenly, with it, everything she felt in the connection rose to her lips in a question that, even as she put it, she knew she was failing to keep colourless. "Is it your own belief that he is with her?"

Translation

This barely fazed Milly for a second. Then, all her feelings about the situation welled up, forming a question she knew she couldn't ask neutrally. "Do you actually think he's with her?"

Aunt Maud took it in—took in, that is, everything of the tone that she just wanted her not to; and the result for some seconds, was but to make their eyes meet in silence. Mrs. Stringham had rejoined them and was asking if Kate had gone—an inquiry at once answered by this young lady's reappearance. They saw her again in the open window, where, looking at them, she had paused—producing thus, on Aunt Maud's part, almost too impressive a "Hush!" Mrs. Lowder indeed, without loss of time, smothered any danger in a sweeping retreat with Susie; but Milly's words to her, just uttered, about dealing with her niece directly, struck our young woman as already recoiling on herself. Directness, however evaded, would be, fully, for her; nothing in fact would ever have been for her so direct as the evasion. Kate had remained in the window, very handsome and upright, the outer dark framing in a highly favourable way her summery simplicities and lightnesses of dress. Milly had, given the relation of space, no real fear she had heard their talk; only she hovered there as with conscious eyes and some added advantage. Then indeed, with small delay, her friend sufficiently saw. The conscious eyes, the added advantage were but those she had now always at command—those proper to the person Milly knew as known to Merton Densher. It was for several seconds again as if the total of her identity had been that of the person known to him—a determination having for result another sharpness of its own. Kate had positively but to be there just as she was to tell her he had come back. It seemed to pass between them, in fine, without a word, that he was in London, that he was perhaps only round the corner; and surely therefore no dealing of Milly's with her would yet have been so direct.

Translation

Aunt Maud understood everything—everything, that is, about the way Kate was acting, the way she didn't want her to act. The result was that for a few seconds, their eyes just met silently. Mrs. Stringham came back and asked if Kate had left, which was immediately answered by Kate reappearing. They saw her again in the open window, looking at them, having paused there. This caused Aunt Maud to practically hiss, "Shhh!"

Mrs. Lowder immediately defused any potential drama by quickly leaving with Susie, but Milly's recent comment to Kate about being direct with her niece now seemed to be backfiring on her. Although Kate's intentions were clear, she avoided directness. In fact, nothing would ever have been as direct for her as this evasion.

Kate remained in the window, looking beautiful and composed. The darkness outside framed her simple, summery appearance in a flattering way. Milly didn't really think Kate had heard their conversation, considering the distance between them. But Kate lingered there, as if aware and with some kind of advantage. Then, in a moment, Milly understood. The knowing look, the added advantage, was simply the one Kate always used—the one Milly knew was connected to Merton Densher. For several seconds, it was as if Kate's entire identity was defined by her connection to him, which led to a different kind of sharpness.

Kate just being there, as she was, told Milly that he was back. It seemed they communicated without speaking: he was in London, possibly just nearby. And truly, nothing Milly did with Kate would have been as direct as this silent message.

Chapter XV

Chapter Summary & Character Study
Summary

Milly and Kate sit together. While they talk, Kate repeatedly gets up and walks the length of the room. Kate speaks about English society, Aunt Maud, and Lord Mark.

In their conversation, Kate says Aunt Maud is using her as a bargaining chip. Milly insists she is not an obstacle for Kate regarding Lord Mark. Kate advises Milly to leave their social circle. Milly asks why she says such things. Kate replies, "Because you're a dove," then embraces and kisses her.

They hear their companions returning. Mrs. Lowder and Mrs. Stringham enter the room. Kate talks with Mrs. Stringham. Mrs. Lowder asks Milly how the evening went, and Milly replies, "I don't think, dear lady, he's here." Mrs. Lowder calls her an "exquisite thing." The visitors then leave.

The next morning, Milly tells Mrs. Stringham that a doctor, Sir Luke Strett, has an appointment to see her at eleven, but that she will be going out. Milly instructs Mrs. Stringham to tell Sir Luke that Milly is home, and then to meet with him in her place. Milly then says she is going to the National Gallery.

Character Study

Based on the text, here is a concise character study:

  • *Milly Theale** is presented as a passive but highly perceptive observer. She feels herself to be in a "current determined... by others," surrendering to being "dealt with." While physically still, her mind is active, analyzing the performances of those around her. An immediate shift occurs when Kate calls her a "dove." Milly instantly seizes this as a "revealed truth," an identity that gives her a new framework for how to act. This new self-perception prompts a change in her situation: she moves from passively receiving plans to actively, if deceptively, creating one by arranging for Mrs. Stringham to meet Sir Luke Strett in her place.
  • *Kate Croy** is presented as an active and theatrical performer. She is restless, "charming," and in "extraordinary 'form,'" moving and talking to dominate the scene. She projects a hard, cynical frankness, openly deconstructing her aunt, English society, and her own "commercial" position. Her situation shifts abruptly in response to Milly's simple, emotional question. She pivots from a pacing, almost predatory ("panther") cynicism to a ceremonial tenderness, bestowing the "dove" identity upon Milly with a kiss, thus changing the dynamic between them from a lecture to an anointing.
  • *Mrs. Lowder (Aunt Maud)** is presented as a powerful social strategist whose influence is felt even when she is absent. Kate describes her as a manipulator who uses her niece as a commodity. When she appears, her purpose is to regain control of the situation ("catch hold... of the loose end"). Her immediate situation shifts when Milly directly counters her unspoken plan; Mrs. Lowder's response is a look of "deep criticism" followed by effusive, tactical praise ("Oh, you exquisite thing!"), showing her ability to adapt instantly to a setback.
  • *Mrs. Stringham (Susie)** is presented as an imaginative and loyal companion. Her role is supportive, and she is easily enrolled in Milly’s plans. Upon hearing Milly’s new arrangement for the doctor, her initial shock is quickly "engulfed" by an "extravagance of assent," immediately accepting her assigned part in the "Byzantine" scheme.

It was doubtless because this queer form of directness had in itself, for the hour, seemed so sufficient that Milly was afterwards aware of having really, all the while—during the strange, indescribable session before the return of their companions—done nothing to intensify it. If she was most aware only afterwards, under the long, discurtained ordeal of the morrow's dawn, that was because she had really, till their evening's end came, ceased, after a little, to miss anything from their ostensible comfort. What was behind showed but in gleams and glimpses; what was in front never at all confessed to not holding the stage. Three minutes had not passed before Milly quite knew she should have done nothing Aunt Maud had just asked her. She knew it moreover by much the same light that had acted for her with that lady and with Sir Luke Strett. It pressed upon her then and there that she was still in a current determined, through her indifference, timidity, bravery, generosity—she scarce could say which—by others; that not she but the current acted, and that somebody else, always, was the keeper of the lock or the dam. Kate for example had but to open the flood-gate: the current moved in its mass—the current, as it had been, of her doing as Kate wanted. What, somehow, in the most extraordinary way in the world, had Kate wanted but to be, of a sudden, more interesting than she had ever been? Milly, for their evening then, quite held her breath with the appreciation of it. If she hadn't been sure her companion would have had nothing, from her moments with Mrs. Lowder, to go by, she would almost have seen the admirable creature "cutting in" to anticipate a danger. This fantasy indeed, while they sat together, dropped after a little; even if only because other fantasies multiplied and clustered, making fairly, for our young woman, the buoyant medium in which her friend talked and moved. They sat together, I say, but Kate moved as much as she talked; she figured there, restless and charming, just perhaps a shade perfunctory, repeatedly quitting her place, taking slowly, to and fro, in the trailing folds of her light dress, the length of the room, and almost avowedly performing for the pleasure of her hostess.

Translation

It was probably because this unusual, direct way of speaking seemed perfectly adequate at the time. Milly realized later, after the strange, indescribable meeting before the others returned, that she hadn't done anything to enhance it. She only became truly aware of this the next morning, as the long, drawn-out day began, because she had stopped missing anything from their outward comfort by the end of the evening. What lay beneath the surface was only hinted at; what was on the surface never admitted to not being the main focus. Three minutes hadn't gone by before Milly knew she should have done something else, something Aunt Maud had just asked of her. She knew this for the same reason she'd known it with Aunt Maud and with Sir Luke Strett. It struck her then that she was still caught in a force determined by others—through her indifference, her shyness, her courage, her generosity, she couldn't say which. It wasn't she who was acting, but the force itself, and someone else was always in control. Kate, for example, only had to open the floodgates, and the force—the force of her own doing, because Kate wanted it—would move. What, in the most extraordinary way, had Kate wanted, other than to suddenly become more interesting than she'd ever been? Milly, for that evening, was absolutely captivated by this idea. If she hadn't been sure her companion had nothing to go on from her time with Mrs. Lowder, she would have almost thought the admirable creature was "stepping in" to prevent a danger. This fantasy faded after a bit while they sat together, perhaps because other fantasies took over, creating a buoyant atmosphere for our young woman as her friend talked and moved. They sat together, I repeat, but Kate moved as much as she talked; she was there, restless and charming, perhaps a little superficial, constantly leaving her seat, pacing the length of the room slowly back and forth in the folds of her light dress, almost as if she were performing for her hostess's amusement.

Mrs. Lowder had said to Milly at Matcham that she and her niece, as allies, could practically conquer the world; but though it was a speech about which there had even then been a vague, grand glamour, the girl read into it at present more of an approach to a meaning. Kate, for that matter, by herself, could conquer anything, and she, Milly Theale, was probably concerned with the "world" only as the small scrap of it that most impinged on her and that was therefore first to be dealt with. On this basis of being dealt with she would doubtless herself do her share of the conquering: she would have something to supply, Kate something to take—each of them thus, to that tune, something for squaring with Aunt Maud's ideal. This in short was what it came to now—that the occasion, in the quiet late lamplight, had the quality of a rough rehearsal of the possible big drama. Milly knew herself dealt with—handsomely, completely: she surrendered to the knowledge, for so it was, she felt, that she supplied her helpful force. And what Kate had to take Kate took as freely and, to all appearance, as gratefully; accepting afresh, with each of her long, slow walks, the relation between them so established and consecrating her companion's surrender simply by the interest she gave it. The interest to Milly herself we naturally mean; the interest to Kate Milly felt as probably inferior. It easily and largely came for their present talk, for the quick flight of the hour before the breach of the spell—it all came, when considered, from the circumstance, not in the least abnormal, that the handsome girl was in extraordinary "form." Milly remembered her having said that she was at her best late at night; remembered it by its having, with its fine assurance, made her wonder when she was at her best and how happy people must be who had such a fixed time. She had no time at all; she was never at her best—unless indeed it were exactly, as now, in listening, watching, admiring, collapsing. If Kate moreover, quite mercilessly, had never been so good, the beauty and the marvel of it was that she had never really been so frank; being a person of such a calibre, as Milly would have said, that, even while "dealing" with you and thereby, as it were, picking her steps, she could let herself go, could, in irony, in confidence, in extravagance, tell you things she had never told before. That was the impression—that she was telling things, and quite conceivably for her own relief as well; almost as if the errors of vision, the mistakes of proportion, the residuary innocence of spirit still to be remedied on the part of her auditor had their moments of proving too much for her nerves. She went at them just now, these sources of irritation, with an amused energy that it would have been open to Milly to regard as cynical and that was nevertheless called for—as to this the other was distinct—by the way that in certain connections the American mind broke down. It seemed at least—the American mind as sitting there thrilled and dazzled in Milly—not to understand English society without a separate confrontation with all the cases. It couldn't proceed by—there was some technical term she lacked until Milly suggested both analogy and induction, and then, differently, instinct, none of which were right: it had to be led up and introduced to each aspect of the monster, enabled to walk all round it, whether for the consequent exaggerated ecstasy or for the still more as appeared to this critic disproportionate shock. It might, the monster, Kate conceded, loom large for those born amid forms less developed and therefore no doubt less amusing; it might on some sides be a strange and dreadful monster, calculated to devour the unwary, to abase the proud, to scandalize the good; but if one had to live with it one must, not to be for ever sitting up, learn how: which was virtually in short to-night what the handsome girl showed herself as teaching.

Translation

Mrs. Lowder had told Milly at Matcham that she and her niece, working together, could practically rule the world. While that statement had a vague, romantic appeal back then, Milly now understood it more clearly. Kate, on her own, could probably achieve anything. Milly, on the other hand, was probably only concerned with the part of the world that directly affected her, the part she needed to deal with first. Based on this understanding, she figured she'd contribute her share to their "conquest." She would provide something, and Kate would take something – both of them fulfilling Aunt Maud's expectations.

Essentially, in the quiet lamplight, it felt like a practice run for a major event. Milly felt she was being "dealt with" graciously and completely. She accepted it because she knew she was contributing her positive energy. And Kate took what Milly offered just as freely and gratefully, renewing the bond between them with each of their long, slow walks, validating her companion's contribution simply by showing interest in it. Of course, Milly assumed the interest was mainly for herself; Kate's interest was probably secondary.

All this talk, this quick hour before they stopped, stemmed from the fact that the beautiful Kate was in top form. Milly remembered Kate saying she was best late at night, and how that statement had made her wonder when *she* was at her best, and how lucky people were to have a consistent time like that. She had no consistent time; she was never at her best – unless, of course, she was listening, watching, admiring, and yielding, like now.

Moreover, if Kate had never been so impressive, the amazing thing was that she had never been so open. Kate, being the type of person she was, could open up, even while guiding and advising Milly. She could be ironic, confidential, and expressive, and tell things she never told before. That was the feeling: that she was finally revealing things, maybe for her own benefit as well. It was as if Milly's errors in perception and understanding, and her remaining naivety, were occasionally too much for Kate to handle.

Kate addressed those irritations with an amused energy that Milly might have found cynical, but that was necessary, as the other woman saw it, because of the way the American mind processed things in certain social situations. It seemed to Kate – who was observing an enthralled and amazed Milly – that the American mind couldn't grasp English society without analyzing every single case. It couldn't use a certain method – Milly didn’t know the exact term, until she suggested analogy and induction, and then instinct, none of which were quite right. Instead, the American mind had to be guided and introduced to each aspect of the "monster" (English society), allowed to explore it thoroughly, whether for extreme delight or, as Kate saw it, for excessive shock.

This "monster," Kate admitted, might seem huge to those who were used to less complex forms of society, and therefore, undoubtedly, less entertaining. It might be a strange and terrifying monster, designed to hurt the naive, humble the proud, and offend the virtuous. But if you had to deal with it, you had to learn how, instead of being constantly on edge. And that’s what Kate was, in essence, showing Milly tonight.

She gave away publicly, in this process, Lancaster Gate and everything it contained; she gave away, hand over hand, Milly's thrill continued to note, Aunt Maud and Aunt Maud's glories and Aunt Maud's complacencies; she gave herself away most of all, and it was naturally what most contributed to her candour. She didn't speak to her friend once more, in Aunt Maud's strain, of how they could scale the skies; she spoke, by her bright, perverse preference on this occasion, of the need, in the first place, of being neither stupid nor vulgar. It might have been a lesson, for our young American, in the art of seeing things as they were—a lesson so various and so sustained that the pupil had, as we have shown, but receptively to gape. The odd thing furthermore was that it could serve its purpose while explicitly disavowing every personal bias. It wasn't that she disliked Aunt Maud, who was everything she had on other occasions declared; but the dear woman, ineffaceably stamped by inscrutable nature and a dreadful art, wasn't—how could she be?—what she wasn't. She wasn't any one. She wasn't anything. She wasn't anywhere. Milly mustn't think it—one couldn't, as a good friend, let her. Those hours at Matcham were inespérées, were pure manna from heaven; or if not wholly that perhaps, with humbugging old Lord Mark as a backer, were vain as a ground for hopes and calculations. Lord Mark was very well, but he wasn't the cleverest creature in England, and even if he had been he still wouldn't have been the most obliging. He weighed it out in ounces, and indeed each of the pair was really waiting for what the other would put down.

Translation

In this situation, she openly revealed everything about herself, including her home in Lancaster Gate and everything inside it. Milly was fascinated to see how completely she gave herself away, bit by bit. She also revealed details about Aunt Maud, including her accomplishments and self-satisfaction. Ultimately, she revealed herself the most, which, naturally, made her more honest. She stopped talking to her friend in Aunt Maud’s style, about how they could achieve the impossible. Instead, she chose to focus, in a clear and contrary way, on the importance of not being unintelligent or crass. For our young American friend, it could have been a lesson in seeing things as they truly were, a lesson so comprehensive and consistent that the pupil, as we've seen, could only absorb it passively. The strange part was that the lesson worked even though she denied having any personal preferences. It wasn't that she disliked Aunt Maud, who embodied everything she had previously described, but the dear woman, shaped indelibly by nature and a terrible kind of art, wasn't—how could she be?—what she wasn't. She didn't have a true identity. She was nothing. She was nowhere. Milly shouldn't believe it—and as a good friend, she couldn't allow it. Those hours at Matcham were unexpected, like a gift from heaven. Or, maybe not quite that, with old Lord Mark, who was full of it, backing them up, it was a waste of time to build hopes and make plans. Lord Mark was fine, but he wasn’t the smartest person in England, and even if he was, he wouldn’t be the most helpful. He measured everything carefully, and in reality, they were both waiting to see what the other would contribute.

"She has put down you." said Milly, attached to the subject still; "and I think what you mean is that, on the counter, she still keeps hold of you."

Translation

"She's put you down," Milly said, still focused on the topic. "And I think what you're trying to say is that she's still keeping you, like, under her control."

"Lest"—Kate took it up—"he should suddenly grab me and run? Oh, as he isn't ready to run, he's much less ready, naturally, to grab. I am—you're so far right as that—on the counter, when I'm not in the shop-window; in and out of which I'm thus conveniently, commercially whisked: the essence, all of it, of my position, and the price, as properly, of my aunt's protection." Lord Mark was substantially what she had begun with as soon as they were alone; the impression was even yet with Milly of her having sounded his name, having imposed it, as a topic, in direct opposition to the other name that Mrs. Lowder had left in the air and that all her own look, as we have seen, kept there at first for her companion. The immediate strange effect had been that of her consciously needing, as it were, an alibi—which, successfully, she so found. She had worked it to the end, ridden it to and fro across the course marked for Milly by Aunt Maud, and now she had quite, so to speak, broken it in. "The bore is that if she wants him so much—wants him, heaven forgive her! for me—he has put us all out, since your arrival, by wanting somebody else. I don't mean somebody else than you."

Translation

"Kate picked it up – 'in case' – 'he should suddenly grab me and run away? Oh, since he's not prepared to run, he's much less likely, of course, to grab me. I am – you're absolutely correct about that – on display, when I'm not in the shop window; in and out of which I’m conveniently, commercially moved: that’s the whole point of my situation, and the price, essentially, of my aunt's protection.'"

"Lord Mark was essentially the subject she'd started with as soon as they were alone. Milly still felt like Kate had brought up his name, forced it, as a topic, directly against the other name Mrs. Lowder had hinted at and that Kate's own expression, as we've seen, had initially kept in the air for her companion."

"The immediate, odd effect had been that she seemed to consciously need an alibi—which, she successfully got. She'd worked it out fully, used it to avoid the situation Aunt Maud had set up for Milly, and now she'd completely, so to speak, mastered it. 'The annoying thing is that if she wants him so much – wants him, heaven help her! – for me – he's thrown us all off balance since you arrived, because he wants someone else. And I don’t mean someone other than you.'"

Milly threw off the charm sufficiently to shake her head. "Then I haven't made out who it is. If I'm any part of his alternative he had better stop where he is."

Translation

Milly dropped her pretense enough to shake her head. "Then I still don't know who it is. If I'm supposed to be a backup option for him, he should just back off."

"Truly, truly?—always, always?"

Translation

Seriously? Really? Always? Forever?

Milly tried to insist with an equal gaiety. "Would you like me to swear?"

Translation

Milly tried to be just as cheerful. "Want me to swear?"

Kate appeared for a moment—though that was doubtless but gaiety too—to think. "Haven't we been swearing enough?"

Translation

Kate paused, seemingly considering, though perhaps she was just being playful. "Aren't we done swearing already?"

"You have perhaps, but I haven't, and I ought to give you the equivalent. At any rate there it is. Truly, truly as you say—'always, always.' So I'm not in the way."

Translation

Maybe you have it, but I don't. And I should give you what I owe you. Here it is anyway. You're right, totally right – "always, always." So I'm not bothering you anymore.

"Thanks," said Kate—"but that doesn't help me."

Translation

"Thanks," Kate said, "but that's not helpful."

"Oh, it's as simplifying for him that I speak of it."

Translation

Oh, it's really helpful for him that I'm talking about it.

"The difficulty really is that he's a person with so many ideas that it's particularly hard to simplify for him. That's exactly of course what Aunt Maud has been trying. He won't," Kate firmly continued, "make up his mind about me."

Translation

The problem is that he has so many ideas, it's really difficult to make things simple for him. That's exactly what Aunt Maud has been trying to do. He won't," Kate continued firmly, "make a decision about me."

"Well," Milly smiled, "give him time."

Translation

"Well," Milly smiled, "he just needs time."

Her friend met it in perfection. "One is doing that—one is. But one remains, all the same, but one of his ideas."

Translation

Her friend understood it perfectly. "Someone's doing it—they are. But the essential thing, the core idea, still remains."

"There's no harm in that," Milly returned, "if you come out in the end as the best of them. What's a man," she pursued, "especially an ambitious one, without a variety of ideas?"

Translation

"That's not a bad thing," Milly replied, "if you end up being the best. What's a man," she continued, "especially an ambitious one, without a range of thoughts?"

"No doubt. The more the merrier." And Kate looked at her grandly. "One can but hope to come out, and do nothing to prevent it."

Translation

"Absolutely. The more people, the better." And Kate looked at her with a superior air. "All we can do is hope for the best and not make things worse."

All of which made for the impression, fantastic or not, of the alibi. The splendour, the grandeur were, for Milly, the bold ironic spirit behind it, so interesting too in itself. What, moreover, was not less interesting was the fact, as our young woman noted it, that Kate confined her point to the difficulties, so far as she was concerned, raised only by Lord Mark. She referred now to none that her own taste might present; which circumstance again played its little part. She was doing what she liked in respect to another person, but she was in no way committed to the other person, and her furthermore talking of Lord Mark as not young and not true were only the signs of her clear self-consciousness, were all in the line of her slightly hard, but scarce the less graceful extravagance. She didn't wish to show too much her consent to be arranged for, but that was a different thing from not wishing sufficiently to give it. There was something moreover, on it all, that Milly still found occasion to say, "If your aunt has been, as you tell me, put out by me, I feel that she has remained remarkably kind."

Translation

All of this created the (whether real or imagined) impression of an alibi. The wealth and luxury were, for Milly, the surprisingly ironic spirit behind it all, and that was fascinating in itself. What was also interesting was that Kate only mentioned the problems that Lord Mark caused, as Milly observed. Kate didn't mention any personal preferences that might create obstacles. This also played a small role in the situation. Kate was doing what she wanted with another person involved, but she wasn't obligated to that other person. Her comments about Lord Mark – that he wasn't young and wasn't genuine – were simply signs of her awareness of herself. They were part of her slightly tough, but still graceful, way of acting. She didn't want to seem too eager to be manipulated, but that was different from not being willing enough to allow it.

Moreover, Milly still felt compelled to say, "If your aunt is annoyed with me, as you say, she's certainly been remarkably kind about it."

"Oh, but she has—whatever might have happened in that respect—plenty of use for you! You put her in, my dear, more than you put her out. You don't half see it, but she has clutched your petticoat. You can do anything—you can do, I mean, lots that we can't. You're an outsider, independent and standing by yourself; you're not hideously relative to tiers and tiers of others." And Kate, facing in that direction, went further and further; wound up, while Milly gaped, with extraordinary words. "We're of no use to you—it's decent to tell you. You'd be of use to us, but that's a different matter. My honest advice to you would be—" she went indeed all lengths—"to drop us while you can. It would be funny if you didn't soon see how awfully better you can do. We've not really done for you the least thing worth speaking of—nothing you mightn't easily have had in some other way. Therefore you're under no obligation. You won't want us next year; we shall only continue to want you. But that's no reason for you, and you mustn't pay too dreadfully for poor Mrs. Stringham's having let you in. She has the best conscience in the world; she's enchanted with what she has done; but you shouldn't take your people from her. It has been quite awful to see you do it."

Translation

Oh, but she really does need you – whatever may have happened before. You're far more helpful to her than you realize. You've become important to her. You can do anything – I mean, a lot of things we can't. You're independent, on your own; you're not tied to this network of people like we are." And Kate, looking that way, kept going; getting really fired up, while Milly stared, as Kate said some surprising things.

"We can't help you, and it's only right to tell you that. You could help us, but that's a separate issue. My honest advice to you would be…" she went on and on, “…to leave us while you still can. It would be ridiculous if you didn't soon realize how much better off you'd be without us. We haven't really done anything for you that was really worth anything – nothing you couldn't have easily gotten somewhere else. So you don't owe us anything. You won't need us next year; we'll be the ones needing you. But that's not a reason for you to stay, and you shouldn't suffer too much because Mrs. Stringham got you involved. She has the best intentions; she's thrilled with what she's done; but you shouldn't depend on us. It's been terrible to watch you do it."

Milly tried to be amused, so as not—it was too absurd—to be fairly frightened. Strange enough indeed—if not natural enough—that, late at night thus, in a mere mercenary house, with Susie away, a want of confidence should possess her. She recalled, with all the rest of it, the next day, piecing things together in the dawn, that she had felt herself alone with a creature who paced like a panther. That was a violent image, but it made her a little less ashamed of having been scared. For all her scare, none the less, she had now the sense to find words. "And yet without Susie I shouldn't have had you."

Translation

Milly tried to act entertained, because it was ridiculous to be genuinely scared. It was certainly strange – though probably not surprising – that she’d feel insecure, late at night like this, in a cheap boarding house, with Susie gone. When she thought about it the next day, putting the pieces together in the morning light, she remembered feeling alone with someone who moved like a panther. That was an over-the-top image, but it helped her feel less embarrassed about being frightened. Despite her fear, she could now articulate her thoughts. "And still, if Susie hadn't been here, I wouldn't have met you."

It had been at this point, however, that Kate flickered highest. "Oh, you may very well loathe me yet!"

Translation

But that's when Kate's excitement peaked. "Oh, you might end up hating me!"

Really at last, thus, it had been too much; as, with her own least feeble flare, after a wondering watch, Milly had shown. She hadn't cared; she had too much wanted to know; and, though a small solemnity of reproach, a sombre strain, had broken into her tone, it was to figure as her nearest approach to serving Mrs. Lowder. "Why do you say such things to me?"

Translation

Finally, it was too much. After watching and wondering, Milly had made it clear with her own subtle reaction. She didn't care; she was too eager to understand. Although a hint of criticism, a somber note, entered her voice, it was the closest she'd come to standing up to Mrs. Lowder. "Why are you saying these things to me?"

This unexpectedly had acted, by a sudden turn of Kate's attitude, as a happy speech. She had risen as she spoke, and Kate had stopped before her, shining at her instantly with a softer brightness. Poor Milly hereby enjoyed one of her views of how people, wincing oddly, were often touched by her. "Because you're a dove." With which she felt herself ever so delicately, so considerately, embraced; not with familiarity or as a liberty taken, but almost ceremonially and in the manner of an accolade; partly as if, though a dove who could perch on a finger, one were also a princess with whom forms were to be observed. It even came to her, through the touch of her companion's lips, that this form, this cool pressure, fairly sealed the sense of what Kate had just said. It was moreover, for the girl, like an inspiration: she found herself accepting as the right one, while she caught her breath with relief, the name so given her. She met it on the instant as she would have met the revealed truth; it lighted up the strange dusk in which she lately had walked. That was what was the matter with her. She was a dove. Oh, wasn't she?—it echoed within her as she became aware of the sound, outside, of the return of their friends. There was, the next thing, little enough doubt about it after Aunt Maud had been two minutes in the room. She had come up, Mrs. Lowder, with Susan—which she needn't have done, at that hour, instead of letting Kate come down to her; so that Milly could be quite sure it was to catch hold, in some way, of the loose end they had left. Well, the way she did catch was simply to make the point that it didn't now in the least matter. She had mounted the stairs for this, and she had her moment again with her younger hostess while Kate, on the spot, as the latter at the time noted, gave Susan Shepherd unwonted opportunities. Kate was in other words, as Aunt Maud engaged her friend, listening with the handsomest response to Mrs. Stringham's impression of the scene they had just quitted. It was in the tone of the fondest indulgence—almost, really, that of dove cooing to dove—that Mrs. Lowder expressed to Milly the hope that it had all gone beautifully. Her "all" had an ample benevolence; it soothed and simplified; she spoke as if it were the two young women, not she and her comrade, who had been facing the town together. But Milly's answer had prepared itself while Aunt Maud was on the stair; she had felt in a rush all the reasons that would make it the most dovelike; and she gave it, while she was about it, as earnest, as candid. "I don't think, dear lady, he's here."

Translation

This surprisingly worked, a sudden change in Kate's behavior, like a blessing. As Kate spoke, she stood up, and Kate stopped in front of her, her face immediately softening with a kind light. Poor Milly got another glimpse of how people, even when they seemed a bit uncomfortable, were often moved by her.

"Because you're a dove." After that, she felt herself being gently, considerately embraced. It wasn't casual or presumptuous, but almost ritualistic, like an official acknowledgment. It was as if she were a dove who could perch on a finger, but also a princess deserving of respect. Through the touch of her friend's lips, she felt as if this cool pressure sealed the meaning of what Kate had just said. For Milly, it was like a revelation: she found herself accepting the name given to her as true, catching her breath in relief. She embraced it instantly, as if it were the revealed truth. It illuminated the strange darkness she'd been living in. That was what was wrong with her. She was a dove.

Oh, wasn't she?—the thought echoed within her as she became aware of the sound of their friends returning. Then, there was very little doubt, especially after Aunt Maud entered the room. Mrs. Lowder came upstairs with Susan – which she didn’t need to do at that time of day, instead of letting Kate come to her – so Milly was sure it was to follow up on the conversation they'd had. Well, what she ended up doing was simply pointing out that it didn't matter. She'd climbed the stairs for this, and she had her moment alone with the younger hostess while Kate, as she noticed, gave Susan Shepherd an unusual amount of attention. In other words, as Aunt Maud was talking to her friend, Kate was listening with great enthusiasm to Mrs. Stringham's description of what they'd just experienced.

In the tone of the fondest kindness—almost as if one dove were cooing to another—Mrs. Lowder told Milly she hoped everything had gone beautifully. Her "everything" was broad and forgiving; it soothed and simplified. She spoke as if it were the two young women, not she and her friend, who'd been facing the city together. But Milly’s answer had already formed in her mind as Aunt Maud was coming up the stairs; she’d instantly understood all the reasons why it would be the most "dove-like" response, and she gave it with sincerity and honesty. "I don't think he's here, dear lady."

It gave her straightway the measure of the success she could have as a dove: that was recorded in the long look of deep criticism, a look without a word, that Mrs. Lowder poured forth. And the word, presently, bettered it still. "Oh, you exquisite thing!" The luscious innuendo of it, almost startling, lingered in the room, after the visitors had gone, like an oversweet fragrance. But left alone with Mrs. Stringham Milly continued to breathe it: she studied again the dovelike and so set her companion to mere rich reporting that she averted all inquiry into her own case.

Translation

Immediately, it showed her how successful she could be, like a dove. That was clear in Mrs. Lowder's long, critical look – a look that said everything without words. And then, the words themselves made it even better. "Oh, you exquisite thing!" The suggestive meaning of that compliment, almost shocking, hung in the air after the guests left, like an overly sweet perfume. But alone with Mrs. Stringham, Milly kept savoring it. She looked at herself again, trying to see the dove-like qualities, and then steered the conversation toward a straightforward description of her friend, avoiding any questions about herself.

That, with the new day, was once more her law—though she saw before her, of course, as something of a complication, her need, each time, to decide. She should have to be clear as to how a dove would act. She settled it, she thought, well enough this morning by quite readopting her plan in respect to Sir Luke Strett. That, she was pleased to reflect, had originally been pitched in the key of a merely iridescent drab; and although Mrs. Stringham, after breakfast, began by staring at it as if it had been a priceless Persian carpet suddenly unrolled at her feet, she had no scruple, at the end of five minutes, in leaving her to make the best of it. "Sir Luke Strett comes, by appointment, to see me at eleven, but I'm going out on purpose. He's to be told, please, deceptively, that I'm at home, and, you, as my representative, when he comes up, are to see him instead. He will like that, this time, better. So do be nice to him." It had taken, naturally, more explanation, and the mention, above all, of the fact that the visitor was the greatest of doctors; yet when once the key had been offered Susie slipped it on her bunch, and her young friend could again feel her lovely imagination operate. It operated in truth very much as Mrs. Lowder's, at the last, had done the night before: it made the air heavy once more with the extravagance of assent. It might, afresh, almost have frightened our young woman to see how people rushed to meet her: had she then so little time to live that the road must always be spared her? It was as if they were helping her to take it out on the spot. Susie—she couldn't deny, and didn't pretend to—might, of a truth, on her side, have treated such news as a flash merely lurid; as to which, to do Susie justice, the pain of it was all there. But, none the less, the margin always allowed her young friend was all there as well; and the proposal now made her what was it in short but Byzantine? The vision of Milly's perception of the propriety of the matter had, at any rate, quickly engulfed, so far as her attitude was concerned, any surprise and any shock; so that she only desired, the next thing, perfectly to possess the facts. Milly could easily speak, on this, as if there were only one: she made nothing of such another as that she had felt herself menaced. The great fact, in fine, was that she knew him to desire just now, more than anything else, to meet, quite apart, some one interested in her. Who therefore so interested as her faithful Susan? The only other circumstance that, by the time she had quitted her friend, she had treated as worth mentioning was the circumstance of her having at first intended to keep quiet. She had originally best seen herself as sweetly secretive. As to that she had changed, and her present request was the result. She didn't say why she had changed, but she trusted her faithful Susan. Their visitor would trust her not less, and she herself would adore their visitor. Moreover he wouldn't—the girl felt sure—tell her anything dreadful. The worst would be that he was in love and that he needed a confidant to work it. And now she was going to the National Gallery.

Translation

As the new day began, she was once again faced with her usual routine, though she found the need to make a decision each time a bit complicated. She needed to be as decisive as a dove. She decided, she thought, this morning was well-handled by simply re-committing to her plan regarding Sir Luke Strett. That plan, she was pleased to recall, had initially been presented in a subtle, understated way. And although Mrs. Stringham, after breakfast, reacted to the plan as if it were a priceless Persian carpet suddenly unfurled at her feet, she didn’t hesitate after five minutes to leave her to process it. "Sir Luke Strett is scheduled to see me at eleven, but I'm going out on purpose. Please tell him, in a misleading way, that I'm home, and you, as my stand-in, should see him instead. He'll prefer that this time. So please be nice to him." It required, of course, a more detailed explanation, especially mentioning that the visitor was a renowned doctor. But once Susie understood the key point, she embraced it, and her young friend could again feel her wonderful imagination at work. It functioned, in fact, much like Mrs. Lowder's had the previous night: it again made the atmosphere thick with enthusiastic agreement. It might, once more, almost have scared our young woman to see how easily people gave in to her wishes: did she have so little time to live that she was always given a free pass? It was as if they were helping her use it on the spot. Susie – she couldn’t deny, nor did she try – might, in reality, have treated such news as a shocking flash, and to be fair to Susie, the pain of it was all there. But, nonetheless, the options always available to her young friend were there as well; and the plan now proposed—what was it, in short, if not convoluted?

The thought of Milly's understanding of the situation had, at any rate, quickly replaced, as far as her attitude was concerned, any surprise or shock; so that all she wanted, next, was to know all the facts completely. Milly could easily speak, as if there was only one issue; she made no point about feeling threatened. The main point, essentially, was that she knew he wanted more than anything to meet someone who was interested in her. And who better than her devoted Susan? The only other thing she mentioned by the time she'd left her friend was that she had initially intended to remain silent. She had originally envisioned herself as sweetly secretive. But she’d changed her mind, and her current request was the result. She didn't say why she changed her mind, but she trusted her loyal Susan. Their visitor would trust her just as much, and she herself would adore their visitor. Furthermore, she felt certain that he wouldn't tell her anything terrible. The worst would be that he was in love and needed a confidante to help him. And now she was going to the National Gallery.

Chapter XVI

Chapter Summary & Character Study
Summary

A woman named Milly goes to the National Gallery. She walks through the rooms, watches lady-copyists, and then sits down to rest. While sitting, she observes other visitors, especially fellow Americans.

Three American women stop near her, looking at something behind her. One calls the object "handsome" and "in the English style," and then the three women leave. Milly gets up and turns around.

She sees a man, whom she recognizes as Merton Densher. She then sees that Kate Croy is with him. Kate sees Milly and smiles. Densher then notices Milly and greets her.

Milly invites Densher and Kate to lunch at her hotel, and they accept. They travel there in a four-wheeler cab. At the hotel, Milly's companion, Susie, is waiting with their meal. After lunch, Kate sits with Susie in one room, while Milly and Densher sit and talk in an adjacent room. Densher tells Milly about his recent trip to the United States.

Character Study

Based on the text, here is a concise character study:

  • *Milly Theale**
    • Milly is presented as a young woman in a fragile, "menaced state of health," seeking refuge from an overwhelming "personal question." She enters the National Gallery wanting cultural immersion but feels too weak for it, identifying instead with the anonymous, absorbed lives of the copyists.

    Her situation shifts abruptly when she encounters Merton Densher and Kate Croy. This shock forces her out of her passive retreat and into a calculated social performance. She adopts a spontaneous, vivacious "American girl" persona as a defense mechanism to control the awkwardness and, more importantly, to delay confronting the ominous news she intuits awaits her from Sir Luke Strett.

  • *Kate Croy**
    • Presented through Milly’s eyes, Kate is a socially masterful and "prodigious person." Her first appearance is in a potentially compromising situation with Merton Densher.

    Her situation immediately shifts from private outing to public encounter, a change she manages instantly and without words. With a single "far smile," she takes control, making the awkward meeting seem natural. Later, she strategically removes herself to sit with Susie, an action Milly interprets as a calculated maneuver to manage Densher.

  • *Merton Densher**
    • He is first presented as an object of others' observation: a "handsome" gentleman, preoccupied and unaware he is being watched.

    His situation shifts from private contemplation to a startling social encounter. His reaction is a "vivid blush," a mix of embarrassment and pleasure. He quickly follows Kate's and Milly's lead, moving from initial confusion to adopting a safe, talkative role, which Milly perceives as him falling in line with the conventionally "kind" way everyone treats her.

  • *Susie Shepherd**
Susie is presented as the silent keeper of a looming reality. Milly observes a "feverish glitter" in her eyes, indicating she holds the report from Sir Luke Strett. Her situation has changed off-page, and she now embodies the unspoken tension that Milly is actively trying to escape.

The idea of the National Gallery had been with her from the moment of her hearing from Sir Luke Strett about his hour of coming. It had been in her mind as a place so meagrely visited, as one of the places that had seemed at home one of the attractions of Europe and one of its highest aids to culture, but that—the old story—the typical frivolous always ended by sacrificing to vulgar pleasures. She had had perfectly, at those whimsical moments on the Brünig, the half-shamed sense of turning her back on such opportunities for real improvement as had figured to her, from of old, in connection with the continental tour, under the general head of "pictures and things"; and now she knew for what she had done so. The plea had been explicit—she had done so for life, as opposed to learning; the upshot of which had been that life was now beautifully provided for. In spite of those few dips and dashes into the many-coloured stream of history for which of late Kate Croy had helped her to find time, there were possible great chances she had neglected, possible great moments she should, save for to-day, have all but missed. She might still, she had felt, overtake one or two of them among the Titians and the Turners; she had been honestly nursing the hour, and, once she was in the benignant halls, her faith knew itself justified.
